statement:
When I discovered that I would be able to apply for this redistricting commission, I was absolutely thrilled. One of the reasons for this elation is my background working in Title 1 schools. I have been a public school teacher for thirty-five years and one of the things I learned early in this profession is how important correct districting is to real people in the real world. It may seem like an abstract or incidental process, but it is absolutely essential to the correct functioning of our republic as well as fairness to the public. What I saw happening in the Title 1 schools I worked in, was that invaluable resources were being sucked into other districts through gerrymandering. This left vulnerable, at-risk students without the resources they desperately need to overcome the various and numerous obstacles that lie between them and success. Furthermore, incorrect districting leaves many with no voice in their government; politicians should not be allowed to pick the people they serve. It is absolutely critical that politicians serve the people who reside in their neighborhoods and districts as they naturally stand.
Moreover, I am extremely interested in maps, cartography, and geography - all things that are closely tied to redistricting. When I was an undergraduate at the University of Denver, I was the research assistant for Dr. John Livingston, chair of the Department of History. In this capacity I poured over maps with him as we analyzed geographic information that he needed for his scholarly writings. Eventually I was made curator of the map and slide collections for the Department of History, a job that I absolutely loved.

This love of maps has served me well in other capacities as well. As a Social Studies teacher for my entire career, geography was a cornerstone of the curricula I taught. Additionally, this propelled me to become a National Geographic certified teacher, which required a rigorous process of online learning, collaboration with a cohort of National Geographic staff and other educators, design and implementation of lesson plans, collaboration with colleagues, and creation of a capstone project. In addition to that, I was chosen by National Geographic from an international pool of applicants to attend their Summer Institute for a week in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. This week entailed intense training in geographic issues, including redistricting. At the conclusion of this workshop, the participants were tasked with training other teachers on the National Geographic framework for educators. This framework includes a commitment to diversity, collaboration, helping students become active citizens, and empathy for all who share our planet. I was able to lead the middle school where I worked through this process during a day of staff development that met with great success. Although the pandemic has brought this collaboration to a temporary halt, I fully intend to continue training other teachers and helping them earn their National Geographic certification as well.

Last and perhaps most importantly, I want to give back to my community. As a recently-retired teacher, I do not want to spend the rest of my life loafing or resting on my laurels. Civic engagement is a core component of who I am and one of the primary reasons I chose to teach Social Studies, rather than any other subject, for my career. Serving as a redistricting commissioner would allow me to continue to engage in very important matters, but in a different capacity. I would be extremely honored to be considered for this position.
professional_background:
As a founding member of NASTAP (Native American Sacred Trees and Places), I have been heavily involved in preserving, interpreting, and educating the public about historic and archaeological sites on both public and private lands in Colorado.This group is dedicated to identifying, interpreting, and preserving important Native American cultural sites. Additionally, we have been able to collaborate with members of the Southern Ute Reservation who have helped this group interpret important sites and communicate their importance to land-owners, public land administrators and other stake-holders. Even more importantly, NASTAP has been involved in bringing Ute youth from the reservation back to their ancestral lands along the front range. I have participated in numerous capacities with these young people in roles ranging from cook to video session moderator. NASTAP holds an annual conference that includes Ute youth, and provides an all-expenses-paid trip to the conference for Ute youth and elders. Additionally, this group funds the research of Dr. James Jefferson, a Ute elder who holds a PhD in linguistics, is the president of NASTAP, and carries out field research throughout Colorado. The work of this group is extremely important to me because of my family’s dedication to preserving Ute and Comanche sites found on my mother’s ranch and also because of the importance of Native Americans to our nation’s history and culture. And, on a personal level, I have learned a tremendous amount from the Native Americans, especially the elders, who participate in the group.

Another group that I have advocated for in a variety of ways is new teachers and teacher candidates. As an experienced teacher working with a high percentage of diverse and at-risk students, I felt that I needed to pass on the knowledge I had gained throughout my career. I served in the official capacity of mentor for many years as part of the Colorado Department of Education’s licensing requirement for new teachers. I have also had seven student teachers and have helped all of them gain their Colorado teaching certificates. Helping forge new teachers involves a variety of skills, with empathy being one of the most important. For example, one of my student teachers was involved in a program through UCCS that helped former military members become teachers. This person was a Marine who had seen front-line action in Iraq, had lost several members of his unit in combat, had sustained a traumatic brain injury (TBI) and a broken hip. Needless to say, there were days when he needed a great deal of support from me, which I was more than willing to provide. At one point he needed a break away from the rigors of teaching, and so I house-sat for him and took care of his dogs so that he could take a much-needed break. I was also able to diffuse a tricky situation with a parent who was unhappy with my student teacher simply by drawing out her empathy. Patience, collaboration, and clear communication are other skills that are very necessary for working with those just entering the teaching field.

Additionally, I brought the National Geographic Geography Bee to Skyview Middle School; this is an international competition, similar to the National Spelling Bee, which encourages students to become well-versed in geographic fundamentals and concepts. I was able to persuade the principal to foot the bill for this activity and then became the building coordinator. In this capacity I was able to help formulate teams throughout the school and oversee the implementation of the competition. At the end of the competition, one student emerges as the school winner and is then able to compete at higher levels. Being the coordinator of this project for a building of more than seventy faculty members and over 1200 students helped me use my organizational and collaboration skills. I was particularly pleased to see that I build a robust organization that continues at Skyview even though I retired at the end of last school year.

Another organization that I worked with at Skyview Middle School was Knowledge Bowl. I was the co-sponsor of this activity, which consisted of daily practices with a team of sixth-graders followed by competition at a regional event. My team placed in the top three teams at the regional finals every year that I coached them and provided an excellent opportunity for our gifted and talented students to participate in an intellectual event while developing social ties with other gifted students. Advocating for advanced students continues to be one of my passions as they are a group that is often underfunded and underserved.
org_list:
As a classroom teacher, I have belonged to the National Education Association (NEA), the Colorado Education Association (CEA), the Pikes Peak Education Association (PPEA), and the Falcon Teachers Association (FTA) for thirty-five years, from 1985 to the present.  These groups advocate for public schools and public school children in a variety of different ways. I have participated with the groups by not only being a member, but by also serving on outreach committees to advocate for new teachers.

Additionally, I have been very active in 4-H, a group that provides leadership training and other skills to youngsters aged six to eighteen. As a child I was involved as a member and as an adult I have been a leader at the Kit Carson 4-H club where I was able to mentor children and young adults who were involved in the poultry and leadership programs. This meant preparing for the state and county fairs and resulted in my club bringing home many prizes including Stockman of the Year, Grand Champion, Bird of Show and many other awards. Through this process I was able to help students grow in terms self-confidence, empathy, creativity, and collaboration.

Further, I hold membership in NCHE, the National Council of History Educators. I was honored to be chosen to present at the NCHE conference in Richmond, Virginia as a representative of the Teaching American History grant (TAH). I moderated a session at this conference as well as submitted a peer-reviewed video I created on the importance of the horse to Plains Indians culture. The theme of that year’s conference was, “Recounting Emancipation: Women, Circumstance and Jazz.” This event brought together educators from throughout the United States as well as from abroad, and we were able to meet to discuss continuing the work of emancipation by building on the legacy of the past.

Additionally, the Teaching American History grant was a multiple-year program that I participated in, geared to improving the civic engagement of public school students. TAH stressed the importance of critical thinking, creativity, leadership, and collaboration in teaching School Studies, and also identified these as measures of success for students in Social Studies classes throughout Colorado. As part of this program, I was instructed by university professors, historians, authors, and other professionals. I was also able to collaborate with and learn from some of the best teachers throughout the Pikes Peak region. As a result of this program, Social Studies instruction has dramatically changed. No longer is this discipline one of rote memorization of names and dates—it is now a vibrant field dedicated to building skills including critical analysis, creativity, and civic action.
analytic_skills:
Using, developing, and fostering the use of logic, analysis, and reason, rather than emotion, is very important to me. Teaching Social Studies is, in fact, instructing students in the development of analytical skills, logic, and reason. I was one of the first teachers at Skyview Middle School to bring the use of document-based questions (DBQ’s) to the middle school. This pedagogy involves teaching students to read and analyze primary source documents and then apply that knowledge to answer open-ended questions. Unfortunately, this strategy often is limited to high school instruction, something that I was determined to end and—I am happy to report—that when I retired from Skyview Middle School, most, if not all Social Studies teachers were using this instructional strategy. So, I have had a great deal of experience in not only using logic, analytical skills, and reason, but also in teaching its use to other teachers as well as middle school students.

Additionally, I have more than ninety post-graduate recertification, college, and CDE credits. This is far beyond what is required to maintain my Colorado teaching license. I have chosen to spend a great deal of my time furthering my education, especially in the areas of critical thinking, applying logic, and problem solving. One example of this is that I have accrued many credit hours from the Bill of Rights Institute, an organization that promotes clear-headed thinking and teaching about the US Constitution. I will continue to pursue professional and personal development through continuing education classes, despite my retirement from the education field.

One of the activities that has helped me hone my analytical skills is debate. While I was in high school I was on the debate team and proudly brought home many trophies for participation in both cross- examination debate and extemporaneous speaking. When I began teaching at Sierra HIgh School, I volunteered to be the assistant debate coach. Both the participation and coaching of this logic-based activity helped me develop critical thinking skills and also the ability to see the merit in both sides of an issue. The structure of competitive debate is that all participants argue both sides of an issue, so it is important that facts and logic—rather than biases or passions—rule the day. Similarly, in extemporaneous speaking, a random issue is given to the competitor who then has twenty minutes to prepare a speech over the topic to present to judges. These issues usually relate to current events and, again, the use of logic, reason, and analytical thinking rule the day with the judges.

In short, being selected for this commission would be the culmination of much of my life’s work. My recently completed career in education, in addition to my own ever-continuing education, have given me the analytical skills, steady-handed leadership in teamwork, and ability to apply logic and reason to make me an excellent candidate for this very consequential redistricting commission. I thank you for your consideration.
consensus_statement:
Fairness is a value that is very important to me and is why I became a teacher in schools with a high percentage of at-risk, poor, and disadvantaged students. I felt that it was very important that these youth receive an excellent education, and I was determined to provide this to the best of my ability and I pursued this throughout my thirty-five year career in education. This is the same spirit that I would bring to the redistricting committee.

Additionally, I have had a great deal of experience with building consensus. With the exception of my college years, I have always lived in rural areas. This has resulted in me having quite different political views than my neighbors. However, this has also led me to being very open-minded and objective on many levels. It is impossible to live in a community and be at odds with its members, so I have learned to carefully listen to varied opinions while gently yet firmly sharing my own ideas. This process is a careful balancing act, but it results in harmonious relationships and community building.

Similarly, I have had a wealth of experience with consensus building in my job as a public school teacher. This position brings with it a variety of stakeholders from students and parents, administrators, the Board of Education, the community, and others. Navigating this labyrinth of conflicting ideas, agendas, and backgrounds has led me to understand the importance of holding true to one’s own values while also incorporating the views and ideas of others.
Pursuant to my quest for fairness and opportunity for all, I have also participated in the Educating Children of Color Conference, held at Colorado College, every year since its inception. This conference emphasizes the important role played by teachers in helping children of color obtain an excellent education, and features nationally recognized speakers and thinkers on this topic. Again, I was able to bring new ideas back to my school and other teachers at the conclusion of each of these workshops.
past_political_activity: I have always been very involved in politics on  the local and state level. For this election cycle I have written to registered  voters encouraging them to get out and vote. Additionally, I have been involved in phone banking  to help folks formulate a plan for actually voting. I have also participated in door-to-door canvassing in Colorado Springs on weekends and after work. I find this work extremely rewarding. Additionally, I have acted as an election judge on several previous elections. Furthermore, I always attend the caucuses and have stood for a candidate at several of these. This grassroots political activity is very important to me and is, I feel, the lifeblood of our democracy. I fully intend to continue my political activity in the future.

occupation: Retired. HOA Board member in CO since 2006, and member of Golden's Citizen's Budgetary Advisory Committee.
education: HS graduate, some college math and English courses, USAF technical electronics school, and various technical and management courses while employed by GTE for 22 years.
statement: Help establish districts that promote fair representation for all Coloradans. To help bring the state's disparate areas together to minimize the growing divides between urban and rural areas, and between younger and older generations.
professional_background: Ability to negotiate and devise compromises in establishing contracts, both in defining terms and conditions, and establishing performance requirements. Especially experienced in setting up programs that require cooperation between functional and project focused organizations, thereby providing for smooth operations throughout their life cycles.
org_list: HOA Board member of Canyon Point Villas in Golden, CO since 2006, member of Golden's Citizen's Budgetary Advisory Committee since 2016 and member of Golden's Historical Preservation Board for four years.
analytic_skills: Twenty plus years of managing successful system development programs (with emphasis on software and hardware integration) which provided real-life experience in trade-off analysis, critical path assessment (PERT charts for those who remember) and analysis of work and process flows. A bias towards evidence based vs ideological positions and thinking.
consensus_statement: Primarily, having no political agenda and willing to listen to alternative views. Historical Preservation Board membership enhanced an understanding of the validity of opposing views, both at the state and national levels.

occupation: Retired High Technology Computer Systems Development and Implementation Executive now owning and operating a small equine ranch in Delta County.  A brief Resume is attached.
education: Graduated from Wheatland High School, Wheatland, Wyoming, 1959.  Appointed to and attended the United States Air Force Academy 1959 - 1962.  Then attended the University of Wyoming, Colorado State University, and the Florida Institute of Technology.  Areas of Study were basic Sciences and Physics / Mathematics with emphasis on Statistics.  Professional experience includes Real-Time Test Conductor at Central Instrument Facility launch support at Kennedy Space Center for Gemini, Surveyor, and Apollo up to Apollo 6 then as a contractor for the NASA Apollo Program Office for Apollo 7 through 11.  Left NASA support contracting in 1969 (my work completed for Apollo 11) to begin a career in the then infantile Computer Systems Industry that spanned the next 35 years until retirement in 2005.
statement:
The difficulties demonstrated by the past two Colorado redistricting efforts ending up in the courts to be resolved (gerrymandering on steroids) created a burning desire in my mind to remove, as much as possible, the political and governmental effect on the redistricting process.  Now the citizens of the state have made concrete efforts to move the redistricting process out of politics and government (per se.)  I believe individuals such as myself should volunteer to take the experience, training, and leadership learned over years of making people and systems work correctly and put those skills to use making the redistricting work for the citizens, not the politicized governmental establishment.  All Colorado citizens deserve to have themselves and their neighbors properly represented in our fantastic democratic republic.  Colorado is diverse from many different perspectives - some rural some urban, some mountains - some plains, some agriculture - some energy, some business – some labor, etc.  The list goes on.  Each perspective deserves the ability to express its collective, and sometimes unique, needs, desires, & contributions, via both the federal and state representations.

Who wouldn’t want to be part of that?
professional_background:
In addition to the GOP County Central Committee above, I have been active in the non-profit Rocky Mountain Wing (RMW) Commemorative Air Force (CAF) serving on the Wing Staff as both Education Officer and as the Wing Newsletter Editor.  Accomplishments include implementing the CAF Rise Above program that has enabled 1,000's of Colorado Westen Slope middle school students to be exposed to and experience the dedication and determination put forth by our Greatest Generation during WWII.  I also successfully campaigned to have the Wing's Grumman TBM Avenger Torpedo Bomber certified as both a Colorado State Historical Object and a National Historic Object (airplane), one of only two that regularly continue to fly.  

Even though somewhat inactive over the past few months, over several years I have written for and maintained a small blog where I've posted many, many letters I've written to Congressmen, Senators, and state officials regarding issues current at the time.  The blog can be reached at www.flyingwblog.com.
org_list: Active Precinct Delegate to the Delta County Republican Central Committee.  During this tenure served on various subcommittees.  Also, a member of the American Legion, Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, National Rifle Association, Commemorative Air Force.
analytic_skills:
In addition to my "professional" career interfacing with (reasoning with) executives and engineers at all levels, I also had a sideline career as a commercial pilot, expanding the use of my own personal business aircraft as a pilot for other commercial aircraft.  I never considered flying these aircraft a "profession" but rather a diversion to hone both my mental skills as well as improve and maintain my piloting skills.  

Without question, piloting today's aircraft in "the crowded skies" requires logic and reasoning skills above the norm.  

Most piloting (with perhaps the exception of crop dusting)can be hours of boredom interspersed with moments of terror!  Those moments of terror require logic and reasoning skills way beyond those necessary to put together a contract for a worldwide computer packet switching network.  Operating within one environment compliments the other - I speak from experience in both cases.

Gathering known reliable and meaningful data, using demonstrated means to analyze the data for information pertinent to the problem at hand, applying the information in acceptable means, and then making sound decisions based on the data - not other outside emotionally charged input -  is the path to success - both in the cockpit and the boardroom.  That same logic and decision path will serve the redistricting commission, and Colorado's diverse citizenship very well.
consensus_statement: I spent my entire professional career negotiating - establishing consensus between groups and individuals.  Yes, I was called a "salesman" or a "manager."  I held titles such as Sales Engineer, District/Regional Sales Manager, Vice President of sales, and even "Owner."  I've had to negotiate agreements between my employers and major airlines, Energy companies, State Governments, large manufacturing consortiums, Universities, Global Communications Carriers, etc., etc.  I've been successful at applying logic and reason to the discussions and planning necessary to forge a successful outcome.  Colorado's citizens deserve equal representation based upon their contribution to the State's success.  Because I have lived and worked in both the metropolitan business arena (Denver area for 30 years) and rural Delta County (20 years) I actually know how much impartiality means in representation.
past_political_activity: Small donations to Congressman Scott Tipton and local State House and Senate candidates.  Total Contributions since 2015 do not exceed $500.00

occupation:
Director of Economic Development, Urban Renewal, and Main Street La Junta.  Employed by the City of La Junta
Director of the History Colorado State Historical Fund
Deputy Director of the History Colorado State Historical Fund
Director of Public Outreach of the History Colorado State Historical Fund
education:
B.A. Kalamazoo College, Art History
M.A. & A.B.D., Cornell University, American History
statement: I am highly analytical and stick to discussing issues and not politics.  I believe in civility and the inclusion of ideas and people not previously part of the discussion.
professional_background: My work has been through state and local government as an employee in advocating for economic development, urban renewal, local education, community development, and historic preservation.
org_list: City of Broomfield, Certified Local Government
analytic_skills: My current and previous jobs all required me to work with diverse groups of people and to determine how to best meld varied interests in a reasonable solution.  Respectful dialogue, the fair presentation of ideas, and a focus on what we can agree upon is essential.
consensus_statement: I've been a peace maker in active discussions for over 30 years.  I like to look at issues from what we do agree upon rather than what we disagree upon.  I also believe that a decision made and voted on should not be revisited--a decision, is a decision even if you don't agree with the outcome.

occupation: Managing Director, Public Finance, Stifel Inc. 2019-2020, Executive Vice President, George K. Baum & Co. 1991-2019
education:
Bachelors Mechanical Engineering, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute 1968
Masters Business Administration, Harvard Business School, 1975

statement: I strongly believe the new way to redistrict on a non-political basis is extremely healthy for Colorado voting and belief in the democratic process. Peoples faith in the validity of the democratic process is enhanced if federal and state legislative boundaries are fairly drawn rather than to favor any political party. In particular, the growth of independent voters strongly suggests disapproval of party affiliation. The Commission will have an interesting difficult task in balancing the desire to maintain districts with common geographical communities of interest against the desire to see more politically competitive districts.
professional_background: I have been active in many civic organizations for over 45 years. For example, I served as Chairman of Denver Civic Ventures downtown Denver organization in the mid-1980s and was on Denver Water Board Citizens Advisory Committee. I also was elected twice to the Denver School Board as an At-Large member beginning in 1975. I was an elder at my Church, Montview Presbyterian Church. I was Co-Chair of the Raise the Bar Yes on Amendment 71 committee in 2016 when that Amendment was adopted. I am on the Executive Committee of Building a Better Colorado, a non-partisan business group promoting state-wide community by community analysis of major civic issues like voting, campaign finance, state budget issues like TABOR and Gallagher
org_list: Member Colorado Forum, Rocky Mountain Prep Charter School Board Chairman, Denver Public School Foundation Board member, volunteer Colo Democratic Party 2020, Co-Chair Amendment 71 (Raise the Bar) in 2016
analytic_skills: I have a technical undergraduate degree (Mechanical Engineering) , an MBA and have been in finance for the last 40 years. I possess strong analytical skills and am highly confident with handling data sets.
consensus_statement: I have an excellent grasp of state-wide issues beginning when I was in the Cabinet and  State Budget Director for Governor Lamm 1976-80.  I have traveled extensively through the state from eastern plains to western slope over my 44 years spent in Colorado. I was Co-Chair of Amendment 71 in 2016 which built a strong coalition of groups for the passage of Amendment 71 in 60 of the State's 64 counties. I am an excellent listener and actively study human decision thinking and political reasoning. I also spend a great deal of time at my second home in Routt County. I have a good appreciation of the views of rural Colorado.
past_political_activity: Michael Bennet for US Senate,  Michael Bennet for President, Jason Crow for Congress, Ed Perlmutter for Congress, Joe Neguse for Congress, Diane Mitch Bush for Congress, Michael Johnston for Governor, Hickenlooper for US Senate, Hickenlooper for President, Yes on Amendment 71

occupation: Retired Commercial Airline Pilot
education: High School Graduate; BS degree in Public Administration; FAA Airline Transport Pilot Certificate; California State Teaching Certificate-Designated Subjects for Aviation
statement: Especially seeing the obvious gerrymandering of my Congressional District (CO-4) I was very supportive of the passage of the law establishing this commission. I want to help Colorado lead in the fair and equitable redistricting efforts nationwide.
professional_background: I was a Member of Douglas County schools Long Range Planning Committee. Held various committee positions and elected offices in the Air Line Pilot's Assn (ALPA) Int'l prior to retirement in Nov. 2008. Local Neighborhood Watch volunteer for our HOA.
org_list: None since 2015.
analytic_skills: After a successful 33-year career with an airline operating world-wide, and in varied types of technically challenging and complex aircraft, I have demonstrated time and again my ability to analyze problems, reason through them logically, and arrive at optimal solutions. This , in both training scenarios that are thoroughly critiqued and real world situations with possibly devastating outcomes.  Intimately involved in this is the ability to solicit, hear, and utilize the input of other crewmembers and resources to insure that one's analysis and reasoning is as near ideal as possible.
consensus_statement: Having successfully negotiated contracts in private industry and union contracts for the pilots in the service of Continental Airlines during very turbulent times in the airline industry, I am confident in my skills to listen, advocate for a position, and still find consensus amongst diverse group and opinions. My experience as an airline Captain should not be trivialized as irrelevant. Under FAA regulation responsibility for the maintenance, refueling, cargo acceptance and loading, passenger acceptance and boarding, weather, and routing of any commercial flight ultimately rests with the pilot in command.  The only way that can be accomplished by a single individual in today's environment is to receive, respect and, if needed, question the input of an extremely diverse group of people. To be respectful of these varied professional inputs and still execute the duties required by law defines the essence of consensus building. I sincerely believe fairness and impartiality are key to these endeavors and are critical if this commission is to be successful in avoiding the vitriol that seems all too common in our political interactions.
past_political_activity: Registered Republican until early 1990's. Registered Democrat since that time. Have volunteered during Obama campaign in 2008. Attended and voted in Precinct caucuses twice.

occupation: CEO of Minds Matter Colorado
education:
University of Pennsylvania - BS Systems Engineering '03
Thunderbird School of Global Management - MBA Global Management '10
The Broad Center - Masters in Educational Leadership, '13
statement:
As are many others, I'm concerned and often overwhelmed by all issues being politicized and partisan, and for elected officials who continually seem unwilling to compromise in a professional and communal manner. All too often members of both parties seem more concerned with solidifying their own interests and political purposes than looking out for constituents and the greater good -- this is something George Washington specifically warned us about and we're seeing come into fruition. 

Especially in a state like Colorado, where so many voters are unaffiliated, the power of parties to draw districts should be minimized or eliminated. I'm grateful that Colorado has independent commissions to do so, and I know the importance of well-drawn non-partisan districts. I'm honored to be considered for the opportunity to ensure the next 10 years are designed to serve the citizens of Colorado, not political parties.
professional_background:
My entire job is advocating for under-represented voices in our community -- I'm the CEO of Minds Matter Colorado, which connects driven and determined high school students from low-income families with the people, preparation, and possibilities they need to succeed in college, create their futures, and change the world. My goal is to help eradicate systemic inequity in higher education for our students, and to expand our programming to provide access to Minds Matter to every student, corner-to-corner across Colorado.

In addition I've been asked to speak at multiple conferences and summits on issues related to creativity, innovation, collaboration, diversity, equity, inclusion, and anti-racism, including the Harvard Innovation Summit, B:Civic Summit, Colorado Mentoring Summit, and the National Association of Independent Schools People of Color Conference.
org_list:
I've been on the boards of the Luminary Learning Network (a collection of innovative schools within the Denver Public School district), the Civic Canopy (an organization geared towards building cultures of collaboration across the state), and the Denver Metro Chamber Leadership Foundation (an organization that serves to educate and inspire civic leaders in the Denver Metro community), as well as the Minds Matter Colorado and Minds Matter National organizations. I have also been nominated to serve on the Trust of the Rocky Mountain Vipassana Association, a volunteer-led non-profit to teach meditation techniques.

I've also volunteered with myriad organizations in various capacities, ranging from providing presentations to teachers and social entrepreneurs, to leading workshops and panels on diversity/equity/inclusion and education.
analytic_skills:
I'm an engineer by training -- my undergraduate degree is in Systems Engineering from the University of Pennsylvania and I love crunching numbers and analyzing data, drawing important conclusions to inform our work. I've studied extensive statistical analysis, econometrics, and data crunching in my undergraduate work, and feel quite comfortable drawing conclusions and crafting a narrative from data.

In addition, as the CEO of a small but rapidly growing entrepreneurial non-profit, I am perennially thinking strategically and big picture -- What is the current state? Where do we want to go? How can we get from here to there? What needs to happen in what order? I do this all rationally and logically, and lay out steps in a clear process, but with an emotional connection to the end goal, and bringing along teams of volunteers to achieve that goal.
consensus_statement:
People who know me will vouch for my willingness to engage with everyone, put judgment to the side, and have meaningful conversations with people who disagree with me. My search is for the truth, not for the upper hand. I seek common ground and shared values and vision, and I consider my ability to bring people together for a higher purpose to be one of my strong suits. 

In addition, in my past as a consultant, I have trained organizations and groups on effective collaboration, creativity, and consensus-building, so I have a great deal of background, knowledge, skills, and practical experience in building consensus and finding collaborative solutions for difficult problems.

I feel strongly that I'd be able to build consensus in contentious environments if I think the cause is powerful and important enough. This redistricting commission feels like exactly such a cause -- I think ensuring the voices of Coloradans of all beliefs, backgrounds, and communities are valued and equitably reflected in our representation is one of the highest callings in the great democratic republic that is the United States of America.
past_political_activity: I've donated to campaigns for people that I know (Aaron Goldhamer, Lisa Cutter, Mike Johnston, Chantell Taylor) for various local and federal offices, and I've donated to Elizabeth Warren's Presidential Campaign. However I've supported and voted for many Republican and Independent candidates over the years as well. I consider myself firmly centrist, independent, and nonpartisan. My goals are to support what is in the best interests of our country and state, not what's in the best interest of any individual or political entity.

occupation: Surgeon
statement: I want to do all I can to ascertain our government is a truly representative democracy that transcends partisanship.
professional_background:
Past  President, Colorado State Society of Plastic Surgeons
Past Chair, Government Relations Committee, American Society of Plastic Surgeons

analytic_skills: In the study and (my over 35 years of) practice of medicine, the scientific method is the foundation of investigation and analysis, leading to conclusions that are driven by scientific data and evidence. Implicit to that process are the evaluation of observer bias, statistical errors/anomalies, as well as errors of logic.
consensus_statement: In my training and career as a doctor, the rigors of science demand objectivity, data drives decisions, judgments are evidence-based. That disciplined approach is the essential to the process of fair governance. Objectivity precludes bias as a foundation for good communication: the ability to listen to and consider an argument with an open mind.

occupation: Public Health Specialist, Garfield County
education: BBA in Advertising, MBA in Marketing
statement: I want to serve as a forward thinking, rural voice to make sure mountain and rural resort communities are best represented at the state and federal level by folks that truly know these communities and can tackle the unique challenges of living and working in western colorado.
professional_background: I organize coalitions and groups around food access and health equity in my paid position. It is my personal and profressional passion to arm communities with the skills they need to advocate for their wants and needs that give them the opportunity to lead their best lives.
analytic_skills: I apply research, problem solving, reflection, and critical thinking to multiple projects and groups of people on a weekly basis. My work requires me to be flexible and nimble, while still evaluating outcomes in a rational manner to acheive my goals.
consensus_statement: I will contribute to creating agreement among commissioners by drawing on my knowledge and experiences of working with and in my own community. I hope that this information can bring new perspectives into the decision making process to have a positive impact on Colorado communities.
past_political_activity: No money donated, but I have helped deliver yard signs for political candidates.

occupation:
Proposal Analyst, University of Colorado Boulder (since May 2019)
ADA Program Manager, CU Boulder (Oct 2018-May 2019)
Military Experience Coordinator, Colorado State University-Global Campus (July-October 2018)
Student, CU Boulder and Naropa University (August 2014-June 2018)
Assistant Manager, Century Theaters Boulder (April 2012-October 2014)
Lieutenant, U.S. Navy (May 2006-February 2012)
education:
Master of Studies in Law, Ethics and Compliance, University of Colorado Law School, May 2018
Master of Fine Arts, Creative Writing and Poetics, Naropa University, July 2016
Bachelor of Science, English Literature, U.S. Naval Academy, May 2006
statement: I believe that nonpartisan, competitive congressional districts are one of the critical precursors to an engaged, informed, and fair electorate. A citizens' commission to create districts reflects the great responsibility we bear as members of a democratic republic: being informed and involved, and seeking to provide a government that represents our communities and not special interests.
professional_background: I serve several high schools across the state as their Naval Academy Information Officer ("Blue and Gold Officer"), interviewing and educating students who are interested in the Naval Academy. I also sat on Rep. Jared Polis's Service Academy Nomination Board for several years, and Sen. Mark Udall's Board for one year.
org_list: U.S. Naval Academy Information Officer since July 2012
analytic_skills: I hold an engineering-heavy degree in English, and advanced degrees in creative writing and compliance. I believe this reflects the balanced approach I take to problem-solving: understanding the parameters, identifying metrics for success, and employing creativity to come up with solutions. As an example, in the Navy we had stacks of documents and procedures to govern nearly every operation and event; however, we still needed to be able to apply those rules on a case-by-case basis and ask "What's different?" and "How do we achieve our goal?" when faced with changing circumstances. Procedural compliance is the baseline, but only through critical thinking and application of knowledge can an organization succeed.
consensus_statement: I have served in a variety of roles in dynamic and challenging environments with diverse organizations: the Navy, customer service and retail, and higher education (both as student and staff). The key component of every success I've ever contributed to or been a part of has been promoting teamwork and consensus, focused on achieving the mission but also caring for, listening to, and soliciting input from every member. I am more of a "listener" than a "speaker," and try to elevate the voices of others. Every member of an organization has one thing in common: they have "shown up," and therefore deserve to be heard. I would hope to continue this practice by encouraging participation from everyone, and recognizing my own privilege and position to amplify others.

occupation: Mostly retired, though I do a bit of consulting on telecommunications. I was a telecom consultant for a decade most recently, a market researcher for a decade before that and a business journalist for a decade before that.
education: M.S. Public Affairs, University of Oregon; B.S. History, University of Oregon
statement: I recently moved from SE Denver to Littleton (Jefferson County). To my shock, I still have the same Congressional representative, because of the way the district was created. That makes no sense to me. My neighbors here arguably have local concerns quite distinct from those of the City of Denver, or Aurora. Our community interests here in Littleton are local, and oriented around South Denver metro.
professional_background: None.
org_list: Member, Pacific Telecommunications Council since 2008, presently Chairman of the PTC Advisory Council
analytic_skills: I am a member of Mensa, the global organization for people with IQs in the top two percent, which has been an asset to me as a business journalist, market analyst and consultant, mostly in the sense of being able to "compute faster" (I do not claim it makes me wiser, or correct). Virtually all my professional engagements involve issues of business strategy, technology implications on revenue models, growth opportunities and threats to specific segments of the global telecom industry. My professional work over more than 30 years has involved analyzing trends and recommending courses of action for various participants in the telecommunications and internet ecosystems. In sum, my professional work emphasizes analysis, outcomes and ways to reach desired outcomes practically, within a definite time frame, within concrete resource and skill constraints, facing competitors with possibly superior advantages. Much of my work has centered on smaller industry "upstarts" and "challengers" who face much-larger competitors. Such firms do not have the luxury of capital or human resources available to the dominant providers, so strategic options always are limited. That being a given, most of my work has involved advice on business models or strategies where there are huge resource constraints; where companies face huge competitors; in a context of shifting end user demand; with prices that drop every year; a shift of value to others in the ecosystem and rapid technology obsolescence. Analysis has been a required professional skill.
consensus_statement: I have served on non-profit boards of directors, have worked for boards and presently work extensively for the Pacific Telecommunications Council, a non-profit focused on communications and information technology for the peoples of the Indo-Pacific region. Our bylaws mandate representation from global regions including North America, Asia, the Pacific islands, the Middle East, Europe and Latin America. By definition, we are compelled to work through building of consensus, across time zones, languages, cultures, business roles and interests. Almost all our day-to-day work involves committees including board members, advisory council members, volunteers and staff, drawn globally, where nothing can be done without building consensus, often quickly (our standard meeting format is virtual, limited to 60 minutes, and a compromise of time zones stretching from India to Europe and across North America). Since many of our members are not English as a first language speakers, everyone has to work fairly hard to ensure successful communication, to say nothing of reaching decisions on the practical matters we address. Also, many of the members are actual competitors in commercial markets around the world, which adds another level of sensitivity. To say those real interests must constantly be balanced with organization objectives is an understatement.

statement: I care deeply about fairness and representation of all voters. I am extremely interested in serving on the Commission. Community service is extremely important to me. I have always served my community in some capacity wherever I have lived.  As a child and grandchild of immigrants, I have always felt it is my duty to contribute to democratic establishments in the United States.  Serving on the Commission would give me an opportunity to represent the interests of rural Western Colorado and at the same time different constituencies that are important to the vibrance of Colorado – ranchers, small businesses, tourist economies, the ski industry, parents and schools.  I feel my voice will be valuable to the Commission because I am a good listener, I have intellectual curiosity to learn more and I am fair and polite when working with others who do not share my values.  I did not learn English until I went to kindergarten and I am the first person in my family to attend college. I have lived in cities and now in a rural area.  I am the mother of two adopted children from Kazakhstan and I now consult for my home county on COVID-19 response.  All these diverse experiences will allow me to help the process of creating fair maps, which are instrumental for future voting and representation at the federal and legislative level.
professional_background: I worked for two years to advocate for a school bond in Steamboat Springs meeting many community groups in the area.  I now work for Routt County providing information on COVID-19.
org_list: Since 2015 -- I am a board member of Routt County United Way, Routt County Integrated Community, Chair of the Steamboat Springs High School Parent Information Committee, Community Committee for Education (CC4E).
analytic_skills: Throughout my professional career, I have had to use my analytical and critical thinking skills in a variety of situations.  I am skilled in strategic communications, coalition building and partnerships, change management, influencing public policy, training, and coaching leaders and staff to reach their optimal potential. I have developed strategic plans for non-profits and government programs like First Lady Michelle Obama’s Let’s Move initiative and the Department of Defense’s Healthy Base Initiative to improve nutrition and increase physical activity at military installations.  I have collaborated with many types of constituencies. For example, although I never served in the military, I worked with leaders at the Pentagon and local military installations in the U.S. to improve nutritional options.  Speaking three languages has also attuned me to listen and gather information about different cultures.  I am comfortable researching different issues, brainstorming, collaborating, developing budgets, analyzing options and communicating with different types of audiences.
consensus_statement: Throughout my career, I have had to build consensus and agreement.  I have found that setting clear expectations is the first step in building consensus.  In addition, using techniques like developing SMART (specific, measurable, actionable, realistic and timebound) goals helps focus teams on what we are trying to achieve instead of personalities, tactics or disagreements. I have numerous examples of practicing empathy and collaborating with others with different opinions.  From 2000-2004, I worked in Greece for the Athens Olympic Organizing Committee setting up the International Media office and supervising media strategy and operations.  Aside from working in an environment where I was usually the only women at senior staff meetings, I managed many Greek staff with very different levels of experience and understanding of how to work in an international environment.  My way of working with them was to always be direct, honest, share information and focus on the ultimate goals.  Along the way, I taught them as many skills as I could on how to handle top level sports reporters from around the world. One of my most enduring legacies is the number of Greek staff that now serve in leadership positions in Greece, England, and Australia and how they credit me with giving them the foundation to working on teams and at a high level of expectations.  In addition, locally in Steamboat Springs, I worked on the Community Committee for Education (CC4E) which was created after a failed bond initiative. Our diverse committee spanned many different perspectives from old time rancher/bankers to restaurant owners to mothers who volunteered in the schools.  We did not come from the same perspectives, but I believe my leadership and communications skills led to a strong proposal that was presented to and supported by 28 community groups in Steamboat Springs.  Even when discussions were heated, I was always open to suggestions and ways that we could move forward as a committee.
past_political_activity: I have worked on presidential campaigns in 1988, 1992, 1996 and 2000.  I worked in the Clinton Administration and Obama Administration from 2010-2011.  I donated to Gail Schwartz for Congress, Diane Mitsch Busch, Biden-Harris, Harris for President, Yang for President.

statement:
When rank partisanship finds its way into processes that are fundamental to our democracy (as it has in other states), it undermines confidence in our institutions and in our system. The unfairness of it can cause apathy and antipathy that lead to civic disengagement and civil unrest. For all their promise, Amendments Y and Z are not the end-all of redistricting reform, but they give Coloradans a shot at a fairer, more transparent process that can help reinforce the legitimacy of our system.

With so many factors at play, “fairness” (in terms of the final map) will be difficult to define and more difficult to achieve. But in Amendments Y and Z, the citizens of Colorado have provided a set of criteria that the commission must work to faithfully balance as they evaluate and provide feedback on proposed maps. They must also work actively to identify, understand, and accommodate communities of interest. I hope to go in clear-eyed on the challenges that come with this task and ensure that we make use of the analytical methods available as we work through this difficult, but necessary, process.
professional_background:
In Colorado, I've organized, represented, and advocated for the Secular Hub--a nonprofit community center for atheists, agnostics, humanists and their families. Bringing experience from volunteer leadership positions in Texas and Arizona, I co-founded the Secular Hub's Community Service Committee, organizing a team of community members to create volunteer and fundraising opportunities and to provide support for members of our community. As the Board Chair and as a POC for outreach events, I represented the organization at public events hosted at our facility and at local festivals like the People's Fair and PrideFest. As a participant in a lobby day at the U.S. Capitol, I shared my community's concerns about pending legislation with the staff for Senator Gardner and Representative DeGette.

I’ve also encouraged increased civic participation in our community by hosting debate viewing parties, a ballot measure Q&A (with an advocate and an opponent), and a Civics lesson with former State Senator Lois Court. More recently, I invited Dr. Beth Malmskog, an assistant professor of mathematics from Colorado College, to speak on how to use mathematics to assess the fairness of proposed district maps.
org_list:
Secular Hub (a community for atheists, agnostics, humanists, and other nonbelievers)

- Board Member, 2016-2018
- Board Chair, 2016-2017
analytic_skills:
Early in the COVID pandemic, I actively tracked, plotted, and shared information about the spread of the disease. I derived the formula for the exponential doubling rate to track how effectively we were bending the curve and sent (unsolicited) feedback to CDPHE on discrepancies I found in their data. More recently, to answer growing skepticism and my own uncertainty about whether COVID deaths could have been overstated (conflated with other comorbidities), I sought out data on monthly deaths in the US from all causes over the last 20 years and compared them to provisional data from this year. Plotting it, I was able to convince myself and some of my skeptical friends that this year is, indeed, quite an outlier. 

An analytical approach is in my nature and it is what my internal compass compels.

When possible, I try to go straight to the source(s), using intermediaries, analysts, and pundits in a supporting role. While they all have important information to provide, they also necessarily apply their own filters in selecting, organizing, and interpreting the information they communicate. When possible, I try to identify and ask challenging questions that get at the heart of the matter; ensure that due diligence was performed; and reveal weaknesses in assumptions, methodologies, and in interpretations and results.

Both my formal education and work life (in aerospace and software engineering) have had an analytical skew. My education led me to informal studies of deductive and inductive reasoning (i.e. the reasoning of mathematical proofs and of the sciences, respectively). An interest in political discourse led to informal readings on logical fallacies, cognitive biases, and heuristics, as well as the role of non-rational processes in political persuasion. I am no mathematician, but I do have some experience with (and an interest in) statistics, which I think will come in handy for this work. A recent personality/work styles profile (that I cannot endorse, but will mention) identified “analytical” as my dominant thinking style.
consensus_statement:
In various leadership and non-leadership positions, I have experienced some of the challenges of working with people with deeply held and diverse viewpoints. Staying clear on our purpose and the constraints in which we are operating will be important to keep the team aligned. As I engage, I work to avoid letting my ego get in the way of progress and I try to focus on getting to the best solution (wherever and whoever it is coming from). Being forthright, modeling humility and open-mindedness (by demonstrating a willingness to be swayed by new information), and keeping a goal-orientation can go a long way in eliciting the same behavior from others.

Filter bubbles--political or otherwise--rarely lead their inhabitants to broad-based understanding, much less fairness. Unaffiliated committee members will play an important role in helping hold the committee accountable, provided those (unaffiliated) members can show that they are well-informed and focused on faithfully performing their duty.

As a demonstration of impartiality (or at least an interest in it), I am an intermittent attendee at local house district meetings for both the Republican and Democratic parties. I do that because we all have blindspots, and hearing facts, values, and framings from multiple perspectives can help reveal some of my own blindspots. It has also shown that while the issues that divide us are often amplified in the media and in our minds, when it comes to many of the issues that face us, we have a lot in common.
past_political_activity:
I vote and have made donations to causes friends are passionate about.  I also attend both my Republican and Democratic house district meetings.

- 7/3/2019 - $100 - Dr. Radhika Nath For Denver Kids

One can only built consensus when social justice prevails and all groups believe they are fairly represented; in essence, I have been lucky/or unlucky to serve and witness first-hand  to see "how consensus" was not done, and it was a learning experience... We need to build from where we are, and work toward "consensus building."  It will not be easy, but nothing I have ever achieved was easy.  ... JUST NECESSARY.  Change takes time, but on this issue of redistricting, it is way past time for change and do it right. statement: This Commission will be one of the most important efforts in the history of this state. Non-partisan redistricting can return fairness to our elections, faith in the political process, and help alleviate our polarized politics by ensuring that voters choose their representatives--not the other way around--and that districts are both geographically sensible and reflect the balanced political affiliations of our electorate. I can think of no better way to serve my community and my state.
professional_background: I want to make my community, state, and country a better place to live, work, and raise a family. analytic_skills: As an attorney, I am hired to spot issues, think critically about how to solve them, and clearly articulate a solution. As a member of several community boards, I am entrusted to identify and explain my positions on policy questions to a diverse group of extremely smart and dedicated people. I apply logic and reason all day, every day. That is the nature of my work, but it is also what drives me. As discussed, I am a pragmatic idealist who is committed to a vision of progress but will follow the facts as I find them and make decisions based on fairness and reason.
consensus_statement: I consider myself a pragmatic idealist. I am committed to a vision of progress but follow the facts as I find them and make decisions based on fairness and reason. I am committed to fairness and reason above all else, including party affiliation--after all, no victory is truly earned if the game is rigged. This philosophy guides not only my personal decision-making but my board responsibilities and legal practice, too. My clients expect me to fight for a cause, but more importantly they expect me to resolve matters as quickly and efficiently as possible. Good lawyers solves problems, they do not create them, and I'm proud that the vast majority of cases I handle are resolved amicably. The boards that I serve on are non-partisan groups dedicated to advancing a cause. Nothing gets done without a majority vote, and there is no majority unless we can find common ground and make progress. Nearly every vote I have cast on a board has been unanimous or near-unanimous, not because the issues were easy, but because we built consensus and agreed to collectively act in a way that advances the interests of our board, and those we serve, not ourselves.
past_political_activity: I have never been employed with a political campaign but, since November 10, 2015, have volunteered my time for Mike Johnston's 2018 gubernatorial and 2019 U.S. Senate campaigns. I also served on Mike Johnston's finance committee for both elections. I also volunteered time to make phone calls on behalf of Phil Weiser's campaign for Colorado Attorney General. I am currently a precinct captain for the Boulder County Democrats and through that work help get out the vote and field questions or concerns from residents within my precinct. I have also donated money to Jenna Griswold's campaign for Colorado Secretary of State, Phil Weiser's campaign, Judy Amabile's campaign for State House District 13, State Senator Kerry Donovan's re-election campaign, and Mike Johnston's two campaigns mentioned above.

statement: I was born and raised in Colorado to a mother who grew up in Boulder and a father who grew up in Colorado Springs. I've lived in or visited most of the bigger corners of the state most of my life. Living in Colorado and growing up in it as a purple state, where those on the left and the right had to work and compromise on important political decisions, has left a lasting impact on me. If we can't trust the systems we choose to elect our leaders, we can't trust our government which would undermine our democracy. I believe strongly in civic engagement and responsibility and I want to take my knowledge of systems & design from both my career and my political volunteering and apply it to the next wave of redistricting in order to ensure the continue existence of a fair and balanced system.

analytic_skills: Being a computer scientist, I spend all of my day analyzing problems and approaching them in a logical manner. If you can't break things down into discrete pieces for analysis and reasoning, you just can't build software. It's as fundamental as that. There is also plenty of computer science research on drawing fair electoral districts based on population and density to draw upon.
consensus_statement:
As a software engineer one of the best skills you can hone is your ability to build consensus and buy in from everyone involved in a project. If you can't establish at least some level of baseline trust people will hide or work against each other, even if they are ostensibly trying to solve the same problem for the same reason. I expect a problem like this to work in a similar way, but with maybe a little more emotion tied in. Fundamentally though I expect everyone on the commission to want the same thing, a system that is fair and doesn't tilt too far in any one direction.

Both of my grandfather's were veterans, as were my father and his brother. From an early age I was taught the value in duty and in being able to serve and execute a mission. I love Colorado and I want to ensure that everyone in the state feels they are being fairly represented in all mechanism of government.

analytic_skills: My process with a problem is to first analyze if I am working with the actual problem or a symptom of the problem.  I continue to search by staying curious and asking questions to ensure there isn't another problem that needs to be resolved.  Once the the true problem is established, I like to gather as much data as possible by doing my own research and calling experts to teach me areas that I am not knowledgeable of.  I use this same process with team projects by asking the full group to share their ideas and knowledge so we can learn as much as possible about the problem.  The next step is to develop the solution during which time I believe the more options the better the end result will be.  If we take just the first two or three solutions we may 1) be settling to appease the group or 2) not thinking through more creative solutions.  Final decisions come down to: cost, improved efficiency,  ability to solve the majority of the problem with time provided, and understanding that the final decision might not be 100% accurate but it brings the problem closer to the solution.
consensus_statement: As with any team project, all commissioners need to express their opinions regarding ideas put forth.  As a fellow team member, I would carefully ensure all participants share their thoughts, knowledge and concern for the betterment of our communities.  To do this, meeting will have agendas with specific topics that commissioners can research prior to the meeting.  Time will be built into the agenda for detailed conversation about the topics sharing both knowledge researched as well as interpretation and opinion. With my coaching background, I am skilled at listening, asking impactful questions and stay curious through conversations.  And, although I will share my ideas the overall goal is to create a redistricting plan that will be the most beneficial for the state in the coming years.
