analytic_skills: As noted in the previous question, I have spent my career in IT and software development. For me, the best way to diffuse disagreements and resolve issues is to remove the emotions and focus on the problem and how to solve it. There are always compromises required. For example, in software development, at times sales people would make promises to customers in order to close a deal. However, when those requirements would reach the development team, I would often be confronted with the need to balance the customer's expectations with reality. A customer may have expected a certain feature to be delivered in 3 months but reality was closer to 5 months. Could I deliver enough of the feature in 3 months and use other workarounds to achieve the same results? Those decisions required a great deal of logic and reason to determine the best course of action and keep a happy customer.
consensus_statement: I have worked most of my career in either IT or software development for Colorado companies, large and small. I have managed hundreds of people in my roles within these organizations. My employees counted on me to represent their interests to upper management. Conversely, I needed employees to understand the goals of the company. I always work from the position of being authentic. Anything less wouldn't be fair to either side. Additionally, it's important to run and participate in meetings with specific goals in mind. If those goals are not understood by the team, you can't reach a consensus. Everyone's voices should be heard. My experience in meeting management and team management could be valuable to help reach the objectives of the commission.

statement: A free and open electoral process is the very foundation of an effective democracy.  Without it, the will of the people becomes distorted and subject to manipulation by a few.  While I don’t always agree with election results, I can accept them if I believe that they reflect the will of the people.  However, if I believe the elections were unfairly manipulated, the legitimacy of the results comes into question.  I believe that this commission is charged with creating electoral boundaries that will permit elections that reflect the will of the people.
professional_background:
In Colorado, I have been on several boards of directors, and planning committees where I have developed a reputation for asking insightful questions, and challenging untested assumptions.  After the Stem High School shooting, our church decided we should investigate how to reduce isolation and help build a more resilient society beyond the church.  A “Wellness Committee” was formed and the focus was narrowed the to young adults between ages 14 and18.  I was elected to chair the subgroup focusing on developing resilience in the 16-18 year olds.  To determine what mental health issues our target population were facing, I suggested that we add members to our advisory group who were in the 16-18 year old target age range.  We then consulted with private therapists, community mental health programs, Arapahoe/Douglas County Mental health consortium, researched the literature, and searched to find what services were already being offered to address those issues.  The Wellness Committee then made recommendations to the church.  While the Corona Virus has delayed an implementation of these recommendations, preliminary efforts are being made to establish an independent nonprofit organization to implement these suggestions to provide preventive services so that the mental health issues do not develop in the first place.

The most relevant example however, was when I was on the Interim Planning Group for the Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services and I chaired a potentially contentious public hearing.  I was told that a group that was upset with HRS might attempt to disrupt the meeting.  I began the meeting by explaining the purpose of the meeting, and laying the ground rules that we would only be discussing issues related to the stated purpose of the meeting.  If people had other issues they would like to discuss, HRS staff would be available at the back of the room to discuss their issues in private.  When the first member of their group began to speak about their grievances, I politely asked if their comments were related to the topic of the meeting.  They agreed that they were not, and I suggested that they discuss their concerns with the HRS staff member at the back of the room.  This process continued through a third person from their group, after which their group no longer attempted to disrupt the meeting.  As I was leaving the meeting, by chance, I met the leader of the group in the elevator, and he apologized for his group’s behavior.  I was able to develop a solution where his group felt heard, but which did not disrupt the intended purpose of the meeting.  So often people who disrupt public meetings are doing so because they do not feel heard, and know of no other way to express their grievances.

analytic_skills:
As President of the Florida Society of Psychotherapists, I felt that our organization lacked focus.  We represented a wide variety of mental health professionals in private practice, including psychologists, mental health counselors, social workers, and marriage and family therapists, each with competing interests.  I called a board retreat to discuss what interests we had in common, and what services we could offer our members that they did not get from other organizations.  The previous President thought this would be a waste of time, but I convinced her to attend.  We looked at what we were currently offering, what other organizations were offering, and what needs weren’t being met, and decided to focus on private practice needs.  As a result, our membership rapidly increased.

As an individual investor, I have been highly successful in applying logic and reason to find promising stocks, analyzing their prospects for long term growth, and assessing obstacles and trends to obtain success.  While I pay attention to several newsletters to narrow the field of stocks to investigate, those newsletters may have biases or may discount important information which I find from other sources.  That is not to say that the stock market is always logical in the short run, or that my analysis is always correct.  But my performance beats the forecasts of many professional financial analyst’s.
consensus_statement:
In my book, Don’t Carve the Turkey with a Chainsaw: Resolving Family Conflict, I discuss how “conflict is not based on reality, but on people’s interpretations of that reality.”  To understand the other person’s interpretation of reality you must listen.  However, most people only listen to the other person’s reality 1% of the time, and when they do listen, it is to attend to information that confirms their own position and discounts contrasting information.  When you are more concerned with what YOU are saying than hearing what the other person has to say, you listen only long enough to defend your own position, or find flaws in your partner’s logic.  They do likewise, and the more they defend their position, the more they believe their own propaganda.

So, what is the best way to promote consensus?
1. First present our facts and our interpretation of the facts, giving reasons. 
2. Understand the other person’s thinking using sincere questioning and listening. Good listening involves detective work that helps uncover not only the content being expressed, but also the feelings, values, motivation, and interpretations behind the content. 
3. Focus on interests, not positions. Positions are the solutions you generate to solve a problem.  Interests are the underlying reasons influencing the decision.  It is frequently much easier to develop consensus about interests than positions. Frequently, a solution can be developed that addresses common interests, and develops a position neither party had previously considered. 
4. Brainstorm win/win solutions that focus on the future, then select the best options.  When we focus on what we want to happen in the future, rather than focusing on past misdeeds, we can avoid blaming, and the defensiveness that comes with it. 
5. Implement the solution.  
6. Evaluate the outcome using independent measures.

All this requires that the people we are dealing with feel safe, knowing that they will not be attacked, or humiliated.  Judgmental comments, insults, blaming, interrupting, interrogating questioning, all-or-nothing statements, and dishonesty all annihilate safety. “Respect is like air.  If you take it away, it’s all people can think about.  The instant people perceive disrespect in a conversation, the interaction is no longer about the original purpose—it is now about defending dignity.”

I believe my ability to be fair and impartial has been demonstrated in leadership roles where I have received considerable respect as documented by the provided letters of recommendation, and experiences. 

•	Quotes are from my book, Don’t Carve the Turkey with a Chainsaw: Resolving Family Conflict.  Free copies are available on request.

statement:
The power of your choice in representation is one of the most critical privileges human beings have in a civilized democracy. With the passage of Amendment Y in 2018, we the citizens of Colorado blazed the trail by being one of the small handful of states (perhaps one fifth)  in our country with independent redistricting committees where the will of the people can be applied without direct political pressure or fear of influence. I feel this provides the rest of the citizens a perspective of democratizing the decision making when gerrymandering is a concern across the political spectrum. 

Being a registered independent ever since I first registered to vote, I feel my perspectives of having seen so many different cultures and people of different backgrounds gives me the empathetic foundation of both the right and the left. I do not believe I ever know more than everyone else about anything, but I enjoy the learning and the ability to get diverse ideas and personalities to come together for extremely relevant common causes like this. Our state is changing just like the rest of the world, and I feel my perspectives and experience working with people around our country and world coupled with my love for Colorado, will make it easier for the committee to be  the fair representation of the citizens in achieving its mission.
professional_background:
I’ve been involved in several civic and community organizations since 2015. 

My primary volunteer experience since 2015 has been as the Founder, Board Chair & Executive Director of the Colorado Fine Arts Association, a 501c3 non profit founded in 2011 whose mission is to increase cultural understanding between our local communities and South Asia through arts. Over the course of the past decade my team has been able to present close to 200 events presenting our events to thousands of coloradans and people around the world to promote our mission. 

The organizing aspect of this is the effort I’ve made successfully in collaborating with the local communities and gone beyond sustaining such a niche area. Our organization is today the second largest receiver of funds from our home counties scientific and cultural facilities district. 

In addition, I have served in multiple capacities as part of various governance board committees at my local charter school for several years since 2015.

For the past 3 years, I have been serving in the Home Owners Association, currently as the President, of my community, one of the largest communities in Broomfield. 

On a professional note, I’m regularly invited to present at various technology conferences and committees around the world.

2. Founder, Board Chair and Executive Director of Colorado Fine Arts Association, Colorado’s premier 501c3 organization that is involved in bringing together local Colorado communities and South Asia through arts

3. President of the HOA and serving for the past 3 years 

4. Chair of the School accountability committee of the local charter school and member of the recruiting committee 

5. Founder and Chief Technology Officer of a very popular worldwide website on the arts & culture
analytic_skills:
I have been fortunate to have worked in the high tech field around various software, semiconductor, financial and professional services companies and organizations for the past 3 decades. During this time, I have applied the analytical skills to make complex organizational and technical decisions that have a direct impact on the lives of millions of people around the world.

In my community organizational experience, the challenges are similar but different. The budgets are tighter, success is measured with a different set of OKRs and KPIs, but I've tried to manage community organizations with the same analytical approach to set the clear goals, agree on the metrics of success and tracking them and continuously improving.

Having managed large set of geographically dispersed diverse people as part of my team across various cultures and languages all working towards a common mission has given me significant insights into looking at all aspects of a problem and solving them by applying analytical skills of observing, listening, researching, interpreting the options as applicable to the problem domain and validating the hypotheses before building an eventual solution.

I have in-depth technical expertise and advanced training in computational science including a popular US patent, data analytics and cognitive science. This unique combination helps me understand difficult situations better that I was able to prior to having this background and practicing this in solving several professional and community problems.
consensus_statement:
My philosophy whether in professional or personal life has been built around building consensus and ensuring that success is built on people working together. We all have unique perspectives we bring from our diverse background, but in order for any cause, community organization or our country to be successful, it is imperative that we find ways to work together under the guardrails provided for us to live in a civilized society. 

In my field of work, I deal with solving extremely challenging and complex technical problems. However, one thing I've learned is that even the most complex technical problems have an overwhelming people side to it. When faced with a situation like this, I use data as the backbone to build consensus. But, I do not believe that data alone is compelling as data can sometimes be manipulated to suit your point of view. This is where we have to find the middle ground that works reasonably well for everyone, not perfectly for a selected few.

I expect the commissioners to be truly representing the changing diverse culture of Colorado. They will be from different political, religious , gender identification, and other beliefs. It is extremely important that the eventual results are reflective of who we are. End of the day everyone irrespective of their race, education, opportunities and accomplishments want the same thing. A peaceful and productive life for themselves and their families, living in a healthy society that continues to be plugged in with the reality of what is happening in this world, not just in our backyard.

statement: I want to serve on the commission because after Amendment’s Y and Z passed in 2018 I realized I could get involved in the re-districting process even as an Independent voter. I want to be active in crafting solutions that benefit Colorado voters statewide. I consider myself a life-long learner, a good listener, a team worker and a fair person.
professional_background: My experience in organizing, representing and advocating for groups is centered on education and literacy. As a veteran teacher I had experience with organizations such as Close Up, The Educational Testing Service, The Colorado Council for Economic Education, The Colorado Geographic Alliance (COGA), and teaching Advanced Placement U.S. History, World Geography, European History and World History. I have been a reader/scorer for the College Board for over fifteen years. I have served as a reader/evaluator for the Children’s Book Council, participating on committees for the Notable Social Studies Award and the Carter G. Woodson Award. For years I have served as a local judge for the National History Day competition.

analytic_skills:
In achieving my Masters in Library and Information Science from the University of Denver in 2007 I had many opportunities to apply sophisticated analysis to situations and scenarios presented as part of my course work and in my subsequent employment as a librarian. 
From developing authentic collections and embracing the needs of diverse patrons to budget considerations within unique tax districts, the focus on analyzing data enabled me to chart a clear path for providing relevant and productive library service for all.

My ability to apply logic and reason to a problem is perhaps best illustrated by my work as a reader for the College Board’s Advanced Placement United States History exam. 
As a reader, our job is to read and score (according to a pre-set rubric) student’s essays answering one topic question during a seven day session that begins each day at 8am and ends at 5pm. The same question over and over, but answered by high school students from all over the country (as well as those attending international schools). We each read hundreds of essays daily by students whose skill sets vary wildly. 
Our goal as readers is to award the students for what they know – not punish them for what they omit or get wrong. Many times logic dictates that the student answered the prompt correctly, looking at their writing holistically, and even though there might be minor errors in their writing. Reason takes that logic by the hand and reminds us as readers that the student wrote the essay in 45 minutes, under extreme pressure and without prior knowledge of the prompt. 
So when we spend the two to three minutes reading and scoring each essay we embrace that reason and logic and our goal to benefit the student’s effort is realized.
consensus_statement:
I will promote consensus by being patient in listening to all points of view expressed and by maintaining flexibility in my own opinions. I believe my career as a public school teacher has helped shape my skills in this regard. High School students share their thoughts and opinions about absolutely everything. An integral part of being a good teacher is listening to what they have to say without verbal or visual signs of judgement, and then working towards an answer, resolution or consideration. 
This skill was, and is, often tested when what is said clashes with my own ideas or realities. That is where the work gets more difficult and can be more rewarding. 
Often in committee meetings, parent conferences, as well as mentoring new teachers, the same patience and honest listening is needed. 
Especially in these challenging times, I have no doubt that building agreement with any diverse group of people will be difficult. I believe with my personal history and experience I am up to the task.
past_political_activity:
My past political activity has mostly involved teaching my high school Social Studies students about local, state, national government, civic participation and the U.S. Constitution. When applicable, I have encourage my senior students to register to vote. In line with district policy, I have always presented a non-partisan view in my teaching as well as in my professional profile. 
As a registered Independent voter I have been fortunate and honest in regarding the issues behind ballot measures and candidates, as opposed to being influenced along party lines.
I vote given every opportunity not only because it is a privilege to do so, but also because I am answerable to my students as a person of responsibility and leadership.
I have not consciously donated money to any political campaign or organization. I was a member of the teacher’s union DCTA and I withheld monies from them that were being directed politically.

statement: I would like to serve on the commission to help create a carefully constructed compromise that proportions the congressional districts to best serve the constituents of Colorado in the U.S. House of Representatives.
professional_background:
Throughout my career, I have been fortunate to have positions where I am able to advocate for Coloradans to promote their full participation in the democracy.  In my college years, I worked on civil rights issues.  My support of women's  equality and women's reproductive rights is demonstrated by my involvement in the effort to pass The Equal Rights Amendment and serve on the Board of Rocky Mountain Planned Parenthood.  To promote women's full participation in Colorado, I was the Executive Director of The Women's Foundation of Colorado and served on the Board of the Women's Bean Project - both organizations serving low-income women on their path to self-sufficiency.

My service on the staffs of a governor, a member of the U.S. House, U.S. Senate and two presidents gave me a chance to make the lives of all Coloradans better - everyday if I did my job well, I helped open doors to services provided by my government.

As a reluctant retiree, I have volunteered at the Library to ensure that "The People's University" is open to all and able to provide services and materials to enrich its patrons' lives.  I have organized volunteers to elect political candidates.  I have gone door to door canvasing.  I have given classes helping people better understand both sides of the issues on the Colorado ballot.

To support a greater voice for citizens in national politics, I served on the Board of Colorado Common Cause and became the first straight person on the Colorado Human Rights Campaign Board - seeking equality for the LBGTQ community,  and I was honored to be the first Anglo on the Latino Community Foundation of Colorado's Board, recognizing the growing and vibrant Hispanic population throughout the state and helping to meet their needs.

My life has been richly textured by these experiences and serving on the commission will give me a chance to help shape a dynamic, fair and unbiased division of the state's population into congressional districts that will well represent us in the decade ahead. As a senior member of Congressman David Skaggs' staff in 1991, I got first hand knowledge of the process as the district was being reconfigured and the decisions affected the constituents and the Congressman.

Finally, I work to develop options, so that if Plan A doesn't work, we can move to Plan B and beyond - I work to be a multi-tiered thinker, realizing that complex problems need complex solutions that can be implemented as straightforwardly as possible.

statement: I believe in a fair and transparent process for drawing district boundaries and believe that boundaries should, to the greatest extent possible, reflect community boundaries and common interests that are known to the general public, not obscure or arbitrary political considerations.  I served on the Reapportionment Commission in 2001-02 and believe that commission had the potential to reach bipartisan agreement on legislative maps.  Unfortunately under the old framework, the party in the majority had little incentive to compromise, so members of both parties who wanted to reach consensus were told to toe the party line.  The new framework adopted by Colorado voters provides a welcome opportunity for consensus building rather than maximizing partisan advantage.

When I served in the legislature (1999-2005), I made a habit of getting to know my colleagues in both parties because understanding what is important and special to each person was indispensable toward finding areas of commonality, especially across party lines.  During legislative committee meetings and during my service on the 2001-02 reapportionment commission, I made a point of regularly sitting with members of the opposite political party to foster informal or personal conversations that built collegiality and trust.

statement:
Redistricting is critically important, and I believe Colorado's new system can appropriately de-politicize the process. I believe I have the experience, judgment, and skill set to effectively collaborate with fellow commissioners, communicate with the public, and reach reasoned decisions consistently with the purpose of the commission. 

I am also a public-spirited person. Before becoming a lawyer, I served my community as a deputy sheriff, and since earning my law degree have devoted a substantial amount of time to pro bono legal services. I view membership on the commission as another opportunity to continue to serve my state and community.

I recently volunteered to judge a writing competition sponsored by the Anti-Defamation League, though that has not started yet.
analytic_skills:
I joke that they beat the creativity out of you in law school, and while I say it tongue-in-cheek, there is still a little truth in that statement. Lawyers are trained to analyze issues in a specific, formalized way. We identify the specific issue in question, develop the relevant facts, apply them to applicable law, and reach a reasoned conclusion. This is called the "IRAC" method. Each step in this analysis is important. If the issue is framed too generally or too specifically or not quite on point, for example, the facts, law, and conclusion will be disconnected from the question presented. The same applies to which facts are "relevant" and which law is "applicable." After 17 years as a trial and appellate lawyer, I have learned to be precise about these kinds of decisions and analyses. 

That said, all of this analytical ability would be effectively worthless if one did not also have the ability to communicate clearly with people from all backgrounds and to ensure that the views of others are heard and that they are valued, as well. I have broad life experience: I have lived overseas, worked every kind of odd job, served in the military, been a police officer, owned a business, and been and a spouse and a parent. I believe this broad experience helps me relate to, communicate with, and understand the perspectives of a broad array of people.
consensus_statement: I consider myself a very collaborative lawyer, even for a litigator. I have worked cooperatively with opponents to solve high-stakes commercial problems, and I have maintained good relationships with opposing counsel long after our cases concluded, which I think speaks to my collaborative approach to problem solving. That said, I can be a staunch advocate for important principles--which I support with analysis, not opinion--but without being disagreeable or overly contentious. I develop facts and apply them to law, but I remain open to different perspectives, as well.
past_political_activity: I have placed signs and flags for the Obama and Biden campaigns at my home; attended a rally for President Obama during the 2012 campaign, and recently waived a Biden/Harris flag on a street corner in Parker. I donated to Phil Weiser's campaign for Attorney General as well as to the America Israel Political Action Committee (AIPAC).

occupation: Mortgage Loan Originator at Colorado Mortgage Holding.
education: Master of Business Administration degree in Banking and Finance.  Bachelor of Arts degree in Spanish.  Associate of Arts degree in Liberal Arts. Course work in accounting.  Licensed as a Mortgage Broker.  Certificate in Medical Interpreting.
statement:
Ever since I researched the subject of redistricting and read a book about it, I became aware how important it is that every American’s vote is counted. I have found that one way to disenfranchise a voter’s right to be equally represented is through the unfair drawing of lines along the districts on a map. Example: if you have knowledge of where the minority population resides on a map and you want to keep them from winning the election, you can exert your power by redrawing the lines in a way to keep the minority from winning an election, thereby disenfranchising their right to have their voice heard.

This is what drives me to serve on the commission.  I am a Navajo Indian; I am unique and come from a population that is underserved and underrepresented.  I believe that my input from a diverse perspective is valuable because I would like to make sure people of my race and other minority population have an equal voice through fair mapping.   

My experiences in the community as Vice President of Morgan County Democrats and my background of volunteer work only enhance my drive to serve to make a difference as a member of the redistricting commission.
professional_background:
I can think of a lot of things as an answer to this question, but I would like to focus on my experience advocating, organizing and representing, as a member and acting as the Vice-Chairman of Morgan County Democrats in Colorado. 

When I moved to Fort Morgan, Colorado a few years ago, I found that the Democratic Party was a minority in the community.  Most residents of Fort Morgan belonged to the Republican Party.  As a result, the Democrats felt oppressed. As a leader, I found that this made it difficult for me to get things done.  

Just to place a sign out in the street was risky for fear that the signs would be vandalized. And it did happen. The signs that we placed on the street were immediately vandalized several times.  

Few people wanted to work with us because we were Democrats.  It was difficult to just locate a venue to host an event in the community.  To rent an office to hold our monthly meeting was an enormous task because organizations refused to rent to us.  

Organizing a float in the 4th of July in order to be visible in the community was unheard of.  Few members of the Morgan County Democrats wanted to even ride in the parade for fear of not only ridicule, but the possible physical harm that may come to them. Few wanted to take these risks. The first time we constructed a float, decorated it with huge banners with huge letters of MORGAN COUNTY DEMOCRATS and rode on it in the 4th of July parade, some people ran out in the streets and threw objects at us. Children sprayed water directly on us. But we survived it.  Those people in the audience, who had secretly claimed to be Democrats, were initially apprehensive to cheer and clap for us.  But I noticed that they slowly came around over the years. Each year they saw our Party in the parade, more of them came out to cheer, voicing their appreciation.  

Losing a job was a concern for the members of our organization. They did not want to deal with the repercussions of being revealed that they supported the Democratic Party at their workplace.  I experienced this myself.  I kept a low profile at work.  In this way I identified with the members’ oppressed feelings.  Some must have lost their jobs before I came on the scene.  

Election time seemed to be a stressful time.  Door-knocking was an insurmountable task. No one dared to knock on doors the first year I came to Fort Morgan.   I personally, alone, had to go knock on doors to get the vote out.  Gradually over the years, I got a few more people to muster enough courage to knock on doors with me.  What helped were the stories I wrote up about my experiences knocking on doors and I emailed these to the members of the Democratic Party in the county.  Slowly, more and more people became willing to knock on doors with me. 

With this backdrop of the circumstances, I felt that I had to advocate for who I am and on behalf of my party, not only to the community of Fort Morgan, but to the members themselves in the monthly meetings.  There was tremendous discrimination and prejudice against the Democrats in Morgan County. Everything that we valued as a party, like gay rights, women’s right to choose, immigration rights, labor rights, environmental protection values, was held against us.  

Therefore, it took a lot of courage, determination, persistence, and the energy to change the minds of the people.  This I experienced while I organized and represented the Democrats and advocated for them in their community as well as within their own party.

A toll-free telephone number was set up where members of their families could call and reach a virtual volunteer, like myself, who took a list of needs like food, water, medical, transportation and cleaning supplies and passed this list on to the ground volunteers who supplied these needs. analytic_skills:
Most of my professional career in mortgage lending over a time span of 20 years involved not just creative analytical skills, but also critical thinking, communication, and research skills.   

When a borrower comes to me for financing, I am required to use all these skills to determine if the borrower will be capable of repaying the money he hopes to obtain.  As the loan officer or mortgage broker, I am the first gatekeeper towards the borrower’s path to obtaining a loan. After analyzing the borrower’s liabilities and assets, I have a duty to make a wise judgment as to whether the loan will close.  This involves gathering data to reveal the picture of the borrower.  I am obligated to input the data accurately into my calculations and verify that the borrower has sufficient income, stable job history, and sufficient reserves to sustain the monthly payment.  I have to determine whether the borrower has the appropriate debt ratio, which is the amount of debt analyzed against the income.  Investigating, verifying, and checking for accuracy are all part of forming the true picture of the borrower. If there are blemishes in the credit history of the borrower, I have the responsibility to determine how the negative credit will impact the borrower’s ability to repay the loan.  Here, my ability to communicate is essential; I am required to draw the information from the borrower to determine if the bad credit is due to consistent negligence or a one-time event that was beyond the control of the borrower. 

When the case is extremely difficult, I am forced to collaborate with my fellow-loan officers and supervisor to see if the deal is too risky or if we can creatively do the financing. An example is if the property falls within a fine-line definition of real property. Real property is one that is affixed to land.  As a mortgage lender, the only properties I can finance are those that fall within this definition of real property. A questionable type of this property is a modular home which used to be a movable property but has since been transformed into a property that would be attached to land. The investors who ultimately put up the money to finance the deal may bring up this question at the last minute of closing and the property could be rejected. A good loan officer has this foresight and avoids this probability beforehand.  

Being at the forefront where everything hinges on how well I reveal the true picture of the borrower is the essential part of whether the investor will profit or lose money on the deal of financing a borrower’s request.  How well I have used my analytical skills and how well I have applied my logic and reasoning to solve the initial problems involved in approving a loan will determine the end result of the investment.
consensus_statement:
As president of a Native American organization, I had a rare opportunity to lead a people that came from two diverse religious beliefs.  One group was of the Christian faith and this group consisted of urban Indians coming from the city lifestyle.  The other group was of the traditional Native American religion which came in from the reservation areas.   I was tempted to cater to one group which had similar beliefs to mine.  But I had to overlook my established way of thinking and become empathetic to those who believed differently than me.  I also noticed that it was easy for one group to turn against the other because they felt, albeit unsubstantiated, there was favoritism demonstrated against them. An example of the diverse of beliefs was how they felt about gay members of the group.  The Christians did not feel that assistance should easily be given to the gay members of the group while the traditional natives had more compassion and respect for the gay members. Though it was a challenge, I had to be fair and impartial. I brought these groups together by promoting consensus by first allowing the members to introduce themselves and to share something unique about themselves.  An important characteristic about the gay members was that they were very artistic.  Most had a talent to perform or to decorate.  This came in very handy when we decided to build a float for an annual parade that had a historical significance to the Native American community.  Our float was featured on television because we brought Native American dancers together to perform on the float.  The Native American motif and design was unique and outstanding.  What resulted from this event was the new respect the gay members gained.  There was a better understanding between the groups and a respect for their diverse uniqueness of the members.  The conservative group became more empathetic to the gay group as well as the traditional native group.  They all started to get along and a much better cohesiveness was created.  As a result, the ability to collaborate on new projects were more easily achieved.

From experiences like this, I feel that I can contribute to the redistricting commission by listening to the different perspectives and points of view, thereby be impartial and  promote consensus among the commissioners.
past_political_activity:
Most of my past political activity has been with the Morgan County Democratic Party.  I led the way to knocking on doors for the Hillary Clinton campaign.  I made calls to voters.  I spent all day on election day contacting those voters who had not yet voted and following up on those who had not responded by visiting their homes in order to make sure that every voter had voted.  I would like to think that due to my efforts, I have contributed to the victory of Hillary Clinton in the state of Colorado.  

Before the Hillary Clinton elections, I helped Barack Obama win Colorado.  I was fortunate to win the Northeastern CO campaign for the volunteer who had gone the extra mile of knocking on doors and calling on voters.  The winner would have his picture taken with Vice President Joe Biden.  I was so excited to meet and pose in a photo with VP Joe Biden. 

I have been very active with the Morgan County Democratic Party ever since I came to Fort Morgan 14 years ago.  I volunteered to head committees to organize dinners, like our annual Big-Ten dinner, as well as the fall and Christmas dinners.  The task of organizing and planning involved a wide range of tasks.  We had to find a proper venue equipped with a kitchen and a facility to hold enough people for the event.  If the event was a potluck dinner, we had to make sure people brought enough food.   We had to come up with a theme and design an agenda.  We had to solicit help to decorate the venue and clean up the location.  Places that had no sound system was an extra task to find someone to provide a sound system.  Providing entertainment for the dinner involved the task of soliciting musical groups to perform at the event.  In order to run an event according to schedule, it was important to follow up with the speakers and presenters to make sure they had all the information they needed so they could arrive on time.  Finally, one of the most important part of organizing an event was to plan a fund-raising project, like an auction during the dinner, that would be lucrative for the Party. 

Community exposure was one of my objectives as a leader.  I wanted the public to know who we were and what we stood for.  I wanted to make the public feel welcome to our center.  With that in mind, I reached out by introducing myself and the Party whenever events came about in the community.  I made small presentations about our monthly meetings, our frequent get-togethers including dinners and parties and made the public feel at ease with us and helped them realize that we had a lot of positive things to offer.  

I donated $35 dollar every year for the Big-Ten dinners since 2015.  I also donated $30 each to 3 candidates since that time.

analytic_skills: I have developed the ability to listen and hear what is being said, and what is not being said. I am strong in common sense and have always been a centrist politically and in my life.
consensus_statement: Building consensus First you take away the win/lose mentality by quickly identifying those things that everyone can agree upon, then going forward you check where the individuals stand on the "I like it, I can live with it, I hate it" level. You hone in on those I hate factors and work through them until you can get them to the I can live with it level. In the classroom, as a chair of a committee, or overseeing a hearing on seeking redress on a governmental program, it's not about you, it's about them.  I also think that my 30 years as an educator and the years of participation with the local League of Women Voters; giving presentations on the bills, moderating candidates meetings, and especially consolidating and rephrasing questions to be asked so they don't show a bias. My goal is to make sure every person and side is presented and I then check not only the facts but the reliability of resources.
past_political_activity: In the 80's and 90's I had served on a number of political action committees for the Colorado Education Association, been a part of three candidate campaigns, been the chair of the county Democratic Party through some 3 election cycles, served as an election judge for over a decade. Since November 10, 2015 , I have donated to Diane Mitsch Bush's campaigns for 3d Congressional District, the local Democratic Party and I think to Micheal Bennet's re-election campaign in 2016.

occupation: Assistant Professor, University of Colorado Boulder
education: PhD, Columbia University (in philosophy of education, with an emphasis on education policy). BIS, University of Minnesota, in philosophy, political science, education policy.
statement: I think there are far too few competitive districts--at both the state and federal level. Such safe districts erode democratic accountability, and often end up in legislators who are not asked to represent diverse, and divergent, viewpoints. I wonder if this situation also undermines the possibilities for political compromise and action. At the same time, I understand that districts also need to represent certain minoritized communities who may be under-represented in general or at-large elections. So, in a sense, I see the complexity of the issues, and hope to help consider these various viewpoints.
professional_background: Before becoming a professor, I worked with several school and community organizations, including in new immigrant communities, working to create reciprocal and respectful partnerships between universities and communities. I do work collaboratively with a range of parents, district officials and other constituents on our district's DAC (district accountability committee). I've chaired the Data and Assessment committee, and played a lead role on the Charter School Application review committee, which often involved negotiating difficult--and vocal--constituencies on the committee, and those advocating various positions. Our committee had to craft careful, fair evaluation reports that could be understood and accepted by advocates both for--and against--expanding charter schools, and also ones that would hold up to subsequent review and appeal.
org_list: I am mostly active in my local school district (serving on the BVSD DAC), and local school (University Hill Elementary). I also served on a state-wide commission to evaluate accountability measures for Alternative Education Campuses (AECs). Through my work and research at CU, I've organized a number of outreach events to help communities better understand--and deliberate about--standards, accountability and assessment. I'm committed to working across political lines to build opportunities for dialogue. I've worked both on the Front Range and also in NE Colorado to hold community forums and smaller school-based dialogues.
analytic_skills: I am trained as a philosopher, and enjoy thinking through the various reasons, criteria or values at play in discussions. For instance, what principles or values might shape or guide redistricting choices? How might these principles be applied, fairly, and with an eye to their consequences, and the perhaps disparate consequences for differently situated groups? I also like careful and analytic writing, from meeting notes to final reports (sometimes an under-rated part of committee work!).
consensus_statement: I am a Democrat, but grew up in a small town with many different political allegiances. I believe that I have a strong ability to hear--and empathize--with other viewpoints. As a faculty member, I have participated on many standing and ad-hoc committees, and often find ways to listen to different viewpoints, forge consensus, and move groups forward productively. I believe my colleagues would say that I am kind, a good listener, and someone who can always keep a sense of humor. While I am a registered Democrat, I strongly believe in fair play, equal representation and respectful debate/ conversation across political positions.
past_political_activity: I am a registered Democrat, and have volunteered for the campaign of Dan Feehan (doing GOTV calls, mostly), who ran for the 1st District Congressional seat in Minnesota (the district where I grew up). I have donated to mostly MN political campaigns: Dan Feehan (2018 and 2020), Amy Klobuchar (2020 Democratic primary) and Biden/Harris (2020 Presidential election). I have also given money to Wellstone Action (a MN organization)

occupation: Software developer, digital globe
education: MS Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences from University of Coloraso at Boulder, BS Geophysical Engineering from Colorado School of Mines
statement:
I want to serve the proud traditions and principles of the us representative democracy, and guarantee my relatively unique viewpoint is represented.
Accurate representation which is focused on solving our most pressing concerns as local communities, while advocating for those communities when solving the concerns of broader shared communities is how our representative democracy works most effectively. The only way to achieve that pillar of our us government is to make sure the resulting representatives most accurately represent the opinions of the voters. This needs to hold true whether their opinions are based on profession, age, ethics, ethnicity, faith, culture, interest or any other trait or belief. I want to help find a districting solution that makes sure the biggest stresses of the most Coloradans are the primary concerns of the our representatives while not suppressing the most critical issues of the minority groups. I want to help make sure every unique minority facet of our beautiful state can see themselves reflected in the advocacy of their representatives.
More personally, I’m 29 years old with a unique skillset with a background in gis and data communication. I will be impacted by the echoing decisions of the committee for not just the next decade, but also by precedent for censuses to come. Likely though, age wise I will be under represented, particularly considering I am near the minimum age requirement of Colorado General Assembly. Despite my age though I have a wealth of experience and skills in geolocational and data based problem solving which is key in districting. I want to do this because I think I am a rare and valuable view point.
professional_background: I have advocated for myself and the interests of people that share my profession, culture, ethics or region. As well as for those who I don’t immediately belong such as the bleeding disorder community, which I joined when I was a teenager because of a close relationship with someone with hemophilia. A recent example of success I have had organizing my community would be solving a storm water drainage issue in my neighborhood. I worked with my neighbors to define the problems causing water to pool in our yards, worked with civil engineers and contractors to develop a solution using chase drains.  Then worked stakeholders like my neighbors, the town of Frederick public works, and our metro district to execute that solution while following requirements like permitting, the drainage plan and funding. The metro district then expanded that solution to other drainage issues in our subdivision.
org_list: National Hemophilia Society colorado chapter
analytic_skills:
I have worked for the USGS (DOI), IBM and Maxar (formerly DigitalGlobe) working as a software developer on several missions in a variety of industries aerospace, meteorology, natural disasters, and shipping logistics.  All of which involve logic and reasoned problem solving with complex GIS data.  I daily: define problems, collect (physical, digital, legal, and financial) requirements, design solutions, communicate those solutions to clients, and implement those solutions.
For example, when I worked for the United States Geologic Service a division in the Department of the Interior in college for 5 years; made earthquake risk maps. These maps are provided to first responders within 15 minutes of an earthquake to best make decisions about where victims meed help and what help they will need. I also made earthquake hazard maps for legislators and policy makers to use when designing building codes. I frequently worked with audiences like first responders and government officials to explain natural disaster risk and refine the information I provided to best serve the common goal of keeping people safe in the most extreme disasters.
consensus_statement:
I can reach a consensus for two reasons: Im an political independent use to finding common ground with both parties, and I am good at communicating complex data driven solutions particularly with maps.
I believe the most stark differences in our political beliefs is not our political party, despite our representatives voting on party lines the majority of the time. When I talk with my diverse neighbors about how legislation would impact them in a way divorced from party and focused on their family, I find the divisions much more tied to their professions, faith, and interests. When I became an independent, it was to find candidates from both parties that shared my opinions and focus for political issues that impacted me. I think I can convince people from both parties of the real contrasts in our communities rather than focus on party and how best to make every diverse voice be represented.
Additionally, I have worked on map and data presentation design to lay out non-partisan intents and draw a solution in a simple and understandable way. I can communicate a data set clearly and prove with reasonable and logical arguments that a solution meets criteria. As well as communicate any potential problems or fallacies and how they were addressed.
past_political_activity: None

statement: My own academic history in mathematics and statistics, and the data literacy and statistical numeracy that I possess would be an invaluable tool to this commission that aims to create independent and fair redistricting processes and maps for the state of Colorado. Further, I'm interested in addressing the incredible population growth and demographic changes that have taken place all over the state (not just on the Front Range, but on the Western Slope, in mountain towns, and in southern Colorado's and eastern Colorado's plains communities. There has been such change in the makeup and sizes of our communities, that it's incredibly important to be able to address the diversity of our state's population, in terms of place, race, class, sex, gender identity, and so many other demographic factors.
professional_background: My most direct experience comes from the equity and representation advocacy work that I am helping lead at the K-12 school where I work. The school is currently working through a multi-year equity and oppression audit, and my role has been to help design and deliver professional development for teachers that is aimed at dismantling the oppression of students by race, class, gender identity, sexual orientation, religion, citizenship status, etc. My work involves considering the wider body of academic knowledge related to equity and inequity in public education, and helping teachers develop their own senses of equity literacy and building inclusive, anti-oppressive learning communities, environments, and curriculum.
org_list:
Following member (not leadership) of 350Colorado - movement for climate justice. 
Sunrise Movement - movement for climate justice and for action against mass extinctions
analytic_skills: Please refer to my years of postsecondary education in the fields of math, statistics, science, and data aggregation and analysis (via work with climate data during graduate research).
consensus_statement: As an educator in public schools, my day-to-day existence is characterized by being able to guide a classroom of diverse teenagers, with unique and particular home lives, guardians' views, and cultural knowledge, to a class consensus in order to move the group forward in their scientific understanding. As a teacher of environmental science, too, I am well-practiced at facilitating conversations and guiding a diverse group's analysis of this scientific field that is still considered "controversial" in many social circles, despite the overwhelming scientific consensus. There are lots of personal, cultural, and economic identities tied up in the issue of the climate crisis that are present in the student population that I work with, and my experience and leadership in that environment demonstrates a commitment to data and evidence that bolsters my ability to be impartial and not to get wrapped up in emotional or socio-psychological concerns that are present around political issues.
past_political_activity:
Monthly donations to the ACLU's national organization

All other political activity has been restricted to attending marches, protests, and community meetings.

statement: I believe it is imperative to create districts that equitably represent the interests of all citizens. To create congressional districts that do not favor one party, the district boundaries must be established to insure voters choose their representatives and not the other way around. The independent commission process for establishing congressional districts is new to Colorado and I would be honored to serve on the first one. Colorado voters deserve competitve elections and the redistricting process should enable that result; by serving on the commission I expect to contribute to realizing that result.
professional_background: Serving on a variety of committees, Boards, and alliances has given me experience in working cooperatively in public organizations. Listening, sharing, setting objectives, and integrating priorities are especially important to achieve results. While members of a group or team might have common objectives, there may be reservations or objections that individuals have that prevent the group from achieving the objectives. When this occurs, the need for conflict resolution methods may be required. I have been trained in conflict resolution and have had numerous opportunities to employ these methods successfully. My experience in conflict resolution may be required in serving on the commission.

This provided a framework for identifying root causes and differentiating them from symptoms. By serving on a variety of committees I gained experience in working with people with both similar and opposing interests to achieve consensus. Where there is a team of people working to achieve an agreed upon objective, one must make sure the objective is understood and if there are any reservations, the reservations are identified, discussed and resolved or the objective will not be readily achieved. This process takes logic and reason and familiarity with conflict resolution tools. Additionally, if data are to be analyzed, knowledge of techniques such as data mining may be necessary in order to process the census data appropriately. I have experience in applying data analysis techniques including pattern recognition, machine learning, and neural networks.

I will promote consensus by listening and using skills acquired from my education, experience in leading meetings, serving on many public and private committees and employing conflict resolution methods gained through certified 
conflict resolution practices. Having worked in the high tech industry for many years, I have had to be fair and impartial in dealing with clients, peers and employees who have high intellectual capacities, advanced educations and skills, often accompanied with large egos. They are highly aware of identifying biases in decision making and not shy regarding pointing them out. I have learned that fair and impartial decisions are requirements in gaining trust and commitments to achieving results. This has also worked most of the time in dealing with my children.

occupation: Retired
education: Clarkson School of Nursing, Registered Nurse 1970; Regis University Bachelors of Science in Nursing, Regis University Masters of Science in Nursing
statement:
I have a growing awareness of the divisines in our politics.  There are many who don’t feel heard when they raise concerns.  Where I live, in Longmont, I know that the chances of electing a person to the Federal House of Representatives who reflects my community are almost nil.  
It is crucial that our political landscape become more about representing people and the local/ regional aspects of the communities where we live. My hope is that by serving on the committee, I can advocate for a fair map where everyone can know that their voice will be heard when voting.  A map that realizes the dream of equal representation, without favoring parties or special interests, while also acknowledges areas of our communities have special circumstances, such as race and economic status that must be reflected in the maps. I continue to hope for a return to civility in politics where we listen to and learn from each other.
professional_background:
I am a long time environmental advocate.  Now that I am retired I have time to become personally engaged by working on issues important to me.  I bring my skills that include close to 40 years in management to this work. I am able to bring strategic decision making, collaboration, planning and financial ability to the organizations I work with.
Building support for sustainaibility throughout our community is vital to the work that Sustainable Resilient Longmont (SRL) undertakes. SRL engages residents across the community, including  youth and people of color in events such as earth day.  SRL Earth day is a focus on children and how they interact with the earth.  In 2020, the event moved on line with youth from local high schools discussing what climate change means in their lives. 
Another important aspect in community/ grassroots activism is working with city government.  I know all of the city council members personally.  I frequently speak at council meetings to advocate for environmental issues.  This relationship was a key element in achieving a Longmont Resolution to commit to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
org_list:
Climate Reality, trained climate leader
Sierra Club 
 Indian Peaks Group Executive Committee, 
Colorado Chapter of the Sierra Club,Executive committee, currently Chair of Executive Committee
Sustainable Resilient Longmont, Board Member
Our Health, Our Future Our Longmont, Board Member
North Colorado Partners for Clean Energy, Coalition member
City of Longmont Climate Action Task Force, member
Longmont Newcomers
Coloradans Resisting Extreme Energy Development
analytic_skills:
My success in Nursing Administration was based on my ability to analyze issues and apply data to arrive at a solution. I will relate a quality improvement project in my last position.  There were three ICU’s.  A QI project to reduce ventilator associated pneumonia was very successful in 2 of the 3.  The third, the Neuro Trauma ICU, was difficult, but knowing that there had to be a reason, a team explored the differences.  We discovered that patients who had head trauma were being transported daily for head CT scans.  The transport was putting them at risk and we were able to define some simple steps to prevent this complication.  
I apply the same type of skills to my activist work. When planning educational events about topics, such as renewable energy, exploring data and research studies informs how we plan events. Reading through online records of meetings and attending board meetings at Platte River Power Authority gives me the ability to discuss electricity generation with our city council and to speak with other community members.
consensus_statement:
As I look at the current political landscape, I see so much division. I grew up in rural Nebraska.  I know and love many folks who are conservative.  I am not afraid to reach out to those who do not share my political views.  In my work in Nursing Administration, being able to build relationships with people in other divisions was paramount to the success in my area of responsibility.  Also, working on projects that involved caregivers on several shifts, in several units on two campuses,  required skills in building consensus.  To bring in physician acceptance required negotiating skills.  I use these skills of negotiating, relationship and consensus building, plus willingness to work with people of diverse backgrounds to my activism work.  I also bring the nursing art and skill of empathy.  Stepping back to see the people behind decisions and how they are affected is needed in any work.
My work with SRL provides an example of how I can apply these skills. Acceptance of the possibility of renewable energy is difficult for many people.  Acknowledging that jobs in the fossil fuel industry will be lost, then discussing the potential of jobs in renewable energy requires listening first instead of arguing. This usually leads to a good conversation while planting seeds that may change minds.
past_political_activity:
Being involved in our democracy is important to me.  My involvement includes donations to candidates at all levels of our government, working with organizations to promote candidates, and personal engagement such as door to door campaigning. 
Locally I work with a grassroots group that delivers candidate information to residents in Longmont.  Through my local Sierra Club group in Boulder County, I work on candidate endorsements based on environmental priorities.  Also, I am on the board of Sustainable Resilient Longmont.  This organization holds candidate forums where candidates are asked questions about sustainability. 

This election season, I determined that I needed to engage in the Presidential Election.  I wrote letters, texted and made phone calls to battleground states through  Sierra Club Independent Action.

Colorado Democratic Party, Boulder County Dems, Longmont Area Dems

occupation: I am a professor of Biology at the Community College of Denver.  I also work as an affiliate Biology professor at Metro State University, and am an adjunct online professor for Anatomy and Physiology for Community Colleges of Colorado Online.  I have been at CCD for 13 years, MSU Denver for 11 years, and CCCOnline for a year.
education: I have a BS in Evolution and Ecology from Universtity of California, Davis.  I have an MS in Biology from Wichita State Univeristy and an ABD (All but doctorate) from the Univeristy of Colorado Health Sciences Center.
statement: I would like to represent the interest and concerns of average voters who want to a fairer and more judicious approach to building a world where our kids can thrive in.  I am an average father of three who simply wants to help I the process of making a more equitable state for us all to live in.
professional_background: I don't have any experience organizing any interests groups in Colorado.  The only representing/advocating I have done was within the context of program administration and development as part of my job duties.
org_list: N/A
analytic_skills: Coming from a science background I have been trained in an analytical discipline.  Mist of my life I have been specifically trained to deeply and actively assess data and to see it with a critical eye.  In science we have a very heavy emphasis on looking at data critically because we are trying to understand the the truth of how the world works.  In this process logic both deductive and inductive is a deeply ingrained part of our process.  All arguments or claims must be based on sound premises that themselves are supported by data.  In addition to this the claim made needs to have data that answers or specifically supports that claim.  Often our data answers a question that is different than what we are asking.  In this case we must always follow the data to determine what it is revealing.  We need to do this always in an intellectually honest way, by acknowledging our biases and then controlling for them so that they do not taint our conclusions.  Everything we do must have an intellectually honest and rigorous framework so that we can discern the rational from the irrational, and control for our biases, and so that we can creat a fair and equitable solution that benefits all voters in Colorado.
consensus_statement: Let's be frank.  Redistributing has often been about partisan wrangling where each party seeks to advance its own political influence and dominance over the other.  This however should not be about parties but about people, and those of us who have to live with the decision that others make.  My whole life I have been a peace maker often looking for pathways between two warring ideals.  The beginning of consensus and agreement starts with listening.  We need to listen and hear each other first and focus on our shared values as Coloradoans.  Often we speak our opinions too readily instead of hearing the opinions of others.  I would listen to what others feel and fear and hope for I this process so that everyone has a voice that is heard.  In scenarios when we disagree we need to negotiate and mutually construct a shared pathway to help us navigate our differences while at the same time protecting the validation of our positions.  When people are heard and considered and their voices and opinions are heard and acted upon it will foster consensus and ownership of a pathway we can all live with
past_political_activity: I have only donated $100 to the Senate campaign of Lindsey Graham.  Otherwise I not have played any active volunteering roles for any campaigns since the 90's nor have donated any money to any other campaigns.

occupation: I am not currently employed outside the home; I generally respond "Homemaker." I have not been employed outside the home over the last 10 years.
education: 1979: Graduated Cum Laude, Marist College, Poughkeepsie, NY, BA American Studies; 1986-88 1.5 years of law school , University of Denver
statement: I want to serve on the commission because I was a supporter of instituting of this commission and the reapportionment commission. I was very disappointed in our legislators in being unable to work for the good of the State in performing their duty to redraw these districts following two previous censuses. I don't believe in the concept of "safe seats", as the seats in the Federal and State governments don't belong to a party or a politician; the "seats" belong to the people, and the people deserve better than what the legislatures have done by deferring their responsibility to the courts.
professional_background: As a precinct leader/captain I organized volunteers within my precincts to knock on doors, drop literature and canvas registered voters. In the Article V groups I have acted as scribe as well as assisted in editing the newsletter and in presenting the groups at local assemblies of politically active individuals.
org_list: Since 2015, I have been a member of the Colorado Committee of Correspondence (an Article V advocacy group) and have recently been affiliated with the State Legislators Article V Caucus. I am a past member of my parish's pastoral council. I am a dues-paying member of the Cherry Creek Republican Women, and occasionally attend their meetings.
analytic_skills: In my professional work I was the Director of Technical Services for an international life reinsurer. Analytical skills and the ability to apply logic and reason to solve problems or support new products were critical skills for me to possess. I utilized those skills every day through project management, coordination among interested departments, and in personnel management within projects.
consensus_statement: I can promote consensus among the commissioners because I have very good interactive listening skills. Also, I have been a registered voter in both of the major parties in my voting lifetime, even though I choose not to affiliate with either at this time. As far as being fair and impartial, I have served on a jury in the past (regrettably, not in the recent past), and understand that I have to hear all viewpoints before making a commitment to a position.
past_political_activity: I started political activity in 1978 working as an exit pollster for the very first Marist Poll. In 1979, I interned in the office of NY  State Sen Howard Nolan (Albany District). After moving to CO, I worked on several federal and state candidate campaigns, and some issue campaigns, as a volunteer, and worked as a precinct leader/captain in Denver and Arapahoe counties. I have worked as an election judge several times, the last time in 2016 as supervising judge. I even organized a candidate forum for candidates for Judicial District 18. As an engineering, I was often called upon to examine a range of factors and data points, some were fixed givens, but often I was forced to take into account conflicting perspectives or desired outcomes.  Ultimately, my teams and I were able to arrive at solutions that satisfied the majority of “stakeholders’, while still considering fixed factors such as cost, schedule, and technology.

(https://magicmomentsinc.org/) I helped raise advertising funds, advocated for special needs youth and adults while selling tickets and helped them maintain their 501c3 status.

analytic_skills: I have degrees in mathematics and statistics. I spent 30 years as a professional statistician before beginning a second career as a secondary math teacher. I approach a problem by looking for the relevant facts, understanding the facts, looking at the broader context, forming an assumption, and then checking that assumption with reality. I am able to distill complex analytical ideas into easy-to-understand lay terms. I love the field of statistics; as I told my Metro State classes--statistics is telling a story with data. It's up to the user to be informed to tell that story truthfully, and not bend the statistics to a point of view.
consensus_statement: First and foremost, I believe in listening to “the other side,” even persons with whom I may not agree.  I am a firm believer and practitioner that more voices improve the final product. Two experiences come to mind. I recently joined the non-profit “Braver Angels,” which seeks to unite “red” and “blue” in building a better tomorrow. I've taken seminars from them that are guides in listening respectfully. In addition I have practiced the scaled version of degrees of consensus many times: 5 = “I agree and will advocate for this;” 4 = “I agree with this;” 3 = “I am neither for nor against this;” 2 = “I am opposed to this;” 1 = “I am strongly opposed to this; it’s a show stopper.” Using this format allows for discussion with those who are not for an idea. When every decision-maker reaches at least a 3, the resulting measure is adopted by consensus. It works.

statement: I think that having non-gerrymandered districts is a crucial part of a working and fair representational democracy. Especially with our "first past the post" system, dominated by two political parties, allowing voters the ability to pick their representatives (and not the other way around) is critical. I strongly believe that a large contributing factor to our current political extremes is due to parties controlling redistricting, almost guaranteeing their victory, which leads to politicians having to go further and further to extremes. If districts were created with voters in mind, it would likely help to act as a moderating effect on candidates. I have read with interest the research that has been done on trying to make districts fair and representative, instead of being created to enable single party dominance.
professional_background: Since moving to Colorado in 2013, I have tried to learn as much about the state and the different populations that live here. I have worked with the Denver Silent Film Festival board to address fundraising, as well as working to help with selections of films that will be of interest to the Colorado community.
org_list: I am a volunteer with the Denver Silent Film Festival, a festival that screens silent films with live accompaniment over three days. I update the organizations website and Facebook page, as well as assisting during the running of the actual festival.
analytic_skills: I like to gather as much information as I can about a topic/problem, and carefully weigh pros and cons. In my job, I often come across systems/processes that have been in place for decades; I like to understand the underlying reason for them, in order to ascertain whether they are still needed, need to be modified, or need to be left alone to complete the business process.
consensus_statement: Although I stand up for what I believe in, I recognize the importance of treating people with respect and consideration. In my jobs I have had to work with people strongly adverse to change, and in some cases openly hostile. I have learned techniques to help calm people down, and re-engage so that progress can be made. It's not about "who wins," it's about ensuring that the best possible outcome for people and their organizations are met. I try strenuously to avoid people feeling left out of decisions and the build process.

statement: I have become increasingly interested in the political climate in Colorado for quite a few years. I believe that I have a unique perspective because I understand the fine balance between a system that offers a safety net for those in need while being responsible and fair with taxpayer dollars. I strongly believe that creating a system that allows marginalized communities to have a say in the laws that govern them and legislators who represent them strengths civic involvement and the fabric of our democracy.
professional_background: My primary involvement in advocating for youth in our state is through my profession. As a teacher, I have had the opportunity to make a direct impact in the lives of my students while learning to meet the unique needs of different families and demographics. In my 10+ years of teaching, I have been a huge advocate for my students by encouraging them to pursue trades or higher education and by writing letters of recommendation for scholarships. I was volunteer youth basketball coach for 5+ plus years before the pandemic. Through coaching, I was able to connect with kids in my community and encourage them to make healthy choices and stay active. Additionally, my family makes yearly contributions to the Ronald McDonald House, Children's Hospital, or Lutheran Family Services.
org_list: none
analytic_skills: I am practiced in understanding that in order to solve complex problems it is necessary to utilize critical thinking skills that considers the view of all stake holders. I feel that in many ways, I have developed the ability to consider that oftentimes, conflict is born out of the inability to differentiate between subjective and objective realities. I think that every person that is involved in public service should have the ability to remove the emotion from charged topics and consider the wellbeing and needs of others. The current climate has become so charged and intolerant, being able to consider different perspectives is in short supply. I value the freedom to choose the morals and values that guide my life and believe that it is important that I honor others freedom to do the same. One of my primary strengths is the ability to approach complex issues with creative problem solving and critical thinking while considering the needs of all the stakeholders.
consensus_statement: I have experience working in groups for a common cause. From working on fundraising campaigns for my children's school or working with administrators and other educators on developing value and mission statements for the program that I work for, I have had success working to build consensus and meet goals. I enjoy the process of debating and discussing topics, listening to multiple points of view, and working towards positive outcomes. I am very invested in groups or commissions that I have joined and regularly go the extra mile to help the whole group succeed. I am passionate about making a difference in my community and State and ensure that every Colorado resident has the opportunity to pursue a life where they and their families thrive.
