BA Political Science, University of Colorado at Boulder
Masters of Public Administration, University of Colorado, Denver
Certificate of Eligibility, Alternative Teacher License
statement: I am interested in the exercise of redistricting because I am passionate about preserving our election system and ensuring a government by and for all the people.  I think this commission would provide a fascinating opportunity to learn more about the districts in Colorado, and the process of mapping those districts. I also know this would be a very rewarding experience to know that I contributed to a worthy effort.   I would be gratified to participate in ensuring that the criteria for drawing the congressional district maps for the state of Colorado were met;  making sure these maps accurately and fairly represent the communities that exist.
professional_background:
I have been active in the Boulder community since returning to Colorado in 1988, after serving in the US Navy.  In each of my professional positions, I was responsible for organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering the interests of communities. I worked in the public sector for nearly 30 years, and then for the nonprofit organization, "I Have a Dream" Foundation of Boulder County for 10 years, where my work contributed toward ending the cycle of poverty through education and youth/family empowerment.  I have been a liaison and partner with numerous organizations throughout Boulder County and sometimes with state and federal partners, helped support youth participation in and organization of community events, and participated in city and school district task forces.  The following are a few examples.  
 
At the University of Colorado, I implemented a new program to promote graduate level work by students underrepresented at the graduate level, and coordinated the efforts of faculty committees in grant awards for their peers.  For the city of Boulder, I provided the staff leadership for a task force of members of the development community advising the city on a new development review and structure of fees for services.  For BVSD, I organized activities and advocated for students with special needs, and for "I Have a Dream" I was able to practice all these skills as I coordinated with more than 100 community partners to match resources with children and families.  In addition, I served on a preschool advisory board, many parent committees, and have volunteered, on numerous occasions, in ways that promote and celebrate diversity.
org_list: "I Have a Dream" Foundation of Boulder County, Dream Big Task Force, Casa de Paz Colorado, City of Boulder task force to consider redevelopment of Washington Elementary School site, BVSD committee for renovation of Casey Middle School, and Boulder’s Community Foundation.  More recently, I have participated in the Forever Indivisible community action group to learn about local and national issues, hear from representatives, and take action in my areas of interest.  I am both a volunteer and a sponsor (financial contributor) for the  "I Have a Dream" Foundation of Boulder County, and a contributor and volunteer with Casa de Paz - assisting newly released detainees, from the ICE center in Aurora, reunite with their families.  The Dream Big Task Force was a collective effort among government and nonprofit agencies to examine opportunities to provide educational and mentoring resources to more of the students living in poverty in Boulder County.
analytic_skills: My education and professional experience were in these exact areas.  I practiced research and analytical skills in school and early in my career.  I was an analyst for the city of Boulder where I lead projects to improve systems within the city's operations.  Throughout my career, I worked to build consensus and to draw upon the strengths and expertise of all involved, recognizing that the best outcomes are always the result of teamwork, respect, and diversity. Again, my entire career was spent analyzing systems, designing and managing projects, and providing leadership that ensured the meaningful participation of all stakeholders.
consensus_statement: I have extensive experience, both professional and personal, in team-building and promoting consensus.  In fact, I am sure that the best outcomes can only result from creating agreement from diverse perspectives.  I also am a person who actually likes meetings, and the process of building consensus as we learn from one another. I will promote consensus and agreement because that is the only way to create and maintain systems that protect our democracy.  I see the commission as an opportunity to participate in the continuous improvement of our democracy and efforts to build impartial and fair representation for everyone in Colorado.
past_political_activity: I have participated in civic engagement activities, and a few political party sponsored events, throughout my life, but not extensively.  For the last few years, I have participated in organized politics via the Forever Indivisible group in Boulder.  I have donated to political campaigns to elect Joe Neguse, Andrew Romanoff, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, and maybe a few other candidates.  I also contribute to the efforts of the ACLU, and Sierra Club.

I have long advocated for innovation and equity in education, first as a kindergarten teacher and leadership instructor for underfunded and refugee populations of students in Denver; then as an innovation assistant at CU, working to democratize education through the use of free online courseware; and now as the founder and editor of Homegrown, a community and newsletter dedicated to helping parents navigate education during COVID-19.

Additionally, my experience as a student of cognitive science and behavioral economics leaves me well versed in the psychology of logical and statistical analysis. I know the common mistakes people tend to make when working with large numbers and complex problems. I believe that all of this positions me not only to think clearly and evenhandedly, but also to help my fellow commissioners do the same, without judgement or animosity.
consensus_statement: My experience as a student, tutor, and teacher across disciplines, as well as my science-communication focused entrepreneurship, prepare me to discuss complex concepts/issues in a way that is practically relevant and comprehensible to those without the same background. Likewise, my relative lack of partisan affiliation, as well as my commitment to listening and open, "steel man" style debate, prepare me to serve the commission thoughtfully without a partisan agenda.

analytic_skills: Whenever there is a problem I look for logical conclusions.  Then with help rule out each until we come to a workable solution.  Case in point.  A friend of mine had a fountain that had to be cleaned and we had to reset the pump.  The upper portion of the fountain weighted around 300 pounds.  Easy solution get 4 big guys to lift the upper portion of the fountain, but this was not an option.  We thought about lifting it ourselves, too much weight for two 60+ people.  Build a A Frame and lift the upper portion, too much construction and possibility it would not work.  My solution was to build a temporary table the height of the lower section of the fountain, then tip the upper portion onto the table and roll it onto the table.  We could then make the repairs and adjustments and reset the upper portion without ever having to lift it.  The solution worked.
consensus_statement: I will work to promote understanding among my fellow community members.  Politics tends to be putting blame on the other party for what is wrong in the state.  It is like the old game of "King of the Hill", whomever beats the others to get to the top, wins.

statement: I am a fervent believer in voting fairness.  In recent years, it seems that partisan interests in many parts of the country have developed a win-at-all-costs mentality rather than focusing on doing the right thing for the voting public.  I know that the CO redistricting commission will have a practical, significant, and long-lasting impact on ensuring that each Coloradan’s vote counts in a meaningful way, and I deeply wish to have a role in that process.  I am convinced that serving on this commission is the most consequential way I can make a difference for fair voting in our state.  Construction of districts to match the statewide electoral balance supports the idea of “one person - one vote,” and creating competitive districts makes our elected representatives more responsive to the wishes of the entire electorate and discourages hyperpartisanship.
professional_background: I focus on concrete, hands-on, data-driven efforts to help further causes that I believe in.  For example, for several years I have led a team that has collected breeding bird data at a Critical Wildlife Habitat in Boulder County.  I analyze and present this data to Town and County staff, boards, and commissions to help inform decisions about management and development around this area.  Recently, this effort significantly contributed to a new water management strategy that meets the needs of both wildlife and downstream irrigation users.

analytic_skills: After several years as a practicing theoretical physicist, and a subsequent career as a cyberinfrastructure expert, I feel that numeracy, logical thinking, and data-based analysis are a part of my very being!  I am comfortable using a number of software packages for data analysis and modeling, and have even created several of these programs myself.
consensus_statement: Even though I am a “Front Range liberal,” I grew up in a deeply conservative area and my family has been supported by agriculture and timber for several generations.  This background helps give me an empathetic perspective on the economic and political perspectives of people from other parts of the state.  In another context, an important part of my last job was to design a supercomputer that had a fixed budget and had to meet the needs of a wide variety of researchers.  I interviewed dozens of faculty from numerous departments across several universities and contributed to a final design that took all of their requirements into account.  I then led the development of a scheduling system that ensured fair access for all of these users.  Not everyone got everything they wanted, but they all appreciated that their interests were taken into account so thoroughly.

Being able to be another perspective in the room is important when decisions are being made that can change a group of peoples way of life even if it means just by the district.
professional_background: Being apart of the House of Representative's has allowed me to gain more outreach skill an the ability to manage and guide diverse groups of people. analytic_skills: While serving as a legislative aide I have been able to help the constituents of my Representative get the resources during the covid crisis and also in order to enact change in their communities. Being able to deduct the needs of other or their line of reasoning is used daily while in my current profession. But being able to leave everyone feeling acknowledged and helped is where logic is applied especially as I handled the cases of unemployment for constituents. In times of peril it was the best to use facts as my base to guide individuals through a complex issue such an the unemployment limbo that most of the public had gone through. It was also a guiding principle to never make false promises or prognostications about what their outcome may be. Problems of all types are best solved or a conclusion is made when facts are used to ensure that options are available to the public. If a enough solutions are provided the best one for any given circumstance is reviled through civil debate.
consensus_statement: I belief strongly that all the people in our state need to be represented fairly and equally. That means that every district in our state is the most logical and representation of the people of Colorado. I'm a consensus builder that is strongly against gerrymandering in any form in our country or our state. I would be delighted to be part of this process to ensure the commissioners create districts that represent the ideological make up of our state. Which in my opinion means that our redistricting should reflect the fact that our state is not largely republican or democratic, but closer to a 50/50 split over the long-term. It would be an injustice to all if our redistricting would cause large disparities between the actual make up of how our state votes and the representation in the House of Representatives. First and foremost I will focus on the realization of my statement above. I will try to convince all commissioners of the need for a fair redistricting process so that all Coloradans are equally represented.
past_political_activity: My only political activity has been as of recently  working with the House of Representatives for the democrats in the Colorado State House. I have not donated money to any campaign or political organizations.

professional_background:
The best recent example would be the 13 years that I spent as an irrigation canal representative on the Rio Grande Water Conservation District Sub District #1 Board, who was charged with developing a water plan that will reduce pumping and revive a rapidly declining aquifer that is the lifeblood of the San Luis Valley.  We had nearly endless meetings and public hearings and would listen to concerns and suggestions on how to attempt to meet our goal.  After developing a compromise plan that was approved by several  entities including the State Engineer and Water Court we are currently working towards our goal. With the current drought and increase efforts from outside our river basin to export water this issue of underground water is still a huge one.
The County Planning Commission is also a board that has to deal with sometimes very contentious views concerning the growth and development of the community.  As a commission member I always listened and try to do what seemed to be best for the entire community.  I also served ten years on the local school board.

statement: I want to serve on the committee because I want to offer my experiences working with a diverse group of Coloradans  to ensure their voices are at the table as well. As a naturalized citizen, I was so excited to vote and be engaged in our democracy when I became a citizen and this process is incredibly important to making sure we have congressional districts that represent ALL Coloradans.
professional_background: I am an incredibly values driven person and I've made it my goal to serve the people of Colorado in the best way possible because this state has given me so much. I am an immigrant to this state from Mexico. I came to this country when I was 2 and grew up in Fort Morgan till the age of 12 and then moved to Greeley Colorado. As the first of my family to graduate from high school and college, I've been incredibly passionate about educational equity and immigrant rights. That has led me to have had a career in organizing and advocating with and on behalf of the most vulnerable in our communities and also for more equitable policies that will give every person in Colorado, regardless of where they come from, a fighting chance to achieve their own American Dream.  That is what drove my parents and that is what drives me. I've worked with Stand for Children Colorado as an organizer to fight more more equitable educational policies. I've worked with Together Colorado to push for human dignity to be at the forefront of every policy conversation. I've worked with Colorado Peoples Alliance that strives for equity when it comes to climate justice, economic justice, immigrant rights, etc. I've worked with Leadership for Educational Equity to advocate for more equitable education policies alongside teachers in Denver. I'm currently working at Lyra Colorado to elevate the voices of parents, teachers and students regarding educational equity. I also helped found the Padres y Jovenes Unidos Action Fund so that people of color could have a vehicle by which they could endorse and advocate for elected.

An example of my ability to be fair and impartial relates to my time starting the Padres y Jovenes Unidos Action Fund. As a board member, I had no voting rights as to who we would end up endorsing and when they time came for our members to endorse candidates, I disagreed with who they ended up endorsing. I respected their involvement in our board and valued it greatly, beyond what my own beliefs were because that's how it should be.

statement:
I love solving big difficult problems. During my time at CDC, I was routinely called upon for special assignments – establishing high-profile programs, leading rapid decision-making units during pandemics, rescuing and rehabilitating programs decimated by political budget cuts.  After retirement, I committed to myself that I would use those skills and that passion to help find solutions in my own community and state, rather than just at the Federal government level.  

I have long been interested in Congressional processes. During my time at CDC, I had the privilege to meet regularly with members of Congress and their staffs to educate them about our programs and answer their questions.  I love the idea of democratic representation and finding ways to make that representation really work.  Spending the bulk of my career living in a state that was heavily gerrymandered (Georgia) was exceptionally frustrating and something I vowed to take seriously when I was free of the Hatch Act restrictions I was placed under as a Federal uniformed services officer.  

When I retired and moved to Colorado in 2016, I knew I was moving to a state with many fewer Congressional districts, and that the population size and distribution was the largest determinant of how those districts are structured. The degrees of freedom for creating districts are extremely limited because of this. But the issues facing voters in CO-3 – one of the largest geographical districts in the nation with a relatively small population – must be considered and forcefully advocated for during the redistricting analysis and decision-making.  I want to represent that perspective while also recognizing that the commission must make the best decisions for the good of the entire state.  I want to apply my analytic, strategic, and negotiation skills to this big, difficult challenge to help the commission succeed in its work.
professional_background:
Upon moving to Colorado, I became an active member of 4 volunteer music organizations – the Cowboy Corral, Symphony in the Valley, the Aspen Choral Society, and High Country Sinfonia. In each, my goal was to serve as an outstanding musical contributor. With Aspen Choral Society and High Country Sinfonia, I quickly became more deeply involved in the organizational and business aspects through appointments to the Boards of Directors.

I joined the Board of the Aspen Choral Society at a time when many important organizational changes were occurring. I quickly recognized that the Board would benefit from having the bylaws updated and a more aggressive public relations and fundraising posture.  I led the revision of the bylaws, facilitated the entire board in reviewing and discussing options for important changes, identified a volunteer to serve as our general counsel for review and advice, and assisted the Board President with socializing and approving the new bylaws among the full board. I also worked closely with a public relations contractor to develop press releases and a more active social media presence. Behind the scenes, I provide guidance to the Board President based on my previous experience and training as a member of a board for a large national organization. 

High Country Sinfonia appointed me to their Board in 2020 to assist with their efforts to become a registered non-profit organization in the state of Colorado. That work is ongoing and draws from my experience developing the bylaws and procedures for Aspen Choral Society.

My approach to organizing, representing, and advocating for both organizations is to serve the three “duties” of a board member – duty of care, duty of loyalty, and duty of obedience. My aim is to improve their business operations through careful shifts in policy and activity, while honoring the long local traditions of each organization and the deep relationships among and between the long-standing members, board members, and the community members who are our donors and audiences.

A second way I actively consider the interests of Colorado organizations is my professional consulting work in public health and strategic planning. I have worked with several governmental organizations or associated entities within Pitkin County including the Board of County Commissioners, the Department of Public Health, the Aspen Pitkin County Housing Authority, and the Pitkin County Elected Officials Transportation Committee (including the Pitkin BoCC, the Aspen City Council, and the Snowmass Village Town Council). In each engagement, I have strived to build rapport, guide the group to a strategic solution, and identify and resolve areas of disagreement all while adhering to the parameters provided by the sponsor/client.  This work has given me deep insight into the political structures, realities, and foibles of the government entities within one county and, critically, how those entities relate to their neighboring counties of the Roaring Fork Valley.

analytic_skills: Medical and public health academic work and applied General Preventive Medicine and Public Health medical residency training all focus on analytic skills. I have an extensive background in conducting analytic studies documented by my publication record (see CV).  As a supervisor and manager, I was also responsible for reviewing and approving analytic studies using numerous statistical data sets (including census data).  In approaching problems of all kinds, I first look to the available data, seek other sources of information, and apply the strategic negotiation and planning skills described above to best analyze, generate options, and solve a problem.
consensus_statement:
In my facilitation and strategic planning work, I use several techniques to promote consensus.  Chief among these is to ask questions to make sure I fully understand the perspective and contribution of the group members. I also make sure that I carefully draw out both the explicit and implicit criteria people are using to make decisions so that I can find areas where negotiation is possible.  I always try to understand my own and others’ self-interests.

I also work to reframe conflicts – what is it we already agree on?  How can we use those points of agreement to find solutions to meet the enlarged interests of the group – in this case the entire state?  When disagreement continues it is usually because the “right” solution has yet to be found. Being creative and drawing on the entire group’s creativity is key. And finally, I aim to always articulate how the group came to its recommendation or solution and what the criteria were. This contributes directly to communications that generate buy-in among stakeholders and so that each member of the commission can faithfully and enthusiastically promote the results of the work.

My training as a scientist, manager and leader and my experience in the highly politicized environment of Federal public health instilled in me the need for fairness and impartiality. One cannot lead a team without being fair. Serving as the steward of a Federal budget requires one to be impartial.  Federal procurement rules build fairness and impartiality directly into the systems within which I was trained. It is my instinct – through disposition and training – to make decisions based on facts, after considering the pros and cons of all the options, while making the decision criteria explicit, and with a deep understanding of how all stakeholders will feel about the decision.

Finally, the most important aspect of promoting consensus and contributing to a fair, impartial and agreeable process is getting to know and appreciate the perspectives of my fellow commissioners. Learning about each other – including who we are and what we value – will be key to the commission’s success.
past_political_activity:
During a 25-year career as a Federal uniformed services medical officer (1991-2016), my political activity was limited due to Hatch Act restrictions.  Following my retirement (September 1, 2016), I participated in house-to-house canvassing during the 2016 general election.  During the 2018 election, I did a small amount of letter writing for the Diane Mitsch Bush campaign (CO-3).  

During 2020, I have participated in the Eagle County Democratic Caucus and as a district/state delegate in March, served as an Eagle County citizen election judge during the June primary, and briefly volunteered for and participated in one meeting of the Eagle County Democrats this summer. Because of ongoing public health consulting work related to the pandemic, I have not been able to continue my volunteer activities at this time. As I wind down these consulting activities, I plan to serve as a citizen election judge again for the general election in November. 

My husband and I jointly made small ($10-25) donations to the Hillary Clinton campaign (2016), the National Democratic Party (2018), and the 2018 and 2020 Diane Mitch Bush (CO-3) campaigns.

statement: I believe partisan gerrymandering has truly hurt democracy in or country. Instead of creating true communities of interest, redistricting has been coopted by interests that seek to protect incumbents and maximize partisan advantage. Politically competitive districts, while not possible in every interest, promote a less polarized Congress and present more opportunities for collaborative policymaking.

When I try to persuade people (colleagues, stakeholders, policymakers, etc.) I likewise root my arguments in reason rather than appealing to emotion. That is when I am most successful.
consensus_statement: I served on the state's Reapportionment Commission in 2001, working on drawing lines for the state's 100 house and senate districts. I worked hard to build consensus maps that respected communities of interest while promoting competitive districts across the state. While we did have our share of disagreements, at the end of the process we had a plan that worked and that the participants in the process were proud of. I also worked hard to try to build consensus around a new Congressional District map (at that time, crafted by the legislature). While we came close, partisan interests prevailed and litigation ensued, resulting in a map drawn by a federal court judge. I was also in the Senate when Republican leadership attempted to re-draw the map "out of cycle" when they controlled both houses of the legislature. That was a low mark of my legislative career when I was unable to convince my Republican friends of the danger to the institution their midnight gerrymander represented.

occupation: Decision scientist working at Colorado State University
education:
PhD in Decision Science and Information Systems, University of Arizona
BS in Mechanical Engineering, MIT
statement: I think, like many Coloradans, I have become concerned about the polarization of political discourse in our country.  I became interested in the redistricting process after stumbling across a monograph by Professor Robert Loevy who participated in the 2010 effort in Colorado.  That spurred me to read "RatF**ked" by David Daley.  Clearly, redistricting is a complex process involving multiple competing priorities.  That type of problem is one with which I have a great deal of expertise.  I have specialized expertise in data analysis and the design decision support systems.  My research is focused on problems involving temporal and geo-spatial uncertainty.  I believe I have a lot to offer the Colorado redistricting effort: I have the time, the interest, and the expertise.  I think I also have the right demeanor  -- I am an idealist but not a zealot.  When facing conflict, I seek out a solution having the most good for the most stakeholders.  In summary, I want to serve because I think I can add value to the process, and because I believe that a successful redistricting process in Colorado might serve as a positive model for our country.
professional_background: As a faculty member at CSU, I deliberately avoided participation in special interest groups.  I believe that by maintaining neutrality on political and social issues, I fostered an atmosphere with my students that promoted free exchange and critical thinking.  So rather than directing my energies to causes that I admire, I have directed my service directly to my students.  For example, using my uncompensated personal time to coach students for international competitions.
org_list: I have served as an officer in each of the HOAs of which I have been a member for the last 20 years, most recently as the President of the Miner's Lake HOA.
analytic_skills: I am a decision scientist by training.  I have spent more than 30 years conducting research into decision scenarios that are characterized by high stakes, time pressure, and uncertainty.  My earlier work involved the study of decision making in teams and small groups, and so I am an expert in processes used to form consensus in heterogeneous groups.  More recently, I have been investigating biases in judgment and perception related to geo-spatial reasoning -- for example, estimating the location of landfall for a hurricane, or the best location to search for an aircraft lost at sea.  The process of redistricting involves many of these same geo-spatial biases.  My research has been funded by several federal agencies, most notably the Office of Naval Research.  I am especially skilled at transforming the findings of my research into practical guidance for sailors and Marines.  I look forward to bringing these same capabilities to bear on the Colorado redistricting effort on behalf of all the citizens of our state.
consensus_statement: I think the key to resolving conflict will be to discover the shared values among the stakeholders.  This requires the ability to listen and have empathy.  Those are skills I possess.  Not all values are shared, and in that case, it is important to understand the relative importance of the goals for each stakeholder.  The process of promoting consensus involves finding ways to promote the shared values while also trading-off on the relatively less-important unshared values.  I have a lot of experience with this sort of small-group decision process via many years of faculty meetings and neighborhood meetings.  Obviously, the stakes in those examples are much lower, but the process is the same: how do you reach agreement without creating animosity among people you work with or live near?  In the case of redistricting, I think I am aided because I don't identify with any political party, so I don't view the process through the lens of winning and losing.  Rather I think I can be fair and impartial while working towards the shared goal of finding the best district boundaries that achieve the priorities of the Reapportionment Amendment and the Hobbs decision.
past_political_activity: I have donated to Amy McGrath in her campaign against Mitch McConnell for the US Senate in Kentucky.  I donated to Pete Buttigieg during the 2020 presidential primaries.  I'm not sure if this counts as "political," but my wife and I donated to the ACLU to help them support the children who were separated from their parents while seeking asylum.

statement: I want to serve on the commission to ensure that Colorado’s districts represent the diversity of our state and that each Colorado citizen has equal representation. My experience working in the public and private sector, as well as my lengthy volunteer experience, ensures that I am uniquely qualified for the role. Voices from all communities, groups of people and walks of life should be represented in each district. I believe strongly in our democracy and the promise it holds for all citizens. Each of us has a voice in selecting who leads us and what policies are put forth. The right to vote and involvement in the political process are central to the success of our democracy and I’ve held both in high regard my entire life. I’m excited about the potential opportunity to work collaboratively with other commissioners to ensure fair elections over the next decade.
professional_background: I have extensive volunteer experience working with and on behalf of low-income people in Colorado. I also have a passion for women's equality and much of my volunteer work is focused on improving the lives of women. I serve on the City of Fort Collins Community Development Block Grant Commission, which works to improve the physical, economic and social conditions of low-income people in Fort Collins. I also serve on the Board of Directors for the Junior League of Fort Collins, a nonprofit that helps women and children in Northern Colorado through a career clothing boutique, food security program and volunteer hours. Additionally, I’ve spent nearly a decade on the Board of Directors for the Center for Work, Education and Employment in Denver, which serves low-income parents as they prepare for and find a career.

I have extensive experience working in a collaborative environment and building relationships with individuals and stakeholder groups, many with opinions different from my own. I am honest and straightforward in my conversations and value the trust that develops when a relationship is formed through mutual respect. I am empathetic and an excellent listener and in all settings, work to ensure that all voices are heard. 

When I led the CEO Search Committee for the Center for Work, Education and Employment (CWEE), we made sure that the committee included a staff representative. We also made sure to hold multiple meetings with staff to gather their input and thoughts about the type of person who should lead the organization. Beyond staff involvement, we also reached out to CWEE’s participants, the low-income career seekers who were part of the program at the time, and asked for their opinion about what CWEE needed and what questions we should ask candidates. We ended up incorporating a couple questions from the participants into the interview process, which was made much richer from the involvement of diverse voices.

statement: Honestly, it would have not been something I’d have even known about had Facebook not decided to advertise it to me, but I’ve been anxious to become involved in service of some kind for sometime; so when I read about the need for commissioners, I thought to myself, “I could do that. And I could do it in a way that is thoughtful and right. I’m political, but not overly so. I have time. I have concern that people be treated with fairness and have a great dislike for the gerrymandering that was at times so blatant in my growing up years in Texas. Maybe I’m naive to think it’s possible for politics to change from the acrid, acrimonious climate it’s slid into if decent people who respect the humanity of their neighbors irrespective of differences will take the time to step out and serve, but here I am in all my middle-aged optimism putting myself forward as a candidate to make a difference.
professional_background: I don’t have any experience with any of these things in Colorado.
org_list: I’ve been a church member, though I have not yet moved my membership to the church where we attend here in Arvada, Arvada Covenant Church. I’ve been a member of the Three Creeks K-8 PTO, but not a very active one.
analytic_skills: I enjoy writing, so gathering relevant information, reading it, interpreting it, analyzing it, and synthesizing it into a product which others can then read to glean information or be entertained is completely in my wheel house. In my poems and writing, I provide social commentary on ordinary life experiences which I see as sacred. The art of writing is thoroughly couched in analytical skills, logic and reasoning and problem solving. As a commissioner, I’d be highly adept at gathering relevant information to consider and insure fair lines are drawn in redistricting.
consensus_statement: As a middle child, peacemaking is in my bones. As a parent of four children ages 13, 11, 9, and 7, it’s not just in my bones, it’s in my daily repertoire. Having a background in education, ministerial training, and senior adult concerns, I have interacted with broad swaths of diverse people groups whose needs and rights weigh heavily upon me. As a student of the humanities, critical thinking requiring an ability to consider opposing viewpoints and live with the tension of occasional cognitive dissonance is part and parcel to the demands of study. I’m well qualified to consider multiple opinions and be gentle and firm in working toward consensus to the greater good.
past_political_activity: I have never donated to a political campaign.

While "communities of like interests" are important, so are competitive districts where practical. I'd like to be part of a system that puts forth "fair" districts rather than politically-stacked ones.
professional_background: As noted above, I served as a Planning Commissioner. As an Optimist, for about 18 years I have been a co-director and head of a loose planning committee for Optimist Brain Bowls, academic contests for 6th, 7th, and 8th graders. Expanding from one annual to four annual contests over the years, the larger two Brain Bowls involved almost 500 students in generally five-person teams, with about 100 coaches, more than 150 volunteers, and spectators, comprising more that 1000 people at a Saturday event in various high schools.
org_list: Since 2015, my only organization is in Optimists, the Sunrise Optimist Club of Lakewood. I am a registered Professional Engineer, nearing retired status. From 2004 to 2010, I served as an appointed Lakewood Planning Commissioner.
analytic_skills: I am a civil engineer so I have done a modest amount of computer modeling, for hydraulics and hydrology. As an engineer I have had to think logically. Engineers are problem solvers essentially by definition. Which occasionally includes "thinking outside the box." We take data and situations and determine solutions.
consensus_statement: As an engineer and a former Planning Commissioner, I am reasonably good with data and facts, explaining them, considering them, discussing them, sometimes advocating  for positions, and evaluating possible impacts. Planning Commissioner ethics , in particular, call for fairness and impartiality, and I believe I was a good, ethical commissioner.
past_political_activity: I was previously a House District Chair, for 2 or 3 cycles, for HD 26, now HD 28. About 2003 to 2010. Numerous small, $100 or less, donations to Democratic candidates.

occupation: Senior Program Officer at Gates Family Foundation
education: Bachelor degree in Sociology, University of Puget Sound; Master degree in Public Administration; UC Denver; Certificate in Education Finance, Georgetown University
statement: I am extremely interested in developing fair and impartial systems and structures that allow our government to best represent and serve all Coloradans. I am encouraged by Colorado voters' pioneering decision to adopt independent redistricting committees. It would be an honor to support this work.

analytic_skills: I have experience utilizing GIS mapping systems to analyze demographic data and changes over time. I have conducted quantitative and qualitative analyses in the public health and education fields. I often visualize data in my work, and have experience presenting data to diverse audiences in formats that are dynamic and clear.
consensus_statement: I believe in utilizing data to inform decision-making, and also in the importance of mutual respect, establishing good rapport, and asking tough questions. I truly believe that a committee structure for decision-making often produces the best outcomes, and have developed initiatives that rely on decision-making by consensus among diverse groups to determine grant awards. The Education Innovation Fund, an initiative I designed and led at Gates to support COVID-19 relief in K-12, involved a review process by a 11-member selection committee where I served as both the facilitator of the group and a selection committee member. The EIF granted $320,000 in awards to 34 efforts across the state. A total of 326 applicants applied to the fund, requesting more than $5 million in grants. Decisions were made by consensus among members from six philanthropic institutions and two nonprofits. I also serve as a strategic advisor to the Governor's Office to support the RISE Education Fund selection committee to award $32.7 million in funding for innovative responses to COVID-19. For these efforts, I have utilized data dashboards and mapping tools to ensure all decision-makers share the same baseline information. This shared understanding is often the basis for creating agreement among groups.
past_political_activity: I have not donated to any political campaigns since November 2015.

Many outsiders are driving the direction this state is going and it doesn't align with the morals and values with which l grew up knowing. org_list: None

occupation: Deputy Director, Upper Colorado Endangered Fish Recovery Program, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
education: I have a Master's in Public Administration and a Master's of Forestry. I have a Bachelor's degree in Geography and Environmental Science with a Minor in Business
statement: I believe drawing redistricting lines in a fair and impartial manner is one of the most effective ways to ensure that we all get a vote that matters.
professional_background: I have recently testified before the Colorado State Legislature to promote increases in fees for Colorado Parks and Wildlife. In addition, I have testified several times in front of the Wildlife Commission in support of hunting and trapping.
org_list: I have spent a lot of time volunteering in my children's school but I am not officially a member of any organizations at the moment.
analytic_skills: I have a long history of compiling and using data to assist decision makers in making rational decisions. I am extremely logical and always begin with the end in mind, and work through issues in a sequential manner until a logical conclusion is reached. I am often asked for advice specifically because I can cut through emotions and personal feelings to find the underlying problem.
consensus_statement: In my current role, I spend the majority of my time managing groups of people towards consensus. Our organization consists of individuals from 10 independent organizations who come together to create science-based policy that affects how resources are deployed in the upper Colorado River basin. Each stakeholder comes to the table with their own ideas and their own priorities, which all must be considered in the final decision. It is rare that all parties get exactly what they are seeking in the result, but very commonly, everyone gets 80% of what they were looking for. Most importantly, all members walk away from the table as partners, fully willing to engage in discussions on the next important topic. During each of these discussions, there is always an important viewpoint to consider from each of the partners, and commonly they are closer to each other than they realize. I find it is my job to dig in to those viewpoints and find the common ground to help the partnership move forward. I like to think that I am fair and impartial - though I imagine most do. In seeking fairness, I often try to get past what people are saying to the fundamental truth that is driving them to say what they are saying. It is often there that we can find more collective understanding than in what is said initially.
past_political_activity: I have donated small amounts ($150 or less) to a variety of campaigns and organizations, including MoveOn, Giffords PAC, Joe Biden's campaign, Andrew Romanoff, Organizing for Action, Bernie Sanders, Cary Kennedy, American's for Responsible Gun Ownership, Jon Ossoff. In looking at these donations, they must appear to be incredibly "blue". One of the things I struggle with most is the partisan nature of our current political climate.  During these recent years in particular, I have been really struggling to find science and fact in the political discourse which has been affecting where I choose to give.

consensus_statement: As an attorney for 43 yrs., licensed in Michigan, Colorado and several Federal Courts, I represented individuals in Product Liability and criminal matters. These litigation matters were involved Mediation and settlement, as well as actual trialsIn addition, I was a Mediator in scores of civil cases in Michigan for nearly 20 years. I was also a Hearing Officer for the Michigan Civil Rights Commissioner. I also served as a State Court Judge for ten years ( County Court Judge-4th Judicial District - 2007-2016). This experience has equipped me to be both an advocate and to facilitate a just resolution.

occupation: US Transportation Manager for Reliance Oilfield Services, LLC
education: High School Diploma with some college course work many year ago.  Certified Director of Safety (CDS) through North American Transportation Management Institute (NATMI)
statement: I don't agree with gerrymandering districts for either party and would like to see the districts as fairly balanced as possible.  I would like to see senate and congressional representatives be term limited and I believe that fairly balanced districts can at least limit "safe" districts for any party, allowing for the possibility of more citizens participating in the process.
professional_background: I have not been engaged in community activities in the past and would like to start getting involved in the civic process.
org_list: The only organization I belong to is North American Transportation Institute
analytic_skills: For a local beverage company I was part of a team that met monthly to analyze sales trends to understand production needs for the next several weeks as well as dissecting P&L's to control costs.  My current job is working with DOT compliance for an oilfield company, teaching regulatory compliance to employees that only fall under regulations a portion of the time.  Helping individuals understand why, how and when regulations apply and how they can be compliant is a constant challenge that motivates me.
consensus_statement: As a manager of people for the past 17 years I have relied on transparency and honesty in all decisions I have had to make.  Understanding that there are no absolutes in life and presenting my ideas with integrity, honesty and transparency I have the ability to find common ground and concensus when working when searching for solutions.
past_political_activity: I have donated to the President in this election, for the first time.  I have also donated this cycle to the senatorial campaign for Cory Gardner and recently began donating to the New Journey PAC for black conservatives.

occupation: Self employed. Cabinet maker.
education: Associate of Science, Electronics. Various training in IT work (networking, OS, computer system repair). CCNA certificate at CCA.  Certificate related to wood working at Red Rock CC.
statement: I believe that redistricting is a much understood & appreciated process. Too often it is not organized to serve an economic & social community, usually geographic in nature. This is a fresh opportunity to organize a new process: that process will be (good or bad -- hopefully overwhelming fair) the basis for the next group -- 10 years from now. It is important to create a fundamental process that can be built upon. In any case, the following 10 years of elections will depend on it being more fair than the past to the Citizens of Colorado.
professional_background: Advocate for Colorado gun rights, attended Legislature meetings. Supporter of, and involved as a leader in 4H, Boy Scouts. Involved in the committee to develop 2nd language standards for Douglas County when the State required all school districts to create them.
org_list: 4H (Cherry Valley Aggies), Ben Lomond Gun Club.
analytic_skills: My past career & education was overwhelmingly in science and technology. Starting in electronics, communications/rf, systems engineer & repair, leading to networking, and computer repair. In all cases solutions to problems had to fit the conditions -- you can't fake data to solve a problem. Research often solved problems (similar problems, or seemingly similar problems often lead to accurate answers). Sometimes you found out that you didn't have enough information; I couldn't be afraid to ask for additional resources when potential solutions didn't work, or results didn't meet expectations. In other words, sometimes you have to start over, as the apparent scope of the problem didn't fit the results. It happened occasionally -- let your customer know that a problem remained unresolved and add additional resources to the data gathering (where often information about prior work changed the resulting efforts). As well as add additional 3rd party technical expertise (more finite analysis of the symptoms). With my business it isn't much different. If a customer wants some work done I am not particularly familiar with, I research the request: process, materials, tooling, time required, ability to master the techniques in a timely matter; will it be financially worth it to do the work (do I expect to do it again, not make as much margin; will the first customer be willing to pay enough to do the work, etc). If it's a small enough part of a job, do I take a loss for the work in the rest of the project? Do I know someone better suited for the work? Do I want to do the work?
consensus_statement: Most of my life I have been in repair in one field or another, the past few years in a new career field running my own business. In all cases this has meant learning, researching, brainstorming, and creating processes. Almost always on a team (at least for significant issues). Considering a large list of inputs, then whittling them down by the conditions to the best or most likely results. Everyone wants to contribute -- it's voluntary to even be on the committee. And everyone has something of value to contribute. Some will contribute ideas, some will contribute by asking hard questions or requiring accurate data. Others simply by putting together data. Even those that aren't in agreement force the rest to confirm their reasons for a decision. Being fair is usually as simple as being polite -- let the other person have a say, wait for your turn, etc. Being impartial shouldn't be an issue for anyone on the committee -- leave it at the door; this is a job as much as it is a civic responsibility.
past_political_activity: Advocate for Colorado gun rights, attended Legislature meetings. Attended Legislature Committee hearings 6 years ago. Registered Libertarian.

occupation: Consultant on professional licensure and certification
education:
Bachelor of Architecture
Master of Architecture and Urban Design
statement: I have always been interested in maps and political maps. I find the work of the commission very interesting and would like to contribute.
professional_background: Did phone banking and door knocking for Jason Crow's 2018 campaign in CD 6. Did door knocking for Tammy Story's 2018 campaign in SD 16.
org_list: Current president of home owners association.
analytic_skills: As noted above, my career has involved using logic and reason to address problems and achieve results.
consensus_statement: My entire work career has been in non-profit associations which operate on a need-for-consensus basis. Unlike in for-profit corporations, non-profits are usually driven by leaders with an emotional reason for involvement. That means that emotions, not profit, tend to drive discussions. As an executive within these associations, I have experience in working with groups driven by emotion to achieve decisions, often through consensus.
past_political_activity: Currently precinct committee person; donated to the 2018 and 2020 elections in CD 6 in Colorado; donated to SD 16 election in 2018

occupation: I am currently self employed as an artist and a stay-at-home mom.
education: I have a Liberal Arts Bachelors degree with my areas of study being biology/pre-veterinary and graphic design
statement: As you can likely tell from my previous answers, I am new to civic engagement. When I was younger I was always interested in and followed politics but due to frequent moves and other major life events just didn't have time to dedicate to volunteering or activism in any significant way. However, due to the current political environment and the birth of my child, I feel a greater call to personally get involved in shaping the future of our country for the better. I know that redistricting is a crucial to ensuring equal representation in our government, but I worry that it perhaps isn't as exciting as other opportunities for people to get involved leaving a vacuum of passionate people. I want to bring my passion for government and politics to this project and use my enthusiasm to make a difference in the future of Colorado and the country.
professional_background: N/A
org_list: This election season I volunteered to write letters with Vote Forward for their "get out the vote" campaign. I do not belong to any other organizations and have not volunteered in any ways since before 2015.
analytic_skills: For me as an artist, my work is all about problem solving. How do you take a reality and recreate it to a two dimensional form? How do you synthesize information into an easily digestible format? To do this you have to gather all the relevant information (reference photos for my work, census data for mapping). Then analyzing this information, which for me involves taking the whole and breaking it down into smaller manageable pieces and considering it from all angles. Then from that analysis you form your conclusions and that information to build the final product. I think my experience as an artist has a lot of overlap with and would be a useful asset to the redistricting project.
consensus_statement: I was raised as a conservative, and my parents are still staunch conservatives while my husband and his family is very liberal, so on a personal level, I am used to straddling the line of impartiality often. I consider myself to be a true moderate. I see value in the ideas that both parties have and truly believe that most people regardless of party really do want the best for our country. I really enjoy debating the nuance of policy and while I may defend my position passionately, I feel that at the end of the day coming away with a compromise that everyone feels is fair is far more important than winning. I think that bringing my personal experience and philosophy to the commission would be a great asset.
past_political_activity: I have voted in every election since I turned 18 (2008-2020). I have an ongoing donation to the NRDC. This past election cycle I donated to Pete Buttigieg during the primary, Amy McGrath, and Joe Biden. Prior to that I have not donated to any other campaigns.

occupation: Executive Director, San Miguel Authority for Regional Transportation
education: I have a BA from the University of Nebraska - Lincoln in Environmental Studies with minors in Sociology and English. I also have a Masters degree in Urban and Regional Planning with significant studies in Transportation Systems Engineering from the University of Pennsylvania.
statement: As an Unaffiliated voter in Colorado, I have found limited opportunities to be involved in politics beyond simply voting. I believe that the redistricting commission has an amazing opportunity to ensure that Colorado's congressional districts serve as an honest reflection of those who live in them, without the partisan gerrymandering we've seen over so many years. I would be extremely honored to be entrusted with a role on the re-districting Commission and believe its work will have a lasting impact on the State - for the better.
professional_background: I think my record with CASTA is probably most relevant, aside from my full time work. As president of the Board of Directors of CASTA, I helped maintain a balanced viewpoint that represented interests from all across the State. From large transit agencies such as RTD in Denver, to very small rural agencies such as the Dolores County Senior Transportation Program, I worked to make sure that all voices and viewpoints were heard and represented. I think the fact that I have been elected to the CASTA Board for two terms now illustrates that my peers and colleagues from around the state (those who elect members of the Board) trust my intent, judgement, and ability to lead.
org_list:
1. All Points Transit (operating out of Montrose) Board of Directors. This is a local non-profit. I am still serving on this Board as board secretary.
2. Colorado Association of Transit Agency's Board of Directors. This is a professional organization who's membership consists of transit providers all across Colorado. I am the immediate past president of the Board of Directors and am still serving on this Board.
3. Northstar Condo's HOA. Until recently I was a Board officer on my residential HOA Board. First as secretary, then as president. I resigned from the HOA Board in early October of 2020.
4. San Miguel County Open Space Committee. I am no longer a member of this local advisory committee.
5. South West Transit Association - Board of Directors. I served as a representative from CASTA on this Board. I am no longer on this board.
analytic_skills: As an urban planner with a background in systems engineering, I am a data driven decision maker. That's not to say that I'm blind to community values and motivations, or that I'm not politically savvy - because I am. As the Executive Director of one of Colorado's six regional transportation authorities, all of my decisions and recommendations are transparent, based in logic, and made with the best interests of the communities I serve in mind. I think this mindset and skillset will serve me well if I am fortunate enough to be appointed to this Commission.
consensus_statement: As an independent voter, I see the pluses (and negatives) of both sides of our traditional political "aisle". As an executive leader with a proven track record working in the public sector with and on behalf of varied communities, I am always striving for consensus and agreement in difficult conversations. This can only be done by being fair and impartial - even in difficult or stressful conversations. I have found (for better or worse - and not always to my pleasure) that I am a natural leader when it comes to pulling groups together to develop mutually beneficial solutions. This has been confirmed by some work over the years with professional coaches and assessments such as Hogan Lead and Hogan Challenge - I'd be happy to share the results of those assessments if anyone wanted to see them. How do I do it? I'm just myself - no bull. I'm also a pretty nice guy who people respect and want to work with - even if they need to give a little. I am always looking for the win-win and my track records supports this.
past_political_activity: I have never ran for any public office, volunteered for any campaign, or donated to any political campaign.

education:
University of Iowa College of Law, J.D
University of Minnesota, School of Business, B.S in Business
Admission to State Bars: Colorado, Kansas, Missouri and various federal courts
Teach legal courses for a university; teach for legal association, teach seminars for lawyers and non-lawyers
statement: This election has been a reminder of the importance of each and every vote and the right of every vote to count. The importance of drawing new districts in a way that is fair for every voter in Colorado is equally important. Although I advocate for my clients, I do so in a way that is objective and fair.  I would like to apply my analytical skills in an impartial way that appreciates Colorado's diversity.
professional_background: As a lawyer, my job is to represent and advocate for my clients. I have represented clients before courts, arbitrations, state and federal agencies and negotiated transactions on behalf of clients. I have lead groups of lawyers and non-lawyers on various projects in volunteer capacities.
org_list:
Political: Jefferson County Democrats

Civic: Jefferson County Cultural Commission, board member (2020-present); City of Lakewood Advisory Commission, board member (2017-present); 40 West Arts District, board member (2017-present); Colorado Attorneys for the the Arts, speaker & volunteer attorney (2017-present); Mi Casa Resource Center, Business Legal volunteer lawyer (2017-present).

Professional:  American Bar Association Intellectual Property Section (Books Board; Landslide Magazine Advisory Commission; Membership Board); Copyright Society, co-chair of the Rocky Mountain Chapter; Colorado Bar Association; Colorado Intellectual Property Inns of Court; International Right of Way Association instructor and International Ethics Committee
analytic_skills:
I routinely investigate disputes to develop a full factual record, research the issues fully so I can advise my clients of its options, advocate for my clients in a transaction or in court. I routinely work with detailed statistical reports, documents, expert reports and investigations, and make determinations as to determining the weight that any such documents or witnesses should be given. 

I believe that these analytical skills will be useful in working to develop the redistricting.
consensus_statement:
I help negotiate agreements with clients who have intractable positions that are odds with other parties whether in a transaction or the settlement of litigation. But, I have been successful (in part) because am able to work hard to find each party's true interests and find a resolution.

My integrity, professionalism, objectivity, and reputation for being fair and honest is how I make my living and I guard that reputation zealously. I serve on an international trade association's ethics committee in large part because I have shown that I am impartial in investigating conflict of interest claims and allegations of violations of professionalism. I have also recently been appointed to serve on the Jefferson County Cultural Commission for the same reasons.
past_political_activity: Precinct co-captain for JeffCo Democrats in HD28; volunteer for local candidates. I don't recall any monetary donations.

education:

La Plata Leadership Program , Kirk Hanna Leadership Program, Graduate of Realtor's Institute
statement: I want to serve on the commission to create fair and equal representation of communities , while remembering geographic limitations.  Colorado is a state of diverse Geography, Values, and Economic drivers;  these must be considered during redistricting.

analytic_skills: I feel that my analytical skills are good as I am applying them in my everyday life.  As a member of a ranching family, I have been involved first hand in decisions that needed to be made – some were very hard but economically correct.  As a real estate broker I find that it is often necessary to help guide clients in those difficult decisions and through the complicated process of buying and selling property.  When making a decision or assisting in a decision, it must be logical and above all, fair, based on available information.
consensus_statement: As a sixth generation Coloradoan and lifetime La Plata County resident, I am and have been involved in local and state issues for my entire life.  I feel because of my background and involvement I would make a difference on the Re-districting committee.  I work extensively with local agricultural and civic groups in La Plata County and Western Colorado.  Discussion is always good but before I make a decision, I look for “the whole story.”  Because of my background, I feel that I can contribute to this important decision and help to keep other rural and urban residents informed of the decisions that were made.
past_political_activity: Election Judge, Served as County Caucus Representative, Republican Central Committee in La Plata County, Colorado, Donated to J. Paul Brown State Representative campaign

statement: There are two basic reasons guiding my interest:  First, I strongly support the interest of fair representation.  Among other things, this means that district lines are not written in such a way to ensure a particular outcome, but rather that citizens in each district are given real choice with candidates that attend to the needs and interests of the population.  Second, I am a strong believer in shared community responsibility.  While it is easy to criticize the decisions of others, we often forget how difficult it is to shoulder the decisions.  I offer my time and effort to share that responsibility.
professional_background: I have concentrated my efforts on addressing environmental issues and community support.  These are issues I take a hands-on approach to through my volunteer activities and then focus on through my classes (regularly teaching an upper division course at CU Boulder focused on environmental policy, for example)
org_list: Boulder Rotary Club; American Red Cross (Boulder-Broomfield Chapter, Disaster Action Team); Institute for Environmental Solutions (steering committee for CO community projects, 2014-present); Global Greengrants (pro bono researcher, 2017-2019); Eco-Cycle (pro bono research associate, 2016-2017); Wild Foundation (pro bono project coordinator, 2015); Colorado Alliance for Environmental Educators; North American Association for Environmental Educators; Community Food Share (weekly volunteer in food distribution, 2015-2018)
analytic_skills: I am well-steeped in a variety of analytical methods, from quantitative to qualitative analysis, and seek the best available data to build understanding.  Not all social phenomena are measurable or accepted as valid, and thus I am also very much attuned to how ideas are communicated, sometimes very intentionally designed to divide.  I have also paid attention to the details of redistricting (legal rules, political manuevering, technology aids in achieving politically-favored results, etc.).  While I cannot claim expertise in mapping, I am an analytical thinker and balanced thinker who can spot bias.
consensus_statement:
Being even-handed and building consensus are critical practices in my teaching and community service.  I seek to identify needs and shared interests in building towards agreement -- moving away from hard positions to language that fosters a commitment to supporting our common ground.  I have long used the negotiation principles and practices developed in the book "Getting to Yes."  
In terms of my ability to be fair or impartial, these are practices critical in any effective community activity or in the teaching environment, and most particularly in the contemporary political science class. I communicate to students at the outset that we should expect disagreement and this is partly due to our different sets of life experiences.  Furthermore, none of us has a lock on "the truth," and instead it is the collective set of perspectives that will help us to identify our common reality and get us closer to "the truth."  This is akin to the traditional Indian parable, "the blind men and the elephant."  With this at the foundation, I am committed to not only giving fair and equal voice to competing perspectives, but also asking individuals to "step into the shoes of the other" as we consider why we might disagree.  I favor coming to the middle rather than than win-lose outcomes.
past_political_activity: As an academic focused on American politics, I am an avid observer of politics, including of redistricting politics.  I regularly teach undergraduates on issues of American politics, including on the US Congress, and oversee students engaged in political and campaign-related internships (for all political parties and a wide range of candidates at local, state and national levels). I am a regular voter, participated in some nonpartisan get-out-the-vote efforts in 2016, and have been a nominal financial contributor (a small donation to Joe Neguse's District 2 campaign (2019); small donations to state Senate candidate Sally Boccella (2020).

statement: Most of my adult life I have worked with the public, be it in law enforcement or customer service and I have come to appreciate the backgrounds, insight and diverse opinions and perspectives I have been exposed to from people all across the world.  People want many different things unique to their own situation, but most of it can be summed up in the general consensus of being treated fairly and equally.  Unbiased electoral maps in our state is the first step in creating a true and just process through fair and equal representation at the voting booth and thus through elected officials.   I would very much like to be part of the solution for an issue which has been troublesome to many parties for a very long time.  No political party should have an unfair advantage over another simply because the way lines are drawn on a map.  Fair and equal is the order of the day.  It will take a great time commitment, dedication and the ability to communicate with people who represent a variety of views and perspective and to be able to find common ground and reach compromises.  I feel strongly I possess these skills and qualities to be successful.
professional_background: As a member of the APWU I worked as a union shop steward for nearly 17-years; Held the position of City Chief Steward; Editor; Vice-President of the area local.  I have always been a strong labor advocate and passionately represented union members and their concerns.  Often times these issues involved fair and equal treatment of employees, dignity and respect on the workroom floor as well as interpretation of labor contracts and memorandums of understanding.  I was also involved with local labor contract negotiations with the United States Postal Service.  I held the board position of Program Director with the El Paso County Progressive Veterans and was responsible for contacting, scheduling and coordinating guest speakers to attend and give presentations which aptly represented their organizations and how local veterans may benefit from the services they provided.  Volunteered - Performed Phone Banking - Assisted with canvassing - Posted and removed yard signs.  My activities have been with many political campaigns at the state and local level.
org_list: American Postal Workers Union - El Paso County Progressive Veterans - Sierra Club - Citizens Project - El Paso County Democrats - Friends of D-11
analytic_skills: Several things come to mind regarding the skills necessary to be successful with this project.  Communication both listening and speaking as well as being able to convey thoughts in writing.  The ability to work with others and build a team atmosphere with the hopes of achieving fairness and equality with the end product.  Thinking outside the box and listening when other do the same thing.  Realizing that while not everyone may agree on all things at all times, it is important to form a consensus as a team with the emphasis again being on fairness and equality.  The ability to look at the facts as they are and be honest with the team as to how it looks and listen to team members as to what they see.   Again, I feel my military background in law enforcement and my many years of working in customer service in the post office has provided me with many opportunities to see problems and situations from various points of view and to apply workable solutions as much as possible.  I want to emphasize the importance of listening and communicating.  I believe I have these skills.
consensus_statement: Common sense, communication, the ability to listen to other points of view and to speak out when needed.  My military background was in law enforcement and my postal background was in customer service.  Experiences in both fields lend themselves to recognizing a situation, problem solving, and reaching compromise when necessary.  I have an ability to be both tactful and direct when interacting with people from all backgrounds and walks of life.  Team work is key.  As a Drill Instructor in the Army several times I was tasked with molding a well functioning platoon which included young recruits from all around the country.  Some of these young people came from the streets of the inner city to farm kids from small towns and remote rural settings and they had to be taught to work as a team to achieve common goals.  These experiences served me well throughout my life as I would often draw upon my understanding of people in order to better understand a situation and resolve problems.  I continue to draw on those experiences even today.

education: I have a Ph.D. in political science from Northwestern University and a B.A.-M.A. from Johns Hopkins University in international relations. My Ph.D. includes a minor in Quantitative Methods. My qualifications include expertise in statistical software packages, such as STATA, and the mapping software Arc GIS. statement: I want to serve on the commission because I know that the geography of political districts has a large effect on representation. The legislative change that put decennial redistricting in the hands of independent commissions in Colorado is a move in the right direction, as partisan gerrymandering has made congressional races less competitive: by some counts, less than ten percent of the seats in the House of Representatives is filled as the result of competitive elections. In addition to creating safe seats, gerrymandering reduces the incentives of elected representatives to be responsive to the median voter, as gerrymandering allows districts to be "packed" with like-minded voters, and is an obstacle to pluralism through the practice of "cracking", or diluting the vote likely to elect the opposing party. These factors combined contribute to higher barriers to entry to political office and lower bi-partisanship.
professional_background: Through my volunteer work with the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network (RMIAN) I seek to ensure that all people have knowledge of their legal rights and receive due process. My work with RMIAN, however, goes beyond my interpretation assignments and extends to helping immigrants become successful members of our community.
org_list: I am a pro-bono interpreter with the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network since 2017. From 2017-2019 I worked alongside Humanitas360 conducting research on prison work cooperatives in Latin America.
analytic_skills: Perhaps the most intense period of training in analytical and logical skills happened for me during graduate school. There I learned to ask questions that lend themselves to empirical testing and to chose and apply the methodology most appropriate to evaluating potential answers. We delved into topics such as whether we can establish a robust relationship between cause and effect and eliminate alternative explanations for a finding, and whether the same findings can be replicated in other settings. I later taught research methodology for the social sciences at the Colorado School of Mines. With my students I explored issues of omitted variables, selection bias, and missing data. My training as a researcher and my experience teaching others how to ask questions and test answers are well suited to the tasks of the redistricting commission: absorbing large amounts of information, analyzing data, and weighing competing interests. I am experienced in the use of statistical software and familiar with geospatial programs as well (e.g. ArcGIS).
consensus_statement:
My ability to be fair and promote consensus comes from my years teaching college students and working in the courts. One of the goals of teaching about politics and government is to give students the knowledge and skills to form opinions and defend them. It is the instructor’s responsibility to facilitate class discussion and model appropriate behavior. One technique I have used to facilitate the free exchange of ideas is to collectively agree on a short set of beliefs for opposing points of view on a policy issue, and then assign students to defend a belief, regardless of his/her own stand on the issue. This exercise illustrates that competing points of view can be grounded in acceptable ideas and be the result of sound reasoning. From there, the exercise moved on to the construction of a counter-argument, where students would choose what position to take on an issue. A similar process can be used in other contexts to facilitate consensus.

Working in courtrooms I have learned that impartiality is as much a state of mind, as the result of adhering to procedure. Jurors, for example, can be instructed to follow a set of rules in the evaluation of evidence. This, in turn, can lead to a shared understanding of the evidence and to a consensus-based decision that is informed but not pre-determined by prior held beliefs. The process of first reaching an agreement on the steps to be followed in the evaluation of information can be used in other contexts as a way of facilitating joint decision-making.

Perhaps the hardest goal to achieve in the process of redistricting is fairness. The American system of representation rests on the idea of equality of representation of all people, yet we know that the same vote will either fall in the winning majority or in the losing minority, depending on the location of the district line. If selected to serve on the commission, I will bring all my energy, knowledge, and experience to achieve this ultimate goal.

statement: I am 10-year resident of Colorado, and my experience living and voting in our great state has only been during this recent decade of change.  The Colorado of 2020 is not the same as the Colorado of 2010 (or 1910); and El Paso County is not the same either.  As a redistricting commission, we are going to need to be equipped to use today’s data to inform choices around district boundaries which fairly represent the all the people of Colorado.  As one example, Colorado’s population of school-aged children has grown by 230,000 between 2010 and 2019.  This is likely to be the fastest growing segment of Colorado residents as the 2020 Census reporting becomes available.  As mother of school-aged children, I want to be sure the commission members analyze fairly the data put before them before drawing districts which have implications for both our current and next generations of voters and elected representatives.
