statement: I believe that districts should be drawn with an eye towards community preservation and with the intent to amplify the voices of communities not dilute them. Gerrymandered districts silence the voice and will of the people. By serving on the redistricting commission, I can promote the needs of communities across CO based on what we see from the data collected in the 2020 U.S. Census. I also see service on this commission as an opportunity to forge connections with proud Coloradans from all across the state who may have different views from my own from which I can learn and grow.
professional_background: I have lobbied both state and U.S. congress people as a private citizen and member of the ASBMB (indicated above). I have functioned as a volunteer organizer for several Democratic campaigns at the state and national level. I am a middle-class, white woman who acts as an ally for the LGBTQ community and people of color. I have a particular focus on advocating for evidence-based policy decisions at the local, state, and federal levels.
org_list: American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology--Advocacy Training Program and Capitol Hill Day (2019-2020)
analytic_skills: As a scientist, I have been trained to analyze data and make logical, rational conclusions and inferences. I understand that there are often gaps in data where hardcore analysis cannot be accomplished. In those instances, I utilize my capacity and experience to make and state logical assumptions to drive hypotheses and make decisions. I work daily with large data sets, statistics, and graphical representations. As a scientific team leader, I coalesce data and interpretations, present it, and plan group actions (i.e. experimentation). One of the greatest strengths I would bring to this committee is my commitment towards listening to reasonable interpretations of the data and ordering those interpretations based on the strength of the evidence.
consensus_statement: I believe that impartiality does not come from having a lack of an opinion; impartiality comes from having an opinion that can be set aside during the decision-making process to make decisions based on evidence. I have served in leadership roles throughout my life where I have learned that listening and is THE essential component of building consensus. It is key to respect. If selected to this commission, I will acknowledge that I need to make the extra effort to listen to and learn from opposing voices. I will absorb the data, absorb the various arguments, and seek to build consensus around principles of egalitarianism, fairness, and justice--principles that I believe the commission was established upon.

statement: Ensuring that everyone's vote counts equally is tantamount to our country's democracy. Gerrymandering disenfranchises voters, creating an imbalanced system that favors one group of voters over another. I would like to serve on the commission to guarantee that all voters feel that their vote matters and their voices are heard.
professional_background:
As a female STEM student, one of my passions is showing children how rewarding, fun, and essential STEM careers are. As a founding member of the Biostatistics Student Association, I have worked for years to establish a relationship with Aurora Public Schools, where we visit middle school students in the fall semester and then invite them to visit the CU Anschutz campus. During these visits, we help promote statistical, epidemiological, and public health concepts in ways that equal parts fun and informative.
I am also a advocate for graduate students as a whole. Serving on the CSPH student council and as a member of GSAG, I have been able to voice the concerns of my fellow students to the Deans and their Associates. Up until two years ago, CSPH graduate students' health insurance was not covered by their research assistantships, which is the case for all other graduate students on the campus. Through organization and persistence, we helped change this policy and now all MS and PhD students in CSPH have their health insurance covered.
org_list: I am a member of several professional organizations, including the American Statistical Association, the Western North American Region of the International Biometric Society, the Caucus for Women in Statistics, the Society for Interventional Radiology, and have held a past memberships with the Organization for Human Brain Mapping and International Society for Magnetic Resonance in Medicine. Outside of these national and international organizations, on the CU Anschutz campus I have been a member of the Biostatistics Student Association (BSA), Statistics in the Community (STAT-COM), the Graduate Student Advisory Group (GSAG), and the Colorado School of Public Health (CSPH) student council.
analytic_skills: With degrees in mathematics, economics, and biostatistics, I have an especially relevant set of skills to data analysis. I am comfortable working with "big data" of varying levels of complexity. As a co-author on over a dozen academic publications, I have shown my ability to distill complex statistical concepts to a lay audience. Through my dissertation research, I have learned how to think creatively by bringing in concepts from seemingly unrelated fields to help solve mathematical or statistical problems.
consensus_statement: As an academic, it is my job to remain impartial to the outcome of a study and to create a data analysis plan that minimizes bias. My work is very collaborative in nature, requiring me to not only be succinct when providing my viewpoint but being open-minded to the viewpoints of others. Willingness to meet halfway on especially contentious issues and commitment to a greater good will result in the optimal outcome for the commission.
past_political_activity: I have donated money to Joe Biden's 2020 presidential campaign, John Ossof's 2020 Senate campaign, Crooked Media's "Get Mitch or Die Trying" fund in 2020, and to Florida Forward Action in 2020. consensus_statement:
I will promote consensus by looking for areas of agreement among the commissioners and seeking ways to expand those areas.  Where agreement is elusive, demonstrating that one has heard and understood different points of view is an effective method of reaching consensus.  As a lawyer, I understand that the best results come in cases where both my client and the opposing party feel their arguments have been heard and understood.  As a U.S. Peace Corps Volunteer in the 1990's, my job was to encourage environmental reforms in a coal mining region of the Czech Republic.  Finding common ground between environmental NGO's and mining interests required tact, diplomacy, and a sense of shared purpose.
I respect others' life experience and point of view, and have actively engaged in interactions with those whose political opinions differ from my own.  I am confident that, from both a professional and personal point of view, I am able to be fair and impartial and express myself diplomatically.
past_political_activity: I participated in a voter registration drive in Denver in 2008, canvassed for Hillary Clinton in 2016, and have (with my husband) occasionally given small donations to Democratic candidates and the Democratic Party.  Since 2015, I have donated $100 or less to the campaigns of Chris Hansen, John Hickenlooper, and Joe Biden.

occupation: I am a retired school administrator and teacher.
education:
Educational Leadership, School Administration endorsement, Type D certificate, University of
Denver, Denver, Colorado November 1992
• Master of Public Administration, City University of New York,
New York, NY, August 1987
• Bachelor of Arts, University of Northern Colorado, Greeley, CO, June 1980
statement:
I am a Colorado native and I love this state. As a school administrator and teacher I dedicated my self to a life of service. A life of service to family, community and especially youth.  Through the commission, I will continue this dedication of service.  Additionally, working on this commission I will represent and serve Colorado's populations that are underserved and underrepresented.  Maps that are fair and equally represent "all" residents of Colorado is important 
 to me from many aspects.  For one, people that know and feel like they count and have representation have a greater potential to become involved in our democracy. When boundaries are done fairly, elected officials are more likely to truly represent all their constituents.
professional_background: Throughout my life and professional career, I have been an advocate for the underserved, underrepresented and oppressed.   As a person of color, I am sensitive to the issues of equity and fairness.  During my time as a college student, I helped to organize college students that provided a voice to Latino students.  As a community member I have created new activities that strengthened our LMAC and its standing in our community.  Recently I was key member in fighting for social justice within our community on behalf of a migrant that had been beaten.  We had several meetings with local officials and District Attorney.  We are advocating a change of procedures when a non-English speaker is involved in an incident involving law enforcement.  As a community member I was co-chair of a group that created the CUBRES program within UNC. CUBRES was designed to be supportive of students of color for college success. When I sat a member of the YMCA advisory, I encouraged more outreach to families that were challenged finically and more families are now being served.
org_list: Volunteer with Colorado Democrats, Volunteer with Longmont Sister City Association, Volunteer with Longmont Multicultural Action Committee, member of LatinX Voice of Longmont, Advisory committee member with YMCA Longmont, Advisory committee member to Congressman Joe Neguse, Non-active member Knights of Columbus, Mankind Project member, ASCD or Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development member, Volunteer with OUR Center or Outreach United Resource Center, Member of Boulder County Latino Committee, Volunteer with Outreach and Inclusion Team, City of Longmont, Children, Youth and Families, College entrance support workshop as a Volunteer
consensus_statement:
Provide a statement about how you believe you will promote consensus or contribute to creating agreement among the commissioners. Please also discuss your ability to be fair or impartial. 
Since I was a child fairness has always been a part of my personal profile and it has always pained me to see someone being treated unfairly. Equity and consensus building are key elements in any good leaders.  People will not listen or follow if they do not believe they are being treated fairly. Fairness and impartiality are showing respect for fellow citizens and any process.  I pride myself in my how I conduct myself in my professional world and my private life. It is how we treat each other that matters most. A primary ingredient in reaching agreement is showing others that they are being heard. This action shows others that the element of respect.  Respect and fairness go hand in hand when working with others.   
As an educator I know that we all learn differently.  Children that are special needs must be provided more time or special assistance to get to the objective, just as all the other students reach the objective following a different path of learning.  This is fair and just. Also, when there was a decision to be made I always try to include others to give staff, students and parents a voice and a path to be part of the solution.
past_political_activity: Assisted with voter registration and GOTV for 2020 and 2016.

occupation: Senior Software Test Engineer - Lockheed Martin Corporation
education: 1981 - Bachelor of Science Degree in Computer Science - State University of New York @ Oswego
statement: I look at the current districts and often wonder - "How in the heck did anyone come up with that map?"  Living in the same spot in the suburbs of Denver during a 17 year span resulted in me being placed in three different U.S. House Districts.  Some of my neighbors two miles away would be in a different district which made no sense to me.  I like to think of Colorado as a giant puzzle made up of 64 counties - or Mountainous or Plains - or Urban Rural, Suburban - or ... and it becomes obvious that coming up with districts that make sense, are fair, and take into account such a variety of factors -  is an extreme challenge and it would be fun to solve that puzzle.
professional_background: I'm not a political organizer by nature but serving as the Treasurer for both a Square Dance Club and an HOA in my past really allows you realize how an organization that seems straight-forward in its goals is comprised of so many people with different goals!  Dealing with money issues as a treasurer forces you to balance the emotional feeling money (and politics) can impair or passionate people which can affect their reasoning skills.  This commission would be an extension of that by treating "groups of people (such as Democrats or Republicans)" in a similar way as you would have to juggle individual people and viewpoints.
org_list: I've been an active member of multiple Square dance clubs in the Denver Metro area and served as Treasurer and board member for one of the clubs.  I'm a member of multiple volunteer groups like the Colorado Trail Foundation, Colorado 14'ers Institute and Continental Divide Trail Coalition.  A year ago I moved to Salida to live part-time while I finished my last year of work in Littleton.  With the COVID-19 pandemic, it has been a challenge to get to know my new community fully with so many groups shut down but I have already participated in the local food banks and homestead "Farm to Table" organizations.  In 2021 I will be "retired" in Salida full-time and look forward to much more involvement when the pandemic restrictions are lifted.
analytic_skills: For my 38 year career, I've been a software Engineer doing coding, testing and design of complicated software that runs and monitors spacecraft designed here in Colorado.  For the most recent 10 years of my career I primarily have designed automated software tests that test application and system software that others have written to verify that on a spacecraft it will perform flawlessly.  Even a very minor mistake can result in the lost of the functionality of a spacecraft that costs 100's of millions of dollars to build, launch and operate.  Using logic and analytical skills are my two strongest traits.  For engineers,  it can be very difficult to use that approach with others and have the ability to understand the intuitive and emotional nature of people which you have to consider to really understand the problem and come up with the best solutions that may at first not seem like the most logical.
consensus_statement: I have traveled though nearly every county and major town in Colorado so I think I can relate to the viewpoints of people who live in the wide variety of places in this state.  I've served as jury foreman on multiple jury trials where fairness and impartiality are of the utmost importance.  "Get the data, brainstorm, listen to others, and come up with the best solution" has been a normal way of life in my entire career.  Having twelve people of different political viewpoints will force us to have to come up with sound solutions that are not secretly based on  "This will help my political party".
past_political_activity: None.  I consider that an advantage of starting with a clean slate and not having preconceived ideas of how the state should be apportioned.

statement: I was excited to vote in favor of Ammendments Y & Z in 2018 because I believed it would put Colorado in a position of leadership when it comes to fair redistricting and elections. I believe strongly in fair elections, and while I have my own personal opinions on issues, I also deeply believe that everyone should have fair representation in elections, regardless of their opinion or position. I have been disappointed to see examples where redistricting became a tool used for voter suppression or gerrymandering and am very excited that Colorado developed a process to avoid these outcomes when redistricting. I believe I can support the process as a member of the commission with my background in leadership, communication, team-building, education, and data analysis and I would be thrilled to be of service to all Coloradans in helping to maintain fair elections.
professional_background: My first experience with organizing was in 2001-2001 when I served as an Americorps community organizer for a year, working with residents of mobile home parks, lawyers, and advocates to represent the interest of mobile home residents and to lobby cities, counties and the state to promote affordable housing solutions. From that role I moved into the field of education and public health promotion. Recently as a member of the board of directors for the Colorado Mountain Club, I have represented the organization in a development and fundraising capacity to community partners. I have also represented my industry (outdoor/climbing industry) by participating on the board of advisors for the Warren Tech High School Outdoor Leadership Program as well as at the Climbing Wall Association annual conference, where I have participated as a panelist. In my current employment, I have also advocated internally to promote access to climbing for community groups and partners, which has led to long-term engagement with several community groups.
org_list: Board of Directors, Colorado Mountain Club, October 2019-present Board of Industry Advisors, Warren Tech High School, Outdoor Leadership Program, 2017-present Climbing Wall Association, 2016-present
analytic_skills: Some of my past jobs and training have involved significant data-analysis and program evaluation, but regardless of my role I am a data seeker in my decision making process. And while I try to empathize with an emotional perspective, I do not let emotional arguments determine my decision making. As an example, in the customer service context that I operate in currently, an individual might bring up a complaint or may be vocal about an opinion. As convincing as they may be about their concern or opinion, I will dive much deeper into the root of the issue to determine if their concern is widely held or represents a larger problem, before making a decision based on one or a handful of comments. It can be tempting to make decisions based only on an individual's compelling argument or emotional plea, but I am committed to delving deeper and gathering more information to understand a problem better (and determine if it is in fact a problem) before attempting to solve it. In the real world, great data doesn't always exist, so to avoid analysis paralysis and be in a position to move forward, I supplement data-analysis with experience, seeking input, and discussing options, and considering potential outcomes before making a decision. I also keep in mind the larger goal - solving a problem should be in service of achieving our vision and mission. For example, my company's current vision is to transform the world through the experience of climbing (we run climbing gyms). When I receive input from customers, I will consider the problem of a member feeling excluded from the community much more seriously than the problem of our gym not having a sauna for member use. One problem (inclusion) is directly related to achieving our vision, the other (sauna) simply represents someone's personal preference for their gym experience, but solving that problem will not contribute materially to our overall vision. Part of the reason I would like to be involved in this commission is because I enjoy the process of problem solving and am excited to participate in the challenging process of redistricting for Colorado.
consensus_statement: I am a big-picture thinker and in my job am frequently required to move a group toward consensus. Of course I have personal opinions on issues, but I do let let an attachment to a particular position cloud my ability to consider many perspectives and keep the larger objective in mind. I have found that my own opinions often evolve as I engage in discussion or a consensus-building process, so I have learned over the years that my initial position on may not be my final position - all of which is to say I am committed to achieving the larger goal/vision of my work than remaining attached to a particular strategy/tactic or position. I am able to listen actively and engage with people who hold perspectives different from my own to reach conclusions or take action. In a group setting such as this commission, I could play a role of facilitator, active listener, observer, and monitor (in the sense of monitoring if our work is on track or identifying if we are getting away from the bigger goal/objective). A major professional challenge I have moved through recently is a merger of two companies, and my role at a leader in the organization was to repeatedly express the vision of the company, the objectives/goals we are moving toward, gather input from stakeholders, and to have conversations that build buy-in to our new company's direction. In this process, I have been able to support two large teams in moving in a new direction, finding common ground with this direction, and generally feeling bought-in to our collective work and the outcomes. I like to approach problem solving as a collaborative learning process, where through the process we elevate the group's collective knowledge and wisdom to come up with solutions and make decisions that best serve our common goal. In this process, I may not always get "my way," but I also know that a group can come up with more brilliant, practical, or elegant solutions that I could on my own, so I promote collaboration, learning, and always refocusing on our common goals. I believe I also am well equipped to be fair and impartial on this commission. I do not put my personal opinions/values above the larger goal, in this case supporting fair redistricting and fair elections. As a manager and supervisor, I have tried to apply principles of fairness to my teams, to reduce the possibility of favoritism or expression of bias.
past_political_activity: To my best recollection, I have donated to the following. I do not recall dollar amounts but all donations would have been in the $25-$50 range from what I recall: Hillary Clinton, 2016 National Redistricting Action Fund, 2017-2019 National Democratic Redistricting Committee, 2017 Ed Perlmutter, 2017 Color of Change PAC, 2016

occupation: I am the Research and Training Manager at the Laboratory to Combat Human Trafficking
education: I have a BA in Forestry, a MS in Forest Sciences and a MA in International Development
statement: I believe in democracy. I have spent about a decade working in countries in Africa, the Middle East and Asia. I've been lucky enough to be present when citizens of Iraq were able to vote for the first time in decades (for example). I do not take our right to vote for granted and believe it is our most important right in the US. I want our elections to be fair and I want the people of Colorado to be represented in a way that is just and not partisan.
professional_background: It is my life's work to advocate for the oppressed. Currently I do so in my role at the Laboratory to Combat Human Trafficking(LCHT) for survivors of exploitation as well as in my role on the board of directors for the child advocacy center. In my role at LCHT, I have spent a great deal of time traveling around the state educating and organizing anti-trafficking task forces and coalitions, there are currently 18 in Colorado. I recently hosted a convening of the leadership of all 18 of these task forces/coalitions and will continue to do so quarterly moving forward. In my position at LCHT I have also received a sub-grantee award from the Colorado Dept. of Human Services to consult on a project that supports anti-trafficking advocates in rural and frontier regions across Colorado. I am also a professor at Metropolitan State University, teaching students about human trafficking and oppression that leads to exploitation.
org_list: I work for a social justice nonprofit based in Denver. Since 2015, I have worked for one other anti-trafficking nonprofit, the Human Trafficking Center. I have volunteered and donated money to the GrowHaus, which is a Denver-based food justice nonprofit. I have served on the board of directors for TreeTop Child Advocacy Center in Breckenridge for a little over a year and still actively do. I was also appointed to Governor’s Colorado Human Trafficking Council Prevention Task Force in 2018 (a volunteer position).
analytic_skills: At my core, I believe in research and evidence-informed action to solve problems. I will always rely on data (if it was obtained legitimately and ethically) that was conducted in a methodological way to inform my decisions. But even when it comes to data, sometimes research can be biased. I will always ask, who is at the table and more importantly, who is not. Representation should be inclusive and intentional.
consensus_statement: It is my job to bring people together. Anti-trafficking work requires collaboration, and collaboration requires trust. I value integrity and truth and lead by example. Additionally, I am empathetic and an active listener, always willing to grow and learn from others. I look forward to this opportunity.
past_political_activity: I've never donated money to a campaign. I am an active and informed voter.

education: B.A. '83 - Marquette University, Milwaukee, WI (Journalism, minor: Business), completed language program '93: Monterey Institute of International Studies (Intensive Japanese), passed the Colorado Real Estate Commission Real Estate Broker Exam, 5/23/15, Toastmasters: achieved the Advanced Communicator Gold designation
statement: I'm fair, and well-reasoned.  I will study something until I have a great command of it.  I should have been an analyst.  However, I'm also great at motivating people and teaching, either one-on-one or in front of groups.  I am fluent in Spanish, and in fact am a proclaimer in Spanish at my Catholic church.  I've delivered many speeches to public organizations like Rotary, in support of the cause of dyslexia outreach.  I greatly dislike gerrymandering, and believe that Republicans need to get involved.  Voting is no longer enough.
professional_background: Dyslexia - Did a 22-minute TEDx speech advocating for the rights of dyslexic kids (7/6/16, entitled: "Remove your mask of disability"), also worked on the Outreach team while I was on the Board of The Liberty School, which raised money to eventually build a permanent school.  Today, The Liberty School is one of the best schools in the country for dyslexic and gifted kids.  In my past, I also worked as part of a team to organize minority community bone marrow drives throughout northern California (one of my relatives was dying from leukemia, and we realized that the bone marrow registry for hispanics was a fraction of the size of the general market bone marrow registry, which meant that his prognosis wasn't good). Founded and served as first president of a 10+ member hiking and investing club for women in Silicon Valley that lasted for years until it disbanded in the early 2000's.  Purpose was to educate women through monthly meetings about researching and buying stocks.  Former president of Durango Earlybird Toastmasters.  From '11 through '14, I advocated for the right to do short term rentals.  I failed, but after months of door-to-door canvasing and adding more owners to my short term rental tent, we did the unthinkable: got a majority of owners to agree to a proposal, which was then killed by the City of Durango.  More recently, I won a traffic appeal, which almost no one ever does.  I felt compelled to fight this racial profiling case in court.
org_list: Republican party, VP Emeritus Board of Directors: The Liberty School, Durango, CO, Toastmasters
analytic_skills: Like I said before, I should have been an analyst.  I know a lot about finance, real estate investing, the Constitution, dyslexia advocacy, parenting, and presenting my ideas through public speaking.
consensus_statement: I don't believe in short snippets, which is why I don't have a social media presence where I spew incendiary comments.  I do believe that if people hear me speak or say something, I better make it worth their while.  Therefore, my outreach is well-reasoned, always.  I believe that politics, and everything really, is complex.  In fact, the road to hell is paved with good intentions.  So, I study everything.
past_political_activity: I attend Southwest Republican Women events, but have heretofore not given money or significant time to the cause.  This year, however, I made three videos to be distributed via social media explaining my support for the Constitution 1) a rap, for young people, 2) in Spanish, for Hispanic voters, and 3) 45 minute video in English, explaining why I walked away from the Democrat party.

I strongly believe that the skill set I have obtained in my career demonstrates that I will dedicate my time on the commission to understanding, listening and impartiality to ensure Coloradans can be fairly represented.

occupation: I am currently the Executive Director for a community-based victim service nonprofit in Colorado Springs, Colorado. I have been in the business of victim advocacy for 17 years and have been working in cultural community-based nonprofits since 1990; whether I lived in urban Denver, or rural Nebraska, or in the growing and progressing Colorado Springs. You will see in my resume that I have served community in local, statewide, and national positions as a technical assistance provider for victim service nonprofits in a variety of settings.
education:
I have earned a GED from the Emily Griffith School of opportunity in 1989 when I left South High School in Denver’s Washington Park neighborhood which is the same school from which my parents graduated and where they met. I attended the Community College of Denver until I became pregnant and left school to raise my children and take care of my family. As an adult, I attended the Women’s College at the University of Denver but have not completed the degree requirements
Over the past 20 years I have built a solid career as a victim advocate, a technical assistance provider, a researcher, and a trainer. I have recently become an unlicensed psychotherapist in the state of Colorado and am attending a yearlong certification course for MindBody Therapy. While I continue to hold out for finishing my university degree one day, over the course of my life I have educated myself, being well read and well mentored. I have attended at least 30 hours of continuing education training in each of the last 20 years.
statement:
I want to serve on the commission for multiple reasons.
First, I was asked to apply by someone I respect and admire as a leader in the city. I want to honor that request, and their recognition of me in the community, as a trusted person. 
Also, I love Colorado. This is my home, where I was born, and raised and have worked and built my life. I have benefited from this state and have on purpose made this my home. 
In different professional roles I have had the opportunity to see the majority of the state with my own heart and eyes. As a child, being a native of Colorado, I traveled and stayed with family in different parts in most of Southern Colorado and along what is now known as the Front Range. I feel connected to rural and frontier Colorado as well as urban centers because of my time in and connections with colleagues, friends, and family who span all of Colorado. 
I come from a multi-racial, economically and politically diverse family. This helps me to aim for options that serve the well-being of all of us. I also know what it is like to move through social tiers and change one’s life trajectory through hard work and participation in the system. I am a testament to that. 
Finally, having built my career and gained professional respect through what some would call, my own gumption, it is also through the network of generous mentors and knowledgeable guides. Many people of many walks have invested in my success. It is my purpose and choice to continue to invest in our collective good and my beloved Colorful Colorado. This commission has a worthy purpose, and I believe I will be able to contribute meaningfully to the commission’s work.
professional_background: I have many years of experience in organizing, advocating for, and considering the interests of people impacted by violence crime, people impacted by social disparities, as well as with cultural communities seeking healing and well-being.  As an anti-domestic violence advocate, a trainer, a coalition staff member, a person engaged in community research, and through other related roles, I have worked to hear directly from people who are impacted, and to work with individuals and communities to find practical ways forward.  I look forward to bringing this perspective and skill set to the commission’s work on redistricting.
org_list:
I am presently on the Domestic Violence Offender Management Board (DVOMB) under the Department of Criminal Justice (DCJ) in the state of Colorado. 
I am a member of the Colorado Association of Psychotherapists. 
The organization, for which I work, is a member of Violence Free Colorado (the state coalition against domestic violence).
analytic_skills:
My natural perspective tends to be strategy and reason. As a person who has had a life full of diversity of social conditions and variety of people and locations, I find that my logical mind is well-balanced with the human relationships that surround me in life. 
In my work I have worked on research teams as support and as co-investigator. I have the ability to connect, value and evaluate the data that research provides. DAta helps to shape policy. In my work, I have also provided connection and support for many victims of violence, having to provide a compassionate connection and support people in learning about and maneuvering with some sense of capacity, the various systems with which a victim of crime can come into contact. I have developed over the years a fair balance of logic and reason with humanity and fairness. Data cannot live in a vacuum, it must be applied to the society in which we all live. Anecdote alone cannot be that which creates guidelines and policy, and it has a place to inform the rules of engagement.
consensus_statement: Differing perspectives are important and valuable in building good solutions, so disagreement is not a problem, but rather an indication that indeed people are putting forward their contribution.  Moving forward once many views have been expressed is then the work of respectful dialogue, listening and considering as well as speaking. When others at the table feel heard and respected, we can talk about solutions or compromises without any personal disrespect. Keeping our eyes on the values and the goals that the commission is tasked with can help in seeing that we are all working on behalf of something none of us can achieve individually.  Fairness and impartiality in terms of respectful inclusion, while being values-led, is a cornerstone of much of the work that I do in my professional life.
past_political_activity: My political activity has primarily consisted of being an informed voter.  Policy issues impact communities, and I take my right to vote seriously.  In addition,my very first donation to a political candidate was to Bernie Sanders in the 2016 primary. I have since donated to the National Democratic Party over this past year, usually in amounts of $5-25 dollars. I have also made a contribution to Colorado Senator Julie Gonzalez’ campaign in a similar amount.

I will not begin as a commissioner believing that I know how to reach the best outcome nor do I expect to know all the challenges that will be encountered.  But I do look forward to listening and learning and then using experience, good judgment, compromise and consensus to reach the best outcome for the people.

statement: I believe that everyone should be represented fairly and I will be a strong advocate for that as demonstrated by my volunteer effort with Tablerock HOA. An independent team to perform redistricting is a great step in the right direction for fairly represented the people of Colorado. I would look forward to working with a team of people to achieve that goal.
professional_background:
Volunteered for Tablerock HOA as a committee member and lead to equalize HOA fees in our neighborhood. Poll watcher in primary 2020.  Participated in (Risk Limiting Audit)RLA for Jeffco elections after the primary 2020. I have volunteered to be an Election Judge in the general election.

Our HOA covenants was set up unfairly such that more than 1/2 of the community was paying more for HOA fees than others and the disparity was growing every time HOA fees were raised because of a covenant rule that a portion of the neighborhood should pay 1.5 times more than the other portion. The HOA fees are used for maintenance of amenities in the community to which all households have equal access.  I lead the committee to research (with the help of a couple of board members) how we could change the covenants and educate the community on how the HOA fees were used for assets to which everyone has equal access. We learned that we would have to have an election to add an amendment to remove the 1.5 times rule. 

I sent out polls for the community to vote on preferred methods of equalizing the fees. Although this seemed like an insurmountable task the poll indicated that 18 or 19 of the homeowners who were paying less would vote for the change to the covenants.  This was a sign that the task was not insurmountable and we proceeded with community meetings and presentations which I put together. Myself and the two board members presented the information. We held an election and my team and I canvassed the neighborhood to make sure everyone voted.  We needed 20 households that were paying less to vote for equalizing fees and increase their fees.  22 fair-minded neighbors voted for the amendment!  We are now in the 3rd year of our HOA fees being equalized across the entire Tablerock neighborhood.
org_list: Volunteered for Tablerock HOA as a committee member and lead to equalize HOA fees in our neighborhood. Poll watcher in primary 2020.  Participated in RLA for Jeffco elections after the primary 2020. I have volunteered to be an Election Judge in the general election.
analytic_skills:
My original and main career was in Computer Science as a software developer in Java and C/C++.  I worked as a team lead and applications architect for developing banking, financial, reporting, and project management software. My analytical skills are strong. (see attached resume for details).  I also have an MS in Landscape Architecture and Urban design which required a great deal of analytical work in mapping and design where I used Adobe software such as Illustrator, InDesign, Photoshop to represent design proposals to a jury of faculty.

I've attached a letter of recommendation for my most recent HOA volunteer work.  I can provide references from my previous careers upon request.
consensus_statement: I and the team were able to convince people that were paying less in HOA fees to see that it wasn't fair that some people were paying more for the same amenities. I was also able to communicate effectively with people that were upset over changing HOA fee covenants by listening, discussion, and outreach via researched information and meetings.  One of the more valuable skills of being a health coach is listening and supporting the client in their goals.  It often comes back to establishing clear goals and providing support to reach them.

occupation: Senior Aide, Denver City Council, Councilwoman Robin Kniech
education: Ithaca College, B.A. Speech Communication and Rhetoric
statement:
As a millennial woman, I would ensure that a diverse voice is brought to the table. These commissions and groups tend to skew older and male because of the time commitment that is required. I am a busy working mom, but I believe in equitable maps. I think my unique perspective as a young, engaged, woman would be an invaluable voice for the commission. 

It is more important than ever to have fair maps that are drawn with a diverse perspective in mind. Colorado has changed a great deal in the last 10 years, and I believe having a diverse set of stakeholders around the table is imperative to an independent and collaborative process. 

I am involved in my community at large, and the opportunity to play a role in creating fair, equitable maps would be a great honor. I am thankful that the voters saw the importance of establishing this process, and I hope to have the privilege of serving on the commission.
professional_background: As a board member for the Mile High Freedom Bands, I represent our bands to sister organizations, such as other LGBTQ+ music groups, and other advocacy groups. When I was an Associate for Strategies 360, I represented a number of different organizations and causes at both the state and local levels, including PERA, the groups seeking to repeal the death penalty, and health care organizations. In these experiences, I have had to understand the intricate details of the organizations I have represented to properly advocate for their needs.
org_list: Since fall of 2018, I have played and performed with the Mile High Freedom Bands, and since July 2019, I have served as a board member for the bands as well. We are committed to making positive contributions to the LGBTQ+ community and allies through musical events and activities that engage, excite, educate, and entertain audiences while supporting performers of all abilities.
analytic_skills: My day-to-day work requires strong analytical skills. My job requires me to listen to the needs and concerns of the community, think of legislative solutions, develop sound policy and advocate to get that policy passed. The policy development piece of that process in particular requires distilling large amounts of information into coherent ideas that can translate into actionable results for the City of Denver. I thrive when given complex problems that require hard, process driven thinking to resolve.
consensus_statement:
I’m a listener. I am not interested in being the loudest voice in the room. Instead, I want to take the time to hear other’s perspectives, understand the rationale behind them, and come to an informed decision after having all the pertinent information. I do not want to play politics; I want to ensure that we have a fair process where many diverse voices are heard. 

In 2017, for CW Kniech’s office, we put together a table of experts from several different sectors to analyze how best to help individuals who were facing evictions. We expected there would be a diverse number of perspectives that would all need consideration. We also had our preconceived notions of what would work best. However, after several months of meetings, we came to an agreement with all parties of what would look best for Denver eviction legal defense and worked to implement that policy. The policy is now funded by Denver and being replicated across Colorado. Because I was able to be impartial and fair in the process, we developed a successful policy that continues to thrive today.

5. Deputy Field Director for Richard Skorman’s Colorado Springs mayoral campaign (2011)
6. Field Organizer for campaign of Colorado U.S. Sen. Michael Bennet (2010)

analytic_skills:
I started my career as an auditor (CPA) only to discover what I really enjoyed working with data. Specifically, I loved how it could illuminate the path forward. Leading that effort built consensus, prioritized budgets, and clarified goals. Not sure how your information is stored, but I've worked with everything from stacks of paper to online databases that need SQL. 

Problem solving starts with the end in mind. Working backwards, define the process that will most efficiently and effectively produce that result. Flowcharting may help, particularly if a group is available to design the process. Each step on the process will dictate the resources, time, and skills needed to complete it. Often I have found solutions by contacting other groups facing the same challenges. Starting collaborations early can help avoid delays and groupthink conflicts.
consensus_statement: In my work life we helped Colorado's destination promote tourism. Not everyone wants tourists. The discussion can get heated quickly. I found it helpful to contact leading parties prior to meetings and hearing their views beforehand. Asking them to suggest boundaries as we work toward common goals - economic development. Perhaps they didn't want ATVs, or pot smoking. It was also important to start them all off with concrete data. Having everyone show up with their own numbers was often counterproductive. While I'm not suggesting my experience will be the same for the commission, perhaps my scars can help find solutions.
past_political_activity: My wife, deceased since 2016, was affiliated with the Republican party and tried to include me in her activities. I am independent and remain unaffiliated. I do not contribute money to parties.

occupation:
Current occupation:  Retired attorney
Resume attached
education: See resume attached
statement: I believe that drawing fair, non-partisan, non-discriminatory congressional districts is critical to maintaining public trust in in our elections and our government.  Throughout my life I have looked for ways to make positive contributions to the world, especially in the areas of law and government.  My legal background in constitutional law, my experience working with community groups, and my interest in good government have all prepared me to help with this important work.
professional_background:
In addition to advocating for hundreds of organizations in my career as a lawyer, I also have extensive experience organizing and advocating for the people of Colorado and various public interest groups.  

•	Tobacco Litigation.  I was appointed as a special Attorney General to defend Colorado’s right to receive proceeds of the tobacco litigation settlement.
•	Colorado Medical Society.  I pursued class action claims on behalf of all doctors in Colorado and the Colorado Medical Society to protect Medicaid reimbursements.
•	Colorado Open Records Act.  I represented the Colorado Broadcasters Association and the Colorado Press Association in drafting and successfully lobby for passage of Colorado’s Open Records law.
•	Colorado Shield Law.  I represented the Colorado Broadcasters Association and the Colorado Press Association in drafting and successfully lobby for passage of Colorado’s Shield Law that limits subpoenas on reporters. 
•	Children’s Hospital Colorado.  As an officer and executive committee member, I helped guide Children’s Hospital through its move from downtown Denver to the Fitzsimmons campus in Aurora.  This work included raising $325 million, multiple zoning and construction issues, and presentations to various constituents and interest groups.
•	Family Futures.  As a founding member and Board Chair, I formed a coalition of more than 20 non-profit organizations to help children and families lift themselves out of poverty.  We obtained a $5 million federal grant, coordinated the efforts of the non-profit providers, and delivered comprehensive services.
•	Qualistar (originally known as Educare).   As a founding member, the Vice Chair and general counsel, I helped create an organization that provided quality ratings to early childcare providers and advocated for quality early childcare.  Our work led to public kindergarten for 4-year-olds in Denver, and to a State-funded childcare rating system.
•	Colorado Storm Soccer.  As a Board Member and Chair of the Fields committee, I built a 20-field soccer complex at Arapahoe and Parker Roads - the Gates Complex.  I was the Chair of the committee that had the idea, obtained the land and water rights, raised the money, and built the complex.  
•	KIPP Colorado.  KIPP is a public charter school network, serving more than 80,000 underserved children around the country, including 2,500 students in Colorado.  As a Board Member and then Board Chair of KIPP Colorado, I helped to grow and expand our school network from 4 to 6 schools, and developed plans for continued expansion.
org_list:
As reflected in the attached resume, I have been on 11 non-profit boards over the last 25 years, including serving as Chairman of three:  KIPP Colorado (a charter school system with 6 schools and 2,500 students), Colorado Storm Soccer Association (a youth soccer club with over 10,000 players), and Family Futures (a coalition of more than 20 non-profits created to study families in poverty)

     Since November 10, 2015, I have served as the Treasurer and then Chairman of KIPP Colorado (2014-18), and the Treasurer of Aurora Community Connection (2018-19).  I am currently on the Board of Directors for Colorado United Soccer Club (a youth soccer club with 4,000 players).
analytic_skills:
As a general rule, lawyers must analyze facts and apply legal rules to those facts.  I have received honors and awards for my legal skills, as reflected in the attached resume.  The attached letters further discuss my analytic skills and abilities.

     The redistricting commissioners will probably need to analyze large sets of data that can be organized and interpreted in different ways.  In this regard, a large portion of my legal practice involved complex commercial cases with experts on both sides in economics, statistics and complex accounting transactions.  I have examined and cross examined many, many data experts.  In one typical case, I represented an engineering company in a suit against 7 employees who left without notice and took my client’s business unit.  I challenged the opposing economist’s damages model at trial by substituting different assumptions he had endorsed in other cases.  On the witness stand, he revised his calculation from $1 million in damages to $3.6 million in damages for my client.  I also handled multiple class actions involving securities fraud, anti-trust violations, medical billing and consumer protection.  In each of those cases, we analyzed large sets of data to support or oppose various positions.
consensus_statement:
I believe I will be able to promote consensus because I have substantial experience forging agreements with groups holding divergent interests.  That experience has shown me the importance of relationships and of always following a principled approach in these situations.

     Experience.  As a litigation attorney, my job was to resolve disputes.  Although I went to trial more than many litigators, I settled more than 90 percent of my cases.  Thus, I spent the vast majority of my 30-year career developing the relevant facts and then reaching agreements based on those facts.  I have been through hundreds of formal mediations and thousands of informal dispute resolution processes.  

     My service on numerous non-profit boards, often struggling through complex community problems, has further prepared me to build consensus and create agreements among groups with divergent interests.  

     I also have experience forging agreements among groups of particularly intense advocates - namely, lawyers.  I was on the management committee for Davis, Graham & Stubbs in 1999 and 2000, a period during which the firm moved to LoDo and changed its compensation structure.  Managing the firm through those changes was often challenging, but the firm nonetheless thrived though that period.  Thereafter, I faced similar challenges and found consensus as the managing partner of two smaller firms.

     Relationships.  In any effort to build consensus among divergent interest groups, the key is to develop relationships with the other decision-makers.  These come, in part, through developing friendly personal connections.  More importantly, however, good relationships come from listening and showing understanding of other positions, and then being consistent, truthful, respectful and principled in all of one’s own communications.  This builds credibility with the group which is indispensable to creating agreements.  Many of my best friends were opposing counsel in litigation.  Similarly, many people have disagreed with me on community boards over the years, but those disagreements did not injure our relationships because they knew I had listened to them, understood them, and taken credible positions based on the facts.  

     Principled approach.  When individuals or groups disagree, two steps help create agreements: (1) focus on the parties’ respective interests, (2) identify broader principles on which the parties have common interests.  Often, if the parties agree on broader principles, they share interests and a consensus can emerge.  For example, when Children’s Hospital had to decide whether to move to Fitzsimmons, many doctors, medical practices and administrators resisted the change.  When we first affirmed our shared interests in providing the best health care possible to sick children, the decision to move followed fairly easily.  When setting partner compensation at a large firm, it was useful to first affirm the shared interest of enhancing the stability and security of the firm by rewarding those who developed new business.

     Of course, compromises are often necessary to reach agreements.  However, when agreements are reached based on shared principles, those compromises take on a different character.  When compromises reflect a shared principle that can and will be used to inform resolution of the next dispute, they become more rational and focused on the greater good. 

     Fair and Impartial.   For many years, I was a serious soccer coach, earning advanced FIFA licenses and coaching highly competitive teams.  In the early years, I coached my son who played on the second team of six select teams in his age group.  I became infamous for moving him to the third team because I didn’t think he was one of my best 16 players.  That is, I cut my own son.  

     In my personal and professional life, I have always been principled, sometimes to a fault.  As a lawyer who holds a profound understanding of and respect for the rule of law, I believe I have not only the ability to be fair and impartial, but also an inescapable drive to make decisions impartially based on the facts and the applicable legal standards.

     In 2010, I applied for a position on the Colorado Supreme Court.  I was selected as one of the 10 finalists.  As part of that process, I was honored to receive letters of recommendation from three people with beliefs and backgrounds different than my own (attached):  a prominent Republican 10th Circuit judge, the President of the Colorado Hispanic Bar Association, and the President of the Colorado Women’s Bar Association.  They noted my respect for diverse points of view and my ability to be fair and impartial.

I have a calm personality - not one to get overly excited in tense situations which I imagine the work of this commission can generate. I am a good public speaker and have good advocacy skills to present the points that are critical to a decision on redistricting. My tenure as a court-martial judge was 10-years. That, together with having handled cases for the defense as well as for plaintiffs in lawsuits has given me a good balance.

statement: I have been teaching and discussing voting with people and students for over 35 years. It is a critical element of our democracy and I find it sadly frustrating that so many people choose not to participate, and yet, still want their voices heard somehow. After decades of discussions and study, I know that people fail to participate because they feel that their representatives don't listen or have their own agendas. I believe much of this attitude is the result of gerrymandering and it has caused great dissatisfaction among the voting population. All people want is for their vote to weigh equally with any one else's vote. Gerrymandering has inhibited fair elections in the US almost since our inception and it is simply time to put an end to this practice. It will encourage more people to participate and will result in more fairness in election results. Additionally, people are sick of the same representatives and senators representing them term after term. The system, as it stands now, is designed to encourage incumbents win re-election, which limits new ideas and voices in our system.
professional_background: This is an integral part of teaching the Social Sciences. My experience would be in the form of advocating for young people who have no political voice (students). I have done work such as this at many levels: individual, building, and district advocacy. I have also advocated for students with special needs an a myriad of forms in my community: private legal advocacy for one student whose special education rights were being violated, teaching teachers how to accommodate students with special needs in their classrooms through building and district in-service opportunities.
org_list: I was a member of the HOA in my neighborhood. I held the Code Enforcement position which required me to ensure that any changes to a home or a property fell within the HOA covenant guidelines.
analytic_skills: Throughout my career, I have been required to analyze data as it relates to my students and their progress. In the last decade of my career, there was a push to use data-driven instructional techniques. Testing data was examined to determine the needs and best fit for students in their educational choices. I used statistical data to determine basic knowledge, basic skills, comprehension checks, among other applications. I also kept statistical records as a Life Coach and Tutor to verify progress and skill completion.
consensus_statement: Promoting consensus is a time consuming, but necessary process. I believe a critical element is LISTENING to others to see where you can find agreement and then build from there. Compromise is often necessary and often leads to even better outcomes than those which might have been created independently. The purpose is to create an environment in which each person feels valued as a contributing member. This requires open and honest communication and keeping an open mind to others' ideas.
past_political_activity: My political activity has been limited due to my teaching position in D20. I deliberately remained "publicly" uninvolved in order to maintain neutrality in my classroom. Since retirement, I have contributed approximately $100 to the Joe Biden Campaign, 2020. Since 1980, I have participated in every election at Federal, State, and Local levels. I have voted at each level for republicans and democrats - depending on the position, the needs of the nation/state/city, my personal preferences, but primarily, character is my guide.

occupation: Executive Director, Assessment and Research, Colorado State University
education: I received my Bachelor's degree in Political Science from Colorado State University in 1974. I received my Master's in College Student Personnel Administration from Colorado State University in 1976. I received my PhD in College Student Personnel Administration from the University of Northern Colorado in 1987.
statement:
In 1969 I entered Colorado State University (CSU) as a Political Science major. My interest in the democratic process was strong then and has continued to grow. After working at CSU for 44 years and nearing retirement in May 2021 I have maintained my strong interest in volunteer public service and citizen participation in the political process. The Colorado Independent Redistricting Commission offers an excellent opportunity to serve the state of Colorado.

The commission provides a solution to promote fair redistricting. I have a strong belief that the process of redistricting should be guided by transparency and public input. Additionally, I believe that maps should fairly reflect the will of the voters and that the redistricting commission can improve outcomes and satisfaction across all stakeholders. Protecting the voting rights of persons-of-color, and balancing the preservation of communities of interest with the preservation of county and municipal boundaries is vitally important.

Serving on the commission requires the ability to be fair and impartial. For the past 30 years at CSU, I have served as an Equal Opportunity Representative on university search committees, a responsibility that has fairness and impartiality at its core. Additionally, my doctoral dissertation was on ethical decision-making. I taught an Ethics course at the graduate level for over ten years, conducted ethics workshops for the university and community, and presented on ethical decision making at conferences nationally and internationally. The quest for fairness has been a lifetime endeavor.

At CSU, I have served on a joint-appointment as both an administrator and faculty member for 37 years. In my faculty role I served as Program Chair for a Master’s program with over 30 faculty which required the ability to promote consensus and agreement on a daily basis. I was able to develop a collegial environment and build consensus on curricular development, course content, and student issues.  Effectively promoting agreement involved listening, collaboration, and clear communication.

For the past 12 years I have served at the Executive Director of Assessment and Research at CSU. A position that requires analytical skills and the ability to apply logic. The position involves analyzing numerous quantitative and qualitative research and assessment projects, evaluating programs and services, and guiding departments through their five-year program reviews. I have been very successful in using the data to help the institution increase its effectiveness and improve its programs. I also served at the Director of Research on the board of directors of the National Association of Student Personnel Administrators (NASPA), and chaired the Committee on Commissioned Research for the Association of College and University Housing Officers – International (ACUHO-I). In addition to analytical skills and the application of logic, the coin of the realm in all of these positions is trust and credibility.

I am currently working half-time and will be fully retiring from CSU at the end of May, 2021. I make the best of every day and look forward to contributing considerable time to the commission.

All my best,

David A. McKelfresh
professional_background: Prior to 2015 I was on the Board for the Larimer County Food Bank; the Fort Collins City's Affordable Housing Board; on the Board for the Centennial Children's Chorus; and the Board for the Lutheran Campus Ministry.
org_list: Member of NASPA - Student Affairs Administrators in Higher Education.

analytic_skills: My most relevant analytical skills in this context were gained through a data science program where we analyzed data of all types to create effective models. I founded a company where we create similar models for law firms to analyze their data. Additionally, while serving as the the Executive Officer for Recruiting Station Denver, it was my responsibility to divide up the areas of responsibility of the states of Colorado, Nebraska, Wyoming, and South Dakota into equitable sectors of population, by zip code, to allow for each recruiter to have a fair chance of writing their monthly quota of contracts. This directly translates into the districting problem set, because you have to come up with the most equitable division of population amongst areas, to include things that make an area a community and groping with large geographical areas.

I pride myself on being fair and impartial, to the point that when I answered questions truthfully, I was selected to sit on a jury, in a courtroom where I clerked for the judge, and where I answered that I has practiced recently as a criminal lawyer. I ended up serving as the foreman in that case and I believe we reached the correct result, which was a split verdict, since we were able to be fair and impartial.

education: University of Colorado at Denver- Bachelor of Arts Degree- Spanish ; Regis University- Master of Science Degree in Criminology; Capella University- Doctor of Philosophy in Human Services
statement: I want to serve on the commission, because it is truly a unique opportunity to be among a diverse group of professionals seeking to ensure that Colorado has fair voting districts. Why should you choose me? I know that there are a number of extremely qualified individuals that have already applied for the role; however, I would bring something a little different to the table. I have a Doctor of Philosophy Degree in Human Services, which provided me with the skills to critique incorporation of social justice matters and to evaluate concepts, skills, policies, and initiatives that are fundamental to human rights.  Aside from my formal education, I have lived abroad in Argentina and Mexico. I have a passion for advocating for disadvantaged and/or marginalized communities.  I would ensure that disadvantaged, marginalized, and other communities of interest are kept intact when possible.  I would work with others to understand their perspectives, and most importantly, I would engage the public and ensure that members of the public feel heard and valued.
professional_background: In my role as the President of the Aurora Public School Board, I have significant experience advocating for and considering the interests of community, students, teachers, and individuals with a vested interest in Aurora Public Schools.  I have organized community townhalls and partnered with a variety of individuals to ensure that people feel heard and have access to speak openly.  In addition, I have experience with unions and an in depth understanding of advocacy from that perspective.  I thoroughly understand the value of teamwork, and empathic response. Empathic response meaning, you listen to all sides for understanding, rather than to respond; even when you have difference of opinion.
org_list:
• Colorado Black Women for Political Action, Political Chair-2017-2019
• NAACP, Youth Committee Vice-Chair- 2017-2019

• Aurora Public School Board- President- 2017-2021

analytic_skills: I am able to analyze a situation extremely quickly, and work with others to accomplish goals. I know first-hand that change is sometimes necessary. Complacency breeds stagnation. There are several elements that are critical to the applying logic and reason in problem-solving. First, it is imperative that you are aware of the Commission’s mission and vision. It is also important to be aware of the gaps/flaws, and create goals that are aligned with the main focus of ensuring equality and adherence to federal laws. Building relationships and rapport is critical; furthermore, when building the infrastructure to emit change, it is critical that you are thinking of all of the people/populations your decision will affect (i.e. rural/urban/etc). Sometimes you have to problem-solve creatively, especially when there may be "red-tape" (I don't mean violating law). By problem-solving creatively, I mean by taking an environmental scan of the critical contingencies that may impact the decisions that will be made. One such example of my ability to apply logic and reason to a problem was during my tenure on School Board.  During a community engagement session, a group of community members disclosed that they were concerned about students often being pulled from their classrooms to interpret in elementary, middle, and high schools. My first step in analyzing the situation was to research whether the District had a policy that addressed this issue; I was unable to find such a policy. During one of our Board of Education meetings, I spoke with my colleagues about the community engagement session, the issue that was proposed. I suggested that we draft a policy to ensure that there was adequate interpretation that did not disrupt students learning environments. Although the Aurora Public School Board operates under a policy governance framework, the other board members voted in favor to allow myself, another Board Director, and the District lawyer to create such a policy. The policy was created and the Board unanimously voted in favor. Aurora is the first school district in the nation to have a policy addressing this issue. Although this is one isolated example, I have a vast array of professional and personal experience with applying logic to situations and analytical skills.
consensus_statement: My ability to be fair and impartial is best portrayed in my role as the President of the Aurora Public School Board.  The role of a School Board Director is unique, we are nonpartisan, elected officials that have one sole job: To improve student outcomes.  In that role, it is important to understand that it is not possible to please everyone; however, you have to be willing to listen to differing perspectives.  You have to be accessible and open to engage judiciously and democratically.
past_political_activity: Past political activity includes running for Aurora Public School Board in 2017. I have also supported several democratic campaigns in the past. I have supported/donated to the following campaigns: Nicole Johnston, Crystal Murillo, Omar Montgomery, Allison Hiltz, Shontel Lewis, Juan Marcano, Bryan Lindstrom, Janet Buckner, Hillary Clinton, Kamala Harris, Joe Biden, and Cary Kennedy. I have also supported/donated to the following organizations: Emerge Colorado; Millennial Action Project; Working Families; and Planned Parenthood.

Therefore, I want to participate in the process of redistricting to ensure that the new lines are drawn fairly, reducing the degree to which voters are “packed” or “cracked” along party, racial, economic or religious lines. I want each district to reflect the variety of electors that inhabits it so that votes matter equally and that the result of an election truly reflects the opinions of the voters in that area and across the state.

statement: I believe that there is work to be done to serve our families and our communities. My husband and my best friend do not share my political affiliation, and yet I know we share values.  I work hard to understand their positions, to find common ground, and to accept our different view points with grace, compassion, and respect - and I politely insist that they treat me with the same consideration.

occupation: I am currently retired but provide consulting support to the company I previously owned, Meeting the Challenge. I founded MTC in 1989. The company provides information and support for businesses, individuals, and state and local governments related to federal disability laws. I sold the company in 2018 and have been a consultant since that time.
education: I graduated from the Ohio State University in June 1972 with dual bachelor’s degrees in aerospace engineering and in computer & information science.
statement:
I believe that the process of creating districts for state legislature and national representatives has long been one that was hidden from public view. Whichever party was in the majority used its position to carve up the state to its own advantage. I believe the process should be open to and performed by the general public, and it's the reason I voted for the propositions to move the process to the citizens in 2018. It is also the primary reason for my interest in serving on the commission.

The 2020/21 redistricting for Colorado will be more difficult than the past several decennial redistricting efforts. Colorado has seen significant increases in its population since 2000 and the population has migrated within the state as well. Colorado’s increased population makes it highly likely that we will gain a U.S. House of Representatives seat and the allocation of seats in the state house and senate will also be significantly modified. For these reasons I think the redistricting commissions’ actions will be challenging. 

I believe that my analytical and organizational skills developed from my academic background in engineering as well as my real-life experience organizing and managing a company and a nonprofit give me the necessary qualifications to participate. I don't believe it's enough to merely shout about why something is a problem. When the opportunity presents itself, it is important to step up and offer your capabilities to improve the situation.
professional_background:
The founding and management of my company, Meeting the Challenge, certainly is my greatest example of all these areas. MTC competed for and was awarded a federal contract to operate the Americans with Disabilities Act Information Center for the six-state Rocky Mountain Region in 1991 and continues to operate the Center today. The company grew from a single person to over 20 employees and expanded its operations to organizations across the country. 

I would also point to my organization of the All Colorado Beer Festival as an example of my organizational skills. The ACBF's 1st festival in November 2013 attracted just under 1,000 patrons and 19 brewers and donated $10,000 to local nonprofits. In 2016 the festival had grown to over 2,600 attendees and 75 brewers. We donated $85,000 that year. Organizing an all-volunteer organization to produce such an event is a challenge on many levels.
org_list:
I was the chairman of the Struthers Ranch HOA in 2016/17. 

I founded the All Colorado Beer Festival in 2013 and continue as the chairman of the board for the organization. The ACBF is a 501 (c)(3) charitable organization that raises money for local nonprofits by staging beer festivals. The ACBF raised and distributed over $500,000 during its 12 years of active operations. 

I was on the advisory board for the Home Front Cares from 2016 through 2019 and on its case review committee in 2018 and 2019. THFC gives grants to veterans and active duty military who have financial difficulties of many kinds. 

From 1974 through the present I have been a member of Theatreworks in Colorado Springs. I was a long-time board member, a technical director for several productions, and part time development director for the organization.
analytic_skills: My training is as an engineer. I deal in analysis and logic. I have applied this training in nontraditional areas. Whether it was the founding and operation of a company devoted to disability rights, a beer festival to raise money for nonprofits, or our HOA, I have used my analysis and logic skills from engineering to present data for others to consider and from that data to build consensus for moving forward.
consensus_statement:
While I have strong views in politics - I am a registered Republican - my political outlook is more libertarian. I believe this outlook allows me to see the positions of both left and right more objectively. My goal if selected for the commission will be to move the process forward by listening to all comments and positions and to present my view objectively. Most people can come to consensus when provided with facts even when that consensus is not entirely their opinion. Several of my past experiences have helped me develop my consensus-building skills.

I was active in the Association of Computing Machinery starting in 1982. ACM is one of the largest professional computing societies in the world with over 80,000 members. I became the chair of the Special Interest Group (SIG) on computing and disability in 1987 and the chair of the SIG Council of over 50 individual SIGs in 1991. As the chair it was my responsibility to run semi-annual meetings of all the SIG chairs and ensure that all the disparate views and needs of the SIGs were fairly represented. In 1992 I was elected as vice president of the entire ACM organization. My experiences at ACM, while somewhat in the past helped me to understand how to get large groups of very disparate individuals to come to consensus.

From 1994-1999, I sat on two federal advisory committees to establish accessibility standards for electronic and information technology and facilities. I was a member of the U.S. Access Board’s Americans with Disabilities Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) Review Committee which was responsible for a complete assessment and rewrite of the ADAAG. The process took two years and required consensus-building to ensure that the new standards met the needs of the various disability groups while still being feasible for the construction industry. The Committee received the National Performance Review Award from Vice President Gore. I was also a member of the U.S. Access Board’s committee on Accessible Electronic and Information Technology and was on the ANSI A117.1 Working Group on dwelling unit accessibility.
past_political_activity:
I ran for and was elected as precinct chairman in the early 1980s and subsequently ran for and was elected as an elector to the district republican assembly and as an alternate to the state republican convention. 

In 1982 I attended a program oriented to teaching business-people and then encouraging them about running for public office. The program was organized by Steve Schuck. One of my co-students was Gale Norton who went on to hold positions in the U.S. Departments of Agriculture and Interior and then Colorado Attorney General. I worked on Steve Schuck’s campaign for Colorado Governor in 1986.

I chaired the unsuccessful primary campaign for district attorney Ed Arcuri in 1984 when he ran against longtime incumbent, Robert Russel. The race was close enough that it triggered a recount which I was required to monitor. Barney Iuppa defeated Russel in the general election.

I provided data analysis for several of Mike Bird’s campaigns for state house and senate in the 1980s.

I have not been active in politics since the 1990s.
