statement: I believe this is an opportunity to ensure each citizen of Colorado has their voice heard equally in our democracy. We stand at a moment in history in which we can leverage the power of incredibly large  data sets to disenfranchise whole segments of our population or use that same data to ensure a fair and equal opportunity voice in government and I would cherish the opportunity to use do the latter and truly build a more perfect political arena for the voters of Colorado.
professional_background: I have limited experience organizing in the political sphere, as I have spent most of my adult life traveling for work. I do however spend the majority of my free time reading up on the issues and staying in tune with state and local politics in Colorado and Denver. I primarily concern myself with Denver as I am a resident here, and wish to best understand how to influence my local community.
analytic_skills:
I have a background in data analysis, having implemented a fundamental approach to sales measurement and analysis to my most recent team. I approach data challenges and logic problems similarly, looking first for the simplest ways to cut the data to get meaningful insights that can lead to better outcomes, only after exhausting the simple data analysis do I wish to move onto a more complex analysis. If you can address easy problems first, you will be able to build upon that data model to address harder problems later on while also making critical improvement along the way.

I am an adherent of the teaching of behavioral economics, and try to understand how to overcome the inherent shortcuts in thinking to overcome bias and ensure the decisions I make are well reasoned and based upon sound processes, even if the outcomes are not always perfect.
consensus_statement:
My professional background is change management, and I have spent my career working to bring people along difficult changes in their workplaces. This has equipped me with skills and experience working with people who are extremely resistant and highly motivated to work against the changes. But I have been successful in building coalitions of support to bring them into the fold. My strongest leadership traits are empathy, relationship building and understanding context. It is these three strengths that I think would be most important to building consensus and agreement on the commission. Building trust and strong relationships among the other commissioners will help ensure that the commission moves forward with a unified vision for Colorado. 
I do believe my relative inactivity in the public political sphere in Colorado to date is a benefit in this area as I do not bring potential baggage of previous negative interactions with other commissioners from having worked on opposing sides of other issues. This, along with my historic ability to quickly build and foster friendly working relationships with others based upon empathy and understanding lead me to believe I would be able to help build consensus on the commission. In regard to being fair and impartial, I certainly hold my own beliefs and political views, but I try to challenge those regularly to ensure they are still the views I believe in. But ultimately, being a commissioner is not about my views and what I want politically, it is about representing the people of Colorado in the fairest way and ensuring each citizen not on the commission is equally and fairly represented as we review and propose redrawn districts throughout the state. I believe strongly in "voice of the customer" in changes as a way to keep your own desires out of the final product, and ultimately, all Coloraoans are the "customers" of this commission.
past_political_activity: Small donations to both John Hickenlooper's Presidential and Senatorial campaigns.

statement:
I want to serve for many of the same reasons that I served on the school board while working full-time and holding down an extra job as a PT community college instructor: I love Colorado and want everyone who lives here to thrive. Complaining about what is wrong with government does nothing to improve its functionality; only putting our shoulders to the wheel to make it turn--no matter how slowly or seemingly imperceptibly--can ultimately effect positive change and improve lives. I grew up in a family of eight children and learned early on that if I wanted to accomplish something, I had better work for it, and my work ethic has served me extremely well for 50+ years.
Furthermore, in Tom Noel's excellent reference, Colorado: A Historical Atlas, "Dr. Colorado" explains and lays out the background in text and maps of our congressional districts from 1893 to the present. The new commission will create the seventh iteration but be the first to do so with balanced citizen input and perhaps, with less of a political focus. And with Colorado's growth since 2010, it is highly likely that an 8th district will be created. While all politics in our large state may not be local, it is certainly regional, and I fully believe that this type of work is work that makes a difference for our state and how fully and fairly its people can be represented in Congress.

Another important point is that as a teacher of many decades, I'm still a believer in doing homework;  while I'm rarely if ever the smartest person in the room, I am sometimes the hardest worker and do a lot of background research to find the best, most accurate solutions or approaches to the issue at hand. I read and absorb information well, make notes, come prepared, and this has been one of the not-so-secret reasons for my success. It is unfortunate, but I have seen many people in positions of power who have *not* done their homework and have thus made poor decisions based on a kneejerk or purely partisan perspective. This cannot be the case on this extraordinarily important venture that Colorado is undertaking. Once the Commission reworks the current gerrymandering of our state, we will have better government; this I truly believe or I would not be willing to put in the great amount of time that this commission will require of me. Luckily, I am in great health and have a positive attitude, so I am up to the challenge!
professional_background:
My primary experience has been on the Durango 9-R School Board, where we seven and then five board members advocated for and considered the interests and needs of students, teacher, classified staff, business leaders, and the community as a whole. Durango prides itself for being extremely community-minded and has a robust interest in its schools and how they are managed. We are a "purple" area with a liberal bentin town proper and many more conservative-minded folks on the "Dry Side" i.e. the more agricultural areas of Durango. Thus, we must consider widely varying points of views and vastly differing needs of students and their families. Fort Lewis College, a liberal arts college moving into more vocational programming, has a 40%+ Native American student population and many faculty and staff with children in the public schools, and this adds its own dimension and diverse perspective. 

Furthermore, we have three charter schools and were the first district to include the charters in our bond issues because those families also pay taxes and it's only fair that they then be included in the allotment of funds. As the former program manager for the local adult education center for the high school equivalency (GED) program, I am also a stalwart supporter of making educational opportunities available and free or inexpensive for adults who left high school before graduation. A more educated Colorado populace creates a stronger, healthier citizenry. I believe in second and third chances for adults attaining more education because I understand that "there but for fortune go I," and the world we live in requires that we all be really flexible, nimble, and capable of accepting and embracing change but not just to jump on a passing educational trend; so much of our mental dexterity and lifelong learning habits depend on our educational system!
org_list:
Durango 9-R School Board member, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer at various times, 2012--2019
Build a Better Colorado member since its inception
CAEPA member and prior Secretary [Colorado Adult Education Professional Association]  
Methodist Thrift Shop volunteer librarian
La Plata County Democrats Executive Council and Outreach Coordinator
I have donated blood four-five times annually since the late 1980s.
analytic_skills:
For many years, I taught research and essay writing skills, from my first position in Parachute, Colorado with fifth graders through to several high school jobs and many colleges, including Pueblo Community College here in Durango. These analytical skills transfer to the same kind of work the commission will be asked to do. We have a problem/challenge to address, so the first step will be the gathering, reading, and digesting of a great amount of information--population demographics, predicted growth/shrinkage of population; changing economic forces and patterns, immigrant influence--etc. Just obtaining and then parsing clear and accurate information itself will be a challenge, and that is why having a balanced group of folks is so essential to the whole process. I expect this phase to take several months, and as we meet we will try out possible options/solutions/compromises and listen to the obvious and less apparent counter arguments/points of view. As Donald Rumsfeld noted, "there are known knowns; there are things we know we know. We also know there are known unknowns; that is to say we know there are some things we do not know." And of course, there are things we don't know that we don't know, and that point leads to one of the ultimate goals of our work on the commission--to have the people of Colorado across this entire state tell us what we don't know that we didn't realize we did not know so that we factor in the critical and important information that all of our diverse regions face.

Again, as a teacher of both writing and literature, my understanding of inference and implication will be useful as will defining our terms and having a full understanding of the history and politicization of the congressional redistricting and other problematic aspects.

We will ask ourselves and one another, as well as the Coloradans we visit with and listen to across the state, important  questions and gather those answers, seeking patterns that reveal potential changes where they will benefit our citizens. We will push for brainstorming unanticipated consequences of whatever decisions we might arrive at as a group. We will set ground rules/expectations that examine biases and how to put them aside to achieve the greater good of the commission.

Interestingly, I have faced this problem/solution/question within just the past few months with friends and colleagues who say that they will sit out the 2020 election, a position I can empathize with but not accept easily. All of the skills I have mentioned are ones I have employed, and I am pleased to say that a few people have left the table saying that now they are not sure whether they will indeed sit out this election year after all.
consensus_statement:
This is perhaps the most critical question you are asking of us as applicants because without consensus, that wheel I wrote of earlier can get awfully jammed. On the many groups I have served in my 20 years in Durango, I learned how to listen and take notes as a way to force myself to hear accurately what the speaker is saying. My nearly 8 years on the school board reinforced this skill and while the board did not always reach consensus or meet our superintendent's exact wishes, we generally functioned well and moved the district forward to strengthen student achievement, pass major bonds and deal with controversial issues well. As a Democrat who believes that clear, factual information is essential, I will help my group, where necessary when we hit a difficult impasse, to work through decisions as rationally as possible, not based on an intense personal or political agenda.

My background as a program manager who managed nine employees at one time also serves me well. We were a wonderful team at the adult ed center but of course, not all the teachers or support staff agreed all of the time, and employees occasionally clashed. As a result, I learned how to bring conflicting factions together and had them each tell their story. This alone created empathy and a new willingness to understand the other's perspective. Listening really does matter. Doing one's homework really does matter. Being willing to compromise and not having to win at all costs really does matter.

Lastly, I served on a federal jury about ten years ago. It was quite an extraordinary case, and I am so proud of how I was able to persuade the lone holdout who did not want to convict the rapist; he kept asking "why didn't she cry out or try to escape?" This gentleman was only familiar with the flight or fight condition that people in extreme danger or assault often take; he knew nothing about the "freeze" mentality that occurs, especially with victims of sexual assault. Rather than yelling at this man or telling him he was stupid or insensitive, I explained quietly about this third "freeze" state, and he was thankful for the information, and we went back into the courtroom and convicted a very dangerous and violent person. Letting people voice their concerns, listening well, and responding in a way that shows you heard them--not that you were merely waiting your turn to counter--can move that collective wheel forward so that we accomplish our goal for that session/meeting/day.
past_political_activity: I don't recall all of my donations since 2015 but I have contributed since 2019 to  the Flip the Senate campaign, Joe Biden, John Hickenlooper, Barbara McLachlan, Diane Mitsch Bush, Marsha Porter-Norton, and Matt Salka.

occupation: KL&A Engineers & Builders in Golden, CO.
education:
Master's degree in structural engineering from the University of Colorado in Boulder (2020)
Bachelor's degree in civil engineering from Colorado State University in Fort Collins (2018)
statement:
I would like to serve on the commission because I want to ensure that the representative district boarders are drawn fairly without the effects of gerrymandering. As an unaffiliated voter, generally displeased with the two party system, I am interested in making sure the Colorado State representatives in congress are elected fairly and competitively. 

Colorado unfortunately has a history of gerrymandering in order to give one political party more power over another. Districting commissions often also re-draw districting lines in order to protect their own seat (or the incumbent member of their party) in office. These tactics need to stop in order for the voice of the people of Colorado to truly be heard. If the districts are organized such that the representative earns the votes of their constituents. This is very important to me as a Colorado voter because not only to I want my voice to be heard, but I want to ensure the same for my fellow Coloradans. Especially if Colorado is to obtain an eighth seat in the House of Representatives. 

The great President John F. Kennedy said, “Let us not seek the Republican answer of the Democratic answer, but the right answer. Let us not seek to fix the blame for the past. Let us accept our own responsibility for the future.” My primary goal as a member of this commission will be to seek that right answer. I love this state, and I believe that the governmental tactics and changes taking place here in Colorado have been and continue to be a model for the nation. That is why I am interested in serving on the commission, not only to serve my state but to serve my country.
professional_background: As a general contractor, it was important to maintain a positive relationship with all of the trade partners working on site to keep them coordinated and functional. As a project engineer with Martines Palmeiro Construction (MPC) I had to advocate for both the organizations who worked under mine and our clients in the day-to-day tasks in the field. Often times a trade partner would interfere with another trade partner’s work for their own convenience. I had to ensure that the best interests of all the trades were executed in order maintain a functional site. Furthermore, it was also my responsibility to ensure that the best interests of the owner were being executed despite the fact that the owner was not present on site. Nearly all of the trade partners I worked with are based in Colorado, as many of them are small businesses in the Denver area.
org_list:
I spent the majority of the past five years since November 10, 2015 as a student at both Colorado State University (CSU) in Fort Collins and University of Colorado (CU) in Boulder. Because of this most of my public involvement was within my university community. At CSU I served as student ambassador for the College of Engineering, which I belonged to. As an ambassador I worked primarily with high school students considering majoring in engineering, at CSU or otherwise. I gave advice to these students as they made their college decisions and offered my perspective to them as both an engineering student and as a CSU Ram. 

At the end of my undergraduate education at CSU, I joined a professional origination known as the Order of the Engineer. This is an organization that upholds the ethical standards of engineers in our society. As many people entrust their lives with the structures and technology designed by engineers, this organization continuously reminds them of the responsibly they hold.

In graduate school at CU, I earned a scholarship from the Structural Engineers Association of Colorado (SEAC) and have attended a number of meetings and site visits with the organization since. Although I am not an official SEAC member, I am currently considering joining this organization as well.
analytic_skills:
Being a structural engineer, logic and reason come very naturally to me. I am a fast learner and an analytical thinker. I am exceptionally good at Excel and I enjoy solving mathematically interesting problems. I am also a young and enthusiastic individual who likes a good challenge. 

When I was a graduate student at CU, I had to apply these skills to my research project in order to report accurate and unbiased results. For this project, I was tasked investigating the effects of a polymer additive on the freeze-thaw properties of concrete. To do this, I had to college and analyze a significant amount of data over the course of several months. I also had to write and defend my thesis in front of several faculty members and concrete experts to prove my results were valic. I would take a similar approach to the task of re-districting Colorado. My “data collection” phase would involve hearing the voices of my fellow Coloradans scattered throughout the state. My “analysis” phase would be the actual re-drawing of the district lines with the assistance of the other commissioners. And finally my “defense” phase would be to convince and mediate among the other members of the committee.
consensus_statement:
As a member of the commission, I will advocate for the use of the shortest-split line method to divide the voters throughout the state into fairly divided, equally populated areas. The use of this algorithm is at least a good place to start, because it uses a mathematical method that is free of bias. I would also use that as an argument among the other commissioners, because you can’t argue with math. As an engineer, I am good at both being analytical and convincing of an impartial answer. 

Next, I think it’s worth considering the cultural density of the various areas of the state. For example, because Baca County and Prowers County are culturally similar to each other, it may make sense to group them together in the same district. However, it is important to make sure there is a healthy amount of competition for the candidates running to represent these districts. For example if it is known that the majority of voters in Weld County are Republicans and the majority of voters in Larimer County are Democrats, it may make sense to group Weld and Larimer County together in the same district to encourage both the Republican and Democratic candidates for that district to campaign harder to earn their votes.
past_political_activity:
In the past five years, I have been interested but not heavily involved in political activities outside of voting. I have not given money to any organizations other than the perchance a Marco Rubio bumper sticker in 2016. At the end of 2019 I also signed a petition in Colorado that put Proposition 115 on the 2020 ballot and made a $5 donation supporting the initiative 

Although I grew up in a mostly conservative household, I am an independent thinker who may align with the Libertarian party rather than the Democratic or Republican party. I even voted Libertarian in 2016 because I felt that both of the two major candidates were not representative of how most people in America think. But because I do not want to subject myself a political party, I am an unaffiliated citizen and have chosen to apply for this commission as such.

occupation: Retired - part time adjunct professor
education:
J.D. Washington Univ. in St. Louis 
B.A. Benedictine Univ. (formerly Ill. Benedictine College)
40 hour mediation certificate
statement: I am a mediator and a lawyer, but my instincts have always been towards the mediation side. I believe in bringing parties together to talk about issues and find mutually beneficial solutions to difficult problems. Our country has drifted apart lately and I want to help find ways to move us closer together so that we can function as one country and one state.  This commission is an opportunity to have substantive discussions with people on the other side of issues. To find our commonalities and to work through our differences so that we can have fair districts for future elections.
professional_background: I served as the President of AFGE Local 3607 and as President of AFGE Council 238 representing employees of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). I served on Lakewood City Council from 2007 -2015.
org_list: Chair of Metro West Housing Solutions; Member of: Colorado Bar Association, AFGE Local 3607, Colorado Peaches senior softball team, Rocky Mountain Ukulele Orchestra, West Colfax Community Association; Volunteer for: 40 West Arts District, Jefferson County Democratic Party
analytic_skills: I am a trained attorney and practiced for 30 years. I currently teach Environmental Law at DU as an adjunct professor. The skills I developed in my profession require one to deeply analyze issues and to apply reason and logic. I have always considered myself a problem solver, not a bomb thrower. I welcome creative solutions to complex issues and do not have a desire to win at all costs. I believe that win/win solutions are possible and necessary to move our state foward.
consensus_statement: I will use my mediation skills to listen to everyone, especially those with views that differ from my own. I will search for issues and concerns that we have in common and use them as the basis for reaching a consensus. I also believe that competitive districts give the voters more choices in candidates and help to move both sides towards the middle, where most America resides.  I have the ability and disposition to work with people on the other side of issues. I showed that when I represented EPA employees in the union and actively worked with management to find solutions that worked for both sides.  I grew up in rural America, but have spent most of my adult life in urban communities, but I remember my roots and have a deep understanding of the wants and needs of rural communities.  I believe that this urban/rural divide drives much of the conflict in our country and that we need to find a way to bridge the understanding gap between these two groups.
past_political_activity: I donate money regularly, primarily to Democratic candidates. analytic_skills:
As a judge I was somewhat constricted by the rules of evidence, precedential case law,  statutory provisions
and applicable burdens of proof in determining an appropriate outcome. That process and analysis is linear
and somewhat constrictive. In my mediation practice I must make the parties aware of possible outcomes from
judges who would be bound in that same process. In suggesting alternative resolutions I am not so bound. It is
refreshing for me and useful to engage in non-linear mode, where possible, to pull the parties together.
consensus_statement: As to the first inquiry, I've been engaged as a mediator from 2003 to the present. As to any given case that requires me to take into account all the information furnished by both sides, to listen attentively to the arguments from both sides, and to suggest possible alternatives in pursuit of an outcome acceptable to both parties. As to the second inquiry, my service as a district judge in Colorado for 22 years required me to be, and I was, fair and impartial. Please see attachments that attest to that.

consensus_statement: I have had extensive experience bringing disparate groups together—in fact groups that were vigorous competitors—when having to Integrate different management teams in three different large ($2, $4 and $10 billion transactions during my 16 years in different Coors entities) transactions. The most important elements in these efforts were to 1) listen intently to others’ points of view; 2) engage and excite others in generating new, value-added ideas, 3) always asking the exciting and important question, “what can we achieve together that we otherwise couldn’t achieve apart ?” With our country, and even to some extent our State of Colorado, so divided, I believe with all my energy that we have to do a much better job advancing and promoting listening to and compromising with those with whom we initially may not agree.

occupation: Retired from State of Colorado where I held several management positions in my 30 plus years of service, working with low-income adults and children, people with disabilities, seniors, while balancing the needs of the Medicaid or Human Services Agencies.  I currently volunteer with Colorado Senior Lobby, an all volunteer, non-partisan non-profit, who provides educational programs regarding how to be your own best advocate at the legislature, we educate the legislature on the needs of older adults throughout the state, and provide updates on the benefits that older adults contribute to their communities and the state.
education:
CSU - BS Communication Disorders,  minor Psychology 1980 
Barnes Business College - Computers - 1988 Certificate
statement: Serving on this commission will provide a voice for the older adults in Colorado and those who may not have a voice of their own.  I want to see my community and Colorado come together in a fair and equitable way.  It's important to have fair and equal representation in each of the Congressional Districts.  Having lived in CD 7, 2 and 3 I have a good understanding of the similarities and differences in each district.   But more importantly, I am familiar with each of the counties in Colorado and their unique needs and how important the local control is to their citizens.  I want to assure that all are represented in the redistricting.
professional_background: My past position as the Director of Aging and Adult Services for the Colorado Department of Human Services, I advocated for Older Adults, Adults with Disabilities, and low-income adults.  I worked closely with the County Departments of Human Services, Area Agencies on Aging, Aging Disability Resource Centers, Independent Living Centers, community providers, State Legislators, other State Departments, advocate groups, the Colorado Commission on Aging, Colorado Cross Disability Coalition and stakeholders.  I am the Legislative Committee co-chair and on the Board of Colorado Senior Lobby for the past 6 years, but a member for 20 years.  I provide training to older adults on how to advocate for themselves and others at the legislature and in their communities.  I have worked for 30+ years serving individuals with disabilities, low-income families, older adults, and school age children.  I toured Colorado doing listening sessions and getting feedback from older adults, service providers, family members and  social service agencies prior to the White House Conference on Aging, then I was selected by the chair of the White House Conference to represent Colorado at this event which is held every 10 years.  After the Conference, I was instrumental in keeping the momentum going, by providing feedback to those who I met with before the conference and formed the "SilverPrint Colorado" entity.  This group had members throughout Colorado working on areas of health care, community engagement, protection and support for at-risk adults, ageism in the workforce and workforce issues for older adults, and transportation.  Throughout my life I have worked to make life easier for those who need and want the help.  In the PTA, I started a parents group for single parents to help them/us with the stresses of life, the issues our children had and to know that "you are not alone" in the journey.
org_list: Adams County Democratic Party, Precinct Chair; Colorado Democratic Party,  Colorado Senior Lobby- Board Secretary, Legislative Committee Co-Chair, Capital Gang Leader; Visiting Nurse Association- Foot Clinic; Direct Care Workforce Working Group - HCPF;  Polis/Primavera Campaign, Rolling Hills HOA - Swimming Pool Design Committee & Social Committee
analytic_skills: As the Director of Aging for the Colorado Dept of Human Services, it was my responsibility to provide budget forecasting for the programs to the Ex. Director, the Joint Budget Committee, and the Office of State Planning and Budgeting, and to the State Auditors.  I have analytical skills, reasoning skills, good communication skills, consensus building skills, and am a creative thinker.  I am able to be detailed oriented as well as being able to see the big picture.  I have used mentoring, guidance, support, brainstorming as well as logic to be able to discuss different ideas and practices.  Between working with the state programs and working closely with school administrators, teachers and parents, I know how to bring people together to arrive at a decision that all can accept.  This doesn't mean that one side gets everything they want, it means we all work to get to a position that we can all accept as being fair and equitable and it can be implemented in an appropriate manner.
consensus_statement: My 30 plus years of working for the State of Colorado in various  capacities and in different levels, I have worked well with others.  I started out working for the Developmental Disabilities programs, then moved to the Medicaid unit, and worked my way up to become the Director of Aging and Adult Services.  Throughout this time, I have worked with many community providers and clients to help them receive the most appropriate services for them and to help them understand the different programs available to them.  I worked with the County Departments of Human/Social  on providing education, receiving feedback and coming to consensus with program directors of the Medicaid and Human Services programs I worked, developed and administered.  It is important to remember that one size does not fit all of the state.  Colorado is very diverse and has different needs in each county.  I was able to work collaboratively with the Counties, service providers and clients to implement long-term care services in each county.  In the late 80's and early 90's when the Single Entry Points were being developed I was working with the different County Commissioners and County Directors to help divide the state into 23 different long-term service providers and case managers.  This was a difficult task as each County wanted to be the center, and some counties didn't want to partner and work with their neighboring counties.  In addition, when Medicaid started to serve clients through the HMOs I worked with various HMOs, state legislators, physician groups, and hospitals to make sure all services were provided to clients in all areas of the state.  Then when I served on the Colorado Commission on Aging representing CD3, which is a very large and diverse district, I needed to be sure that all the cities, counties, rural and urban areas were represented and needed to work with the other Commissioners who represented their CD.  The Commission had a Democrat and a Republican from each district and worked on consensus.
past_political_activity: HD 34 Kyle Mullica, SD  24 Faith Winter, Andrew Romonoff Primary Congressional Senate, Adams County Democratic Party, Colorado Democratic Party, Congressional Senate Democratic Party

analytic_skills: Whenever approaching a problem, I consult existing reputable and peer-reviewed research and knowledge on the topic, talk to peers, and reflect on my own experiences (and how that might color my perspective). Considering all of these pieces, I often also conduct my own research, through surveys, comparisons, or other methodology, to ensure I am on the right track. I firmly believe in a data-driven approach to applying best practices. That also means that if the data shows something to be ineffective, then I make adjustments, no matter how committed I was to the process originally. Additionally, I always try to look at the complete picture before forming decisions, not jumping to conclusions or making assumptions.
consensus_statement: With my volunteer work, I facilitate difficult discussions to deepen people's abilities to resolve conflicts and find consensus. Through my volunteer and professional work, I regularly practice and teach active listening, the process of consensus, and effective communication. I will apply these skills in the commission and work to understand what my peers are saying and where they are coming from, and clearly state my views, and work to identify the compromises and agreements between them. I practice fairness and impartiality in my life regularly, including taking steps to fully understand others' points of view. For instance, when arguing with friends or partners, I often do a mental exercise with a third party where I take the argument of my "opponent" and let the third party argue my side. This allows me to more completely understand their perspective and adjust my POV or argument to better resolve the conflict. This, along with active listening and a deep care for others and all humanity, has provided me with the skills to manage and develop all sorts of relationships. Although, I am a registered democrat, both of my parents and much of my family are ardent republicans and we regularly have civilized discussions and come to agreements on topics that we initially disagreed upon.
past_political_activity: My political activity is primarily within my circle of friends and family through discussion on politics and assisting others in conducting research on ballot initiatives to make informed votes. occupation: I am, at this moment, retired from the workforce
education: High School, some college in Small Business Management, CDIAA+ (Certified Document Imaging Architect), multiple Harvard based Managing/Mentoring Programs, Wilson Learning Writing training certificates
statement: Decades of gerrymandering by our two political parties have brought American's to the realization this is not healthy for our democracy. Local and state alignments should be competitive and not "safe" districts as this leads our elected officials to become detached from being more closely connected to the needs of their constituents.
professional_background: With my working career ending in 2018, I have become more involved in the Irish/American community and begun laying the groundwork for supporting mental health and preventing suicides in young people. This past summer, one of my interns from Northern Ireland was going to be assigned to a mental health support with the City of Broomfield when the pandemic cancelled those plans. My long term focus is to have this be a Colorado and Northern Ireland collaborative outreach to young people.
org_list:
I am the Colorado Coordinator for Project Children and have been for more than twenty years. This non-profit, HQ in New York, has been engaged in peace and reconciliation efforts in Northern Ireland for more than forty-five years, fostering ways to bring Catholic and Protestant children, and now university students, to find common ground. Our leader, Denis Mulcahy, a former NYPD Bomb Squad detective, has twice been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. 

I am also on the board of directors for the non-profit, Mile High Writers Group. An organization that helps writers improve their work and support efforts to become published authors.
analytic_skills: Recognizing a problem exists is the first step. This commission is that first step. The process is then determining a desired outcome to resolve the problem and the road to take to reach that point. Reaching the summit of all of Colorado's fourteen thousand foot mountains is not a straightforward process. Having achieved this feat, I learned along the way how to navigate where there was no clear path using a combination of assessment of the slope and whether it was attainable. If not, regroup and try another path. This metaphor reflects my ability to see a challenge, pay attention to the environment, test hypothesis, and focus on the task at hand. In a social situation, listening to the other person and determining what is actually being said, is critical to finding common ground. As the attached letters and my resume highlight, this is one of my strengths.
consensus_statement: I have been a life-long student of this country's history and that of my mother's home country, Ireland. Additionally, I have participated in finding, and providing for, common ground for young people to break down their walls of religious and political separation so they can build a more equitably functioning society. As in the negotiations of the Good Friday Agreement, led by Senator George Mitchell and later implemented by our own former State Department liaison, Jim Lyons, the key to any process of this importance is determining common understanding of terminology used by all interested parties. This lays the foundation for effective dialogue and negotiations. I have no interest in seeing this state, or country, reach the point where we no longer trust or have confidence in our elected officials. If we align our districts in a more competitive way and will draw greater participation from our citizens to participate in the process of the selecting candidates for office.
past_political_activity: Many years ago, in the 1980's, I was Chairman of the Speaker's Committee for the Republican Party in Va. Beach, VA. I attended their state convention and helped organize get out the vote in my community. As the party became more polarized, and I moved to Colorado in 1990, I dropped out of active participation and began voting Democratic. I have not been active in any party since I moved here.

occupation: Lawyer, self employed
education:
B.S. University of Texas 1980 and 
J.D University of Texas School of Law 1983
statement: Colorado is the best state in the union, we are a beacon of hope for the rest of the nation. We strive to organize our institutions to be fair and just. There is an area however, that could use some improvement. Denver is the Capital and has the population concentration of the entire state. The remaining parts of the state are rural and rural resorts. It is understandable that Denver would have an outsized role in our state, however in the interest of fairness, the rest of the state also needs representation. The Western Slope often does not have a big opportunity for input in policy making decisions. Additionally, the Western Slope is becoming more diverse every year and that diversity also needs to be considered. Through my involvement in various philanthropic activities and civic and political organizations, I have learned a great deal about the communities of the Western Slope and I would like to bring some of my experience and knowledge of the area into the discussions of the Redistricting Commission.
professional_background: Promoting social justice and advocating for others has been a large part of my life. Through my service with Alpine Legal Services, we were able to provide pro bono legal services for the extensive portion of our community who cannot afford legal services. Members of the community have often contacted me to assist them with other non-legal family issues. I have been able to assist them by connecting them with the constituent services of our elected officials, particularly with Senator Bennet's office dealing with immigration questions. When COVID began, we were very alarmed at the high percentage of Latinos who were contracting COVID in our community. I was able to have 18,000 masks donated and was able to connect the mask distribution with the Food Bank line in Rifle and Glenwood. When our son was enrolled in the Aspen Public Schools from kindergarten through high school I served on many Advisory Committees assisting the schools on many school projects. When it was reported that the Department of Homeland Security was detaining children at the border in cages, I volunteered to help with asylum cases in Texas at the El Paso and McAllen sites. I worked there under the auspices of The Center for Human Rights and Constitutional Law and under the American Bar Association's Pro Bar Legal Project. I am scheduled to continue to work on more asylum cases within the next few weeks.
org_list: Community service has been an important part of my life ever since I graduated from Law school. For many years, I was Chair of Alpine Legal Services which serves our Roaring Fork Valley from Rifle to Aspen. I am a former Board member of the Aspen Youth Center and of  the Aspen Valley Medical Foundation. I served on several Advisory Committees at the Aspen School District and chaired the successful bond election for the construction of the new Aspen Middle School. I presently serve on the Advisory Board of Aspen Words (Formerly known as the Aspen Writers Foundation) and I am excited to be one of the founding board members of the new Latino Advocacy group, Voces Unidas de las Montañas, where I serve as the Board Chair. I presently serve as Chair of Boldly Forward, a non-profit C4 which is an issues advocacy organization. I have also served on Governor Hickenlooper's Judicial Performance Commission and Governor Polis' Judicial Nominations Commission. I also served as Co-Chair of Governor Polis' Inaugural Committee.
analytic_skills: Developing your analytical skills and applying logic and reason to a problem was critical to being a successful law student. These skills were used throughout your assignments and exams. It has been my experience that once you are trained as a lawyer, your approach to your life changes. My law school training has taught me to approach most projects and problems in a certain step by step methodical way in order to complete the task or to achieve a solution. It is just second nature.
consensus_statement: I am the eldest of five children, building consensus and creating agreement was a mater of survival. Later, when I was in college, creating consensus was the best way to get your group project finished and submitted on time. Later, as I served on numerous boards, I learned that consensus building definitely made you a more effective board member. I consider myself a compassionate person. One of the basic characteristics of a compassionate person is to be fair and balanced. Being fair is also associated with being just, which is a trait found in thoughtful lawyers. Being fair and just to others is a goal I strive to meet every day.
past_political_activity: I have been very involved in politics at many levels, my entire life. I have been a grassroots community organizer for voter registration, phone banks, canvassing and postcard writing. My husband and I have also hosted several hundred political events in our home, some were fundraisers, many were "friendraisers". We have hosted events for Aspen City Council & Mayoral Candidates and Pitkin County Commissioners as well as state candidates at all levels including the Governors races. We have also hosted events for federal races for congressional, senatorial and Presidential candidates. I have contributed to many candidates and PACs  in Colorado at every level, city, state and federal. I have also contributed to candidates and PACs from other states.  I am attaching two documents which list the campaign contributions which I have made since 2015. I do not keep a list myself but I believe the bulk of my contributions, if not all my contributions are captured on these two lists.

Therefore in a job like this, I am prepared to go above and beyond in every way I possibly can, in order to create the best result possible for the People of Colorado.

It is just a matter of being persistent, and having the right resources to get through any challenge that we may be confronted with. (Note: for References please see my LinkedIn profile under linkedin.com/in/zviabird. Some are attached to my resume yet they may not be current phone numbers. )
consensus_statement:
Creating consensus is a key skill when working on any project, especially in Government. I have advocated for the citizens of Manitou Springs by attending numerous City Council meetings as a private citizen. This gave me the opportunity to make statements to our City Councilors in a respectful and concise way as Government officials have a very limited time to be briefed on the circumstances, review the information before making a decision. Further I am not intimidated by their status as a professional, an attorney, or whatever background they may come from, as I have worked with people from all walks of life including many celebrities. I am not swayed by anyone's position or power they yield, and I have excellent manners. I promote a win/win scenario in any transaction if possible, and will always keep in mind whom I would truly be serving, namely the people of Colorado in all its wonderful diversity. 
Therefore it is important that any personal political bias be left at home, no matter how passionate I might be about any party. We must work together as the American people. Being fair and impartial is a must in this type of work.

analytic_skills:
My 'first career' after college was in mapping and GIS, including working for the current 'National Geographer' at National Geographic (Alex Tait) when he ran his own cartography business.  During the summer of 1999, I spent my MBA internship working for Etak, an in-dash vehicle navigation company later sold to Tele Atlas/Tom Tom.  (Etak's work was the precursor to much of the google maps navigation technology we are all using today).  My focus there was on a geocoding plug-in used with ESRI's ArcView software.

The past 20 years I have been working in the private sector with businesses that, among other things, use GIS for marketing purposes. I solve problems like 'fine me daycares nears King Soopers in neighborhoods that index high on Hispanics'  This sort of project requires the collection of quality data, and the software necessary to analyze that data.  I think that my experience building high quality datasets and using tools to analyze them will come in handy when analyzing congressional districts.  [Note: I will not collect letters of recommendation at this stage unless I am told by someone reviewing this that it is important to my application.  If it is important, I will likely reach out to one or more of the following people: Gary Justus, neighbor, EMHA president, fellow EMHA board member during my tenure; Ingrid Mielke, principal, Parmalee Elementary; possibly Alex Tait, National Geographer, National Geographic. Not sure Alex has the time though!)
consensus_statement:
Have you ever been an HOA president?  It is a ton of work, largely thankless, and all about building consensus as best as possible.  In every community you have those people I call the 'spear throwers' who complain and do nothing to help.  I've managed the helpers, and managed the spear throwers.  I much prefer the helpers.  :) 

In the case of this commission, it certainly is easier to build consensus with people who are being paid!!!  Sort of like being a business owner, which I have been the past 13 years.

When it comes to being fair,

statement: I voted for this referendum when it was presented because I believe that there’s a better way to do redistricting than the highly charged political process that has been evident in past redistricting processes. I sat on the reapportionment commission in 1990 and experienced how difficult it was to reach consensus in a process that was designed to encourage political clashes between the two major parties. I thought then and I believe now that there must be a better way to do this and I am encouraged that this process will produce a much better product than what we have seen in the past. I thought then and I believe now that there must be a better way to do this and I am encouraged that this process will produce a much better product than what we have seen in the past.  Whether I am selected or not I believe that this process may be the salvation of our democracy, which I think is in serious danger we  don’t figure out how to work together.
professional_background: The best experience I have sitting on the Colorado Wildlife Commission. The commission is a combination of Democrats and Republicans who work together to manage the wildlife resources of the state of Colorado. Through this process I learn to work through issues with people of opposing opinions to find a middle ground that was beneficial to the wildlife resources of the state. I also sat on the board of trustees for Adams State University for eight years and was the chairman of the board for three consecutive years. This board is also made up of members who are from opposing  political  parties who also must work together to serve the best interest of the University. These two experiences have given me a tremendous insight into working with people of different backgrounds, different political parties and different philosophies. But through this I also learned the true, honest and constructive dialogue and keeping in mind the best interest of the resource/organization  can bring constructive public  policy that could advance the best interests of the state of Colorado as a whole.
org_list: Trust for Public Land, Adams State University Board of Trustees,
analytic_skills: As a healthcare administrator I have spent my entire career analyzing healthcare policy and implementing programs that are generated from those policies. I am very adapted following regulations and meeting the requirements of state contracts as a contractor for healthcare services for the state. Addition my experience working with the University as well as my work with the wildlife commission have taught me how to take information from  subject matter expert‘s and formulate that information into public policy that adhere to the spirit and letter of the law and regulation. In addition I specifically understand the work of redistricting from my experience on the Colorado Reapportionment Commission in 1990. Through this process I became very  adept at understanding demographic information and was able to structure that information into decisions that implemented the intent of the reapportionment commission.
consensus_statement: I have work in the business of healthcare my entire life, in particular in the business of behavioral health. My training as an MSW gives me the skills to understand people and to always work towards consensus. Through my job I have managed partnerships of healthcare providers where it is imperative that everyone work together.  My job as CEO in these organizations was to make sure that the partners all felt like they were being represented and that the partnership was being fair to everyone. My success as a CEO depended on my ability to develop consensus and have the partners feel like they had equal voice and  were able to participate in a fair and equitable process. I believe that this real life experience will be useful in the process outlined here in.

analytic_skills: I love intellectual challenge.  I approach challenge first with thorough study and confidence that a right solution can be revealed by process.  Then I listen to all points of view before I work toward deriving a consensus.  As mayor of a village in New York, I had experience in brain storming, problem analysis, negotiation, finding solutions, and supporting those solutions with calm and patient explanation.
consensus_statement: I was the first woman and first gay elected as mayor in a historically industrial village in New York.  I was the only mayor in the county who negotiated a police contract without arbitration.  When people in the village organized an angry protest, I was able to go into the street and listen to their concerns to defuse the misunderstanding.  I resolved all pending law suits against the village, some of several years' duration.  In one instance I had to bring together branches of state government that had never before met to solve a problem together.  Working with the New York State DOT, I brought about a compromise on road design that had been argued for years.  Negotiating with neighborhoods, local town boards, and prospective developers, I was able to preserve critical open space. Also negotiating with the US Senate committee on environment, Nabisco as the owner of polluted property, and professional remediation companies, I was able to address the clean up of three Superfund sites which had been in litigation for nearly twenty years without further threat to the environment.  I bring opposing voices to the table.  I listen.  I believe in working together to find a solution as a team.  I am patient with the process of consensus.  Working to achieve marriage equality for gay couples took years of listening, patience, and understanding the concerns of others.

occupation: Principal, Golden View Classical Academy
education: BA in Political Science at CU Boulder (2007); Ph.D in Politics and Policy at Claremont Graduate University (2012)
statement:
I am committed to free and fair elections which accurately represent the citizens of Colorado, those like me and those unlike me. We have a chance as a state to demonstrate what a bi-partisan, civil, moderate assessment of joint interests can look like, and be a model for states seeking stronger traditions of electoral integrity.

As a student of politics for over 15 years, I have learned about the importance of how our districts are structured to increase civil conversation and promote democratic values. As a husband and father who is similarly committed to the future of our democratic process in Colorado, I am excited to be part of a commission who shares that commitment.
professional_background: As Principal of a charter school, I have experience in working alongside a variety of stakeholders in children's education, including the City of Golden in terms of parking arrangements, the Golden Police Department with security arrangements, Golden Fire for code enforcement, both Jefferson County Public Schools and the Charter School Institute of Colorado, and a variety of businesses and parents with strong opinions about what a school should do and be.
org_list: I have belonged, in my professional capacity, to the Colorado League of Charter Schools, an organization which advocates for parental choice in education.
analytic_skills: Analytical skills, logic, and reason are the bread and butter of a doctorate level program, which I completed in 2012. I am continually presented with situations involving public health, law and statutes, pedagogical challenges, and school governance, which require both a comprehensive vision of the problem or issue at hand, and an assessment of the sub-problems and stakeholders who will be affected over the long-term. This helps me avoid the tyranny of the urgent and dedicate thought and action to the ultimate consequences of my decisions.
consensus_statement:
My commitment is to increase district competitiveness, which would compel those running for office to draw their opinions toward a more moderate position. The overall tendency of that in our system would be to promote the virtue of compromise, which in my opinion has decayed of late. 

As a Principal, employer, and teacher, I have learned the absolute necessity of being fair. I ask students if the quizzes I give were fair. If they weren't because I didn't cover something enough, then why not change the questions to make it fair? In discussing contracts and salary, I always ask if my assessment is fair, and invite a conversation and a reconsideration.
past_political_activity: I have donated money to multiple Republican and Democratic candidates through their websites, including but not limited to Hillary Clinton, Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, and Donald Trump.

I worked well with and was respected by both prosecutors and defense attorneys for that reason. I also interacted with members of the community with a wide range of backgrounds.

professional_background: I have a lot of experience in advocating for people and some experience in organizing and representing organization. In my time with the District Attorney's Office, I have had considerable experience advocating and speaking with people from all walks of life. While on the board of the Pro Bono Project we made strides in our representation and advocacy for survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault. The Grand Valley Ducks Unlimited chapter also gave me experience in organizing a decent-sized fundraiser and having to deal with the transition to a completely online event due top COVID restrictions that was a big success.

analytic_skills: As an attorney I have spent years developing my analytical skills. Applying logic and reason to problems is also a daily task for me. While making a decision for bringing criminal charges, I have look at the facts presented to me and analyze how they fit within the laws of the state. I often have to make determinations based upon logical conclusions that can be drawn from the information presented to me prior to that decision. I also bring the logic and reason to solving any problems I encounter as a parent. Recently there was a safety concern at my child's daycare and my wife and I brought to the attention of the supervisory staff and requested a meeting. In an area where it is easy to get emotional and defensive, there were no raised voices or short tempers; just conversation and understanding that lead to a resolution all parties could support.
consensus_statement: My job as a district attorney is to create agreement between people by presenting them with facts. My job also requires a fairness and impartiality for the effective and efficient administration of the justice system. My time on the board of the Pro Bono Project also helped me develop skills in promoting consensus among professional organizations that have diverse and sometimes competing interests in order to attain a common goal. With the Grand Valley Ducks Unlimited chapter I contributed by soliciting donations from various organizations and businesses and also took recommendations from various stakeholders in the community to the board for consideration.
past_political_activity: I have voted in almost all available elections. I was an intern in Representative Cory Gardner's (CO-4) DC office in the summer of 2012. I have donated to the following political campaigns: Pete Buttigieg, John Hickenlooper, and Jake Niece.

occupation: I am currently a Loadmaster at a Chrysler Corporation Warehouse.
education: I am a Graduate Of Miami University in Ohio. I was a Double Major in Social Work and the Humanities(Comparative Religion). This educational background has allowed to see things acutely, at the community and local levels and understand the needs of the people, with empathy and with clear solutions.
statement: I believe that I will be a great asset and addition to the Redistricting Commission, because I have a love for fairness and equality. My focuses in university allowed me to be diverse in my approach to serving the public, while understanding the role of Government, and how to make it all work together. My experience in management has allowed me to experience working under pressure and meeting deadlines. And having being an Educator I understand that everything we will do will be to the benefit of the future, and the legacy passed on to generations down the road. Being part of this Commission, I will bear all of this in mind.
professional_background: I have a great knack for organizing, and creating harmony and results in the process. Sometimes its like not having a recipe to cook from, but having rich ingredients , all the same. I know where to put which spice, and how long to simmer, and 'viola!, we all have a great, but trying day. The work is done and we are fulfilled... until the next time. With my company FCA, we have committed ourselves to community engagement, and at any chance possible, I try to do this on my free time, here all across Colorado. And let me just say, the beauty of the state make it all that much easier.
org_list:
Colorado Democratic Party. Michigan Democratic Party. Cincinnati Civic Garden Club.
Alpha Sigma Phi Fraternity
analytic_skills: I base much of my reasoning on a legal term called RPP, or Reasonable Prudent Person. In many situations, while I may tend to overthink, I will ask myself, "what would a reasonably prudent person do in this situation?" and If I am armed with all of the facts I usually come to a favorable conclusion, for the prudent. It is a simple approach, but it works more than it doesn't.
consensus_statement: Whether it is stated, or not, we as Commissioners will be delegates, bringing with us our experiences, and reasoning based on our make up, and our environment. This is a good thing. We are all human beings, and citizens of Colorado at the end of the day. And while we may disagree on some matters, the objective and aim will be the same. And we will always find common solutions. I will listen to all sides of a matter, and be fair and seek council, even from those with an opposing view, to come to a clear solution.
past_political_activity: As a child, my parents were active in the community and local government. They taught me and my siblings the importance of our vote. and of doing our parts to be good citizens. At 16, I was a volunteer at the Cincinnati HQ for the Clinton campaign in 1992. Not even old enough to vote yet, I still felt like my canvassing and phone bank calls to voters made a difference. I have been active with my local party for every election since. Be it Registering people to vote, to giving classes on local measures, I believe that it is my civic duty to inform. I have remained neutral and haven't giving to any campaign or organization.

statement: The redistricting function is a crucial part of ensuring that our political process is fair and that public resources are fairly distributed. As I have strong science and math background I believe that I have a solid aptitude to understand data and apply this to fostering sound recommendations for how district boundaries are determined. My fundamental ethic is to be collaborative, well informed, have integrity and to act in the best interest of the broader community rather than myself. I would bring this dedication to this role.

As a Native American and Latina woman I have been involved in supporting and leading a variety of important initiatives. These include but are not limited to: supporting the technology industry in Colorado via long term board involvement in of the Colorado Technology Association, efforts to educate women and minority students- with an emphasis on science and technology, economic development efforts that support Denver and Colorado, training and mentoring in the entrepreneurial and innovation communities, efforts to improve the quality of health care in Colorado and manage costs, and important philanthropic contributions aimed at supporting under served communities and our environment. In short, I have consistently donated money, time and the important value of my network to support our Colorado Community in a broad and generous manner.

In addition, the entire curriculum reinforces the 'scientific method' for analysis and problem solving. This background has been reinforced in my role of running a technology services company. This has required objective and creative approaches to solve complex technology problems, working with people to take action and at the same time inspiring their dedication.  I am confident in my intellectual aptitude to analyze, understand and communicate the story that the data is suggesting.
consensus_statement: I would start with my ability to review information from a scientific and objective view. Engineers are trained to understand numbers and data and then to derive a story from that information- not the reverse. I would appeal to the fact that biases today can create problems down the road. But mostly, I believe that FOR ANY ORGANIZATION OR CAUSE THAT A PERSON WOULD DONATE THEIR TIME TO, THE ORGANIZATION COMES FIRST. In this case, it is about the State of Colorado and how this commission can come together with recommendations that are fair to ALL Coloradoans- not a particular party.

statement: Despite my non-participation in political organizations and advocacy groups, I am highly interested in the nature of political power, representation, and state authority. My PhD work is substantially based in political theory and as a Colorado resident for nearly two decades I have developed a vested interest in how our state manifests its duty to represent the interests of the people.
professional_background: None
org_list: None
analytic_skills: I have completed graduate level academic training in logic and analysis. My current position at the University of Denver has me engaged in methodologies that demand the most stringent standards of analysis and reason. As stated, these are attributes for which I have a natural affinity. This was expressed during my time as a member of the US Army and subsequent career in academia, in which I have been afforded innumerable opportunities to pit my own ideas against those who found reason for disagreement. I soon identified the problems that ideological belief presented to rational thought—in my opponents, yes, but most importantly within my own moral and political conceptualizations. Seeking, as all people do, to attain a grasp on something manifestly true, I have consciously essayed to extract all functions of ideology from my logical processes, without fooling myself that they no longer exist. My remedy is to communicate the biases I know myself to hold as variants of interpretation while seeking simultaneously elicit expression of those biases from those who often are unaware of their existence. By way of this conscious effort do I make judgements and arrive at conclusions that are as devoid of irrationality as I am capable.
consensus_statement:
I have a natural impartiality towards evidence and do not shy away from whatever conclusions are empirically derived. Although I have a deep interest in politics and have voted every two years since 2008, I have always done so without emotional involvement, choosing candidates based upon my assessment of their potential for adherence to the US Constitution—of which I have extensive familiarity with both the historical and theoretical underpinnings thereof. As such, I am deeply aware of the dangers gerrymandering poses to representative forms of governance. I give no regard to which party or individual gains authority so long as the people are ensured their right to elect someone whom they decide best represents their interests, which gerrymandering significantly undermines. 

Moreover, I have strong communication skills and am able to be very precise in my language. I recognize the difficulties attendant to the accurate expression of conceptual ideas, particularly as regards one's own understanding of not only what, but how, one is thinking, and have been trained to overcome those difficulties. I am confident in my ability to organize my own thoughts, communicate them accurately and effectively, verify that others have received those communications without distortion, and make appropriate corrections as necessary.
past_political_activity: None, other than voting

statement: I had never served on a public board and I wanted to learn about how citizens can interface in the governmental process.  It has truly been one of the most rewarding experiences. For me, I have been able to witness Robert's Rules of Order in operation. I have been able to benefit from a great Chair who has been able to engage all of us in respecting true "meeting" procedures.
professional_background: About 2 years ago, the local library asked me to apply to be on the Board of the Library. I applied and the Mayor of Littleton called me and asked me if I would consider moving my application to the Licensing Commission. The Licensing Commission issues new licenses in the City of Littleton for any on site consumption of alcohol and reviews current licensure. In addition, the Licensing Commission issues new and renewal licenses for medical marijuana dispensaries.  We also are the administrative body that reviews any sort of licensure issues, including failure to comply with compliance checks, etc.
org_list: I sit on the City of Littleton Licensing Commission
analytic_skills: I am an attorney and have been for over 20 years. As an attorney, my instinct is analysis. Every problem is, in my opinion, 3-dimensional. We have to consider it from every angle. My philosophy is to look for the "gaps". What information are we missing? and Why? I find that the search for "negative" space really changes the perspective on any problem.
consensus_statement: I am a health care attorney. As a health care attorney we are often thrust into situations where people are at their most vulnerable.  No one wants to be at the hospital. Patients and their families are often scared, nervous, angry and often grateful...all at the same time. People in their most emotional of times often struggle with decision making.  As an attorney, I'm often called on to be an intermediary between health care providers and patients/families. Now with COVID restrictions, we are even more sensitive to the challenges of having a health care event. Every day I have to navigate differing opinions, differing "rights", considering nuance of privacy law, and protecting the institution. Each day ultimately, my job is to insure that patients and families are able to continue their journey with as much dignity as possible.
past_political_activity: I have donated through Act Blue to Biden-Harris, Sara Gideon in Maine, Jamie Harrison in South Carolina

Negotiating with empathy and seeking to start from common ground has been the most successful in my experience.

statement: I am a student of our democratic process and enjoy learning about our democracy.  I feel a responsibility to encourage others to get involved.  Serving on the Redistricting Commission would expose me to an area of elections that I have not previously been involved in.  Coincidentally, I have been involved in the planning of the last two Census cycles through Denver’s Complete Count Committee.  It would be fascinating to see how our Census impacts the redistricting process.
professional_background: I have spent the last decade of my career as a public affairs executive advocating for numerous policy and civic issues.  Most recently, I spent the last seven years as a Mayoral Appointee in the City and County of Denver in the Hancock Administration.  I served as the Director of Regional Affairs, the Mayor's liaison to all local governments across Colorado and then as the Director of External Affairs for Economic Development.   Prior to my time in local government, I worked as the Director of Government and Community Affairs for Denver's tourism industry and regularly traveled the state visiting with regional tourism interests or advocating for tourism issues at the capitol.

My skills were further advanced though policy work as a public affairs executive over the last decade. I enjoy a great challenge and rely on teamwork to achieve solutions.

I have also traveled to numerous counties across Colorado and have been active in Democratic Party politics for several years.  I believe I have the experience, objectivity and communication skills to be helpful on the Redistricting Commission.  I am also a proud Coloradan and spent my childhood on the Western Slope before moving to Denver around the time I started the 4th Grade.  I also come from a family with diverse ideological interests that are registered in both political parties.  I believe the breadth of my personal, professional and political experiences will allow me to see each commissioner's perspective with a unique lens.  I am confident that I will be able to engage in a respectful dialogue with all of the commissioners as we work through the difficult task of redistricting.

statement: I'm concerned about the rigged, gerrymandered districts that are common around the country, but hopeful that Colorado is moving in the right direction with this independent commission.  I want to be part of the solution.
professional_background: As member and vice chair of the Arapahoe Design Advisory Board, I weighed development rights with zoning and neighborhood design guidelines to facilitate the best outcome possible for the community.  As Chair of Seattle's Design Review Board I often had to manage meetings where competing interests had to be negociated in real time, often in contentious neighborhoods where any change is seen with suspicion.  As the founding chair of Seattle's Urban Forestry Commission, where a goal of reaching 30% tree canopy cover by 2037 was broadly accepted, industrial and commercial interest groups were resistant to added requirements on their properties and compromises had to be made to move the needle in the right direction.  While some of these examples are outside Colorado, my background and experience at the intersection of public, commercial and private interests, I believe, has prepared me to be a valuable contributor to the redistricting commission.

analytic_skills: Problem solving is only possible through logical analysis.  However complexity becomes a real challenge for a group, where layers of information must be processed and given appropriate importance, before a decision or direction can be taken.  Synthesizing complexity is an invaluable skill.  In a group setting, it's often when strategic leadership is needed, and when timely expert advice is critical.   I spent my entire career working in teams, frequently to solve complex multilayered spacial problems based on dense quantitative data.
consensus_statement: I have served on and lead several Boards over my career, they have shown me that diverse and even diverging opinions often have something in common, and it's focusing on our common goals and concerns that we can move forward, offering compromise on issues that may be in conflict.   It can be messy, and it's hard work to forge compromise, but it's the only path through gridlock.

analytic_skills:
In 2019 the Supreme Court famously left the field of addressing partisan gerrymandering, with Chief Justice John Roberts proclaiming it simply too hard for justices to grapple with the various theories on how to make voting districts efficient and fair. But in fact this was not true-- the theories are relatively simple; Roberts was interested mainly in staying out of it. 
I have served as an executive in the cable industry for fifteen years, requiring a remarkable amount of intricate budgeting and spreadsheets, with an eye towards gleaning meaning from the numbers. Roberts knew this stuff was not impossible to follow, and it's not.
consensus_statement: I am very interested in fairness, mainly because unfairness causes agitation and brittleness in the system. I have no objection to the slight benefit to be gained by one party leading the drawing of the maps, but I believe I can build a concensus around following formulas that make sure that too many votes are not wasted.
