occupation: Retired since December 2017. Resume to be uploaded.
education:
Master's degree in Social Work from the University of Denver
Bachelor's degree in Social Work from the University of Nebraska at Lincoln
statement: During my professional career I had little time to participate in something as time consuming and demanding as serving on a commission like this. I have always been drawn to opportunities like this one but have hesitated both because of time considerations and also because of potential conflicts with the requirements of my employment. I am now free to take on something like this wholeheartedly and with great enthusiasm. I began thinking about this possibility as soon as I saw the ballot issue that created these commissions. I was thrilled to see it pass with voter approval. I am proud of Colorado for being on the forefront with this new and exciting process. I would love to serve as a commission member, knowing full well how much responsibility this would be and embracing the challenge. The outcomes of the decisions made by the commissions are highly impactful and important. I believe I can help build consensus and provide needed objectivity, seeing the big picture and the needs of our State as a whole while also valuing the impact to various localities. During my employment with Colorado State University, I met with students in the Distance Learning Program around the State of Colorado, with much of my time spent in Colorado Springs and Denver Metro as well as locally in Larimer County. I visited students in Gunnison,  Salida, and in La Junta. In a separate effort I did consulting work in Durango evaluating local needs and resources for a potential self-sufficiency program. I believe I have gained valuable experience regarding statewide needs during the course of performing these duties.
professional_background: While employed as Executive Director for Project Self-Sufficiency of Loveland - Fort Collins (1989-2014) I worked closely with the Board of Directors to set policy, create the budget, and engage in community relations. During this time I often assisted in resolving differences, explaining the needs of the program participants and staff, and setting the direction for the organization. I took a democratic approach to staff supervision and utilized staff meetings to make joint decisions after listening to varying points of view.  I represented the organization and our constituents at advocacy meetings in Denver at the Women's Foundation of Colorado. There we discussed barriers to the well being of our constituent populations and planned interventions to secure resources and encourage needed governmental policy changes. We gathered data on the "cliff effect" that results when families lose benefits following very small wage increases. I attended many interagency community meetings in Fort Collins over those years to engage in conversations with many other organizations serving similar client populations. We networked, found ways to work together to solve problems, shared information and resources, and worked together to communicate with funders on behalf of disadvantaged individuals and families. I continue to maintain many of these relationships today and am sometimes called upon to assist in my retirement years. This has included volunteering for the City of Loveland during their annual event to distribute needed items and resource information.
org_list: I have a group of friends who write letters to elected officials and I have done this with them a number of times over the past year. I have done much of the upfront research on the issues this group addresses. I continue to volunteer for Project Self-Sufficiency of Loveland - Fort Collins, a local nonprofit that assists single parents in moving from poverty to financial independence. I was the Executive Director for that organization for 25 years and continue to serve on the Scholarship Committee, host a table at the luncheon, and consult with the current Executive Director. I serve on the Board of Directors for the Sam S. Bloom Foundation (Centennial, Colorado) that funds nonprofit organizations statewide. I chair the Nominating Committee and the Motivated Families Program Committee for that organization. Recently I served on Larimer County's advisory committee to distribute federal COVID 19 dollars to local organizations. We read proposals and made recommendations. I am a field instructor for the Colorado State University School of Social Work field education program. I worked for that organization for three years and then continued as a volunteer field instructor after I retired in December of 2017. This involves meeting with either graduate or undergraduate students weekly throughout the semester to provide guidance and instruction.
analytic_skills: I pride myself on thoroughly thinking through a possible decision, considering all possible outcomes, pros and cons, potential unanticipated consequences, while keeping a focus on the intended purpose and ultimate goal. During my professional management years, it was important to consider the mission of the organization while setting program and organizational policy. Constantly reminding myself and others of why we were there, what we were setting out to accomplish, who was counting on us, and why it was important. When relevant I would look at research and best practices, considering similar situations and how those decisions turned out. Learning from past mistakes is critical.
consensus_statement: I believe the basis for consensus building is seeking common ground and looking at shared values and experiences. I would seek to understand the thinking of my fellow committee members and identify shared concerns and values. I would look carefully at differences of opinion and consider any bias I might be experiencing. I would listen carefully to information provided by staff and the testimony of Colorado residents in forming and sharing opinions. I would be open to hearing and considering varied points of view, looking at possible unintended consequences and long term impacts of decisions to be made. I would add my own research to that of others in considering all possibilities and narrowing options. I am rather compulsive about fairness. I would consider all the various populations and communities that would be impacted and what their special needs might be. I would be cognizant of income disparities and ethic diversity. How would their experiences with this system vary? How would the outcomes affect their lives? I would use common sense in keeping communities together in the same district and work hard to avoid splitting communities of interest.
past_political_activity: I am currently volunteering for the Gordon McLaughlin campaign for DA for 8th Judicial District and also for the Biden-Harris campaign. This involves phone calling and sign delivery. Prior to this, I assisted two campaigns to secure signatures to get on the primary ballot. The candidates were Kim Akeley Charron for Larimer County Commissioner and Lorena Garcia for US Senate from Colorado. In the past I have delivered literature and sometimes knocked on doors on behalf of candidates. I have also made phone calls and sent text messages in support of various campaigns over the years. I am currently supporting 25 to 30 different local, statewide, and national candidates for office in amounts that range from $25 to $100. I do this approximately once each month. I always attend my local precinct caucuses. I have attended some virtual county and state Democratic Party meetings in recent months.

statement: I firmly believe that a strong democracy requires the election process to be fair and transparent. I am proud that Colorado is held as a positive example for the entire country and I want to make sure that this process succeeds for us. Besides, redistricting is a fascinating multi-dimension optimization problem. I believe that I can contribute in perhaps unique ways.
professional_background: I am a volunteer with All On The Line, an organization dedicated to the production of fair maps and an accessible redistricting process.
org_list: I am a volunteer classroom assistant at the Emily Griffith Technical College for beginning English.
analytic_skills: After surveying current tools for comparison of competing redistricting plans and finding none freely available, I wrote one. "PlanAnalyzer" is a desktop computer application that analyzes redistricting plans for fairness, comparing them under a variety of different metrics. Whether or not this tool will be ever useful in a production setting, it was invaluable to me as a learning device. I now have considerable insight into the trade-offs and competing goals inherent in the redistricting process. My application, by the way, is open-source, available to anyone at https://github.com/chuckcoughlin/redistrict-colorado. Documentation is available on the site and as an attachment to this application.
consensus_statement: I believe discussion among committee members will be less contentious if the primary focus is on the definition of what is "fair" followed by concentration on the processes, algorithms, and metrics to get there. As an engineer, I have often found myself in the role of fact-gatherer prior to important decision-making. I would promote use of tools that provide a factual, numerical basis for plan evaluations. Mathematics is non-partisan

statement: Every elected official represents a community of people.  The challenge, the problem to be solved, is how to divide the state population into logical smaller communities in a way that is fair - in a way that is not contrived to benefit one group over another.  I think this is an important task and I think I have qualities that will benefit this process.
professional_background: I do not have a lot of experience in this area.
org_list: I have been a member and a volunteer at the Schlessman YMCA, teaching Aqua Fitness classes to a mostly senior population.  It was a fitness class but also more than that - it was also a social network that has managed to continue via Zoom during the pandemic when access to the pool has been limited.
analytic_skills: My career in research points to my strengths in logic and analysis.  I enjoy solving problems that include complex relationships and caveats.
consensus_statement: I think it is important for the group to start by defining the overall goals - to be sure that we all agree on what we are trying to do.  On a broad level, it shouldn't be too hard to agree on the overarching goals - the conflict will come in the details.  To promote consensus I would advocate that we start by each person putting forward ideas and concerns without comment from others.  Discussion can then be directed at addressing these concerns.  In group discussions where there is disagreement I like to try and listen to and acknowledge people's emotional response and use that to identify issues that can be addressed impartially.  I recognize my own partiality, I recognize that the political outcomes that I want are not what everyone wants.  I can feel strongly about my own political agenda and still be strongly committed to finding a way to fairly and impartially divide up the state into logical communities for representation.
past_political_activity: I am an active voter - I vote in every election and I research the candidates and ballot issues.  I donated money, made phone calls, canvassed neighborhoods and helped run the local field office for the Clinton campaign on election day 2016.  I also donated money and did some canvassing for Ashley Wheeland when she ran for a seat in the state house.  In 2016 I was chosen as a delegate at my precint caucus and at the county assembly and I participated in the state assembly and convention.  In 2020 I donated to Kamala Harris' primary campaign and to Joe Biden's presidential campaign.

That is the true purpose of good politics, and not to stab all others in the face while you pat their back saying "it will be fine, give me more money".
org_list: None
analytic_skills:
I tend to be a natural advocate for the unknown, unheard of and thought of as well. 
When need arises for solutions, my mind has worked out several before I suggest even one...and usually before others clearly understand the issue. Its ironic you use the term "analytical". That is my strongest and most used saving grace, other than that of the Great Almighty who graced me with it and his protection, that is. I can't honestly take credit for my natural analytic skills, only for honing them. 
Logic seems to be lost in current day society, especially in governance. What I call logic, many others call impossible. 
Scenario: 
Intensely cold snowy 6 degree morning, 
car will not start
only transportation to work
what to do? quickly
Most people call off work, or report they'll be late
Some will call a cab
Many would call a tow truck
Others will open the hood and attempt to jump
I open the hood, attach jump box
Still no cranking
Now call the boss, and someone to arrange a ride
I do not call a row truck or repair shop
I do not go buy a new battery
I do not risk illness and injury in the inclement weather
I wait. 
When the weather warms I check wires and connections for loose, frayed, broken or dead short
Now I try to jump start again. Then decide the next steps.
I just relayed to you the basic conversation with my son when this came up from last storm. It was the right way to deal with it too, as it turns out. It was a faulty connection causing a draw while it sat. 
The aforementioned groups "most" "some" and  "many" are the very type of people I used to rely on for work in the auto repair field because they rely on people like me. I was the face of the company. The tester, estimator, negotiator - on all sides, i.e. cost to customer vs cost to company - as well as the public relations and human relations, business to business sales and coop coordinator/closer; customer sales, negotiator/deal closer; and more. All while overseeing schedules for techs and work orders to attain and maintain smoother operations; parts manager; tear down technician; assess and clean units; liaison between shop and office admin; R&R tech assistant; torque converter specialist AND shop driver for multiple tasks and errands, including customer transport and banking. I was the universal joint for the drivetrain of a fast moving vehicle, essentially. Its is also, by nature, one of my strengths to assume that role and way of thinking in all aspects I possibly can. I can apply my strength and balance to the reasoning process to avert illogical attempts at a solution. These character traits usually quickly become valued and relied upon in anything I take on. I may not be able yo make 100% of the people happy, but I do my best to include 100% in my thinking and problem solving. the 2-3% I fall short did and do matter to me, being unlike the politicians and all/.

statement:
I have been involved in our civic, non-profit, and business community my entire adult life.  In all of these roles, I have been in a position to listen first and try to build consensus among the stakeholders in the conversation.  That is my skill.
This skill has helped me build a business from scratch to the point where it was recently acquired by a publicly-traded company.  I built a customer base, worked with partners, managed employees, and collaborated with vendor partners to achieve a successful result for whatever specific situation we were working on.
I have a wide network of individuals in a range of areas around our state and am confident I could listen to the various opinions that will be directed at the commission and work with my fellow commissioner to focus on a set of over-arching principals that I would expect we could agree on before we sit down with maps and numbers.
I am eager to apply my talents and energy to help Colorado inaugurate this innovative redistricting process.  I will focus on collaboration and consensus so that we can provide a result to the Citizens of Colorado that meets their aspirations for this new process and provides as level a playing field as possible on which we can conduct our political discussions over the next 10 years.
professional_background:
I have been involved at increasingly senior levels in organizational leadership, advocacy and community conversations for my entire career.
As a citizen of Louisville, I first was involved in designing and implementing a municipal arboretum as a member of what was then known as the Tree Board.  I next worked on the Board of Adjustments to listen to Citizen’s application for variances from our zoning codes to accommodate their specific property issues and aspirations.  As a two-term member City Council, I had the opportunity to work with a wide spectrum of the community on a variety of issues spanning power lines, residential and commercial development, school location, power line relocation, extra-municipality communications and many more.
As I look back, my favorite subjects where looking at long-term, region wide collaboration and planning opportunities.  As a member of the Boulder County Consortium of Cities, I spearheaded an effort to explore sharing of sales taxes to reduce redundant commercial development and to share library and recreation facilities.  As a member of the DRCOG Board, I worked with a wide-variety of stakeholders from other local governmental bodies to prioritize local and regional transportation issues and to manage the MetroVision Plan’s urban growth boundary.  This required balancing the needs and priorities our Louisville citizens with the more aggressive development interests of other communities in the metro Denver area.
I also have served on multiple non-profit boards and commissions.  My latest work with the Imagine! Foundation and the Imagine! governing board has taught me about the world of individuals with intellectual and development disabilities and allowed me to take that message to our community so that we can continue to implement a world of opportunities for all abilities.  
Even as  private citizen and as a Mayoral candidate last year, I became reacquainted with the local political scene – rekindling old friendships and meeting new citizens.  I got involved with a dispute between a group of neighbors and a individual who was redeveloping an older Louisville home and was able to help them reach a consensus on how to move forward.  I also worked with the team that was seeking to develop the old StorageTech property along US36 to help them express their message to the community so that we could find a way to ensure that Medtronic reinvested in our great community.
I have been involved in our civic, non-profit, and business community my entire adult life.  I have a wide network of individuals in a range of areas around our state and am confident I could listen to the various opinions that will be directed at the commission and work with my fellow commissioner to focus on a set of over-arching principals that I would expect we could agree on before we sit down with maps and numbers.

analytic_skills:
I received a degree in Economics and History from Northwestern University.  As part of that degree, I took many classes that required the synthesis of multiple concepts and sources.  Whether learning the more analytical but theoretical concepts of micro and macro economics, to the intricacies of money and banking to the abstract historical concepts that can be gleaned from Economic History. 
After Northwestern, I worked in the restaurant industry for two years learning customer service and management of a business.
Finally, in Law School, we learned to study the facts and the law and apply these concepts to achieve outcomes that achieved some sort of justice for our clients.
In my business career, I have developed skills in managing budgets, building and managing proforma projections, managing cashflows all while attempting to ensure that we were developing our software efficiently, and getting our message out to potential customers in a compelling fashion.
I am not an engineer.  However, I understand Colorado's geography.  I am familiar with the range of constituencies throughout our State.  I also understand the requirements that we draw maps that encompass the required population numbers in a manner that encourages competitive races so that all citizens are represented.  
I have worked my entire adult life to resolve legal, municipal, neighborhood, and organizational challenges by spending time to learn the facts, understanding the underlying framework within which we are working, gaining stakeholder input, and, most importantly fostering a consensus-building environment where, whenever possible, the stakeholders themselves can achieve a mutual agreement resolution.  I look forward to applying that same philosophy to the redistricting commission.
past_political_activity:
I served as a Councilman in the City of Louisville from January 2000 through December of 2007.  Prior to that, I served on several city advisory boards including the Tree Board and the Board of Adjustments. I ran for Mayor of Louisville unsuccessfully in 2019.  I served on the DRCOG Board of Directors from 2003 through 2007 and the Boulder County Consortium of Cities from 2005-2007.

I have donated money to many democratic candidates over the past 5 years including, but not necessarily limited to, Phil Weiser, Jena Griswold, John HIckenlooper, Sonja Jaquez-Lewis, Diane Mitch-Busch and Michael Bennet.

I have been involved with the Boulder County Democratic Party sporadically over the past 30 years helping run the County Assembly on at least two occasions.

statement: At my core I love fairness. Gerrymandering goes against my sense of fairness and I hate the thought that redistricting is done with a bias to help ensure a party wins.
professional_background: None
org_list: None
analytic_skills: Besides the fact that I actually took a class in logic in college, I'm an engineer and a man and to some, I'm overly logical at times (just ask my wife). I feel redistricting can be done from a starting point of dividing up the state in areas containing the same people where those areas are all rectangular and determined by a straightforward algorithm. Then the only thing left for the commission to do is to tweak boundaries so that they make sense from a perspective of geography and governance (it may not make sense to cut a little town in half, for example). I think if districting is done from a set of rules instead of from opinionated political puppetry, persons can be assured that it was done with fairness in mind.
consensus_statement: I manage 25 people at my workplace and do it from a sense of fairness and respect and try to get buy-in for what needs to be done and by whom, rather than just to tell people what to do with no context. Not everyone agrees on things in this polarized world, but it's still important to find out where you have consensus on things and where some is still needed and then strive to get there. I don't always get my way, even as a superior to others in an organizational chart, because sometimes they have to try things I don't think will work in order for them to buy in to what I believe. I think this same willingness to compromise will serve me well when working on this commission.
past_political_activity: None

statement:
I want to serve on this commission for three reasons.

First, I strongly support the mission of this commission. I know from personal experience that competitive districts benefit our communities. I seek to help the commission fulfill its mission.

Second, I am uniquely qualified to serve on this commission. All of my experiences seem to be pointing to this particular opportunity. In other contexts, I have put into practice the skills and abilities called for—organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering interests. I have a proven track record of fairly and impartially creating agreement and promoting consensus. My experiences campaigning and as a candidate have provided me with analytical skills that are particularly relevant for this effort.

Third, I desire to leave a legacy. If this commission does its job well, its impact will be no less than 10 years, the period until the next census. I believe, though, that the commission’s legacy could be much longer. The precedents set and procedures put into place are likely (with tweaks) to be used by future commissions. The echoes may be generational. In addition, Colorado is a leader in the nation in the use of citizen-based independent redistricting commissions. We may be able to show the rest of the country how to be successful in putting an end to partisan gerrymandering. I want to be a part of this legacy. 

I am applying for both the Legislative and Congressional Redistricting Commissions. My preference is to serve on the Legislative Redistricting Commission. However, I would consider it a privilege and honor to serve on either commission.
professional_background:
Two experiences illustrate particularly well my abilities in organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering interests. The first is when I lead the Poudre Schools District Accountability Committee review of the first charter school application in Fort Collins. The second is successfully leading my homeowners’ association in changing the neighborhood covenants.

As an unpaid volunteer, I was an active participant in the Poudre Schools District Accountability Committee when the first charter school application was submitted. At the time, charter schools were a political hot potato. Following state law, it fell to the District Accountability Committee to review the application and consider the interests of the applicant, the school district, and the community as a whole. I volunteered to head the review subcommittee and organized four other subcommittee members. Under my leadership, the subcommittee created a fair and impartial process by first identifying 28 application requirements specified by state law and the school district. The subcommittee then painstakingly reviewed the application against these standards and evaluated whether required information was provided, whether it was sufficiently detailed, and whether the applicant's proposal for each requirement was acceptable. Finally, I represented the subcommittee by presenting to the entire District Accountability Committee and to the school board our findings regarding the merits and deficiencies of the application.

The subcommittee did a masterful job and, as a result, everybody was angered. The pro-charter people were upset because we did not unquestionably accept the application. The anti-charter people were upset that we did not flatly deny the application. These reactions are evidence of our impartiality. 

And the subcommittee? We had more than consensus. We were unanimous in our findings. By focusing on the standards set by law and first developing a fair and impartial process for review of the application against the standards, the subcommittee was able to stay above the political fray.

In the end, the applicant was able to address deficiencies in the application and the charter school was approved. Since then other charter schools have come and gone in Fort Collins but this school remains strong and successful. I truly believe our subcommittee deserves some credit for that. I am proud of my efforts in organizing the subcommittee, representing the subcommittee before the school board, advocating for the subcommittee’s recommendations, and considering the interests of the various stakeholder groups.

I envision a similar process for the redistricting commission. This effort has the potential to be politically destabilizing for some entrenched interests. After all, if the commission does its job well, some currently uncompetitive districts will made competitive... and some people are not going to like that. I believe if redistricting commission focuses on the standards set by law and develops and follows a fair and impartial process around those standards, it will be successful in achieving its mission.

More recently, as an active participant in my homeowners’ association, I served on the Board of Directors when it sought to make a covenant change. Want to take on a challenge? Volunteer for your HOA!

As President for much of this process, I organized most aspects of this effort. I sought to ensure that Board members were thoroughly informed of all available options. With impartially, I insisted that the Board patiently allow anyone to speak and that everyone be heard. In this way the Board was able to consider the interests of all our neighbors. I also stepped aside when others wanted to take a more active leadership role (and then stepped back into leadership when they decided leading really was not that much fun). In this way I was able promote consensus by building trust and creating buy-in.

In the end, the Board reached unanimous agreement on a proposal to present to our homeowners. We were able to achieve consensus among our homeowners with 150 of 175 voting households in favor of the proposal. These numbers are truly amazing--a very high level of neighborhood engagement with 86% of households in agreement!

Per state law, our final step was to obtain court approval of the changes. I represented my HOA in court and advocated on behalf of my neighbors.

Our efforts were successful. Following approval by the court, the covenant changes went into effect. They had an immediate impact on our HOA, greatly strengthening its financial situation. This summer costly repairs were made to the asphalt path through our neighborhood common area. The funds for these repairs were made available because of the changes to our covenants. I am deeply satisfied to see the legacy of my efforts and the positive impact of effectively organizing this project, representing and considering the interests of my neighbors and our neighborhood, and advocating for them.

These experiences give me confidence that I will serve well if selected to serve on this commission.

My two engineering degrees certainly speak to my analytical skills. More importantly, I have relevant analytical skills developed by working on campaigns and being a candidate. I am experienced digging into voter and demographic data to determine precinct and district composition and to assess likely electorate behavior. 

I am a people-oriented analyst. This means that I have the soft skills to work effectively with others while possessing strong logic and reasoning skills.

I have great confidence in my ability to serve well on a redistricting commission. It is my sincere hope that I will have the opportunity to do so.

Respectfully submitted,
Eric Kronwall
consensus_statement:
In my discussion of my experience in organizing, representing, advocating for, or considering the interests of groups, organizations, or associations in Colorado, I recount two challenging situations where I promoted consensus, created agreement, and was fair and impartial. Please carefully review that portion of my application.

I am a process person. How we get to an outcome is often just as important as the outcome itself. I have found it is much easier to get to agreement and consensus when processes and procedures are hashed out beforehand. If selected to serve, I will urge my fellow commissioners to first develop processes and procedures for how business and hearings are conducted and how proposed district maps are evaluated relative to legal requirements and competitiveness. 

Building trusting on a one-on-one basis with the other commissioners facilitates agreement and consensus. I have done this in the past by:
> Making and keeping promises,
> Transparency,
> Bending over backwards to elicit and listen to the input of others, and
> Assumption of positive intent.

In addition to creating agreement and promoting consensus, good processes help to assure fairness and impartiality.
past_political_activity:
For at least the past 15 years I have actively participated as a volunteer for numerous political campaigns, supporting candidates for Fort Collins and Loveland City Council, State House of Representatives, State Senate, and Larimer County offices. In 2011 on my own initiative, I developed a campaign training course for candidates and campaign managers. My current campaign participation is most often as an unpaid strategy and messaging consultant.

My most significant political activity was running for Fort Collins City Council in 2015. This non-partisan race was very competitive. In a district with about 14,000 registered voters, I lost by 140 votes. While I did not care for this outcome, I know in my heart of hearts that the citizens of Fort Collins benefited from a competitive race.

I have first-hand experience and a perspective shared by few others--that of a candidate--about what makes a race competitive and the benefits enjoyed by our communities from competitive races. This fuels my motivation to serve and partly explains my strong support for the mission of the redistricting commission. My experience and perspective uniquely qualify me to serve, having provided me with relevant analytical skills.

Since November 10, 2015, I have donated money to: Vote for Eric Kronwall Committee, REALTOR Political Action Committee, Vote Nate Budd Committee, Larimer County Republican Party, Irene Josey for Treasurer Committee, Sean (Dougherty) for Larimer County Committee, National Republican Senatorial Committee, Elect Noah (Hutchison) Committee, Elect Emily (Gorgol) Committee, Wade Troxell Mayoral Committee, Aislinn (Kottwitz) for Larimer Committee, Cory Gardner for Senate Committee. In addition, a portion of my annual Colorado Association of REALTORS and National Association of REALTORS dues are used for political purposes.

I will not serve as a partisan on this commission and would be sure to insist the same from others. This work has to be about what is best for the people of Colorado and not about my own personal goals. I have a deep understanding of how to use to data to ensure fairness and would apply that knowledge to this work to keep my decisions impartial.

When political parties can choose their voters and create a favorable electoral landscape then undemocratic forms of power can consolidate away from the people themselves. I see the success of democracy not just in simply receiving the consent of the people but also in its ability to distribute power broadly and evenly.

I always try to meet the context that the other person/party is bringing to the table and negotiate between the reality of the data and our respective interpretations. My principled dedication to justice and fairness has engendered an overarching skepticism towards all interpretations, including my own, as I believe the answer is usually found in between interpretations and with the data itself.

That summer we were stopping people and verifying that those vehicles were not fire hazards.  This summer at our annual association meeting, the riders were brought up again.  Once it was pointed out that our state was just getting out of lockdown and everyone was ready to leave that time behind, the neighbors agreed that letting people have fun outside is a good thing.  We had had spring moisture to keep the fire danger low for early summer, and the activity was only for 3 weekends out of the year.

other_names: Adelia Dawnene Tripp, Dawn Tripp, Dawn Tripp-Morris, Dawn Tripp-Sena
occupation: Director of the Social Work Department , Colorado Mental Health Institute.
education: I have a Bachelors and Masters degree in Social Work (MSW). I am a Licensed Clinical Social Worker (LCSW).
statement: I would love to serve on the commission because I am passionate about equality, equity and justice. I am the kind of person that considers all sides and fairness is one of my core values. I have been able to use my skills at CMHIP with positive results for 10 years now; being on a committee where my work will have a positive effect on all Coloradoans and the citizens of the USA would be a dream come true!
professional_background:
As the director of Social Work department my mission is many-fold. I am in the position to advocate for better working conditions and salaries for my staff, advocate for the patients to ensure their rights are not being violated and advocate for the patients’ social supports such that they are treated with dignity and respect when they call to see how their loved one is doing in our custody.
I have been a member of Colorado WINS, where I took these issues and came up with a strategy to get a salary increase for Social Workers in the Colorado Department of Human Services (CDHS). I worked on this for 8 years without tiring, even though I would not get an increase myself. Because of my advocacy large salary increases came to all the Social Workers in the CDHS in July 2018! These were not regular raises but compression pay that raised the Social Workers pay to be competitive with the Department of Corrections and the private sector. 
I was on the Executive Steering Committee for the collaboration between employees at CMHIP and Executive management at CDHS for 4 years. Being elected to this committee by the employees at CMHIP gave me the opportunity and put me in a position to speak to executive staff at CDHS regarding the need for compression pay for the Social Workers.
org_list: I am a member of the NAACP, Colorado WINS, National Association of Social Workers, and Association of Black Social Workers. I am also a member of the Daughters of Promise a group of women who sing at different fundraisers and vigils for different  causes, i.e., immigration, voting suppression and other current events/issues.
analytic_skills:
One of my responsibilities as the director of the Social Work department is to ensure that every patient has a Social Worker per Centers for Medicaid/Medicare regulations. At one point the department was down 50% (14 staff) and I had to figure out how we were going to cover 494 patients with half of a department. I was able to implement a plan with the buy in of the Social Workers until we were able to hire more staff. 
The main reason for the loss of Social Workers was salary. Most of these Social Workers left CMHIP to work for the Veterans Administration because they offered a better salary and working conditions. The conclusion I came to was if we increased salaries to a competitive wage, we would have fewer resignations. Fewer resignations would be cost effective for the company because we would not be constantly spending money to train new staff.
Being a member of the Executive Steering Committee representing CMHIP, I had to present issues in a way that the Executives at CDHS would be open to hearing the issues and the solutions provided. Being elected to this committee by the employees at CMHIP gave me the opportunity and put me in a position to speak to executive staff on a regular basis regarding the need for compression pay for the Social Workers. This was one of the last items CDHS supported in the legislature before their 2nd term was completed. Recruitment and retention have increased since compression pay was implemented with only 2 resignations in the last 2.5 years.
consensus_statement: This is exactly what the profession of Social Work does. Social Workers looks to right injustices, advocate for victims, community advocates for change. I have wanted to be a Social Worker since I was 5 years old, it's in my blood. As I stated in my statement above fairness is one of my core values. Though I am not applying for a Social Work position I believe my experience as a Social Worker makes me an excellent candidate for the commission.
past_political_activity: I donate monthly to ActBlue, I have donated several times recently to the Biden/Harris campaign. I donate monthly to PushBlack and Colorado WINS/COPE. I have been a moderator for question and answer sessions of political candidates that wanted to be endorsed by Colorado WINS. I have also attended the legislative BBQ at the Colorado State Fair as a WINS representative.

statement: Gerrymandering is a profoundly anti-democratic problem, effectively disenfranchising millions of voters & causing our legislative bodies to become increasingly radicalized, as representatives from "safe" seats for either party are essentially elected at the primary level instead of the general. I think I could provide the commission with a knowledgeable voice, based on my education & professional experience with GIS. However, I am not deeply involved in politics (aside from being an engaged citizen).
professional_background: I do not organize, represent, or advocate for any groups, organizations, or associations.
org_list:
8/2015-present: House for All Sinner and Saints (church)

analytic_skills: I wrote my Master's project on gerrymandering, focusing on Pennsylvania (which was the subject of Vieth v. Jubelirer, 541 U.S. 267 in 2004). I studied the strengths & weaknesses of various algorithms for generating "neutral" district sets. I have experience explaining complicated scientific problems to lay audiences. Professionally, I am called on to provide logical, reasonable analyses to complex problems as a matter of course.
consensus_statement:
I am not involved in many organizations, but in my professional work, I spend a lot of time developing consensus between groups with different points of view, sometimes in rather contentious settings. For example, I was the response manager for the Gold King Mine spill site for two years. I had to work with community members, EPA, BLM, the Uncompaghre Ute tribe, neighbors, & landowners to complete our scope of work, while managing my own team of workers and subcontractors.  That experience taught me how to listen to opposing points of view and genuinely consider how to incorporate those viewpoints and concerns. 

I am also truly disinterested in dictating the outcome of any election, other than making it fair. I would be thrilled for every Congressional district in Colorado to be competitive, if its electorate was truly split. I want distinct parts of the state to be represented, not packed or cracked. I think that fair redistricting may help revive belief in our system of government.
past_political_activity:
In 2016 I was a delegate to the Denver County Democratic Convention. I think I donated money (small sums, under $200) to either the Sanders or Clinton campaigns, possibly both. I think I donated money (again small sums, for example $25 on 9/30/19) to Jason Crow's campaign in 2018 & 2019. Donations since July 2019 (when I started keeping better records):

occupation: I am a public health research scientist employed by Denver Health and Hospital Authority. I study drug abuse on the national stage.
education: I hold a doctorate from the University of Denver in biophysics.  I've been formally trained in statistics and the hard sciences. My career since school has been as a researcher in public health studying drug abuse across the nation. Relevant to this application, I'm an expert in statistics, demography, and spatial mapping. More broadly, I'm also an expert in epidemiology, research study design, and technical writing.
statement: I believe districting must be scientifically based so that votes from citizens best represent the will of the people. Modern statistical and GIS techniques should be employed so that demography and geography are leveraged for the benefit of the people. Independence of the commission is of utmost value, so that partisan influence is minimized. Colorado's split demographic among Republicans, Democrats, and Unaffiliated is an ideal design for the commission.  I wish to represent the unaffiliated voter, since my political outlook is a centrist attitude, not skewed toward one party or another. I believe my background has the right technical skills, but since I am not politically active, I would fit the criteria for an unaffiliated member of the commission.
professional_background: I have not represented or organized for any political organization.  I have experience participating in scientific societies as advocate for students and presenting my scientific work.
org_list: I'm currently a member of the American Statistical Association. Prior to this, I was a member of the American Chemical Society for  8 years.  I am not a part of any political organization.
analytic_skills: As a PhD scientist, on a daily basis, I employ complex statistical analytics to solve scientific problems (as demonstrated in my published scientific work). Before a solution is discovered, we must correctly frame a problem and the goals of any analysis. Once a problem is correctly framed, then a solution can be sought. I build defensible bodies of evidence to support public health initiatives in my professional work. In this commission, I would employ the same skills to the redistricting task. The redistricting problem must be correctly framed, the tools to solve the problem characterized, and the solution well defended logically.
consensus_statement:
In my professional work, I regularly communicate complex scientific ideas to non-scientists in government and industry. We learn skills that help those not familiar with science to understand the science. I think this experience will be helpful in this commission. As commissioners, we must find consensus on the best districts to represent the citizens of Colorado. I would need to bridge understanding between commissioners and between the commission and the public.

I work for a nonprofit safety net hospital. We provide statistical analyses to the pharmaceutical industry and to federal government regulators, where our independence is crucial to our success. Our role is intentionally and specifically impartial so that we might provide the best analysis for government to develop policy, not favoring either side in an evaluation of drug safety. We must be impartial so that medicines are proven to be safe and effective for the benefit of the populace. I believe my impartiality as a public health scientist to pharma and regulators would be best utilized by this commission.
past_political_activity: I am generally only active as a voter. I have voted regularly in elections since moving to Colorado in 2003. I do not consider myself affiliated with either party. I usually split my ballot between Democrats and Republicans, as I assess each candidates based on past experience and stances on issues. I felt the 2020 election ballot, in it's entirety, is the most important election of my life.  Only in 2020, my wife and I have donated a small amount of money to Kamala Harris's primary campaign. That was the first time I donated to a candidate in my life.

statement: I voted for the creation of the commission and strongly believe in the mission of creating voting districts that are fair and non-partisan. I have wanted for some time now to do something more than just complain about how our legislative branch is run in the United States. I feel the antidote to my anxiety over the state of democracy in the United States is to get involved and take some action to make it better.

I am very analytical and have a talent for breaking a task down to smaller, logical steps.  I am very fond of the saying: "How do you eat an elephant? One bite at a time." occupation: Retired from the State of Colorado and now Small Business Owner
education: 4+ years college/university without receiving degree
statement: I have wanted to continue public service after retirement and believe that I can bring my knowledge and ability to create a redistricting plan that is fair and equitable to the entire state of Colorado.  When working with the Colorado Department of Transportation as the Director of the Center for Equal Opportunity, I had the opportunity to work with the Transportation Commission and understand the commitment I would be making if selected.  I believe I could bring a unique perspective as a native Coloradan who has close ties to colleagues, family and friends from across the State that includes both metropolitan centers as well as rural Colorado
professional_background: During my career and community life in metropolitan Denver, I have had the opportunity to work with small, emerging, minority, and women owned businesses to assist them in working with the State of Colorado, other public institutions, and corporations.  I have worked as a volunteer at KUVO Public Radio Station as an on-air host.  I worked as a member of a curatorial team to Mexico, Colombia and Brazil to build working relationships with theatre and performing artists to perform in the United States.  Using these travels to see cultural performances around our hemisphere, I was able to bring home important improvements to our work.  As a member of the American GI Forum, I have been given the opportunity to advocate on behalf of Latino veterans and their families to ensure they receive their benefits and create educational opportunities for the families of the veterans.  I have also served on numerous boards of directors of non-profit organizations over the past 40 years working in the fields of human services, mental health and economic development.
org_list: American GI Forum Mile High Chapter; Jeffco Democratic Latino Initiative; KUVO Public Radio Station; Su Teatro Cultural & Performing Arts Center
analytic_skills: As noted above, on an annual basis, I was responsible for working independently as well as with my staff and consultants to analyze past and current data (small business utilization, employment date (broken down by gender, race, ethnicity, age, ability, etc.), census information, and more) to develop goals and activities for the next year.  These goals and plans were presented to the effected communities, employees, businesses, and elected and appointed officials.  It was critical that I understood the data analysis, anecdotal information, survey information and more when proposing goals and plans.  In addition, I became proficient in reading, understanding and interpreting Federal Regulations and State Statutes in order to ensure that our programs and plans were in compliance with Federal and State Rules and Regulations.
consensus_statement: In my role as Director of the Center for Equal Opportunity at CDOT and before that at the Regional Transportation District, I worked with numerous stakeholders that included large and small business owners, prime and subcontractors, impacted communities, elected officials, and grassroots community members.  When we would set annual goals for business and employment, it was important to hold and lead discussions that would eventually bring groups to a consensus.  On many occasions it was critical for me to put my personal feelings aside and work to find agreement with all parties.  I also understand that once agreement is found between a group of decision makers that it is important to support the final decisions and not undermine those made by the group.
past_political_activity: Crisanta Duran, 2016; Joseph Salazar, 2017; Xochitl Gaytan School Board, 2017; Angie Rivera RTD, 2018; Adrienne Benavidez 2016

occupation: I teach K-12 mathematics as Lead Instructor at the Mathnasium of Longmont.
education: I hold a Associates in Science from Front Range Community College. I am currently a student at CU expecting to graduate with a Bachelor's of Arts in Mathematics in spring of 2021. As part of my studies I'm taking a class from Professor Jeanne Clelland which covers the mathematical aspects of redistricting, with a focus on using ensemble analysis and historical data to test the fairness of electoral maps.
statement: It sounds like an unusual sort of adventure. I was thrilled when I first saw amendments Y and Z on a ballot, and I would be equally thrilled to help fulfill their vision of a truly independent and objectively fair voting map. I'm also one of the few people in Colorado old enough to serve on the commission, but young enough to have studied the mathematics of redistricting in school. I believe it is essential that someone with that technical experience be on the commission, in order to provide the commission with the tools to create an objectively fair map.
professional_background: I have not been particular active in the public sphere previously, so while I'm eager to consider the interests of all groups impartially, I imagine this is a skill I will learn through my experience on the commission rather than something I bring to the table.
org_list: I am a young and generally private person so I've had limited involvement with volunteer organizations, neighborhood associations, professional organizations, or appointed boards.
analytic_skills: In general my mathematics education and personal temperament make me well suited to solving complex analytical problems. In the case of electoral maps specifically I have a detailed understanding of the metrics which can be used to judge electoral maps, their limitations, and even some recent case law. I also have experience with the Gerrychain software developed jointly by Tufts University and MIT. I can use it both to measure the qualities of a given map (compactness, competitiveness, proportionality) and to perform an ensemble analysis. This technique involves teaching a computer to draw several billion legal maps that then serve as a representative sample that you can compare any given map against. My core concern is that the map drawn by the commission fairly represents the population of Colorado and has neutral to no impact on the outcome of future elections.
consensus_statement: As a teacher it's my job to communicate complicated ideas in an accessible way. I listen to my students and seek to understand and root out the causes of misunderstandings. I'm also a generally friendly person who can discuss political issues in an apolitical way. I see the flaws in both major parties, but I also understand the noble sentiments and sensible reasoning which leads them to their respective views of government. As such I can act as a political translator who can decode the reasoning of a Republican to a Democrat, and the reasoning of a Democrat to a Republican, and hopefully lead both back to the common ground this commission will be built on.
past_political_activity: I have never donated to or volunteered with a political campaign. As a long term resident of Weld County I've grown up in a predominantly Republican environment, and as a student at Front Range and CU-Boulder, I've been educated in a predominantly Democratic environment. After voting along party lines in my first election (though I remained unaffiliated) and seeing the outcome I made a personal commitment to vote for a mix of Democratic, Republican, and Third Party Candidates in each election, a commitment which I have carried out in both the 2018 and 2020 elections.

I have an outstanding ability to remain cool under stress and lead people to reasonable decisions.

statement: I think the representation that Colorado receives in our government, at the state and national levels, is fundamentally important to our democracy.  I believe all people should be represented fairly.  How these lines are drawn will determine if certain groups have outsized importance in our public policy.  I would love to do my part to help insure fair representation of all Coloradoans.
professional_background: With the current social justice activity happening in the state, now more than ever I am deeply concerned with the interests of underrepresented groups in Colorado, although I have not formally been involved.  To date, I have only participated in peaceful protesting for women's and reproductive rights, and for Black Lives Matter.

analytic_skills: I started my career as a financial analyst, so this has always been a core skill of mine.  I spent 7 years doing financial modelling and financial analysis in both investment banking and venture capital investing.  Since moving into corporate development and operations, I use analytics to inform all of my business decisions.  Whether understanding markets to determine whether we should launch a particular business, understanding an existing customer base to identify future sales targets, speaking with customers to inform product development, or projecting sales forecasts and budgets, all of my decisions are based on the analysis of relevant data.
consensus_statement: Throughout my professional career, I have had to influence people who did not report to me, in order to meet my goals and get things done.  Beginning in venture capital, I was not in a leadership role but had to promote investments, nor was I on the board when I needed our CEOs to undertake initiatives.  Later, in a corporate development role at Madison Square Garden, or in operations with K1 Capital, I had no formal control over the people I needed to accomplish my professional goals.  I have always done this by understanding the perspectives and goals of each person around the table, and articulating why said initiative can help to further their goals, and focusing on other people's strengths in accomplishing these team goals.  I find that finding the common thread - the common purpose - brings people naturally onto the same page.  Keeping everyone's goals in mind allows us to find a single direction and work together.

Donated to senate campaigns for Mark Kelly, Amy McGrath and Jaime Harrison (2020).

statement: This commission represents a wonderful opportunity to spotlight Colorado’s commitment to equity in representation. Fair mapping is critical to democracy, and it would be a privilege to bring my unique set of skills to this work. As I have mentioned, I am an active member of the Fort Collins community and choose to do so because the work genuinely enriches my life. I am happiest when I am of service and feel like my work is making a difference in the lives of others. The opportunity to support the efforts to ensure that the people of Colorado are fairly represented for the next decade and be part of the group that lays the groundwork for future commissions would be a privilege.
professional_background: I was asked to facilitate the Board of Directors retreat for NoCo Equality, an LGBTQ organization in Fort Collins. During this process, I helped the group clearly define board members' responsibilities and expectations, strategize actionable goals for the short and long term, and determine strategies to improve communication between members to reduce misunderstandings.

As referenced in my resume, I am an active and engaged member in my community. I served as a commissioner for the City of Loveland Human Services Commission for three years and currently sit on the Laporte Area Planning Advisory Committee. Additionally, I am a weekly volunteer for Meals on Wheels – Fort Collins, an organization that coordinates volunteers to provide a hot noontime meal and social interaction to homebound seniors. I am also a member of the United Way of Larimer County Community Impact Committee and work with other members to distribute grant funding to local nonprofits and human services organizations. Additional relevant volunteer or community engagement experience is listed below :
Facilitator, Northern Colorado Equality Board of Directors annual retreat, February 2019

analytic_skills: I am highly organized with a sharp eye for detail and have a variety of past experiences that highlight my analytical skills. I have undertaken multiple projects at work that require strategic planning, collaboration, and project management. I am currently managing a complex fundraising strategy for emerging infectious disease research in the College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences at Colorado State University. This project involves many different stakeholders and collaboration across multiple college and central university units. I am also pursuing a Master’s degree in Organizational Leadership, which offers a significant opportunity to further develop my critical thinking, research, and communication competencies.
consensus_statement: I am highly intuitive and quickly able to read and respond to individual and group dynamics while building trust and holding space for thoughtful and solution-based collaboration. I am an adept communicator, always with the express intent of ensuring that all participants feel valued and heard. My past work as a commissioner for the Human Services Commission for the City of Loveland and my current appointment on the United Way of Larimer County Community Impact Committee have provided ample opportunities to practice collaboration and reaching consensus. Both groups are comprised of community members who come together to determine how best to support the efforts of local human services agencies and not-for-profits, using either state funding or private impact philanthropy. It likely isn’t a surprise that the total requests for funding far outpace the amount of award dollars available in most funding cycles. Thus, the distribution of these awards always requires thoughtful, careful consideration on the part of committee members, and then collaborative and productive conversations to reach consensus on how best to award grants strategically to achieve the best possible outcomes for our community.
past_political_activity: My past political activity has mostly involved making financial contributions to democratic campaigns, both locally and nationally. Additionally, I organized friends and family to write postcards to swing-state voters to encourage them to vote on Tuesday, Nov. 3rd, 2020.

statement: I truly love Colorado.  I was born here and cannot fathom living anywhere else.  As a native of the western slope but current northern front-ranger, I feel deeply that I personally represent both District 3 and District 2.  In addition, I have family, friends, colleagues, and co-workers all around the state, from the eastern plains to the four corners.  I want to see each and every one of them vote with confidence.
professional_background: My main civic experience comes from raising my children in Colorado.  As the mother of both a gifted child and a special needs child, I found myself training to be an educational advocate and volunteer coordinator.  That work was a study in listening carefully to everybody - students, parents, teachers, siblings.  I explored equitable solutions with the aim of helping everyone thrive.

analytic_skills: I am currently taking coursework specifically related to the mathematics of redistricting.   I am learning first-hand how to audit redistricting plans.  I attended the Colorado College's 'Best Practices in Redistricting' workshop in September, 2020 to learn more about the legal requirements and background, and have been studying how other states established their districting rules and prioritized different criteria.  My aim in doing so is to become a fully-qualified commissioner on day one.
consensus_statement: My overall approach is to recommend what is best for Colorado as a whole.  We have a strong state with many positive aspects, none of which I want to see diminished or endangered.  I want to listen carefully to what everyone has to say.  Ultimately, this commission will be considering tradeoffs between different criteria. Since there will be no straightforward, universal consensus on what is "fair", I believe we should first establish ground rules on what we will prioritize based on legal requirements, community input, staff guidance, and the unique attributes that make Colorado great.  As we move into looking at partitioning plans, I would respectfully guide the commission to play by those ground rules.  We do, however, have guidance on what is not fair: gerrymandered district partitions.  I will keep a keen eye out for that and question all proposals that look to contain outlier partitions not allowed in the ground rules.
past_political_activity: No past political activity.  I've always focused my community involvement in the educational arena then the political arena until now.

I believe that I can advocate for people's concerns to be placed at the nexus of this commission's work. I believe that achieving consensus is possible via a formulaic approach to meeting problems as they arise, discussing their provenance, determining potential solutions and evaluating them along the lines of impact, and implementing ideas in a testable manner. Fairness and impartiality are objectivist constructs - I am instead able to locate myself in my lived experiences, and have awareness of where those experiences are limited and need additional input from folks who have diverse view points.

occupation: I am currently self-employed as an attorney.
education: I earned a B.A. at Oberlin College in 1992 with a major in mathematics and three minors: history, government, and law and society. I earned a J.D., cum laude, at the University of Michigan Law School in 1994. I am admitted to the practice of law in New York State and in Colorado.
statement: My firm command of the mathematical and legal considerations that go into drafting district boundaries, my rich and detailed knowledge of Colorado's physical, human, political, social and historical geography (drawn from practicing law both on the Western Slope, in its mountain communities, and in all major Front Range cities rural and urban, and from having family in Akron, Colorado) and skill and experience with working fruitfully within committees makes it possible for me to provide a well informed, thoughtful contribution to the commission's work.
professional_background: I am a long time active member of the Democratic Party and a long time advocate for good government and evidence based policy making. I have been an advocate for secular people in Colorado and an advocate for weaker land use regulation.
org_list: American Humanist Association, Colorado Criminal Justice Coalition, ACLU, George Washington High School Speech and Debate Club, Colorado Bar Association, Member of Colorado Bar Association Provider Of Alternative Legal Services (PALS) subcommittee (previously called the LLLT Subcommittee), Oberlin College Alumni Association, University of Michigan Alumni Association, author of Wash Park Prophet blog, author of Dispatches From Turtle Island blog, contributor to Law.StackExchange and Politics.StackExchange forums, former member of Society for Professional Journalists
analytic_skills: I provided mathematical support of cluster analysis methods used in the development of the National Drought Atlas (an effort my father who was a leader in geographic information systems was leading). I have routinely analyzed census data and other public domain data down to the census block and individual school level since I was in high school for a variety of purposes. For example, I analyzed Denver Public Schools data to show the effect of different high schools in its system on the college prospects of students identified as gifted and talented (shocking negative in the case of former West High School). My undergraduate studies were focused on applied mathematics including statistical analysis and operations research in which I solved problems such as developing algorithms for airline logistics, traffic light systems, and efficient delivery routes. I have used multidisciplinary methods including archaeology, climate history, linguistics and population genetics to develop credible hypotheses in historical linguistics, some of which have been cited in academic journals. I routinely analyze legal problems in transactional tax analysis and in litigation at the trial court, intermediate appellate court and Colorado Supreme Court level.
consensus_statement: I have spent a lifetime taking complex technical issues as applied to specific factual situations in a manner that an ordinary layperson can understand, and I have decades of experience (predating my professional career through involvement in student government in college and law school) in negotiating compromises among people with serious disagreements (e.g. labor and manage disputes, protester and administration disputes, and Republican and sex-coop disputes while in student government). One of my hobbies is science journalism via my Dispatches From Turtle Island blog on issues of anthropology, prehistory, population genetics, and fundamental physics. I have successfully mediated a hot and ideological litigation disputes with a self-identified Nazi with a dog named Himmler. In the several layers of the caucus process every two years in Denver, I've been one of the most efficient and effective meeting facilitators in the City. I have experience conducting meetings with a Feminist process or consensus process as well as conventional Robert's Rules of Order processes. I have facilitated class discussions as a professor on highly charged issues. I know how to listen and have many years of experience judging speech and debate competitions impartially. I am committed to the goal of drawing even handed electoral districts for Colorado.
past_political_activity: I have been active in the Democratic Party since arriving in Colorado in 1996. I have attended more than one state Democratic Party convention all prior to 2012, I was a treasurer for a Democratic Party counter commissioner candidate in Mesa County, Colorado in the late 1990s, I served for several years as a Precinct Committee Person in my Denver neighborhood in the early 2000s, I was Treasurer of the Democratic Party of Denver (2/07-2/09), and I was a law partner of a Anne McGihon (as Democratic party state representative) through 2009 and assisted her in her official as well as her professional duties in that capacity. Since November 10, 2015, I have donated money to Jena Griswold for Colorado (three donations of $360 from 12/28/17 to 10/2/18); Romanoff for Colorado ($50 on 9/29/19), Denver Democratic Central Committee ($20 on 3/9/20); McCorkle for Colorado ($100 on 5/17/2020); Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez For Congress ($27 on 6/21/20) and ActBlue ($2.70 on 6/21/20).

occupation: I am the Head of School at the High Mountain Institute in Leadville
education: B.A. and M.A., both in History. My MA is from CU-Boulder and my BA is from Middlebury College
statement: The work of this commission will have an enormous impact on my community. This will be the third re-districting cycle I have experienced since I moved to Leadville. Each time, I have seen Lake County placed in districts in which we are on the far periphery; once we were placed in a Colorado Springs-based district and we are now in one centered around Pueblo and the Western Slope. Lake County has been divorced each time from our communities of interest, such as Summit and Eagle Counties, and our needs have differed vastly from the needs of other communities in the districts. It often feels like we have not been seen in the redistricting process. I'd like to help make sure Lake County's voice is heard in these efforts, as well as to hear the voices of other sometimes-forgotten parts of the state. Further, as someone who is a registered and proud Democrat, I would be taking a Democratic seat on the commission. Lake County is a Democratic town, but our needs as an under-resourced rural community are different than the populous urban areas and uber-wealthy resort towns that we often think of as making up the Democratic Party in Colorado. Still, we are loyal to the Democratic Party, and I believe my community too deserves to have a seat at the table on the Democratic side as we work through the question of what effective representation will look like in Colorado for the next decade.
professional_background: Please see above. I am deeply involved equity efforts in Lake County and bettering our under-resourced, rural community. I am a founding board member of the Lake County Community Fund, which convenes community agencies, helps fund non-profits, and strives to meet community needs in Leadville/Lake County. I am also been actively involved in the governance and day-to-day operations of the Bright Start Early Learning Center, Leadville's only childcare center. This effort involves working with state regulatory agencies, elected representatives, and community leaders to meet the critical need for early childhood care in rural Colorado. In the summer of 2020, I brought together Lake County commissioners, Leadville’s mayor, and the LCSD superintendent to help find a new location for Bright Start. I was part of a successful effort to ensure the school district, which is constructing a new elementary school building, received a BEST (restricted educational construction funds from the state) grant waiver to allow it to build sufficient pre-school classrooms for Lake County's growing population. As part of our response to COVID, I organized other boarding schools that are part of the Association of Colorado Independent Schools to seek interpretations from the Office of the Governor of his public health orders to address the unique situation of boarding schools in our state.
org_list: I sit on the boards of two non-profits, the Lake County Community Foundation and a local preschool, Bright Start Learning Center. Since 2015, I have served on the Finance Committee of the Association of Colorado Independent Schools. I also served in 2016-17 on the organizing committee for Get Outdoors Leadville, which was awarded a multi-million-dollar grant from Great Outdoors Colorado (GOCO). I am a highly active and involved parent in our local school district, Lake County R-1.
analytic_skills:
This may be my strong suit, and why this commission appeals to me. There are hundreds of possible answers to how Colorado can draw district boundaries--we will need to select one. Understanding a problem, identifying possible solutions, and evaluating the merits of each is where I thrive. It is what I do every day in my work. In education, we have a principle called Backward Design. The idea is to start with a goal and work backward to identify the steps most important to achieving that outcome—and to avoid getting distracted by interesting but inconsequential details. Backward design works wonders while planning effective classroom lessons, and I could see it helping solve many problems our commission will face as well.
As a Head of School, I must also decide how to use my time each day. I need to determine which questions are urgent and important (they need my attention and time) and which questions are unimportant and unurgent (others can address these problems). The battles that are worth fighting are the ones that will have adverse long-term consequences for the most important goals. I am good at seeing the difference between signal and noise, and will often ask others in the middle of a discussion to remind us of the problem we are trying to solve. The answer to this question will often tell us if we are discussing the right topics.
Finally, I am creative. My mind goes to work as soon as an important issue feels intractable. The Lake County School District, for example, was awarded a state BEST grant in 2019 to help construct a new PK-2 elementary school. The rules that govern the grant are complex, but new buildings cannot contain more classrooms than exist in the current one. Yet Lake County’s school-age population is booming: as our student count grew, we were faced with the prospect of moving into a new school that would be obsolete the day it opened. School leaders saw the problem as intractable, but I saw it as existential. I went before the school board and suggested appealing the issue to the state governing board; I hoped the board would show flexibility, especially if declining construction costs would mean we could add additional classrooms within the original project budget. The school district decided at the eleventh hour to appeal the original ruling, and our school district won the appeal! Our new school will open next year with sufficient classrooms to serve our community’s children.
consensus_statement:
I am an educator: what I do is try to teach students how to collaborate, assume the best in others, and think critically. These skills are what lead to consensus and create agreement. On the commission, I pledge not to exploit the weakest parts another member’s arguments to discredit the entirety of their positions. Instead, I will do what I try to teach my students: identify the strongest parts of the positions of others and use these to find consensus. For example, I am working on a committee currently at school to address issues of diversity, equity, and inclusion. We could take many different pathways to chart the work of this group, and we have heard from many stakeholders. In the end, I believe everyone I consulted will find aspects of their feedback and ideas in the final draft. 
Additionally, in my professional life, I am part of a talented, committed, and diverse team. I contribute to agreement by remembering I am a conductor of a choir: everything is better when we elevate all voices ensure they are heard. As we chart a path forward for my school, I need to listen for shared values. Common values often hold the key to reaching agreement. If we can agree on objectives, suddenly we find we can compromise on the ways to achieve those goals. For example, we recently were seeking to identify facilities needs for campus for the next twenty years. I had an idea to address HMI’s needs, but other people in the working group broached a different proposal. In the end, their idea achieved the same goals I shared, in a possibly more creative manner. We incorporated some of my ideas into the second solution and adopted it. 
The second part of this question is about being fair and impartial. This is also what I practice every day as a Head of School. I find I can only have one agenda: what is good for students and right for my school I am willing to hear any ideas or perspectives that address this concern. On this commission, my goal will be to best serve the people of Colorado. I will be open to any ideas that address this concern: I can never be a wedded to one approach. I am very well practiced in setting aside any personal agenda I have for the good of the mission in front of me. Serving on this commission is not about me and my wishes, it is about the citizens of this state.
past_political_activity: My only political donation I remember since 2015 was approximately $25 to Michael Johnson’s primary campaign for governor in 2018. To be honest, I have spent my free time over the last several years focusing on the needs of my community over electoral politics. I am a regular voter, but have not participated actively in campaigns recently. I worked on Capitol Hill in DC twenty years ago, and I volunteered for then state-representative candidate Dan Gibbs during his first campaign in 2006. I also understand, however, the importance of the electoral process. I try to follow the dictum: "Go where you are useful." Recently, it has seemed like I could be most useful serving on non-electoral boards and commissions. Now, however, ensuring Lake County has effective electoral representation feels like where I can have the greatest impact.
