statement: I believe that political polarization is destroying rational political discourse and compromise and, unless we find a way to reduce it, will eventually destroy our democracy.  I am hopeful that careful, balanced redistricting will reduce polarization and promote civil, respectful conversations and compromise.
professional_background:
I’ve spent more than 40 years organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering the interests of groups, organizations, and associations in Colorado as a public finance lawyer and as a board member of a variety of Colorado governmental and nonprofit organizations.

As a public finance lawyer, I’ve represented and advocated for the interests of state and local governments in hundreds of complex financing transactions involving many billions of dollars.  As the “bond counsel” (the lead lawyer) and principal draftsman of the documents governing these transactions, my role has been to ensure that the interests, rights and obligations of my state and local government clients, as well as the other governments, financial institutions, groups, organizations, associations and private parties involved in the transactions, are thoroughly considered and balanced so that I can draft the legal documents that clearly describe the rights and obligations of all parties.  I’ve organized new Colorado governmental organizations by drafting and working in the legislature to enact legislation creating new governmental organizations, negotiating and drafting intergovernmental agreements and organizational documents governing the new governmental organizations and representing those organizations in negotiating and completing financings; examples include public highway authorities, regional transportation authorities, CDOT’s bridge enterprise and high-performance transportation enterprise and the Building Excellent Schools Today program. 

As a board member and officer of a variety of Colorado governmental and nonprofit organizations (see list of organizations in the answer to the preceding question), I’ve had intensive hands-on experience in organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering the interests of my organizations, the constituents of my organizations and the other Colorado groups, organizations, and associations with which they interact.

analytic_skills:
I’ve spent the last 40+ years using my analytical skills, logic and reason to solve problems and bring people together: to complete complex, multi-party public finance transactions as a public finance lawyer; and to implement community-based policies and programs as a board member and officer of a variety of governmental and nonprofit organizations.

As the “bond counsel” (the lead lawyer) for hundreds of complex public finance transactions involving billions and billions of dollars, it has been my job: to identify the legal, financial and operational issues involved in the transactions; to facilitate negotiations among the parties until everyone agrees on all the rights and obligations of each party; to draft the legal documents governing the transactions; to revise and rerevise the legal documents until everyone’s issues have been resolved and written down; and, finally, to deliver legal opinions that the financing transaction described in the legal documents complies with a complex array of federal, state and local laws.
	
As a board member and officer of governmental and nonprofit organizations, I’ve spent thousands of hours using my analytical skills, logic, and reason to identify and resolve issues for my constituents, the community we serve and the public.
consensus_statement:
I’ve spent the last 40+ years successfully promoting consensus and helping to create agreement among a wide variety of people with competing interests and agendas.  As a public finance lawyer, I’ve successfully promoted consensus and helped create agreement among people with competing interests and agendas in order to complete financings.  As a board member and officer of governmental and nonprofit organizations, I’ve successfully promoted consensus and helped create agreement among people with competing interests and agendas in developing and implementing community-based policies and programs for the benefit of  governmental and nonprofit organizations, their constituents and the public.

I have experience being fair and impartial in hearing and ruling on student discipline cases as a member of the Denver School Board, evaluating employees as a partner in a law firm, as a member of the Denver School Board and as a board member of nonprofit organizations and evaluating and selecting the best proposal for services and goods submitted pursuant to request for proposal processes as the Treasurer and a member of evaluation panels for Denver Public Schools and as a member of evaluation panels established by my governmental clients and the nonprofit boards on which I have served.

occupation:
Technical Sales Manager, REI Drilling
Owner of PS Kreative, LLC, dba "BottlePro"
education: Bachelor's degree in Mining Engineering and a minor in Business from Virginia Tech.  Graduated Dec 2009.
statement:
I am a moderate who agrees with certain views from each party.  However, both parties have strayed so far to the extremes that I don't feel like I have a real choice anymore, and I know there are many other people who feel the same way.  I've found in my relatively short lifetime that when two sides are very far apart, 80% of the time the best course of action is somewhere in between.  Right now, the loudest sides of both parties drown out any calls from moderates to have civil dialogue and actually create compromises.  There are many reasons why this has happened (media and social media bubbles on both sides, the current primary system weeding out moderates, etc...), but one of the primary factors is partisan gerrymandering leading to non-competitive districts.

This independent redistricting commission gives me hope that it's possible to make non-partisan districts that are truly competitive and where each citizen's vote has the same impact no matter where they reside.  I'm a firm believer in the statement "citizens should choose their representatives, not the other way around," and this commission, if run correctly, is a good step in the right direction for this state.  It's one of the few ways I've seen available for moderate citizens like me to be involved in a meaningful way, and I would be honored to be a part of this effort.  There are certainly other steps that would need to be taken to help raise the bar of dialogue, but this is a step in the right direction.

org_list: n/a
analytic_skills: I'm an engineer by training and am very comfortable with numbers and fact-based problem solving.  I often make spreadsheets for my own use, like with analyzing real estate deals, budgeting/saving, projecting sales for a new product, and many other situations.  I use these spreadsheets and the resulting information to guide personal and business decisions, not the other way around.
consensus_statement: I would act as a check to any extremes from both parties.  My main focus would be to create districts that are fair for all citizens, regardless of party.  I've spent years managing ~30 employees at a drilling company, and I've also started my own business.  Both experiences have trained me to be patient, listen more, and then find the best and fairest solution moving forward.  There are many times when friends or family of a particular party complain about the other side, and while I may agree with their points, I'll often act as the Devil's advocate for the opposite party.  I feel very strongly that the vast majority of people are reasonable when they're not yelling or getting yelled at, and it's this kind of civil dialogue that I will help promote if I'm on the commission.

statement:
I want to serve on the commission because I believe I that fair redistricting is a cornerstone of representative democracy and because my soft and hard skills will both contribute to a process that will serve the people of Colorado.
I have been interested in redistricting since college, when I participated in a 1985 project led by Common Cause in Indiana. I demonstrated that it was possible to create a city council district in South Bend, Indiana, that united much of the central-city African American community in one district rather than dispersing the members of that community among districts that extended from the center to outlying neighborhoods. I continued working with Common Cause in Indiana in a citizen-led effort to show how single-member state legislative districts could be created that respected jurisdictional boundaries. At that time, in the early 1990s, Indiana used multimember districts around some major cities that diluted the voting power of certain communities by merging them with outlying areas that would drown out their voice.
I resumed engaging with redistricting after my retirement from the Air Force. I provided comments on El Paso County Commissioner districts, where the process was particularly disturbing. The county would tweak its maps frequently, shuffling precincts to ensure that one party would win every seat. Sometimes a precinct would be swapped so frequently that its citizens would not be able to vote for commissioner for several cycles. In recent years, the county has gone to extremes to imagine communities of interest that are not based on the real identities of local citizens. My dismay at this process was one of the reasons I ran for County Clerk and Recorder in 2010.
After being defeated by Wayne Williams for county office, I actively participated in the public comments for 2010 statewide redistricting and also became involved in a successful effort to reduce the proportion of at-large city council seats from 5 of 9 to 3 of 9. Prior to this, no city council members were living in the central areas of the city. I then engaged with community groups to argue for a district that would unify the southeastern portion of the community, with its distinct interests, rather than splitting and dispersing that community among several districts.
My overall takeaway from these experiences is that elected officials have an inherent conflict of interest in redistricting: preserving their own power and that of their political party. These override an important principle of living in a democratic republic: that the voters select their representatives, not the other way around.
professional_background:
The longest and broadest example of such advocacy stems from my service to the Public Trustee Association of Colorado, on its board and on its legislative committee. Working with representatives of all 64 Colorado counties helped me develop a deeper understanding of the variety of interests in different parts of the state. While I represented a very large county, I recognized that proposals that might make sense in Colorado Springs would not meet the needs of rural counties. At the same time, I also learned how to help the elected officials in those counties understand the needs of the larger and urban counties. 
Since 2007, I have also advocated for the protection of public lands in Colorado. I helped lead an effort to map out the boundaries of a large roadless area in the Rampart Range and promote awareness of the recreational opportunities in that area. My work resulted in the addition of over 1000 acres to the roadless area by discovering mapping errors. I have continued my advocacy through developing and coordinating public comments on Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management proposals and by helping Wild Connections develop reports on lands with wilderness characteristics. I also take direct action in this area: as a certified trail crew leader, I have led teams to design, build, and repair trails in El Paso, Teller, and Douglas counties.
From 2008-2014, I served as an at-large member of the Community Advisory Committee to the Pikes Peak Area Council of Governments. In that role, I heard the concerns of different groups within the region and helped evaluate priorities for infrastructure and parks.
org_list:
Throughout the period, Conservation Chair of the Pikes Peak Group of the Colorado Mountain Club
2018-2019 Member of the Board of the Public Trustee Association of Colorado. Also served on the board earlier in the decade, and a member of the association throughout.
2008-2019 Public Trustee for El Paso County (appointed by Governors Ritter, Hickenlooper, and Polis)
analytic_skills:
I have strong mathematical and linguistic skills. I taught research methods for several years at the Air Force Academy and now coach graduate students through the development and execution of research projects. This requires me to help them use logic and reason to develop methods that will answer their questions.
While my graduate degrees are in political science, I am trained as an engineer. My Air Force acquisition assignments fell into the realm of systems engineering, which is defined by bringing logic and reason to problems. Early on, I conducted a safety analysis of the Air Force One wiring system that became the basis for a high-level decision not to retrofit the system because the risk was acceptable. Soon after that, I helped Strategic Air Command develop workable solutions to a problem with isocyanate hazards in missile maintenance facilities. Toward the end of my time in weapons system acquisition, I was in charge of ensuring that the implementation and installation of a new pilot training management system would meet the needs of the Air Force and the country.
I spent fall 2004 in Baghdad, where I served as the political strategist for the military coalition. To an even greater extent than other assignments, this work required me to obtain and synthesize a vast amount of information—on militias, the campaign plan, the Iraqi election, a Sunni Arab engagement strategy, and many other topics—and develop succinct summaries and recommendations for command. As one of the most junior officers in the strategy office, I had to rely on tight logic and reason when presenting information that was often not what senior leaders wanted to hear. This work was also conducted in a fairly high-stress environment.
A particular strength that sets me apart from others in these areas is my skill at mapping and spatial representation. While it may not translate directly to the work of a commission member, I am very good at understanding geographic relationships. Beyond my comments to public lands management plans, I am a skilled land navigator in the backcountry and have designed and constructed new trail alignments in the forest. Both of those tasks require an agility at abstract manipulation of space to understand how to best create a route, either for the day’s hike or for a trail. Similar abstract manipulations may be helpful in envisioning options for develop legislative districts that serve the interests of the people of Colorado.
consensus_statement:
I demonstrated my ability to be fair and impartial while I was serving as Public Trustee for El Paso County for 11 years. In that role, I had to ensure that my deputies and I administered foreclosure law fairly and equitably, setting aside any personal feelings about particular cases or how we might wish the law were different. 
I will be able to promote consensus and contribute to creating agreement because I am good at listening to others and understanding their interests and preferences. That allows me to reflect on their argument and show good faith by reconsidering my own positions and where they could be more in alignment with those of others. At the same time, I am able to couch my own views in ways that appeal to the values that others hold. This was particularly useful as a member of the Public Trustee Association Board and Legislative Committee, during which time most of my colleagues were elected officials of another political party and had been representing rural counties for many years.
My ability to promote consensus in those ways largely stems from my Air Force career, as described in more detail in the next answer. In most assignments, I was by rank the junior person even when I was a peer on the organization chart. That meant that the only way I could promote safety, design decisions, or a wartime engagement strategy was by persuasive discussion and making sure that I had data to back up my position. I also found it helpful to let others take credit for my ideas as if they were their own rather than merely coming into agreement with me. These experiences also taught me to engage when I thought it really mattered and hold off from trying to get my way for its own sake. 
I have also used these skills to build coalitions during public lands discussion periods. While environmental groups share broad common goals, they do differ in their priorities. It was important to find ways to get several groups to sign on to a single letter rather than taking divergent positions that would not help land managers reach the decision we preferred. The comments I developed for these federal decisions were always richly detailed in maps and coordinates that provided rich detail about facts on the ground that were the basis of our response.
past_political_activity:
I ran for El Paso County Clerk and Recorder in 2010 (lost). I was a Democratic Party precinct chair from 2008-2010.

Logic then followed in formulating and evaluating options, and reason was then applied to reach decisions.  Data and facts govern the process, not emotion or subjective opinion.
consensus_statement: In my experience as a Naval officer, and especially in my duty with the US Embassy in Venezuela,  I developed skills in communication on sensitive topics of diverse opinions. In my later career as a developer of planned communities (involving extensive public dialog), together  with my experience in civic and non-profit organizations, I have further enhanced my skill in managing discussion among a diversity of attendees.  All this experience has contributed to a proven ability to lead groups to consensus through open, civil discourse. Inherent in that skill is the need to be open to all information and opinion, without bias; to then assess all opinions and facts objectively; and to then finally reach impartial determinations in achieving the mission and goals at hand.

occupation: Please see resume
education: Bachelor of Arts - Adams State University - Double major- Business and Psychology
statement: I m a fifth generation Coloradoan and I want to assure that Colorado remains strong and representative of all Coloradoans.  I was shocked and saddened how map manipulation in other states caused a distortion in their representation at the federal and state level.  I think this leads to voter disillusionment and a feeling that their votes do not matter.  One of the educational events held at my home was about Amendment Y and Z.  I have become more aware of the importance through All On The Line, which educates people about the importance of fair maps.  Voters need to pick their representatives at the federal and state level, not the other way around.
professional_background: I completed the Organizing for Action Fellows program.  As part of the program, I organized an educational event on Climate Change at a library.  I also hosted educational events at my home, like books club discussions and speakers on ballot issues as well as post card writing parties.  I also had phone banking events at my home to bring attention to events in Denver.  I also helped organize texting events.
org_list: I volunteered with Organizing for Action in December 2016.  That organization merged into All On The Line of which I am currently a member.  I have also attended events with Indivisible Front Range and Indivisible Denver. I attend my House District 6 meetings and activities when I am able.  I used to be a part of a breakfast group “Pancakes with Progressives” that hosted progressive candidates for an informal discussion around a breakfast table.
analytic_skills: My career as a human resource professional required multi-tasking, problem solving and excellent organization and communication skills.  As a HR Generalist, my job responsibilities centered on benefits and recruitment.  I was the team lead for implementing a new payroll/human resource software system. I am proficient in Microsoft office.  Retired from Human Resources, I am now in Philanthropy.  The non-profit I work stopped using their Customer Relationship Software.  I developed a spreadsheet for use in our department that can track needed data and can pull information using pivot tables.
consensus_statement:
One of my earliest memories was going to pick up my grandmother on election day, she was an election judge.  Voting has always been important in my family, but I would not have considered myself “political”. My dad was involved in town council in Pine Haven Wyoming and my aunt was mayor of Pine Knoll Shores in North Carolina.  They both leaned Republican and many in my family still are Republicans. I aligned with the Democratic Party in 2008 because I wanted to help with the convention.  As I have become more involved, I more closely align with the Democratic platform, such as health care and environmental protections than with the traditional Republican platform of less government involvement and conservative social values. With my background, I have cultivated skills that have built fairness and impartially in my core values.
I struggle with the current administration and it is my hope that after November there will be an increased desire for people to work together for the common good.  We can begin this ideal by working together locally. A couple of years ago, I attended an event at the Denver Film Society in which one of the panelists was Eleanor Clift, a Washington journalist.  She proposed that the intense political division was created in part because people did not know each other at the personal level. She mentioned that Tip O’Neill and Reagan could be friends because they created opportunities to be together after work.  With today’s politicians leaving Washington as soon as work is over and not cultivating after work relationships, the camaraderie is lost.  I will suggest that the commission meet on a non-formal basis to cultivate relationships with each other.  If the group as whole chooses not to do this, I will reach out on a one-on-one basis to build camaraderie.
past_political_activity: I have donated money to Steven Woodrow Colorado HD6, Diane Mitsch Bush CD3 and an organization called “Stop Republicans” through Act Blue.  I have also donated money to Amy McGrath for Kentucky Senate and Diana DeGette Colorado House Rep District 1.

consensus_statement: The biggest thing is as Americans, we all have the right to vote as an American citizen.  My opinion does not matter.  Making sure all votes are accounted for abd everyone has a voice is

education:
University of Denver Sturm College of Law -- JD, 2016
University of Beijing -- Teaching English as a Foreign Language Certification, 2010
University of Michigan -- BA, 2009
statement: Civic engagement is the highest form of democracy and community service. I was born and raised in Colorado and value a truly representative democratic future for our state. I am proud of the direction our state has taken: Moving closer and closer to being a leader in one-person-one-vote and equitable, free-and-fair elections. I want to be a part of the next step in this process--this is a calling, an opportunity, and a privilege.
professional_background: As a juvenile civil rights attorney, I have worked in several capacities to collaborate and support community organizers and grassroots organizations. For example, I provided legal research and organizing support for Padres y Jovenes Unidos' efforts to lobby the Denver Public Schools' Board to cancel its contract with the Denver Police Department. In my current role as board member of several organizations and groups, I work to encourage and promote civic engagement as well as wider engagement with education--specifically around individual civil liberties.

Colorado Criminal Defense Initiative Board of Directors
Words Beyond Bars Board of Directors
analytic_skills: As previously mentioned, my career as a lawyer requires daily application of logic and reason to all sorts of complex issues. I regularly reconcile detailed factual circumstances with nuanced law so as to resolve issues my clients face. At times, this requires issue-spotting--i.e. identifying problems that my clients may not initially label but may become significant barriers as we move forward. I must also think critically and analytically about how opposing parties, potential partners, or the court will address issues.
consensus_statement: As an attorney, my job requires the ability to be a neutral assessor of facts and law. This is invaluable in building consensus and bridging differences of opinions. My work also requires high-level listening and communication skills--hearing what others are saying (even when it requires "reading between the lines") and articulately and precisely conveying my positions as well as my understanding of others' positions. Additionally, lawyers typically convey power and consume attention and focus in the room--people often defer to lawyers' expertise; my humbling experience working with community organizers, grassroots organizations, and several nonprofit boards has helped me understand how to effectively step-back and allow space for others to speak, take on leadership, and engage effectively as equal partners in a project.
past_political_activity: To my knowledge, I have not donated to any campaigns or political organizations. I have made donations to several nonprofits (e.g. ACLU of Colorado, Learn Your Rights in the Community, etc.), but I do not think I have given any money to political campaigns, action committees, or organizations.

statement: As indicated above, I think working in a group toward a common solution to be a strength; it's something I can offer.  I'm interested in fair and equitable representation, less subject to the whims of vested interests, while acknowledging the legitimate role of representative government.
professional_background: My entire career as a special education teacher serving emotionally and learning disabled children involved organizing, advocating, and considering the interests of diverse and often contentious stakeholders, steering individuals and groups toward solutions that the group could live with.  I consider effectively and kindly working in and with groups to be a strength.
org_list: I volunteered as a grant writer for a medical organization serving low-income immigrant populations.  I am a member of the NAACP.
analytic_skills: Unfortunately, I was a Philosophy major as an undergraduate.  I even damaged myself further by recently taking a senior seminar class on Aristotle-just for "fun".  Apart from the ability to construct and deconstruct arguments/theses/positions, etc. I am able to use my analytic skills in a humane manner such that the group process can proceed effectively.
consensus_statement: First, I don't have to be in charge; I can be part of a group and thus, I am able to listen and be present without alienating other members of the group.  Two, I know how to perceive and summarize the essence of what individuals are saying and reflect this back to the group in a helpful manner.  Three, I can integrate diverse interests into common themes and help individuals move forward. Finally, I'm able to keep conversations and individuals on track according to stated agendas for a particular meeting time.
past_political_activity: My political involvement has been limited to donation and the occasional letter/note to my congressperson.

As deputy Commander for Operations at the 2nd (now 50th) Space Wing up until retirement in 1988, I had to deal with many manning, funding and personnel challenges.

As an Affiliate Faculty Member at Regis University I had to facilitate hundreds of student group projects with a wide range of individual commitment to the group goals to produce a composite product in a short 5-8 week period, often resolving personality conflicts and disagreements.  White I consider myself to be primarily conservative in orientation, I respect divergent views and the right of individual to hold and live them.

occupation: Retired
education: BS,Engineering Mechanics, US Air Force Academy, 1972; MBA, Sul Ross State University (TX)1976; MA, History, Arizona State University, 2003; PhD, History, Arizona State University, 2007; Air Command and Staff College, 1986 (USAF); National War College, 1991 (Joint).
statement: I lived and voted in Texas for much of my 21 year Air Force career and witnessed first hand the ridiculous results of partisan gerrymandering in that state. I strongly oppose partisan manipulations designed to artificially enhance party election advantage to the detriment of the citizens of the districts. Election districts should be composed of regions designed with primary consideration to geography and cultural similarities of the area not political affiliation.
professional_background: I rewrote the CCRs and Articles of Incorporation for the Songbird Owner's Association, our local HOA based on my previous experience as Vice President of the Needles Homeowner's Association (Durango), President of the Cielo Vista HOA (Mesa, AZ), and member of the Red Mountain Ranch HOA (Mesa, AZ). The rewrite included a thorough review of Colorado statutes and creating a two thirds majority to approve the new documents. I performed similar functions in the earlier organizations. As a member of the Historic Preservation Board, I took part in efforts to preserve the history the city and several significant structures in Durango, CO.
org_list: Habitat  for Humanity; Songbird Owner's Association; Historic Preservation Board (Durango); Treasurer, Christ the King Lutheran Church, Durango; Site Steward, Canyons of the Ancients National Monument.
analytic_skills: As an undergraduate engineer and later as a doctoral candidate, I learned to apply a reasoned and logical approach to the solution of problems. Certainly as a fighter pilot and airline captain, such an approach was essential to my professional success.
consensus_statement: During my Air Force career, I served as a fighter squadron commander after l gaining experience at lower levels of command. I know how to work with people and inspire them to perform as a cohesive unit under difficult circumstance. After completing the course of study at the prestigious National War College in Washington, DC I served as a staff action officer on General Colin Powell's Joint Staff where I learned the fine points of operating effectively in a bureaucratic organization where consensus was the primary goal. My primary activity during that time was to work with the services from a joint perspective on the Report to Congress on the Conduct of the (first) Gulf War. Fairness and impartiality were essential in command and staff assignments. Later, I served a Captain with Southwest Airlines, once again responsible for leading a team to provide a safe and profitable operation.

occupation: Retired science teacher for Cherry Creek School District - substitute teacher as needed
education:
M.S. University of Utah  Exercise Physiology
B.S.   Utah State University  - Secondary Education, Chemistry Empahasis
Career and Technical Education  - STEM certification
Career and Technical Education - Integrated Science certification
Colorado State Teaching Certificate
statement:
As a high school science teacher I have had the opportunity to work with young adults on a daily basis,
both in and out of the classroom. They are generally more candid and to the point than adults and seeing
things from their viewpoint is a valuable tool that I will bring to the commission.
I am a woman, of Asian descent, from a rural community, currently living in a suburban area. Growing
up, I understood the high cost of farming, and how things could turn with an untimely storm or drought,
as well as the magic of watching a crop grow, and the value of a hard day's work. My Asian heritage
provides background knowledge on the minority experience of racial and cultural discrimination. Being a
woman and adoptive mother provides additional lenses to view life. Finding one’s identity is especially
difficult for an adopted child who must sort through abandonment issues, and racial issues compounding
the already complex task of growing up. Women face every day challenges of balancing work and family,
often providing care for elderly parents and sick family members.
Fair maps will help ensure that each vote counts equally, and areas will not be skewed to the advantage of
any particular group or party. Fair maps will ensure our election officials accurately represent their
constituents.
Volunteering on several campaigns at the local, state and national levels has shown me the importance of
the election process in the preservation of our democracy. Working in public schools and engaging kids
in extracurricular activities gave me the opportunity to work with parents, professionals in the community,
and motivated students. These groups see things from slightly different viewpoints and it is a valuable
lesson in broadening my perspectives when interacting with a wide variety of groups.
professional_background:
As a member of Heritage Camps for Adoptive Families, we advocated for transracially adopted families
of all ethnic groups and genders. I helped organize family camps for several ethnicities as well as other
activities for families to educate, and provide social spaces for children to be with families who are in
similar situations.
In TUFIR we actively supported students and adults who were in the GEO ICE facility, and also
immigrants that were newly released from the facility. We provided food, clothing and money as support
as well as letters to ICE and our school district in support of immigrants. We also held training seminars
for adults and students on knowing your rights.
As the lead mentor for our FIRST Robotics team I advocated for kids of all ethnicities, genders and
abilities to have a true STEM experience. I started two teams, one in each school I was at, and
spearheaded fundraising for each team, and outreach to elementary and middle schools about robotics and
STEM.
In my church I have been a teacher of both adults and children, choir director, and volunteer with several
service projects.

Colorado Science Teachers Association (CAST) - member
National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) - member
ASM International (formerly American Society for metals) - member
American Chemical Society (ACS) - member
Career and Technical Education (CTE) - member
Teachers United for Immigrant Rights (TUFIR) - member
Cherry Creek School District Asian/Asian American Affinity Group - member
FIRST Robotics - lead mentor
Denver Buddhist Temple - volunteer for Cherry Blossom Festival

analytic_skills:
As a scientist, critical thinking, research, analysis and communication skills are vital to what we do. On
our learning team, as teachers, we collected data, analyzed, reported out and modified by consensus our
teaching methods to improve student achievement. We always worked within a strict budget to purchase
chemicals and equipment. As a teacher, I taught students about the importance of producing data,
analyzing the data, checking for error and causes of error, and coming to conclusions based on data and
analysis.
As lead mentor for robotics I was in charge of creating and maintaining a budget to build the robot and
participate in competitions in and out of state. Engineering requires critical thinking and analytic skills to
design a robot that not only functions on paper, but also in real life competitions over several days.
During the build season we strategize, prototype, analyze and communicate to determine the best design.
We are constantly testing, analyzing and reworking designs. As is evident, I am very adept at not only
utilizing analytical skills, but also teaching them.
consensus_statement:
When I had conferences with parents and students, I always allowed the parent and student to speak first,
so I could understand where they were coming from and gauge their level of frustration with the situation.
Using appropriate empathetic verbiage, I could attempt to get us both on the same page for goals, and
work backward to determine what actions would be needed to achieve those common goals.
Each year the robotics team has to tackle the challenge of designing and building a robot to play a new
game designed by engineers at FIRST. Our team consists of high school students, teachers, and engineer
mentors from the community. We established norms developed by our leadership team and mentors. At
the brainstorming session we announce and emphasize that everyone's opinion is important and worth
hearing. We divide into small groups, and after everyone has presented, make a list of pros and cons for
each idea. This helps make the process objective and is a framework for collaboration I would bring to
the commission.

other_names: Carrie M Lamitie, Carrie Margaret Lamitie
occupation: I have been a social studies teacher in DPS for the past 10 years.  I worked for George Washington High School and Emily Griffith High School during the past 10 years.
education: I got my BA from the State University of NY at Albany.  I got my law degree from Albany Law School.  I got my M.Ed. from Regis University
statement: The House of Representatives was structured by the founding fathers to be highly responsive to the will of the people.  Yet this function is thwarted when district lines are drawn in a partisan way to benefit either party.  Colorado needs neutral drawing of district lines to ensure that our growing contingent Colroado reps truly reflect the voice of the citizens.  It would be a privilege to serve as a Commissioner to work toward that end.
professional_background: I have volunteered and participated in many campaigns in a non-paid capacity.  I worked with the Obama campaign twice, and I did some phone banking an postcard writing for the Biden campaign.
org_list: As a teacher, I am one of 3 union reps for my school, Emily Griffith High School.  I volunteer as a textline volunteer for the Labratory to Combat Human Trafficking.
analytic_skills: I graduated in the top 5% of my law school class at Albany Law School.  Thereafter, I practiced law for over a decade, working as an appellate public defender in New York City, as a staff attorney for the Colorado Court of Appeals, and in 2 large law firms, both In New York and in Denver.  I also ran a small solo law practice for the transition year when I was preparing to get certified as a secondary social studies teacher.  In these roles, I developed the analytical skills that are essential to understanding the issues and identifying possible solutions in the context of the Commission's work.  And while these skills are necessary to the job, they are not sufficient.  They will only lead to effective work when combined with the ability to build relationships, to listen, and to work toward consensus and practical, win/win solutions in the context of complex, real world issues.  I believe that my background as a lawyer and as a teacher have prepared me well for the role as a citizen commissioner.   In light of the many applicants and the nature of the selection process, I will submit letters of recommendation and any further documentation of my background if selected to move forward in the process.
consensus_statement: As a high school teacher, I know that the best decisions are made through a consensus model.  Particularly in the context of complex questions where many solutions might work, the most important skill to bring to the table is an ability to listen, and an understanding that no one person has the best ideas.  I have learned through experience that the process of building consensus from a position of open mindedness can yield win/win solutions that are genuinely better than those initially brought to the table.  I also believe strongly that relationships are a key to effective consensus building among people of different beliefs; a context of respect and a genuine desire to understand the concerns of all group members is the surest path to strong decisionmaking.
past_political_activity: I have donated small amounts toth Clinton and Biden campaigns.  I also contributed small amounts to Democratic Senate campaigns both in CO and in swing states across the country both in 2016, 2018, and 2020.  I believe that I donated small sums in the Gubernatiorial race in CO in the last election.

occupation: CEO Keystone Policy Center
education:
MA, Nonprofit Management, Regis University, Denver, CO 
BA, History, Regis University, Denver, CO
statement: I believe strongly in the value of competitive and/or balance in congressional and state districts.  I think the state better represents the interests of its citizens and democracy is best served when people feel their vote matters and that their voice and interests will be heard. This aspiration will best be met when the state has achieved the goals of the commission's work.  Also, being from the Western Slope I hope to bring a different geographical perspective to the commission.
professional_background: I was a State Representative from 2007-2010 for HD56 which then incorporated Summit Lake and Eagle Counties. Mine was a competitive district almost evenly divided between Republican, Democrat and Unaffiliated voters and I worked hard to serve in bi-partisan manner at the State Capitol and to meet the interests of my diverse district.  I then served as Governor John Hickenlooper's Legislative Director his first term in office.  The Governor tasked my office with working to find bipartisan agreements to the majority of legislative priorities the Governor's office was supporting.  As a result, I would often convene legislators of both parties together to forge compromise agreements on a myriad of bills.  At Keystone Policy Center, a nonprofit organization I lead - our mission is grounded in the belief that when you bring together a diversity of stakeholders to tackle tough policy issues the negotiated agreements that are produced represent lasting and sustainable solutions.  Our work is bipartisan or nonpartisan in nature and addresses policy issues in health, environment, energy, education and tribal affairs; we have a 45-year history of impact at the local, state and national levels. Our mission statement is to help leaders rise above entrenched positions to reach common higher ground - which I think translates directly into supporting the work of the commission.
org_list:
Trustee, Board of Trustees  - University of Northern Colorado
Council Member - El Pomar Foundation High Country Council
Commissioner - State Land Board
Board member - Climb Higher Colorado
analytic_skills: At my organization - Keystone Policy Center, we ground all of our multi-stakeholder dialogues in science,data and a shared understanding of the policy drivers and implications related to possible outputs from our processes.   I have practiced the analytical and logic skills necessary for effective negotiation and compromise for my professional career - both in public service and in my work in the nonprofit sector.
consensus_statement: I believe strongly in collaborative leadership and the power of consensus among diverse interests, but you much work to elevate negotiations above least-common denominator decision-making to be impactful.  I am trained in facilitation and negotiation and all of my work experiences have leant themselves to furthering those skills.  I will work hard to be both fair and impartial and have found that most efforts of this sort are grounded in building some level of respect and trust as a collective group.  All negotiations are in-part relational meeting people where they are but recognizing differences.  These values are part of my work everyday.
past_political_activity:
2004-2008 Elected to Summit County Board of Education, Served a Board President 
2007-2010 Elected to HD56 as a State Representative
20010-2013 Served in the Governor's Office as Legislative Director to Governor John Hickenlooper 
2020 - donated to Joe Biden campaign ($75), John Hickenlooper campaign ($100), State Rep Julie McCluskie campaign ($200), Andy Kerr  County Commissioner campaign ($100)

occupation: Retired Self Employed since December 31, 2015.  Prior to retirement I was sole owner of LMC Solutions Company, a subchapter S corporation.
education: BS University of Wyoming, Graduated 1980
statement: I understand the history of gerrymandering and how it creates a system where politicians select the voters instead of voters selecting their politicians.  It is an unfair and toxic political manipulation for power and control rather than representing a populace.
professional_background: I was self employed in the market segment of public and school libraries for over 25 years.  I believe if you can read and write, there isn't anything a person can't learn.
analytic_skills: I understand how to look at problems from many different perspectives and positions.  Problems are not solved effectively when special interests drive the conversation to serve narrow opportunities.  It's time to consider a doughnut economic system serving people over profit, eliminate an electoral college component created to support slavery as an economic platform consolidating power to the few and provide an equitable system of one voter equals one vote.  After 50 years of voting, it's time to look forward instead of backward.  The "good old days" were on great for the "good old boys."  It's time for this country to mature to include all Americans as citizens of a country that actually works for them rather than against them.  This country was founded on white supremacy and it's time to own up to our real history and stop telling ourselves stories that degrade and demoralize people of color, women, non-binary folks, disabled communities and under privileged people who work 2-3 jobs or more to support their families.  It's time to stop deluding ourselves with American exceptionalism and privilege.  We can all do this together if we really want to.
consensus_statement: I believe in collaborative systems instead of competitive set ups.  Competition is a zero sum game where one side has to win and one side has to lose.  Compromise sets up an atmosphere of whining that you didn't get what you feel you deserve.  Collaboration brings everyone to the table to define the issues, combine possible solutions to collaborate on decisions where everyone benefits instead of the entitled or privileged minority with wealth, influence and corruption.
past_political_activity: Was a Democrat to Independent to Democrat to Independent to be able to participate in primaries and caucuses.

occupation: I currently own a small business with my husband.  Our business provides mechanical insulation for industrial-sized projects, including power plants.  My job duties include scheduling job walk-throughs, all aspects of bookkeeping and payroll, and other miscellaneous office tasks.  Prior to becoming involved with the family business, I was employed as a paralegal with a small law firm in Pueblo, Colorado.
education: In May of 2020, I graduated from Colorado State University-Pueblo with a Bachelor of Science degree in Sociology.  I graduated Summa Cum Laude, having a GPA of 3.97.  In 2003, I graduated from Pikes Peak Community College with an Associate of Applied Science degree in Legal Studies.  In addition to my two college degrees, I have attained certifications as a Certified Nursing Assistant, principles of accounting, and I am a Notary Public for the State of Colorado.  Please see my resume for more information.
statement: This commission is a bipartisan group of citizens who are tasked with working together to ensure district lines are redrawn in a fair and equitable manner.  Appointees must adhere to federal and state laws as well as court decisions that address racial and ethnic fairness.  This commission is an imperative part of our electorate process.  It seeks to prevent gerrymandering and illegal voter suppression.  As a proud citizen of the United States and resident of Colorado, it would be an honor to serve on this commission. I am fortunate enough to have the flexibility in my home and work life to commit my time to the commission.
professional_background: My role as a member of the Swallows Charter Academy Board of Directors included representing all of the school stakeholders during decision making.  It was important to seek out public opinion of students, parents, staff, and community members.  An example of a controversial decision involved deciding whether or not to change to a four-day school week.  It was my duty to consider how this decision would positively and adversely affect our stakeholders.  When we are representing a community, it is important that we not allow our personal opinions to influence our decision-making. We must gather facts, data, and stakeholder opinions.
org_list:

analytic_skills: Research and analysis are my two greatest professional strengths.  As a paralegal, I had to gather all facts regarding a case. I had to research statutes and case law to determine whether or not our client could succeed in court.  Attention to detail was crucial.  Laws and procedures change constantly, so I could never assume I knew the answer already.  There was little room for error.  Likewise, my role as President of the SCA Board of Directors required me to research the Colorado Charter Schools Act, CDE guidelines and mandates, adhere to the Colorado Open Records Act while maintaining confidentiality when necessary, and offer tact and diplomacy when tackling difficult issues.  I am more than prepared to take on this role as a commissioner.
consensus_statement: My previous work and volunteer experience has prepared me for a position such as this.  All political matters involve a great deal of controversy.  If I am appointed to this commission, I will not lead with emotion.  I will not take opinions personally.  Emotional control is of utmost importance when faced with conflict or disagreement. I will validate the concerns of all commissioners and work together to promote unity and fairness with each and every decision we make.
past_political_activity: In 2016, I assisted the "3 for $3 campaign" in Pueblo West.  This was a grassroots campaign that was attempting to get a ballot initiative passed under the Pueblo West Metropolitan District to raise property taxes by no more than $3 per month to fund three new parks in Pueblo West for our area youth.

statement: Political parties do not talk anymore and no longer compromise. analytic_skills: I have been a licensed attorney since October of 1994. I have helped resolve many issues but the most common type as applicable here may be in employment law.  It is important to understand the law, the parties, the competing interests and to try to determine where overlap, and therefore compromise can occur.  This requires analysis, logic, reasoning and continually adjustment.  These skills could translate very well to the commission.
consensus_statement: I suspect a good place to start in drawing boundaries is to determine what the most important criteria is or should be.  I would propose trying to create a list of priorities and then see if we could rank them or at least group them by order of priority.  If this didn't work for the commission, then it is time to listen to what others think may be more appropriate.  Should jurisdictional boundaries be more important than related issues?  If a group can agree upon and floow an agreed upon approach, much disagreement on potentially more divisive issues can hopefully be avoided.  The process must start with listening to what others most care about.  Specific ideas can follow.

analytic_skills: I like to start by having a clear understanding of the problem we are trying to solve.  Unless, and until, there is clarity on this question, the potential solutions will be elusive.  By having clarity on the problem we are trying to solve, one can rule out a number of potential options that will not help solve the problem.  At this point, one can focus energy on the analytical skills, logic, and problem solving skills needed to identify the potential options available for solving the problem.  Also important early on is clear understanding of the decision making criteria.  I have used this approach with my personal pursuits, as well as in business.  The challenge is not so much finding options to solving the problem, but the wisdom (discernment) to identify the solution that best fits the decision-making criteria and provides the best common good for the stakeholders involved.
consensus_statement: I am interested in and believe data and varied perspectives are important contributions to any decision making process.  Therefore, discipline must allow for open conversations to ensure all viewpoints have been considered.  As one trained in organizational dynamics, I am aware of how dominant personalities can overshadow those who may not be as charismatic in their communication style, and may be tempted (or intimidated) to shut down.  I will encourage these individuals to share their perspective and opinions so that we have as much data as possible before any decision is made.  This process also allows for unity (e.g., consensus) from a diverse group.

professional_background: Beginning in 2009 I chaired the South Metro Denver Health Care Policy Task force.  Our task force wrote a proposal for consideration by Colorado's 208 commission on healthcare reform.  This proposal was later written as legislation that was presented in the Colorado legislator in 2009 and 2010.  We worked with business and community organizations and health care trade associations to articulate the significant issues in our healthcare system.  This advocacy for rational reform in healthcare, which would actually reduce the cost of the system, and the cost in the system to governments, business and individuals, has been revived this year.  In 2010 I cofounded and chaired the Coalition for Effective Healthcare a 501C4.  In 2012, at the request of the South Metro Chamber Board of Directors I wrote a white paper on the significant challenges for business of Colorado's very complex sales tax system.  That white paper was presented to the then Colorado State Senate President.  That led to my personal advocacy with mayors, DOR and some legislators.  Ultimately, after soliciting the involvement of American Furniture Warehouse and Colorado Automobile Dealers Association, we interested businesses and trade organizations in joining the effort to fix Colorado's Sales Tax System.  We formed the Coalition to Simplify Colorado Sales Tax.  The Coalition, working with legislators, has participated in the writing of and advocacy of 5 bills that have all passed the legislature and are step by step moving Colorado toward a far more user friendly sales tax system, that is revenue neutral, at worst, and very well may generate more sales tax revenue for the state and home rule cities.
org_list: State of Colorado Task Force to Simplify Colorado Sales Tax 2017 to present; Vice President Board, Coalition to Simplify Colorado Sales Tax; Board Member Cornerstone Productions, 2014 to present; South Metro Denver Chamber of Commerce, National Federation of Independent Business
analytic_skills: I am a business owner and prior to owning my business, was the Colorado senior executive of a company with 650 Colorado employees.  I have consistently in my life faced challenges that required analysis, consideration of multiple courses of action, developing strategic direction and decision making and implementing strategic plans.    We have successfully navigated very difficult situations.  2008-2019 was very difficult for most businesses.  We were no exception.  We developed strategies to navigate our business through a significant recession.    the shutdown of much of our economy as a result of Covid 19 has brought a whole new set of challenges that required fast assessment of the looming problem, multiple options to address the business challenges, selecting a go forward set of plans and implementing it.  Our business has been dramatically impacted by Covid.  Today, we have as many employees as when the pandemic first resulted in stay at home orders.  Our outlook for the future is strong as we have made and implement many decisions that have preserved our company and positioned us for future prosperity.
consensus_statement:
In my sales tax simplifications advocacy I have met with and been in meetings with all stakeholders in the sales tax system - the Coloroado Department of Revenue, Colorado Municipal League, individual Home Rule cities, counties, Colorado legislature, business trade organizations and individual businesses.  We were able to listen, respond to disparate interests, find common ground and common objectives and move the ball progressively toward a much better sales tax system for the state of Colorado.

With my healthcare reform advocacy, we engaged political leaders, business organizations, and even healthcare trade associations.  This is a really difficult issue to rally interested parties toward a common solution.  The actual fix to the healthcare system problems, is not that challenging.  Aligning the various players is very challenging.  The businesses of healthcare themselves are the most difficult to move as the American Healthcare industry is the largest industry on the planet with significant players who have a major financial stake in the structure of our system.  We were able to achieve alignment with many at the table including advocates for a single payer healthcare system, with whom we found significant common ground.  As part of my work in this area, I was a significant contributor to the legislation that enabled the Colorado healthcare insurance exchange.

statement: I'd like to be part of the effort to stop the gerrymandering of congressional districts. Let's make things fair for everyone.
professional_background:
My past employment, before retiring, was with the U.S. Dept of Health & Human Services (HHS). I traveled throughout our state, and the states of Utah, Wyoming, Montana, North and South Dakota. Part of my work involved working with leaders of the various Indian tribes in these states, to include the Southern Ute and Ute Mountain Ute tribes in the southwestern corner of Colorado. Too often the communities on these two reservations are ignored or forgotten. I hope the Commission will include a representative from one or both of these Colorado tribes. My job was to listen to tribal leaders and help identify the most pressing health care issues. Our regional HHS office would hold annual listening sessions for all of the tribes in the entire region on health care issues. 

Prior to that I was the Executive Director of a non-profit agency which worked within the Denver area and statewide on Hispanic issues. Being bi-lingual (English & Spanish) was a great asset in this work. When I was hired, the agency was in danger of losing it's accreditation and funding by the United Way. We turned things around to the point that one of the United Way officers asked to serve on our board of directors. While I was there I initiated a monthly luncheon program during which key community leaders were invited to speak at the luncheon. One of the most successful luncheons was when the national president of the League of United Latin Americans Council (LULAC) was our guest speaker.

occupation: I am a part-time self-employed consultant to non-profit organizations working in the progressive advocacy community. I help non-profits with membership, events, fundraising, and strategic planning. I am also the mom of two school-age children.
education: I have a Bachelor of Arts degree from Tulane University in Political Economy and Women’s Studies. I grew up in Aurora, CO and am a graduate of Overland High School.
statement:
We have seen what happens in other states when districts are drawn in a way to include certain voters and exclude others – and it’s a major step to erosion of democracy. We are lucky that it doesn’t have to be like that in Colorado, where we can create maps that are reflective of our communities. Fairly drawn maps are a pillar to making sure Colorado is prosperous and equitable for all who live here, not just those who live in the right district. 

I view drawing fair maps as the first part of a cycle. If districts are created fairly, then leaders who truly represent their communities will be elected. Citizens will feel their needs are being met and their lives will improve, and they will be more inclined to participate in democracy by voting and holding their elected leaders accountable. Fair maps help to eliminate the power of special interests or corporate interests.
professional_background: I consider myself an active participant in Colorado's progressive community. I have supported non-profits that register young people to vote, and that advocate for reproductive rights, among other issues. I often talk to members of my community (like fellow moms) about what's happening in Colorado and how they too can get involved in advocacy. In 2018 I hosted postcard writing parties for candidates and ballot initiatives (Great Schools, Thriving Communities). During the Denver teachers strike, I organized a fund to raise money for grocery gift cards for teachers at two neighborhood schools.
org_list: Cobalt Advocates (formerly NARAL Pro-Choice Colorado); I have served on the board since 2015.
analytic_skills: I would bring strong analytical skills to the commission, and the ability to keep an eye on the big picture as well as the small details. My strength would be identifying opportunities and challenges, communicating well with other commissioners, and being able to juggle multiple data points to come up with possible solutions.
consensus_statement: If I am chosen to work on the commission, I would work earnestly in a process of consensus decision-making, where all members are able to feel they have achieved a fair outcome. This requires active listening, understanding different viewpoints and lived experiences, and sometimes making compromises. It is in the interest of the people of Colorado for the commission to work hard to find a consensus solution and for this to be a legitimate process. I believe one of my strengths is understanding where someone else is coming from and helping to communicate that to other members of the commission. I would also seek to make sure that no one individual is dominating the process and that all voices are heard.
past_political_activity: I have been a volunteer for campaigns, including No on Proposition 115 (2020), Jason Crow and Phil Weiser (2018), and others. I have also donated to campaigns in Colorado (especially to women running for the state legislature) and at the federal level. In my role on the Board of Directors of Cobalt Advocates, I serve on the Small Donor Committee and have participated in candidate endorsements (interviews, etc).

statement: This is a unique opportunity to end the gerrymandering process that political parties have engage in and move us to a system that is designed for greater representation of citizens.  Colorado has an opportunity to lead the nation in redistricting with this new process but only if we can have citizens who are interested in drawing lines that benefit communities of interest rather than political advantage.
professional_background: While on HOA board, I opposed a fee increase for internet upgrade but when it passed by neighbors, I led the effort to implement the new fee and served as Treasurer and point person.  As Regional Director at Americans for Prosperity, worked with the ACLU to pass a campus free speech bill and criminal justice legislation in several western states. analytic_skills: Applying analytical skills is one of my strengths. I've used these skills in getting bipartisan legislation passed in Congress and in state legislatures in the past.  To me, analysis and problem solving is essential in finding a workable solution and one which can build consensus.  The goal is to get a balanced outcome which all parties can live with and nobody feels like they were run over in the process.
consensus_statement: I have always been someone who tries to evaluate plans, ideas or proposals based on how they match up to my guiding principle.  Here, my guiding principle would be to evaluate plans based on how they best represent communities and I would stick to that focus.  In addition, I have consistently shown throughout my career that I work with those on the other side of the aisle to form a consensus.  As an example, while working as a Republican staff member in Congress, I worked with the Clinton administration to write the Military Family Housing Privatization Act which became law.  I also worked with Nancy Pelosi to stop Most Favored Nation trade status for China and also with former Congresswoman Pat Schroeder and her Chief of Staff Kip Cheroutis on numerous military installation issues including the closure of Fitzsimmons Army Hospital and the attempted closure of Fort Carson.  These examples demonstrate my ability to work with those that I may disagree with politically for the greater good.
past_political_activity: I ran for Congress in 2006 and 2008 but have not been active in the Republican party since then except voting. statement: Commissions like this represent the best that government can do to directly engage with the citizenry , while addressing critical shortcomings that traditional approaches to redistricting have created - namely gerrymandering and the disenfranchisement caused by such approaches.  I see no more important role of an informed electorate and member of our society than to help shape an electoral landscape that promotes  fair representation for all Coloradans.
professional_background: In my job as an renewable energy transactional attorney, I spend my day advocating for my client's position and seeking common ground with counterparties in order to structure transactions that meet the needs of my client and the communities in which they serve.  As a member of the Leadership Committee for the establishment of Soaring Heights PH-8 School, I worked with the administration and faculty of the school in the months leading up to the opening of the school to establish the principals, values and priorities that would shape the school, its focus and curriculum.

analytic_skills: As a practicing attorney, my workdays are spent constructing, analyzing and rebutting logical arguments as they relate to an issue and shaping results on the basis of those arguments.  While logic is necessary to the analysis, logical reasoning alone is not sufficient.  It is merely one tool, among many.  You must be willing to engage in the particulars of the problem, immerse yourself in the subject-matter at hand, and apply the logic, along with whatever other factors are relevant, and come to a decision.  As an attorney advising a renewable energy business on contract negotiation, I inform and temper the legal/contractual logical arguments we make with my knowledge of the subject matter and an understanding of the business's needs and objectives.  By understanding the subject matter and business's primary concerns, we can evaluate the risk inherent with a transaction and use logic to focus on those issues that are most important and how to adequately address them.  I would take the same approach with respect to the congressional redistricting process - immerse myself in the facts, listen to the electorate and turn to subject-matter experts to inform our decision-making process in order to create the best result possible.
consensus_statement: I'm a critical listener and I approach each problem ready to be persuaded.  My role as a transactional attorney is to use my experience and knowledge to understand the concerns and motivations of both my client and the counterparty, and create solutions that address those concerns while meeting the party's mutual goals.  The best result comes from negotiating around a party's interest and not simply negotiating from a stated position.  I would take the same approach here: find common ground, and make sure we are driven not by a pre-determined result that is to my liking but that the results are driven from first principals, values and that common ground we share, all in accordance with the law and our charge as commissioners.

I have the dubious honor of being "ABD" (all but dissertation).  All this means I've worked with numbers and analytical techniques, experimental design, and data analysis quite a bit.  Before pursuing graduate work in Colorado I worked as a research assistant in two University Hospitals where I was responsible for academic paper preparation, statistical analysis of study data, custom programming for data collection as well as analysis.  I enjoy attacking complex problems and developing flexible efficient solutions.
consensus_statement: In the context of the commissions' work, I would want to let the data lead us to agreement.  I would advocate that our results should be supported wholly by the data or be broken down into two parts: components supported by the data, and elements that have been arrived at by compromise, consensus, and cooperation.  In a professional setting I assess proposals based on evidence, I consider the scaffolding on which a proposal is built with an eye toward its accuracy and efficacy, and I tend to be a "Devil's advocate", viewing a proposal from many different angles or perspectives.  Given these habits, I like to think I arrive at fair and impartial impressions.  This also means that I respect and appreciate opposing views when they are arrived at through a similar strategy.

occupation: Retired. Currently volunteer president of the League of Women Voters of Pueblo. Board member approx. 15 years. Last paid employment 2009-2012, with ACOVA, the victim advocate program of the Pueblo County Sheriff's Department.
education: Have a bachelor's degree in English. Am trained to teach reaction to traumatic death, victimology and death notification. During my 15 years as a volunteer and paid staff, I learned to talk with people and intercede on their behalf.
statement: I believe that both these commissions are extremely important for healing the great divides that exist in this country. I believe that gerrymandering has disenfranchised and disempowered people from the "other" party, whichever one is out of power when the districts are drawn. All Coloradoans need to have their points of view heard and fairly represented.
professional_background: I started advocating for crime victims in the late 1990s as part of the Sheriff's Department's ACOVA (victim advocate) program. Later, as I joined League, I saw how supporting legislation could assist crime victims. I have always believed that organizations with similar goals should work together, and I try to bring League representation to every other organization I get involved with, and vice versa.
org_list: Board member of LWV-Pueblo since approx. 2009. Current member of the local NAACP branch. Former board member for the YWCA of Pueblo, which operates a domestic violence shelter. Founding member of the Heroin Task Force in Pueblo, which became the Substance Use Response Ecosystem (SURE). Former co-chair of SURE community pod; presently a member of it's prevention pod. Currently chair of the Colorado LWV's Nominating committee and represent LWVCO on Action 22.
analytic_skills: I can listen to all of the side discussions, and keep them in mind, but then concentrate on the core issue. I understand that people have emotional reactions sometimes, and need to be reminded to focus on the facts. For instance, I was on a board where the executive director was caught embezzling. People on the board who considered her a friend tried to defend her behavior, thought it was a mistake. I was one of the few who believed it was a crime immediately, and one of only two who could muster the nerve to say, "look at the checks. This is a crime. Your feelings are important but you must recognize reality."
consensus_statement: I learned to listen to others, and to talk with them, as a victim advocate. It can be difficult, sometimes, to avoid blaming victims for their circumstances. And for my own safety I had to be able to read faces and body language to know when someone was about to become angry or react badly to their situation. I've gotten quite good at validating others, listening to their point of view, listening for what they don't say as well as what they do say. I have a few personal rules. 1. Listen to others and validate what they say. Even if you ultimately disagree, they will feel like they've been heard. 2. When things go wrong, apologize if someone needs to hear it, even if you feel like you didn't do anything wrong. It shows a willingness to accept responsibility, and calms others down. 3. Stay civil. He who uses stereotypes and perjorative terms for others doesn't have a good argument, and therefore loses the argument.

statement: The development of drawing new boundaries for elected official districts is a critical piece of democracy. Ensuring these boundaries are developed fairly with equal representation for each demographic sector of our state's communities is by the far the most important and critical component of ensuring democracy is working effectively for everyone. It would be an absolute honor to contribute to this enormous and essential task. As an active community member in various Denver and Boulder county neighborhoods, schools, and Jewish community organizations across Colorado, I have a unique perspective on working with many different sectors of our Colorado community which I believe would greatly contribute to the commission's work.
professional_background:
I moved to Colorado to run the Office of Sustainability for the Denver Mayor in 2007. In this role, I worked across government departments and in collaboration with Denver neighborhoods to improve natural resource conservation measures. I represented the City and County of Denver to the broader community and among other municipal governments across the country working toward similar goals. 

For three years, I organized a coalition of 40 Colorado Jewish organizations, working to represent the broad Jewish community on local, state, and federal policy issues of relevance and impact to this Colorado constituency. 

On a neighborhood level, I organized monthly magazines for the residents of Denver's Hilltop and Lowry neighborhoods for four years, working closely with residents and neighborhood groups, to share news of interest to the community. That work led to playing a similar role for the Denver metro Realtor community, and I currently run this industry trade publication. My role is to help build relationships between top producing Realtors and local businesses that service the real estate industry. 

For the past two years, I have been an active parent at Eldorado PK-8, serving on the PTO and School Accountability Committee. When COVID jeopardized the 5th-grade commencement festivities, I organized a Netflix Movie Night for the 5th-grade class. I convened a group of parents to help set up the technology, design gift bags, and organized delivery of gift bags to each 5th-grade household. I am currently organizing a pandemic-friendly safe Halloween program for children in the Rock Creek neighborhood. My neighborhood involvement has also included advocacy work to prevent gun violence in our community and keep our children safe.

I always said that if I had the time later in life I would address this issue. It is where the rubber meets the road in the voting process. Colorado is fairer than most states but it could be better.
