occupation: Airline pilot, FedEx Express
education:
Bachelor of Science-Aviation Technology:  Purdue University
Airline Transport Pilot (MD11, ERJ170/190, DHC-8, ATR-42/72)
Airframe and Powerplant Mechanic
Certified Flight Instructor (no longer current)
Commercial Driver License
statement:
I am fiercely independent.  I have NEVER belonged to a political party, and I absolutely revile the use of government systems to benefit any political party.  The idea that political parties have used their power to redraw district lines to benefit the parties is in my mind the antithesis of what a representative democracy should be.  And while I don't believe that Colorado has a major Gerrymandering problem like other states do, I don't want Colorado to have such a problem in the future.  Additionally, as a resident of very rural Clear Creek County, I believe that I can bring a "mountain perspective" to the commission.

I also am privileged enough to enjoy a career and a job that would allow me to participate in this critical process, without major disruption of my professional life or paycheck.  I feel like most working age residents might generally not attempt to participate for just this reason, leaving overrepresentation by groups who don't the encumbrance of a job.
professional_background:
Lead and co-lead the Represent.US Denver chapter at various times.  Helped draft a campaign ethics bill for the city/county of Denver (the bulk of it's language was adopted as Denver Referred Measure 2E) working with other non-partisan and cross-partisan groups to draft said language.

I have circulated petitions for a small number of "good governance" measures (the Denver Democracy for the People Initiative--that became 2E).  I have supported Colorado "good governance" measures to include Amendments Y and Z (for example:  https://denverite.com/2018/10/18/jennifer-lawrence-wants-you-to-illegalize-gerrymandering-in-colorado/).  And I have been involved with a number of non-political organizations (such as the"Como Project" DSP&P Railway).
org_list:
I have been involved with Represent.US since 2014.
International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 357 (airline union)--union member
Air Line Pilots Association--union member
analytic_skills:
My professional life consists of taking a packet of information (weather, aircraft mechanical state, airport conditions, terrain considerations, and in some cases geopolitical considerations) and distilling that information into a useable plan to accomplish a given task (to fly from point A to B).  This involves the rest of the flight crew I am operating with (I have been a captain, first officer, and relief pilot at various times, all of which involve different leadership gradients), a dispatcher with joint responsibility, and many other entities during complex flights.  All of this must end up with a consensus on how we should operate the flight.  From the moment that plan is agreed to, it is continually monitored and re-evaluated, and adjusted should conditions warrant.  All of this while weighing pros and cons, and operating under a continually ticking clock and continually depleting fuel reserves.

In less time critical situations (which is how the commission would operate), I tend to prioritize a task by critical criteria, starting with what seems most pressing.  Once prioritized, I seek to apply any desirable criteria--especially if I am working with others who might rank the criteria differently than I do.  And once a workable plan appears to be presented, I seek ways to test that plan against the criteria, and adjust it if necessary.
consensus_statement:
I have spent over 10,000 hours flying airplanes, which is mostly an exercise in assessing information, and building consensus amongst the operating crew members, a skill that I have honed to a pretty high degree.  

I also served a term as an elected leader for a pilots union (IBT Local 357), during one of the most contentious bargaining environments in Railway Labor Act history.  It was one of the driving factors for me running for that position, and I largely acted as the "independent" board member making peace between factions on our board.  As part of my experience in union representation, I eventually developed the skills to handle EXTREMELY sensitive discussions (including high stakes discipline, substance abuse issues, harassment cases, hostile membership, and negotiations) respectfully amongst parties who typically displayed open disdain for one another.

As a dyed in the wool independent, I would be unencumbered by partisan pressures entirely, while being naturally inclined towards consensus building as the most effective form of agreement.  I operate in a world that requires a shared mental model and buy in of any decision in an airplane, it's a way of life for me, and has been for over 20 years in my professional life.

I also like to think that I am really good at letting bygones be bygones.  A disagreement with another person on one topic does not need to effect other attempts to build consensus with that person, and it is incredibly important to disagree without being disagreeable with one another.  I basically cannot recall the last time I disagreed with someone I was working on the same task with--I believe because my skills at building a shared mental model lead to consensus so efficiently that things never rise to the level of a real disagreement.

Impartiality is achieved both by my fierce non partisan belief and lifelong devotion to non partisanship, along with the inclusion of fairness and impartiality as critical criteria to work for.  People are allowed to have their own beliefs (including partisan motivations that I might agree or disagree with), but that does not necessarily mean that their viewpoint is not valid and deserving of thoughtful consideration.
past_political_activity:
Represent.US
Rocky Mountain Wolf Project/Action Fund (Prop 114)

occupation: I am retired.
education: I have a masters degree in urban and regional planning as well as a bachelor's degree in journalism. I was a certified planner during my career (American Institute of Certified Planners).
statement: I have become concerned with the increasing polarization of the U.S. body politic, a trend exacerbated by district gerrymandering that creates safe seats for relatively extreme elected officials who eschew compromise on behalf of the greater good in favor of merely scoring political or ideological points. I see an analogy with the shift away from beneficial debate within legislatures to reliance on petitions and constitutional amendments (TABOR, Gallagher, Amendment 23 etcetera). Competitive congressional districts would increase the potential for beneficial exchange of ideas among our elected leaders.
professional_background: The bulk of my professional career was spent in city planning, work which is quintessentially advocacy on behalf of the community at large and the myriad groups, neighborhoods, special interests and underrepresented factions which comprise our urban areas. I developed comprehensive plans in the cities of Aurora, Boulder and Glenwood Springs, documents which ultimately derive their authority from the people and businesses proactively engaged in a rational and deliberate process managed by city officials. I continue that work today as chair of The Fax Partnership board as we engage with the city of Denver in development of the East Area Plan. I also have experience in non-governmental settings. For example, I served three years on the state board of the Colorado Mountain Club and as chair of the Boulder Group of the CMC. The CMC is a venerable Colorado organization dedicated to conservation of the Colorado back country and the education of back country users. Population growth, climate change and the shift away from social organizations were among the challenges addressed while I was in a leadership position with the CMC.
org_list: Since my retirement in August 2015, the bulk of my volunteer activity has been on behalf of The Fax Partnership, a non-profit whose mission is support of existing residents and businesses and promotion of equitable redevelopment along the East Colfax corridor. I currently serve as board chair. I have done limited amounts of volunteer work for Habitat for Humanity with plans to do more once the pandemic eases.
analytic_skills: City planning is all about analyzing existing conditions, developing a vision and goals, then applying logic to devise potential solutions. A particular challenge facing planners is the need to avoid unintended consequences when drafting comprehensive plans, development codes or zoning regulations. This requires attention to the big picture while at the same time attention to detail in the drafting of policies, regulations and processes. Regarding this commission's task, some of my work experience with the city of Aurora is particularly relevant, including: responsibility for the city's population forecast; calculation of future land use needs and development patterns; and, testimony in a district court case supporting the city's interest in being located wholly within one congressional district following results of the 2010 federal census.
consensus_statement: Drafting comprehensive plans for a city, such as I have done in three Colorado cities, can only be successful by managing a project based on community engagement and the pursuit of consensus. A city planner can only succeed to the extent to which they are perceived as fair and trustworthy. The issues of land use, development rights, environmental protection and community goals are highly contentious and can only be resolved if those entrusted with the planning process do their job in a fair and impartial manner. Similarly, in every professional or organizational setting, I have been selected to a leadership position whether that has been with a city (Aurora, Boulder, Glenwood Springs), a non-profit (Colorado Mountain Club, The Fax Partnership) or even with a social group (A.P.E.S, the Architects, Planners and Engineers of Garfield County). I have also managed large groups of professionals, for example, a staff of 13 in my service as Aurora's Manager of Comprehensive Planning. One can succeed in such a setting only as a servant leader, mediating conflicts, giving a voice to all participants, being an honest broker among competing interests and maintaining a focus on the organization's goal.
past_political_activity: My political activity has been limited to posting of yard signs and making financial contributions to individual campaigns (e.g., Andrew Romanoff, Jason Crow, Tom Tobiassen [Aurora City Council].

other_names: Sarah Elizabeth Erickson, Sarah Piersky, Sarah Elizabeth Piersky
occupation: Occupational Health Registered Nurse-Children's Hospital Colorado
education: I have my bachelors degree in nursing and am currently a licensed registered nurse working at Children's Hospital Colorado. I have previously worked in the ICU at the Denver VA Medical Center, as a hospice case manager, and in a sexual health clinic. I am currently enrolled in my masters degree in nursing with a focus in healthcare policy through Chamberlain University.
statement: Over the past two years, I have been re-evaluating my professional career and thinking about how I want to best utilize my skills as a nurse. I have become very interested in the political process and the intersection of how healthcare and policy can ensure more people have access to high quality healthcare. I am currently working on my masters in nursing with a focus on healthcare policy and want to work at a state or federal level to advise, research and craft policy that makes our healthcare system more efficient, effective, accessible, affordable and equitable. Serving on the commission would be a perfect introduction into learning how individuals and communities engage with government and the civic process, and would allow me to use my voice to advocate for those who are unable to advocate for themselves.
professional_background: As a nurse whose career has spanned age, race, economic, religious and sexual identity demographics, I have become passionate about using my voice to advocate for those whose voices are often overlooked. Since 2015, I have volunteered with Hope House Colorado, a nonprofit organization that provides educational and financial assistance to teenage mothers that come from generational poverty. In the past five years, I have created several educational opportunities to allow the teens to learn more about their bodies and safe sexual practices, while also occasionally being a professional mentor to young women who have expressed interest in pursuing careers in the healthcare field. I am additionally involved with Cobalt, which raises awareness and supports policies at a state and federal level that protect women's access to reproductive healthcare.
org_list: I volunteer with Hope House Colorado as the volunteer nurse educator. I have also previously been involved with National Nurses United, a nursing union that I was a member of when I worked at the Denver VA Medical Center.
analytic_skills: Many times throughout my career, I have had to draw on logic and reason to solve a problem. Frequently in my time as an ICU nurse, I would need to utilize critical thinking and applied logic to determine why my patient was declining quickly, which involved referencing their medical chart, looking over previous lab values and anticipating what the provider might order to help resolve the patient's problems. In my current role managing calls from employees regarding COVID, I must use algorithms and policies to determine who needs to be tested for COVID and who is safe to return to work without potentially infecting other employees. I utilize logic and reason every day in my job as a nurse and as a masters student, and will bring that same level of commitment to the commission as well.
consensus_statement: As a nurse, it is my responsibility to take medically complex information given by providers to give patients and their families the necessary information to make the best decisions for their care. Additionally, I take the expressed wishes of patient and their families about their goals of care and advocate for their needs to their medical team. A significant component of my job is creating consensus among many groups of people with often very differing views. As nursing is the intersection of science and caring, I am able to use both appeals to emotion and appeals to reason to bring people together towards a common goal. Nursing requires fairness and impartiality, as my job is to care for my patients and advocate for their expressed goals rather than applying my thoughts, feelings or opinions to their care. I will use all of the skills and knowledge I have generated as a nurse to promote consensus, agreement, fairness and impartiality on the commission.
past_political_activity: I have only recently become involved with politics and civic engagement. I have not volunteered for any political campaigns or organizations yet, but have donated money. These are some of the political organizations/campaigns I have donated money to: Human Rights Campaign, Planned Parenthood of the Rocky Mountains, Blue Revolution 2020, Cobalt, John Hickenlooper for Senate, Joe Biden for President, ActBlue.

occupation: Self-Employed.
education: BS Engineering with Political Science double major, MA Political Science, Airline Transport Pilot.
statement:
Having worked to pass these amendments, I know they can only succeed if non-partisans continue that work.  This is one of life’s ‘If not now, when?  If not me, who?’ moments.  I mean that, really.

I earned two political science degrees and taught American Government to future military officers.  That officer corps has a well-earned reputation for being the most trusted, least partisan group in our nation.  That’s how I taught as well; non-partisan.  The students still didn't know my political views at the end of the semester.  That open minded approach attracted me to Y & Z.  It’s also why I’ve been a member of both major political parties at various times in the distant past but have been unaffiliated for many years.

This commission’s goal of ending gerrymandering in Colorado is critical to our democracy and will be a model for our republic.  That’s well worth doing; it’s well worth a citizen’s time and effort.
professional_background:
Volunteer in the effort to pass Y & Z.

My other perhaps relevant efforts are all local, such as organizing volunteers to teach character and ethics at a university, organizing neighbors to mitigate against wildfire risks, and organizing neighbors to join the county approval process for a local commercial development.

analytic_skills:
I am far more analytical than emotional.  It’s kept me alive in aviation, an unforgiving profession.  I also taught data analysis and forecasting to professional analysts in my small business.  And I have three US patents with a few more unsuccessful applications.  Patents require initiative and insight as well as analysis.

Building on that experience, my business partner and I created a method to measure group cultures empirically and despite the resistance, fear, delusion, etc. that often invalidates surveys.  That’s a current and concrete example of applying data analysis to human issues.

All of that means I see patterns in data and impartially follow them to their logical conclusion.
consensus_statement:
I have an acute sense of fairness.  I support the underdog and resist bullies.  At the most basic level, that’s why Americans with much talent and many options choose to serve our nation in various military and civilian capacities rather than follow easier, more lucrative paths.

I’ve also been a partner in a small data analysis firm, following facts where they led.  That background is certainly relevant to demographics, census data, affiliations such as minority groups, etc.

I believe such experience and qualities will be common among the commissioners and so will contribute to consensus, or at least agreement, that meets the commission’s charter and Coloradans’ intent.
past_political_activity: I volunteered on two presidential campaigns and two congressional campaigns, all in Colorado and for both Democrat and Republican candidates.  The last of those was in 2010.  I have not donated money to any campaign or political organization since November 2015.

The best way I know to promote consensus is to be a great listener and to provide a clear and concise thoughts on the matter at hand.  By providing time for each person to give his or her thoughts as well as his or her reason will hopefully give him or her a feeling of worth within the discussion.  At this point we as a team can determine where the similarities are and are not.  Then by picking away and negotiating back and forth on the dissimilarities, the team can achieve a consensus.  
I am able to be fair or impartial by consistently admitting any bias that I have to the group to put a fair criticism on that particular thought.  Granted the values I look for in person running for a congressional seat cannot be defined as left or right as I only care about the values of the person and not what party he or she run under.  With this viewpoint, I am under the impression that I will not be influenced either way on party politics leaving me only to care about my impartiality and fairness on the matter at hand.

analytic_skills: Does raising four teenagers and being married for 34 years to the same woman count as my ability to apply logic and reason to a problem? Just kidding. It is a joy to hold the position I have with my family. Besides taking the requisite higher education courses in logic, philosophy and analytics, I learned much about analysis and logic as a military officer. I have deployed twice with Special Forces and faced highly stressful situations, never losing anyone in my charge. One thing learned in Special Forces is that chaos breeds chaos and calm breeds calm. Most triggering causes have a root issue (i.e. security, loss of power, acceptance, etc.). Find the root issue and try to look past the emotional manifestation of the problem. Then determine the best way to address the root issue. The emotional flare up will normally take care of itself.
consensus_statement: The military — perhaps the most successful diverse community in America — welcomes men and women from every walk of life and then relentlessly enforces uniformity. That is the environment that I was immersed in for 22 years of my life. Honestly, when the matter is life or death, I could care less about your political ideology. I want to know that we have a common enemy. Most of us have more in common than we have uncommon. This was brought home to me when I toured the US Supreme Court and found out that most votes on the Supreme Court are 9-0. It is only the big issues that have a 5-4 split that we hear about. I like the adage, "We have two ears, two eyes and one mouth for a reason". More can be learned from listening and observing than talking most of the time. My focus is always on the commonalities. Agreeing on the common items paves the way for better conversation on the difficult topics.

occupation: I am a math and physics instructor at Northeastern Junior College
education: I have a bachelors (CU) and masters (CSU) degree in physics.  I also completed the welding program at Pickens Technical School in Aurora, CO a long time ago (I was certified but it has lapsed).  I also maintain a CDL with tanker endorsement.
statement:
Quite simply, I want two things:  
1. I want rural Colorado to have more of a voice in Colorado politics and decision making.  I believe a thoughtful redistricting will help this.
2. I will be perfectly honest and say that I want to influence the districting.  I have no interest in political office, but I have been concerned at the direction things have taken of late and want to have a hand in shaping the future direction the state goes in.
professional_background: My experience thus far has been mainly in contacting elected officials, unelected officials, and the media concerning issues that are of importance to me.  My main focus thus far has been in advocating for privacy rights and transparency in using cell phone data to track citizens' movements, advocating for having the (once the initial emergency has been cleared) Colorado Assembly decide how to respond to pandemics rather than one man in the Governor's chair, and advocating for the rural parts of the state to have more of a voice in Colorado government.  I contact people via phone, via email, and have begun using social media as a way to contact officials and to reach directly through to people using my Facebook group Colorado Accountability Project.  I am also trying to encourage others to get involved by contacting their elected officials.
org_list: Outside of being a registered Libertarian since I first started voting, I am not a member of any political organizations.  I am not a member of any civic organizations or community organizations either.  Outside of commitments at my work (which wold be mostly internal committees like the Human Resources Leadership Committee) I am not a member of any other associations
analytic_skills:
I am not sure how to take the word “analytical” in your question; i.e. I am not sure if you mean analytical in terms of the ability to understand and parse an argument or position, or whether you mean analytical in the mathematical/statistical sense.  In either case I feel that I am well suited in this regard.  I did not take the road into academia, but most of my education has been along that line and I regularly work on learning new things in physics (which requires the ability to understand and break down mathematical/logical arguments and the ability to apply math to them).  I will be honest and tell you that my knowledge of some higher level statistics concepts is incomplete, but I learn quickly and don’t anticipate a problem.
As regards the second part of your question, I do not feel as though I will have an issue applying logic and reasoning to a problem.  When you go to solve a problem in physics or mathematics (especially once you are beyond the level of memorizing a formula and into the areas of novel study) that’s exactly what you do.  Interestingly, it’s also what you do when trying to fix something (I’m working on restoring a track loader and help my dad in his semi restorations) though perhaps with less or a different form of math.  I feel as though I am well practiced in this regard.
consensus_statement:
I am glad I’m coming upon this question a few years after I got married, because I believe being married has greatly shifted (for the better) my perspective on reaching consensus among two people who have strongly-held, opposite opinions.  If you’re also married, I’m sure you understand as well.  My experience thus far has taught me that promoting consensus or agreement starts by recognizing that people of good will can disagree, and that someone else not seeing things the way I do doesn't make them ignorant or careless or etc.   Starting from that point, I think consensus building or compromise takes the form of outlining why you feel the way you do, what your goals are, outlining what you can't live with, and then finding areas of agreement.  For the things that you cannot agree on, you return to what you can't live with, and start saying what you'll tolerate.  I think keeping in mind that the essence of good compromise means that you (and all other parties) will be a little unhappy helps too.  It keeps you focused on what a reasonable outcome will look like.
I would like to say that I’m perfect in regard to being impartial, but I cannot.  Being fair to others, however, is a big value of mine.  In my experience as a teacher, I have had numerous times where I’ve had a student that I didn’t like, or one that sent a nasty email to my boss, or some such.  I have then had the chance to catch that student in a “gotcha” situation—a situation where they’d broken some minor rule or forgotten a homework or some such.  I cannot tell you how good it would have felt to bring the hammer down, but if I allow everyone else one free mistake, I must allow the troublesome students the same grace--difficult as it is.  That’s plain fairness.  It’s how I would want to be treated.  As another example, you may have been able to read between the lines thus far and know that I disagree vehemently with many things that Gov Polis and others have done.  Perhaps not, but let me know make it explicitly clear.  I disagree vehemently with many of the policy decisions and actions that Polis and others have undertaken.  In my Facebook group posts (Colorado Accountability Project—you’re welcome to go see), I do my best in posting to not step outside the truth and to be fair.  For example, in a recent post (recent as I write this on 8/13), I wrote some notes on Polis taking grant money to fund some of his political priorities.  The very first thing I wrote is that it’s not illegal and he has not been the first governor to do so
past_political_activity: This one will be brief.  My political activity is mostly recent. statement:
I believe that voting is a sacred trust and protecting that trust is essential if our democracy is to survive and thrive.  Chief Justice Earl Warren said “The basic principle of representative government remains, and must remain, unchanged – the weight of a citizen’s vote cannot be made to depend on where he lives.”  While gerrymandering has been with us since the nation’s earliest days, this practice has intensified over the last 20 years to the point that over 90% of House of Representative seats are considered noncompetitive.  Moreover, gerrymandering has been used to limit the electoral impact of ethnic communities.  Gerrymandering continues to erode the public’s trust in the value of their vote and, as a result, has discouraged some from participating in the electoral process to the long-term detriment of our democracy.

My desire to serve on the commission is to ensure that congressional districts are fairly drawn to ensure the equality of all votes and to promote the competition of ideas necessary to sustain the health of our democracy.
professional_background: None.
org_list: None.
analytic_skills: My training as a scientist and engineer ingrained in me the importance of objective, evidence-based data to analyze problems and create solutions.  My training as a business executive taught me that the best decisions were not solely driven by hard, objective evidence, but required an understanding of the people or emotional elements.  Taken together, my training has enabled me to not only use logic and reason to solve a problem, but to consider the human side of a problem to create a logically sound and emotionally satisfying solution.
consensus_statement: Bringing people together to achieve a common end has been foundational to my career success.  People will always have differing views on or approaches to solving a problem or achieving an end.  Consensus is satisfying but elusive. Agreement through informed compromise, however, is readily achievable.  A key principle to achieving consensus or agreement is trust between team participants as well as with stakeholders.  Developing trust requires a commitment to each other, respectfully listening to competing views, honestly considering these views, recognizing and setting aside our own biases, and persuasion. Whether a team leader or participant, I work to promote trust through dialogue, transparency, and patience to create an environment all will see as fair and impartial.  Once trust is established compromise to achieve agreement is possible.
past_political_activity: No political activity beyond voting and donating to candidates.  Donations to candidates for various federal offices over multiple elections. statement: I am a Coloradan who believes fair representation is the lynchpin of a legitimate republic. I want to help give all Coloradans an equal voice in choosing our representatives and turn our state into a model of successful reform to combat gerrymandering.

analytic_skills: In my current work, I routinely analyze projects from policy, scientific, and engineering perspectives in order to judge their viability. Problems can arise from all sorts of angles and it’s my job to anticipate and mitigate those potential issues. In my brewing career, problems were often more acute and required immediate, effective action to resolve. There is little time to deliberate when an enormous tank is leaking, and so I developed a quick response time to problems that does not compromise the effectiveness of the solution. In my academic training, I built a foundation of logical and reasoned analysis since the field of chemistry tolerates no other type of analysis. In my leisure time, I’m always eager to learn a new board game or puzzle because they help me think about strategic problem solving in a new light. Tasks like the Commission’s are a good fit for me.
consensus_statement:
I have found success throughout my personal and professional life in guiding meetings and conversations to a place that promotes consensus. I once managed a 30-person team of graduate student volunteers, which is a fragile coalition to hold together since students always have competing interests for their time and, being volunteers, I could offer them no material incentives. I was ultimately able to keep the group engaged, and on this and other teams I have relied upon a few key building blocks to set the stage for productive collaboration.


Confirm goals and check assumptions: Do we have a common understanding of our purpose? Are there facts we all recognize? Many disagreements can be forestalled by establishing a baseline of goals and information that the entire group accepts.


Match outcomes to goals: What does success look like? Does this hypothetical result comport with our mission? Why or why not? Holding up possible outcomes for consideration helps ground the group in the reality of their decisions.


Connect actions to outcomes: If we take this step, will it lead to the result we want? The result that we agree will help achieve our goals? Actions can be more easily agreed upon if their connections to prior points of consensus are made clear; it is also important to deliberately give proposed actions a reality check for unintended consequences.


Half the battle (at least) of gathering consensus from a diverse group lies in simply avoiding derailment, since tangents constantly threaten to intrude and have a tendency to build their own momentum once instigated. Furthermore, it is crucial to follow good evidence wherever it leads and to be an active listener who strives to hear the truth in the experiences of one’s peers. These steps, attitude, and adherence to evidence are crucial ingredients for impartiality and consensus-building, and I believe a good process leads to good outcomes. While a harmonious ending is never guaranteed, these factors maintain a focus on the right questions and lead to the right conversations. I will strive to foster this collaborative process on the Commission.

statement:
The crux of our democracy is the ability of all citizens to vote and have their vote matter to the same extent as everyone else’s vote.  My academic training was mostly in philosophy (with a smattering of political science), and one of my main interests was in ethics.  The intersection of democracy and ethics is the notion of equity for all citizens; viz. that every person has equal say and power to shape the nature of the political bodies which affect his/her live.

The way that voting districts are set up is, obviously, the foundation of whether any particular system is equitable or not.  Redistricting has been used for partisan purposes—by all political parties—from well before Governor Gerry ‘gerrymandered’ the Massachusetts districts in 1812 up to today.  This has been the source of a considerable lack of fairness in our political system.  I would be honored and excited to be able to participate in this important work.

I am proud of Colorado for being a leader in the movement to take the redistricting function away from legislatures in order to try to come up with a fair and rational process which will benefit all citizens in a equitable fashion.  This is an important step forward both for Colorado, and through our example, for the rest of the country.

I believe that I am intellectually suited and trained to be able to wrestle with the issues that a redistricting committee will face, I have a very strong sense of the importance of fairness, I have strong organizational skills, and, of course, I also am very well versed in map related subjects.
professional_background:
As a dealer in antiquarian maps and prints, I joined the board of the Denver Public Library Friends Foundation almost as soon as I moved to Colorado, from Philadelphia, in 2010.  The library holds an important collection of western material, and both my wife and I are long term supporters of reading as a means for children and adults to improve their lives.  Even once I left the board, I have continued to work with the Friends, running a number of programs for them to help raise awareness and money, including some "Antiques Roadshow" type events (I have been a regular appraiser on that TV program) and giving regular, free lectures on maps and prints.  

I have also been a board member of the Rocky Mountain Map Society, running both their regular lecture programs and their annual Map Month every May (except this one).  These are all free programs open to the public.

My wife and I have been regular supporters of a number of local arts groups, including Wonderbound and the Baroque Chamber Orchestra of Colorado, as well as local history related groups such as Historic Denver, History Colorado, Colorado Preservation, and Four Mile Historic Park.  I worked as a board member of the BCOC for three years.
org_list: Board member, Denver Public Library Friends Foundation, 2010-2014; Board member, Baroque Chamber Orchestra of Colorado, 2015-2018; Board member, American Historical Print Collectors Society, 2010-2015, 2020-current
analytic_skills: I studied philosophy in higher education institutions for almost a decade, and indeed originally planned to teach philosophy as a profession.  Two of my main areas of study were ethics and logic.  The latter is something which I feel is a sine non qua for any rational argument, and indeed I have taught a class in informal logic to high school students as I think it is a skill necessary for any “reasoned life.”  I believe one of my most important and strong skills is the ability to reason in a logical manner.
consensus_statement:
My academic training was much focused on philosophical argument, in the sense of being able to take an open-minded and clear-eyed look at the issues involved in any particular question to be decided.  I have the ability to identify the core issues of various questions and to present them in a clear and unbiased manner.  Even if I disagree with another person in an argument, I am adept at understanding his/her viewpoint and am able to lay out exactly where and why we disagree.  This does not always solve the argument, but it at least lets the parties understand the real issues involved.

In terms of fairness, my belief in the fundamental importance of fairness is rooted in the moral belief which I hold to be the most important to live by, viz. that everyone should treat others as they wish to be treated.  If one follows this Golden Rule, then fairness necessarily follows, as no one would want to be treated unfairly by another.  I have mostly supported the Democratic Party in the last decade or so, but that support is circumstantial; my support for a fair, equitable political system is far more foundational to my beliefs.
past_political_activity: I was a Precinct Committee Person for the Democratic Party, Precinct 623, House District 6, from 2015 to 2016.   My wife and I have made small donations to the Cary Kennedy campaign (2108), and also some small donations to the campaigns of Michael Bennet, for (Senate) and John Hickenlooper (Presidential & Senate)

analytic_skills: Basic algebra plus basic (if not so simple) human nature.  You can't solve a problem without first identifying the knowns and unknowns and determining relevancy of both, then seeking and validating the facts required, and you can't be reluctant to start over again if things don't add up when you test your hypothesis.  Similarly, you can't take people at face-value--their knowledge base, their abilities, their intentions and motivations--if you haven't listened to and observed them in a variety of situations, and you can't assume that they "just don't get it" mainly because nobody else has yet managed to explain effectively the matter at issue.  On the other hand, you sometimes have to recognize obstruction for what it is and honor consensus by leading the group to move forward, even without the obstructor; with any luck (and patient reiteration), someone may lead the outlier back to the shared position--or may learn something critical that the group overlooked and needs to reconsider.
consensus_statement: My life has been devoted to problem-solving:  asking relevant questions, assuring objective analysis and seeking collaborative resolution to serve the overall goals of diverse and often conflicting interests.  Past successes and failures have taught me that participants' tendency to favor predetermined "fixes" up front cannot be allowed to blind the group to the need for first agreeing the nature (and sources) of the problem at issue and then reaching consensus on the objective criteria defining success.  You don't diminish the former without listening, first; you don't achieve the latter without patience, persistence and a willingness to review and reconsider what one or more voices insist is "obvious" or "settled".

statement:
I want to serve on the commission because I want to make a difference.  I want to make a difference for Colorado voters.  As Booker T. Washington noted, “Those who are happiest are those who do the most for others” 

And, what can we do for others that is more important than ensure Colorado’s voters are fairly represented in our state’s Congressional and state districts?  The doctrine—one person, one vote—requires that electoral districts be apportioned fairly and accurately.  The 2021 redistricting of Colorado is extremely important.  Our state’s population has grown over the last 10 years.  Based on new census data, Colorado could gain an addition seat in the U.S. House of Representatives.  That would expand our state’s influence in national politics and increase federal funding for state projects.  Redistricting also impacts representation of Colorado’s growing diversity.
professional_background:
When I arrived in Washington, DC, there were two women working in the government affairs area.  One worked for the railroads and the other was with the International Ladies’ Garment Workers of America.  Those of us being hired for similar positions had few mentors.  We needed direction.  Twelve of us in the food industry founded Women in Government Relations.  Monthly luncheons featured effective speakers who gave us confidence and professional guidance.  For example, Elizabeth Dole spoke at a luncheon when she was serving on the Federal Trade Commission.  We shared books on effective management.  Our first salary survey resulted in 15 women getting raises after they presented the data to their bosses and demonstrated they were underpaid.  

My work with the Front Range Community College Foundation includes writing pieces some of which emphasize the importance of scholarships in graduating skilled employees who meet Colorado businesses’ needs and how important they are to the state’s economy.  I gave an endowment to the college for needed equipment for students enrolled in our new Center for Integrated Manufacturing programs.
org_list:
Current:  Front Range Community College Foundation – Board, Executive Committee, Chair of the Communications Committee; National Marine Mammal Foundation – Board, Secretary, Chair of the Communications and Investment Committees; Women in Government Relations – retired/emeritus/one of the 12 founders of the group
Past:  Ranch Reserve Homeowners Association, The Senior Hub, and Susan G. Komen Colorado
analytic_skills:
You cannot successfully run an organization without realistic budgeting.  You cannot successfully run a homeowners association without realistic budgeting and sufficient reserves for the future.  You cannot chair an Investment Committee without a Board-approved investment policy.  You cannot hire a new investment manager without a Request for Proposal.  You cannot look forward without thoughtful strategic planning.  No new challenge is unsurmountable.  You analyze.  You do research.  You learn.  You get it done.

While head of the Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums, mediation was rarely needed.   But, a few situations demanded it.  A member was doing or saying something to the media that embarrassed another member.  Changing behavior and coming to an agreement takes patience, empathy, and persuasive skills.  

And, then there is communications.  A messaging strategy is the key to successfully marketing a business, a product, a political campaign, or a new concept, as well as effectively meeting both professional and personal goals and objectives.  The Front Range Community College Foundation depends on generous, caring donors to fund scholarships for needy students and capital improvements.  I draft many funding requests for Foundation staff to distribute.  The challenge is to understand your audience, analyze their motivations, and identify what has value and will motivate a potential donor to give.  This has been especially important during this pandemic, which caused students to lose their part-time jobs and their parents to lose their jobs and businesses.  The Foundation created a High Needs Fund for both students and adjunct instructors.  Many needed help, which required constant fundraising.  It was very rewarding when donors reacted positively and we could help so many students continue their educations.  One story we told often is that of a single mom who lost her job because of Covid.  She could no longer afford her apartment.  She moved in with her grandparents.  Because they are elderly, she could not search for another job, fearing if she brought the virus home they could die.  She needed help paying basic bills once she lost her income.  Booker T. Washington’s words ring very true when helping FRCC students reach for their dreams.
consensus_statement:
My Washington, DC, experiences and the various positions I held were centered on finding consensus among members of these organizations with different points of view and varying political perspectives.  I could not have succeeded without being fair and impartial.

I have never worked for any organization where I did not discuss issues with a team in the course of making a decision.  It varied from working with the Board to working with members of a committee.  Yes, I analyzed the issue, researched it, and crafted a recommendation.  But, it was only through consensus that a decision was reached. 

Cognitive empathy is essential in coming to any agreement.  Active listening is effective.  It requires listening attentively and paraphrasing what has been said in any response, underscoring that you have heard and understand the point being made by another team member.  I socialize monthly with a neighbor who supports the opposite political party.  I bring up many, many subjects for discussion on which I know we can agree as caring women.  It underscores that we all have more we can agree on than disagree on in this sadly divisive time.
past_political_activity: I was a volunteer in Dianne Primavera’s last campaigns for election and reelection to Colorado’s House of Representatives. I have contributed to the campaigns of John Hickenlooper, Jason Crow, Joe Biden/Kamala Harris, Jaime Harrison, Amy McGrath, Mark Kelly, Steve Bullock, and Jared Polis/Dianne Primavera.

statement: The foundation of our democracy is free and fair elections. America was founded as a republic with a representative form of government and all citizens are entitled to be fairly and impartially represented to the greatest extent possible. Gerrymandering distorts the process of how and by whom the people in our state are represented in Congress and the State legislature. I believe this commission provides an opportunity to bring fairness to the process of drawing politically neutral legislative districts in Colorado and, as an unaffiliated voter, I believe I can and will be impartial in carrying out the responsibilities of the commission to achieve that goal.

As VP for the UCAR Foundation I was responsible for advocating for and negotiating the transfer of intellectual property from the scientific community to the private sector. As VP for the Summerlin HOA I was involved in representing the homeowners' rights and interests with regards to public rights of way, public roadways, as well as private property disputes.

At UCAR, I was responsible for contracts, legal, intellectual property, finance, budgeting and facilities management. Each of these areas requires good analytical skills and the ability to apply logic and reason to solve problems. This requires collecting relevant data and information, analyzing that data and information for relevant facts, determining logical and reasonable options and then making the decision about the best option to solve the problem.
consensus_statement: As a negotiator at UCAR, I learned that to be successful I needed to listen to and understand each party's needs and perspective and to try, as much as possible, to reach an equitable and fair consensus among the parties. To accomplish that usually requires weighing all of the pros and cons of each position and being able to communicate how each party can achieve their main objectives while making concessions so that everyone feels that they have come to a win-win for the group as a whole. I believe I have the ability to be fair and impartial because I do not belong to any political party.

occupation: Freelance writer and Editor
education: BA, Political Science, minor English, Colorado State University.
statement:
I wish to serve on this commission because I deeply believe in our American system of representative government.  I hold a political science degree from Colorado State University.  During the course of my studies, I participated in the Legislative Internship Program, and was paired with the late State Senator Claire Traylor.  Senator Traylor was a Jefferson County Republican, and member of the Joint Budget Committee.  It was a great honor to learn from her how local and state policy making work.  This was before politics became so wickedly divisive. I witnessed someone with strong political convictions, which weren’t overly partisan, legislate in a responsible and respectable manner. It was during this time that I built a foundational belief in policy making that is incremental and consensus built. Over the past decade or so, our elected officials have moved away from this manner of legislating. I also believe that common people like me, with enough experience to understand how policy is made, but removed enough to be free of agenda and institutional political influence, are in the best position to advise on issues and policy that drive our representational government. I am so excited that Colorado is leading the way to restore districting back to a representational, not political process.
To this end, my work in advocacy for equitable public education funding has lead me to believe that our state and country has some work to do beyond just education equity. Non-partisan political districting is a foundational way to achieve greater equity in our governmental representation.
I also understand Colorado and Coloradans, living here for all but the first (4) years of my life.  I understand what ‘Colorado Republican’ is. I experience the bluer wave happening in our more urban and suburban areas. And all the unaffiliated and smaller party members. I know old school Denver, when it was a ‘cow town’. I entered my young adulthood as the city of Denver became more cosmopolitan. I interacted with our agricultural and ranching communities while attending Colorado State.  I remember when skiing on the weekends didn’t involve a 4 hour drive, and the direction you put your skies atop your car said something about where you came from. I’ve grown as our microbrew industry has grown, and our outdoor recreation industry became more sophisticated.  Many don’t think of Colorado as being particularly diverse.  I know this isn’t true. And I believe voices from all of those sector of Colorado society and culture deserve representation on this commission.
professional_background:
I have participated and lead community advocacy in a few different capacities.  I was first drawn into public education advocacy when I began volunteering at my children’s school.  As I learned more about the state of Colorado’s public services funding mechanisms, I began to see what great inequity exists in our public schools, due in large part to lack of adequate funding. I began to participate with Great Education Colorado, learning as much as I was able about how to repair these inadequacies. I began to talk to anyone who would listen about what was happening, and what the voters of Colorado needed to correct course. I was a vocal community supporter and advocate for Amendment 73.
As a steering committee member of both our local school district’s bond and mill levy override campaigns, I advocated in a more formal manner to encourage members of my community to vote yes on these measures. I also formed an ad hoc committee of community members to organize and advocate for our neighborhood’s interests during the redistricting of boundaries in our school district. My interest and participation in our district’s accountability committee was borne from a passion for representing the interests of my children’s school. Through these experiences, the greatest lesson I have learned it that the best advocacy, whether in a formal or informal capacity, is respectful and informed discourse between people, even those that disagree. In my opinion, it is most profound way to create impactful change.
org_list:
Citizens For LPS Debt Free Schools mill levy override campaign steering committee member, 2020
Citizens for LPS Bond campaign steering committee member 2018
District Accountability Committee, Littleton Public Schools, 2015-2018, Vice Chair 2018
School Accountability Committee, Highland Elementary school, 2013-2017, DAC representative 2016-2017
Highland Elementary School PTO, various roles, 2015-2020, Communications Chair, 2019-2020
Principal Selection Committee, Littleton Public Schools, 2020
Design Advisory Committee, Littleton Public Schools, 2020
analytic_skills: I am not a mathematician or a statistician, but I do believe in data driven decision making. In my view, data is the most impartial place to begin a conversation around how to build new districts.  My strength however, is the ability to understand different perspectives in a fundamental way, while withholding judgement if those perspectives are different than mine.  I am also a natural mediator, process oriented manager and big picture thinker. Perhaps most of all, I understand people.  Most of us on some level are motivated by a basic desire to be heard and understood. When members of a group experience this level of understanding, they tend to be able to work together better and more productively, because a basic level of trust and cooperation exists. I think this would be one of my greatest contributions to the commission.
consensus_statement: The ad hoc group of community members I formed is the best way to demonstrate my ability to build consensus.  Due to unusual school locations in the LPS district, our neighborhood was quite a distance from our home school, which created a situation where many people chose to enroll their children in closer-by schools.  This was a detriment to both our neighborhood community and our school community, but easy to understand why parents would make this choice. So with the prospect of a newer, nearby school opening due to the passage of a bond in 2018, I called on a group of 15 parents, mostly moms, to collectively advocate for our neighborhood to attend that school together.  Initial drafts of these boundaries split our neighborhood in two, which we had already experienced the negative impacts of. When considering the formation of this committee, one thing stood out to me; while I would be the person who organized the group, and the relationships I’d built in the district would be helpful, this needed to be a collective, communal effort. I wanted the direction of our advocacy efforts to be informed by what best represented the wishes of our neighborhood.  Parents with young children, maybe not even yet in school needed to be included. Parents who had children who had gone through the schools in a divided neighborhood need to be included.  And with those perspectives, a collective mission and voice was built.  Everyone had the chance to share ideas around what they wished to see and the best way to move forward. Everyone had the chance to contribute their strengths, whether it be letter writing, new map formation, local property value expertise, or representing the potential negative impact on other school communities. Our efforts were successful, and I’m certain it was because we created a campaign built on team consensus and respectful communication.
past_political_activity: I’ve volunteered on two local education funding initiative campaigns for Littleton Public School, a bond in 2018 and mill levy override in 2020. I donated to both of these campaigns, as well as the campaign to pass Amendment 73 in 2018.

statement: I am the daughter of an immigrant. I am Latina, I am married to a black man, and I am the mother of two children, one with special needs. For the past ten years I have advocated for under represented members of my community. I wish to continue to be a voice for people who are not often enough heard. I want to ensure a fair redistricting process to ensure an equitable future for my children.
professional_background: Although not prestigous, much of my organizational experience was obtained while I was president of the PTA. This position required me to reach out to every parent in the school in an attempt to get them involved. I was also responsible for organizing school events where I had to manage a team of volunteers. The largest PTA event I managed hosted 1,000 people. This experience was a launch pad for me to start my own non-profit called Zero Waste Services. For four years Zero Waste Services strived to increase waste diversion and recycling in Jefferson County. Our largest endeavor was to improve the recycling and composting efforts for Festival Italiano, an event that hosts 100,000 patrons each year. This required recruitment, training and management of a large team of volunteers. Currently, I work with Adelante Jeffco. This organization's mission is to provide health and educational resources to the Spanish speaking community. Through our efforts, we have been successful in providing resources to the Latino community during the Covid crisis including a food distribution center and a special bilingual Covid testing site. Politically, I have hosted and organized several fundraising campaign events for candidates ranging from City Council, all the way to U.S. Senate candidate Lorena Garcia. As a PCP, I have organized my neighbors for lit dropping campaigns as well as GOTV efforts. I have frequented many City Council meetings to offer my public comment on issues ranging from Autism, sustainability, education, and racial equity and representation.
org_list: Since 2015 I have volunteered and served for following organizations and boards: Belmar Sustainable Neighborhood (Chair of Waste and Recycling), 3RC Foundation (board secretary), South Lakewood Elementary PTA (president), Zero Waste Services (co-founder), Kendrick Lakes Elementary School PTA, Alameda Connects, Lakewood Forward (board member), Adelante Jeffco, and the Colorado Statewide Parent Organization (board member). I was recently voted onto the board of the Jeffco Public Schools Foundation. My three year term will begin in January 2021. I am also a member of the Jefferson County Democratic Latino Initiative and a precinct chair person in HD 28.

I feel comfortable I can use these skills to serve the commission well.

I get people to side with me or at least understand where I am coming from by painting a clear picture of my viewpoint. People have always gravitated to the passion I inflect when I speak.  I have an ability to explain complex topics by breaking them down into digestible pieces. My moral compass is guided by the common good. This is very evident to anyone I work with, therefore there is never a question about my true intent.

occupation: I am a landscape architect, but I am not currently working beyond looking after a toddler.
education:
My highest level of education is a Master of Landscape Architecture from the University of Melbourne in Australia. 
My undergraduate degree is a Bachelor of Arts with majors in Russian Language and Arabic Literature and Language from the University of Sydney also in Australia.
I also studied at the University of British Columbia for one year at the bachelor level.
I studied abroad during my bachelor’s at Moscow State University in Russia and Notre Dame University in Beirut, Lebanon. 
I have also taken several classes at the Denver Botanical Gardens for botanical illustration. I hope to one day complete the full botanical illustration degree.
statement:
I have wanted to contribute to the democratic process with my renewed admiration for democracy since returning to the US. I am specifically interested in serving on the commission, because the issue of redistricting has become so controversial nationally. I feel this community-generated commission is a genuine opportunity to change that narrative and move away from a non-productive, hyper partisan country. I also see great potential for this commission to become best practice nation-wide. I believe that this century will present unimaginable challenges and the current atmosphere in the country is toxic and will debilitate us a nation to respond to these challenges, unless we decrease the partisanship. We need to rebuild trust in community, institutions, and professionalism. I also don’t believe the level of partisanship within this country is inevitable, as I do not think that I have experienced such deep partisanship in other countries that I have lived. Finally, I believe I have useful qualifications for this position. 


Since returning to the US, I have wanted to contribute to the democratic process with my renewed admiration for democracy. I feel this would be an ideal avenue for this Since returning to Colorado, I have been actively trying to increase my personal engage with democracy, which I do not take for granted, having lived in Russia and Ethiopia. Therefore, I try to make phone calls and write letters whenever I hear of potential legislation or issues that I believe need to be changed. Within the past half year, I have become increasingly focused on work with Canada Geese Protection Colorado. It has been fascinating to witness how with continual perseverance, change is starting to happen. The group is now allowed to attend biweekly meetings, which ensures increased transparency. Denver Parks and Recreation has agreed for us to help set up a task force, which I will probably be a member of, regarding this issue.  They have also said that there will probably be no further culling next year. I have learned that change needs persistence and governmental systems need to be understood to be effective.  contribution.
professional_background: Since returning to Colorado, I have been actively trying to increase my personal engage with democracy, which I do not take for granted, having lived in Russia and Ethiopia. Therefore, I try to make phone calls and write letters whenever I hear of potential legislation or issues that I believe need to be changed. Within the past half year, I have become increasingly focused on work with Canada Geese Protection Colorado. It has been fascinating to witness how with continual perseverance, change is starting to happen. The group is now allowed to attend biweekly meetings, which ensures increased transparency. Denver Parks and Recreation has agreed for us to help set up a task force, which I will probably be a member of, regarding this issue. They have also said that there will probably be no further culling next year. I have learned that change needs persistence and governmental systems need to be understood to be effective.
org_list:
I am an active member of Canada Geese Protection Colorado. I am also a founding member of an internet group called Ethiopian Architecture and Urbanism.
I was in the Chair of Landscape Architecture at the Ethiopian Institute of Architecture, Building Construction, and City Development. There, I wrote the curriculum, launched, and lectured in the first degree for landscape architecture within Ethiopia.
analytic_skills:
I believe that by having a master’s I have demonstrated a commitment and ability to apply logic and reason to a problem. While I worked at the Ethiopian Institute of Architecture, Building Construction and City Development, I received the highest student feedback of any academic staff of which there were over 200, which testified to my commitment to my position, which was fundamentally about teaching students how to apply logic and reason to their own work.

In Melbourne, I worked as a consultant for the City of Melbourne doing community engagement. Through this work, I learned that people are generally rather reasonable with their beliefs and issues. However, it takes listening with an open heart to understand their issues. This experience gave me direct experience with community engagement and consensus building.

My background in landscape architecture will be directly relevant to this position. I use GIS and CAD and have made many maps within my professional life at different scales. I have analyzed and generated large watershed-scale areas as well as microclimates on a smaller scale. I have generated maps based on several specific parameters and then generated other maps with different, but similar, parameters and compared them. This experience has given me intimate exposure on how maps can be manipulated and the importance human generated lines can hold. Inherent to a landscape architecture education and the profession is the overlap it has with city planning. Therefore, I think this will also contribute to my ability to understand population dynamics. 

I have published several academic works, such as a conference paper and two book chapters. Such publications were all written in connection with various universities spanning three continents. In addition, in my personal life I enjoy continued learning.
consensus_statement:
I have spent nearly the entirety of my adult life living, studying, and working amongst different cultures and people often with opposing beliefs and values. I feel that the most important aspects to understanding and appreciating a culture or person different from you is deep listening and being open to what is being said. Therefore, I would use this same approach when beginning to promote consensus amongst the commissioners. However, as the process proceeds, the position I form will be based upon facts. Therefore, I would not approach this task with the aim of trying to convince others about my beliefs or political views, but rather about the facts and what they indicate. Therefore, responding to the facts would be the basis of my position and would be the means I use to attempt to convince others of my position. In addition, I do not think it will be possible to achieve a ‘perfect’ outcome with complete consensus with everyone. Therefore, compromise will be essential to how I approach challenges and situations and ultimately a fair result. My own family composition attests to an ability to compromise and thrive with difference. My husband is Ethiopian and we have different religious, cultural, ethnic and historic experiences, yet we have been happily married for over five years with a beautiful son. 
Beyond the belief that fair redistricting will also help to rebuild trust within communities and lessen the toxic partisanship of our nation, I feel that my background in academia and research will help me be fair and impartial.
past_political_activity:
I am politically active, but not in an official capacity. I have voted in every election since being of age. I donated to several democratic campaigns in the past year, including: Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and most recently to the Democrats in Georgia to help flip the Senate. Before this year, I do not believe that I have  donated to other political campaigns. I often write letters and call political leaders when there is legislation to be decided and I want my voice heard regarding that legislation. I have been doing this for years, including while I lived abroad. Lately, I have been regularly active in campaigning to end the culling of geese and for more transparency  in the city of Denver. Through this process, I have become more aware of how the City Council, Denver Parks and Recreation, and the Mayor’s office operate. Together with other advocates, we are working to set up a community science group to watch the lakes and learn more about the geese. 
While living in Moscow, Russia, I volunteered with an organization that helps forced migrants and refugees, where I taught English on a weekly basis. I later started volunteer translating for the European Court for Human Rights. For this position I would translate legal documents from Russian into English that would be presented to the Court. The vast majority of these cases were against the Russian Federation.

occupation: Dentist - Self employed
education: BA College of the Holy Cross, DDS University of North Carolina
statement: I feel our biggest political problem in this country is the Gerrymandering of congressional districts. A two-party political system with noncompetitive districts means primaries become too polarized. Candidates only have to compete with a staunch base and not have to compete with the general population. That leads to a polarized legislative body unwilling to compromise with the opposing party. Scott Tipton was an effective, conservative representative for the 3rd District of Colorado but the hard core base that shows up for primaries elected what I consider a "fringe" candidate. This has made the traditionally very conservative 3rd district competitive for Democrats. It shouldn't take a "fringe" candidate's election in a primary to make a district competitive. They should always be competitive between the two parties they represent.
professional_background: I feel that I’ve reached a point in my life where my commitments to my children and family have freed me up to now to be able to devote time and give back to my community. I thought I had reached this point in 2016 when my youngest son graduated high school and was heading to Cal Poly for college but the injury he suffered altered everything. He suffered a C-5/C-6 cervical neck fracture and is now quadriplegic. This injury changed everything for our entire family. His perseverance has pushed him forward and he is now in his senior year at CU Boulder and he has progressed immensely in developing his independence. There are still many challenges for him and my wife and I but I feel that I’m now able to look beyond the world we’ve had to adapt to over these last four years. The challenges we’ve faced have ranged from medical emergencies, to adapting living spaces, navigating government services, and providing reassurances when none seemed possible, all the while maintaining a dental practice that allows me to provide the income needed to overcome the many financial burdens. I’ve needed to juggle so many competing challenges that have made me more pragmatic and empathetic to issues we all must face.
org_list: Due to family commitments over the past 4 years I have had little time to volunteer to any organizations outside of career associated groups. My son experienced a cervical neck fracture shortly after graduating from high school in 2016 that left him in a wheel chair and quadriplegic. These last four years have been a challenge for our family and I have devoted all my free time towards helping him achieve the goal of going to CU Boulder and completing college.
analytic_skills: My undergraduate degree was Chemistry and prior to attending Dental School I worked for 3 years as an environmental engineer. I look at any issue I'm faced with through the lens of science and math. I try to learn as much as I can about any issues I'm presented with from as many differing perspectives as I can find and then make informed, calculated decisions as best as I can. I feel my contribution to this commission would be to bring that same mindset to the decisions that these commissions would be responsible to make.
consensus_statement: I feel I am a pragmatic, empathetic, practical person always willing to look at issues from differing perspectives. I have built two dental offices over the course of my career, the first involved four dentists with separate practices moving into one common space and the second involving myself and one other practice. Getting us all to agree on certain decisions was always a challenge and I feel I have always been the one most readily to compromise and provide solutions in order to achieve the goal of moving forward and completing the projects.
past_political_activity: In past years I've donated to both Republicans and Democrats but since 2015 I have donated only to Democrats including Joe Biden, John Hickenlooper, Jaime Harrison, Jon Ossoff and Amy McGrath. I come from a staunch Republican family from NH but have found the past four years to have been disappointing for Republicans and wish to try to affect real change.

I am not interested in gerrymandering for any side, including one that may help the party I support.

analytic_skills: I'm an architect. Analytical skills come with the job. Having the world view that I have (Judeo Christian) has become somewhat of an outlier these days. Because of this, my skills of logic and reasoning have been sharpened as I get into discussions with the prevailing materialistic world views that surround us. I also teach classes on how to logically defend a Christian world view and how to recognize fallacious arguments.
consensus_statement: I enjoy discoing difficult issues with those who have opposite views, so long as those discussions are respectful. I believe that honest people can work together to come to a consensus if they can respectfully communicate. Everyone is biased to some degree, that's human nature, while I know what my biases are, I also understand what is fair and when to compromise. Our founders did not embrace gerrymandering, the legislature was intended to be filled by citizen legislators, not career politicians who push gerrymandering to maintain power. I know that I can be fair and impartial.
