statement:
As a high school science teacher I have had the opportunity to work with young adults on a daily basis,
both in and out of the classroom. They are generally more candid and to the point than adults and seeing
things from their viewpoint is a valuable tool that I will bring to the commission.
I am a woman, of Asian descent, from a rural community, currently living in a suburban area. Growing
up, I understood the high cost of farming, and how things could turn with an untimely storm or drought,
as well as the magic of watching a crop grow, and the value of a hard day's work. My Asian heritage
provides background knowledge on the minority experience of racial and cultural discrimination. Being a
woman and adoptive mother provides additional lenses to view life. Finding one’s identity is especially
difficult for an adopted child who must sort through abandonment issues, and racial issues compounding
the already complex task of growing up. Women face every day challenges of balancing work and family,
often providing care for elderly parents and sick family members.
Fair maps will help ensure that each vote counts equally, and areas will not be skewed to the advantage of
any particular group or party. Fair maps will ensure our election officials accurately represent their
constituents.
Volunteering on several campaigns at the local, state and national levels has shown me the importance of
the election process in the preservation of our democracy. Working in public schools and engaging kids
in extracurricular activities gave me the opportunity to work with parents, professionals in the community,
and motivated students. These groups see things from slightly different viewpoints and it is a valuable
lesson in broadening my perspectives when interacting with a wide variety of groups.
professional_background:
As a member of Heritage Camps for Adoptive Families, we advocated for transracially adopted families
of all ethnic groups and genders. I helped organize family camps for several ethnicities as well as other
activities for families to educate, and provide social spaces for children to be with families who are in
similar situations.
In TUFIR we actively supported students and adults who were in the GEO ICE facility, and also
immigrants that were newly released from the facility. We provided food, clothing and money as support
as well as letters to ICE and our school district in support of immigrants. We also held training seminars
for adults and students on knowing your rights.
As the lead mentor for our FIRST Robotics team I advocated for kids of all ethnicities, genders and
abilities to have a true STEM experience. I started two teams, one in each school I was at, and
spearheaded fundraising for each team, and outreach to elementary and middle schools about robotics and
STEM.
In my church I have been a teacher of both adults and children, choir director, and volunteer with several service projects.

Colorado Science Teachers Association (CAST) - member
National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) - member

American Chemical Society (ACS) - member
Career and Technical Education (CTE) - member

analytic_skills:
As a scientist, critical thinking, research, analysis and communication skills are vital to what we do. On
our learning team, as teachers, we collected data, analyzed, reported out and modified by consensus our
teaching methods to improve student achievement. We always worked within a strict budget to purchase
chemicals and equipment. As a teacher, I taught students about the importance of producing data,
analyzing the data, checking for error and causes of error, and coming to conclusions based on data and
analysis.
As lead mentor for robotics I was in charge of creating and maintaining a budget to build the robot and
participate in competitions in and out of state. Engineering requires critical thinking and analytic skills to
design a robot that not only functions on paper, but also in real life competitions over several days.
During the build season we strategize, prototype, analyze and communicate to determine the best design.
We are constantly testing, analyzing and reworking designs. As is evident, I am very adept at not only utilizing analytical skills, but also teaching them.
consensus_statement:
When I had conferences with parents and students, I always allowed the parent and student to speak first,
so I could understand where they were coming from and gauge their level of frustration with the situation.
Using appropriate empathetic verbiage, I could attempt to get us both on the same page for goals, and
work backward to determine what actions would be needed to achieve those common goals.
Each year the robotics team has to tackle the challenge of designing and building a robot to play a new
game designed by engineers at FIRST. Our team consists of high school students, teachers, and engineer
mentors from the community. We established norms developed by our leadership team and mentors. At
the brainstorming session we announce and emphasize that everyone's opinion is important and worth
hearing. We divide into small groups, and after everyone has presented, make a list of pros and cons for
each idea. This helps make the process objective and is a framework for collaboration I would bring to
the commission.

statement: I wholeheartedly endorse the goal to limit the impact of partisan politics on the electoral infrastructure, which includes the creation of district boundaries. I believe it is important for citizens to choose their representatives in a competition of ideas that fairly represents the interests of the community. For too long, and in too many places, political interests have manipulated the drawing of boundaries so that political leaders essentially choose their voters, when it should be the other way around.
professional_background: As mentioned above, I consider schools to be important community organizations for social change and citizen empowerment. My choice to do school leadership work as a career involves a great deal of "organizing, representing, advocating for, or considering the interests of groups" in diverse school communities.  As part of my responsibilities in schools (in Colorado and Brazil during this time), I have worked with students and teachers to develop community-facing service projects.
org_list: I currently participate in my homeowner's association meetings. I am a member of the Aurora Education Association, my teacher's union. I have worked as a school leader in every community where I have lived since Nov 2015; I consider schools to be vital community organizations.
analytic_skills: My work in school administration, and previously as a special education teachers, involves analysis of demographics, budgets, and a wide array of assessment tools and performance indicators. I am a sophisticated reader of qualitative and quantitative data. While I use these skills to identify trends and to draw conclusions, it is just important to identify unknowns and generate questions for further inquiry.
consensus_statement: Much of my work involves empowering students and teachers to make decisions about issues in our school community. This requires respectful facilitation of discussion, active listening, and identifying consensus that can motivate collective action. My impartiality will be driven by my commitment to empowerment of citizens to engage in a fair electoral process.
past_political_activity: I have been a regular voter, even when I lived outside of the US for much of the time from 2002-2018. Since November, 2015, I have made occasional small donations to political candidates that advocate for citizen empowerment and anti-corruption efforts. education: MS Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences from University of Coloraso at Boulder, BS Geophysical Engineering from Colorado School of Mines
statement: I want to serve the proud traditions and principles of the us representative democracy, and guarantee my relatively unique viewpoint is represented. Accurate representation which is focused on solving our most pressing concerns as local communities, while advocating for those communities when solving the concerns of broader shared communities is how our representative democracy works most effectively. The only way to achieve that pillar of our us government is to make sure the resulting representatives most accurately represent the opinions of the voters. This needs to hold true whether their opinions are based on profession, age, ethics, ethnicity, faith, culture, interest or any other trait or belief. I want to help find a districting solution that makes sure the biggest stresses of the most Coloradans are the primary concerns of the our representatives while not suppressing the most critical issues of the minority groups. I want to help make sure every unique minority facet of our beautiful state can see themselves reflected in the advocacy of their representatives. More personally, I’m 29 years old with a unique skillset with a background in gis and data communication. I will be impacted by the echoing decisions of the committee for not just the next decade, but also by precedent for censuses to come. Likely though, age wise I will be under represented, particularly considering I am near the minimum age requirement of Colorado General Assembly. Despite my age though I have a wealth of experience and skills in geolocational and data based problem solving which is key in districting. I want to do this because I think I am a rare and valuable view point.
professional_background: I have advocated for myself and the interests of people that share my profession, culture, ethics or region. As well as for those who I don’t immediately belong such as the bleeding disorder community, which I joined when I was a teenager because of a close relationship with someone with hemophilia. A recent example of success I have had organizing my community would be solving a storm water drainage issue in my neighborhood. I worked with my neighbors to define the problems causing water to pool in our yards, worked with civil engineers and contractors to develop a solution using chase drains. Then worked stakeholders like my neighbors, the town of Frederick public works, and our metro district to execute that solution while following requirements like permitting, the drainage plan and funding. The metro district then expanded that solution to other drainage issues in our subdivision.
org_list: National Hemophilia Society Colorado Chapter
analytic_skills: I have worked for the USGS (DOI), IBM and Maxar (formerly DigitalGlobe) working as a software developer on several missions in a variety of industries aerospace, meteorology, natural disasters, and shipping logistics. All of which involve logic and reasoned problem solving with complex GIS data. I daily: define problems, collect (physical, digital, legal, and financial) requirements, design solutions, communicate those solutions to clients, and implement those solutions. For example, when I worked for the United States Geologic Service a division in the Department of the Interior in college for 5 years; made earthquake risk maps. These maps are provided to first responders within 15 minutes of an earthquake to best make decisions about where victims meed help and what help they will need. I also made earthquake hazard maps for legislators and policy makers to use when designing building codes. I frequently worked with audiences like first responders and government officials to explain natural disaster risk and refine the information I provided to best serve the common goal of keeping people safe in the most extreme disasters.
consensus_statement: I can reach a consensus for two reasons: Im an political independent use to finding common ground with both parties, and I am good at communicating complex data driven solutions particularly with maps. I believe the most stark differences in our political beliefs is not our political party, despite our representatives voting on party lines the majority of the time. When I talk with my diverse neighbors about how legislation would impact them in a way divorced from party and focused on their family, I find the divisions much more tied to their professions, faith, and interests. When I became an independent, it was to find candidates from both parties that shared my opinions and focus for political issues that impacted me. I think I can convince people from both parties of the real contrasts in our communities rather than focus on party and how best to make every diverse voice be represented. Additionally, I have worked on map and data presentation design to lay out non-partisan intents and draw a solution in a simple and understandable way. I can communicate a data set clearly and prove with reasonable and logical arguments that a solution meets criteria. As well as communicate any potential problems or fallacies and how they were addressed.
past_political_activity: None

statement: I believe this effort is one foundational element in helping our democracy work more fairly. I would like to see the Colorado process be held as a national standard of good practice in achieving fairness in redistricting.
professional_background: As a part of my projects I have organized the public outreach and stakeholder involvement processes for large controversial projects, ultimately bringing people together around a consensus for improvements.
org_list: I have belonged to the Metro Denver EDC.
analytic_skills: I have been facilitating large groups of stakeholders for 20+ years of my career. These are often groups with vastly different desires and levels of trust in the agencies proposing the improvements. I have used the multi-objective matrix analysis tool for many years to help everyone understand the choices and ramifications of those choices. This work then results in a recommendation that must be presented in an formal environmental document ultimately supported and approved by a Federal agency.
consensus_statement: I would advocate for a published transparent process of decision steps designed to give all stakeholders the information they need to understand and support the ultimate outcome of the commissions work. This would entail laying out a stepped process starting with a statement of the desired outcome, the criteria to be used, the alternatives possible and the recommendation. I would lay these steps on a schedule that included the opportunities for all stakeholders and interested citizens to provide their input. Finally, I would define how all input will be used in the process. It is foundational to success that all stakeholders understand how the decisions will be made, when they will be made and how they might engage in the process to affect the outcome.
past_political_activity: I have donated money to Joe Biden, Everyone Votes, and Amy McGrath.

statement:
I would like to serve on the commission to learn and work on redistricting issues and am driven to make sure all people are correctly

occupation: Retired
education: Clarkson School of Nursing, Registered Nurse; Regis University Bachelors of Science in Nursing, Regis University Masters of Science in Nursing
statement:
I have a growing awareness of the divisines in our politics.  There are many who don’t feel heard when they raise concerns.  Where I live, in Longmont, I know that the chances of electing a person to the Federal House of Representatives who reflects my community are almost nil.  
It is crucial that our political landscape become more about representing people and the local/ regional aspects of the communities where we live. My hope is that by serving on the committee, I can advocate for a fair map where everyone can know that their voice will be heard when voting.  A map that realizes the dream of equal representation, without favoring parties or special interests, while also acknowledges areas of our communities have special circumstances, such as
race and economic status that must be reflected in the maps. I continue to hope for a return to civility in politics where we listen to and learn from each other.
professional_background:
I am a long time environmental advocate.  Now that I am retired I have time to become personally engaged by working on issues important to me.  I bring my skills that include close to 40 years in management to this work. I am able to bring strategic decision making, collaboration, planning and financial ability to the organizations I work with.
Building support for sustainability throughout our community is vital to the work that Sustainable Resilient Longmont (SRL) undertakes. SRL engages residents across the community, including  youth and people of color in events such as earth day.  SRL Earth day is a focus on children and how they interact with the earth.  In 2020, the event moved on line with youth from local high schools discussing what climate change means in their lives. 
Another important aspect in community/ grassroots activism is working with city government.  I know all of the city council members personally.  I frequently speak at council meetings to advocate for environmental issues.  This relationship was a key element in achieving a Longmont Resolution to commit to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
org_list:
Climate Reality, trained climate leader
Sierra Club 
 Indian Peaks Group Executive Committee, 
Colorado Chapter of the Sierra Club,Executive committee, currently Chair of Executive Committee
Sustainable Resilient Longmont, Board Member
Our Health, Our Future Our Longmont, Board Member
North Colorado Partners for Clean Energy, Coalition member
City of Longmont Climate Action Task Force, member
Longmont Newcomers
Coloradans Resisting Extreme Energy Development
analytic_skills:
My success in Nursing Administration was based on my ability to analyze issues and apply data to arrive at a solution. I will relate a quality improvement project in my last position.  There were three ICU’s.  A QI project to reduce ventilator associated pneumonia was very successful in 2 of the 3.  The third, the Neuro Trauma ICU, was difficult, but knowing that there had to be a reason, a team explored the differences.  We discovered that patients who had head trauma were being transported daily for head CT scans.  The transport was putting them at risk and we were able to define some simple steps to prevent this complication.  
I apply the same type of skills to my activist work. When planning educational events about topics, such as renewable energy, exploring data and research studies informs how we plan events. Reading through online records of meetings and attending board meetings at Platte River Power Authority gives me the ability to discuss electricity generation with our city council and to speak with other community members.
consensus_statement:
As I look at the current political landscape, I see so much division. I grew up in rural Nebraska.  I know and love many folks who are conservative.  I am not afraid to reach out to those who do not share my political views.  In my work in Nursing Administration, being able to build relationships with people in other divisions was paramount to the success in my area of responsibility.  Also, working on projects that involved caregivers on several shifts, in several units on two campuses,  required skills in building consensus.  To bring in physician acceptance required negotiating skills.  I use these skills of negotiating, relationship and consensus building, plus willingness to work with people of diverse backgrounds to my activism work.  I also bring the nursing art and skill of empathy.  Stepping back to see the people behind decisions and how they are affected is needed in any work.
My work with SRL provides an example of how I can apply these skills. Acceptance of the possibility of renewable energy is difficult for many people.  Acknowledging that jobs in the fossil fuel industry will be lost, then discussing the potential of jobs in renewable energy requires listening first instead of arguing. This usually leads to a good conversation while planting seeds that may change minds.
past_political_activity:
Being involved in our democracy is important to me.  My involvement includes donations to candidates at all levels of our government, working with organizations to promote candidates, and personal engagement such as door to door campaigning. 
Locally I work with a grassroots group that delivers candidate information to residents in Longmont.  Through my local Sierra Club group in Boulder County, I work on candidate endorsements based on environmental priorities.  Also, I am on the board of Sustainable Resilient Longmont.  This organization holds candidate forums where candidates are asked questions about sustainability. 

This election season, I determined that I needed to engage in the Presidential Election.  I wrote letters, texted and made phone calls to battleground states through  Sierra Club Independent Action.

State:  Singer, Foote, Jones, Bernett, 
County: Jones, Singer
City: Martin, Peck, Rodriguez, Waters
Colorado Democratic Party, Boulder County Dems, Longmont Area Dems

Our state is not highly gerrymandered, but other states are, and I wish to be involved in and understand how these decisions are made on a state level.

I understand how to look at data, how to interpret data, how to view maps and their effects on real people's lives. I am also quite good at breaking down the relevant problems for other people to understand and discuss, find language which gets to the heart of a problem, and am more than willing to find out where someone is stuck in their understanding and work through disagreement.

I think I could do an excellent job of looking at the data presented to the commission, summarizing and analyzing said information, and presenting it in a concise format for discussion. I'm very comfortable with public speaking and answering public questions in a concise and precise manner, especially when prepared by group discussion and consensus. In terms of impartiality - I want what is best for the citizens and voters of Colorado. I have no party affiliation but have always voted for those local candidates, regardless of affiliation, who I think will do the best for my community. I think I could apply that impartiality to state-wide issues without problem.
past_political_activity: I have never donated money to a political campaign or candidate. I'm registered unaffiliated so I have the choice to see either ballot in the primary election.

occupation: Currently self-employed, part-time, as a children's books consultant for Usborne Books & More.
education: I have a Master's Degree in Elementary Education from Regis University, and earned my BA at CU Boulder, in English Literature.
statement: Districting is incredibly important to our Democracy, and when it is done without proper study and understanding -- or worse, with malicious intent to disenfranchise people and thus retain power unethically -- I believe that it hurts everyone.  I want to serve on the commission because I believe that I can contribute thoughtfully to creating districts that are as fair for every voter as possible.
professional_background: I have not done this type of work on any large scale.  However, I work very hard to seek out and understand many perspectives on societal issues that I encounter.  I was also on my HOA board in Denver back in 2014, so had to do my best to represent the needs of all owners in that capacity.
org_list: I attended Foothills Parks & Recreation's South Jeffco Business Alliance meetings regularly throughout 2019, as an Usborne Books & More consultant; and this year I made calls to voters as a volunteer for the Colorado Democratic Party.  I also attended a few School Advisory Committee meetings at my local elementary school, when my son was in preschool there last year.
analytic_skills: I am someone who analyzes just about everything, and picks apart what I read.  I check sources, seek out faulty logic, and criticize lop-sided and poorly-researched arguments.  If I don't know about something that I want to discuss, I go and learn about it first.  Government matters should not ever be about personal preferences, but about how best to serve the constituents.  It should be based on data, reason, and empowering the people.
consensus_statement:
I believe that finding consensus among a group of commissioners that seeks fair representation for everyone in Colorado should be relatively straightforward.  In the event of facing a decision that involves trade-offs somehow, I would do my best to refer to the data and encourage others to do the same.  It is the data, the voters, and the extent to which each vote matters (which we should be maximizing), that should guide decision-making and help us to find consensus.
Fairness has always been incredibly important to me.  As the youngest child of three, I felt that much in my life was unfair, and from that I learned how to empathize and also how to work with others to find solutions that work for everyone -- so as to not leave them behind, as I had often felt left behind as a child.  While I realize that life itself is certainly not fair, we, as a commission with the intention of drawing fair districts for our state, should strive for fairness -- for making each vote count as best we can, regardless of who is casting it.
past_political_activity: I definitely lean liberal and Democrat, though I was registered as Independent for several years.  I believe it is incredibly important to vote, and that civic engagement is crucial in a Democracy.  As I recall, I donated to Obama's campaign in 2012, and I definitely contributed to Amy McGrath's campaign in Kentucky this year, but I believe those are the only times I've contributed directly to a person's campaign.  I've otherwise donated to activities to increase voter turnout: this election, I supported MoveOn.org's voter turnout efforts.  Those are all the donations I can remember.

occupation: Technical Training Specialist at HelloFresh
education: Master's degree in Criminology & Human Behavior; Bachelor's degree in Criminology
statement: I am passionately committed to preserving the integrity of democracy and ensuring all Coloradan voices are heard. I am committed to equity and inclusivity, and hope to ensure Colorado continues to be a place where voters decide our future and elect our leaders and are fairly represented.
professional_background: I volunteer with and am a Community Outreach Coordinator with Alternatives to Violence Project Colorado and am a volunteer victim advocate for Glendale Police Department. I volunteer for Foster Together, preparing meals for foster families. I am also an approved mentor for the Colorado Department of Corrections.
org_list: My political activity is primarily within my circle of friends and family through discussion on politics and assisting others in conducting research on ballot initiatives to make informed votes. I do not recall any precise donations, but I have not donated more than $25 to a political organization.
analytic_skills: Whenever approaching a problem, I consult existing reputable and peer-reviewed research and knowledge on the topic, talk to peers, and reflect on my own experiences (and how that might color my perspective). Considering all of these pieces, I often also conduct my own research, through surveys, comparisons, or other methodology, to ensure I am on the right track. I firmly believe in a data-driven approach to applying best practices. That also means that if the data shows something to be ineffective, then I make adjustments, no matter how committed I was to the process originally. Additionally, I always try to look at the complete picture before forming decisions, not jumping to conclusions or making assumptions.
consensus_statement: With my volunteer work, I facilitate difficult discussions to deepen people's abilities to resolve conflicts and find consensus. Through my volunteer and professional work, I regularly practice and teach active listening, the process of consensus, and effective communication. I will apply these skills in the commission and work to understand what my peers are saying and where they are coming from, and clearly state my views, and work to identify the compromises and agreements between them. I practice fairness and impartiality in my life regularly, including taking steps to fully understand others' points of view. For instance, when arguing with friends or partners, I often do a mental exercise with a third party where I take the argument of my "opponent" and let the third party argue my side. This allows me to more completely understand their perspective and adjust my POV or argument to better resolve the conflict. This, along with active listening and a deep care for others and all humanity, has provided me with the skills to manage and develop all sorts of relationships. Although, I am a registered democrat, both of my parents and much of my family are ardent republicans and we regularly have civilized discussions and come to agreements on topics that we initially disagreed upon.
past_political_activity: I have no professional or formal experience organizing, advocating, or representing. I am politically active personally, and vote in every election I can, and engage my friends and family to vote and educate themselves on candidates and ballot initiatives.

The company provides information and support for businesses, individuals, and state and local governments related to federal disability laws. I sold the company in 2018 and have been a consultant since that time.
education: I graduated from the Ohio State University in June 1972 with dual bachelor’s degrees in aerospace engineering and in computer & information science.
statement:
I believe that the process of creating districts for state legislature and national representatives has long been one that was hidden from public view. Whichever party was in the majority used its position to carve up the state to its own advantage. I believe the process should be open to and performed by the general public, and it's the reason I voted for the propositions to move the process to the citizens in 2018. It is also the primary reason for my interest in serving on the commission.

The 2020/21 redistricting for Colorado will be more difficult than the past several decennial redistricting efforts. Colorado has seen significant increases in its population since 2000 and the population has migrated within the state as well. Colorado’s increased population makes it highly likely that we will gain a U.S. House of Representatives seat and the allocation of seats in the state house and senate will also be significantly modified. For these reasons I think the redistricting commissions’ actions will be challenging. 

I believe that my analytical and organizational skills developed from my academic background in engineering as well as my real-life experience organizing and managing a company and a nonprofit give me the necessary qualifications to participate. I don't believe it's enough to merely shout about why something is a problem. When the opportunity presents itself, it is important to step up and offer your capabilities to improve the situation.
professional_background:
The founding and management of my company, Meeting the Challenge, certainly is my greatest example of all these areas. MTC competed for and was awarded a federal contract to operate the Americans with Disabilities Act Information Center for the six-state Rocky Mountain Region in 1991 and continues to operate the Center today. The company grew from a single person to over 20 employees and expanded its operations to organizations across the country. 

I would also point to my organization of the All Colorado Beer Festival as an example of my organizational skills. The ACBF's 1st festival in November 2013 attracted just under 1,000 patrons and 19 brewers and donated $10,000 to local nonprofits. In 2016 the festival had grown to over 2,600 attendees and 75 brewers. We donated $85,000 that year. Organizing an all-volunteer organization to produce such an event is a challenge on many levels.
org_list:
I was the chairman of the Struthers Ranch HOA in 2016/17. 

I founded the All Colorado Beer Festival in 2013 and continue as the chairman of the board for the organization. The ACBF is a 501 (c)(3) charitable organization that raises money for local nonprofits by staging beer festivals. The ACBF raised and distributed over $500,000 during its 12 years of active operations. 

I was on the advisory board for the Home Front Cares from 2016 through 2019 and on its case review committee in 2018 and 2019. THFC gives grants to veterans and active duty military who have financial difficulties of many kinds. 

From 1974 through the present I have been a member of Theatreworks in Colorado Springs. I was a long-time board member, a technical director for several productions, and part time development director for the organization.
analytic_skills: My training is as an engineer. I deal in analysis and logic. I have applied this training in nontraditional areas. Whether it was the founding and operation of a company devoted to disability rights, a beer festival to raise money for nonprofits, or our HOA, I have used my analysis and logic skills from engineering to present data for others to consider and from that data to build consensus for moving forward.
consensus_statement:
While I have strong views in politics - I am a registered Republican - my political outlook is more libertarian. I believe this outlook allows me to see the positions of both left and right more objectively. My goal if selected for the commission will be to move the process forward by listening to all comments and positions and to present my view objectively. Most people can come to consensus when provided with facts even when that consensus is not entirely their opinion. Several of my past experiences have helped me develop my consensus-building skills.

I was active in the Association of Computing Machinery starting in 1982. ACM is one of the largest professional computing societies in the world with over 80,000 members. I became the chair of the Special Interest Group (SIG) on computing and disability in 1987 and the chair of the SIG Council of over 50 individual SIGs in 1991. As the chair it was my responsibility to run semi-annual meetings of all the SIG chairs and ensure that all the disparate views and needs of the SIGs were fairly represented. In 1992 I was elected as vice president of the entire ACM organization. My experiences at ACM, while somewhat in the past helped me to understand how to get large groups of very disparate individuals to come to consensus.

From 1994-1999, I sat on two federal advisory committees to establish accessibility standards for electronic and information technology and facilities. I was a member of the U.S. Access Board’s Americans with Disabilities Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) Review Committee which was responsible for a complete assessment and rewrite of the ADAAG. The process took two years and required consensus-building to ensure that the new standards met the needs of the various disability groups while still being feasible for the construction industry. The Committee received the National Performance Review Award from Vice President Gore. I was also a member of the U.S. Access Board’s committee on Accessible Electronic and Information Technology and was on the ANSI A117.1 Working Group on dwelling unit accessibility.
past_political_activity:
I ran for and was elected as precinct chairman in the early 1980s and subsequently ran for and was elected as an elector to the district republican assembly and as an alternate to the state republican convention. 

In 1982 I attended a program oriented to teaching business-people and then encouraging them about running for public office. The program was organized by Steve Schuck. One of my co-students was Gale Norton who went on to hold positions in the U.S. Departments of Agriculture and Interior and then Colorado Attorney General. I worked on Steve Schuck’s campaign for Colorado Governor in 1986.

I chaired the unsuccessful primary campaign for district attorney Ed Arcuri in 1984 when he ran against longtime incumbent, Robert Russel. The race was close enough that it triggered a recount which I was required to monitor. Barney Iuppa defeated Russel in the general election.

I provided data analysis for several of Mike Bird’s campaigns for state house and senate in the 1980s.

I have not been active in politics since the 1990s.

statement: A representative democracy is the bedrock of our country, and an opportunity to help in ensuring that Coloradans are being fairly represented is the first step. Drawing the district lines to reflect the changes in our demographics is something we only do every ten years. Talk about making an impact! This is why the work must be done well, thoroughly and carefully knowing that these maps will be how Colorado is represented at the federal level. I want to serve because I grasp the magnitude of this work. I am committed to public service and see this as another opportunity to serve.
professional_background: I've worked for the City of Denver as well as the state legislature for the last several years and bring stakeholders together to find common ground is at the very foundation of governing and government operations. As a society, big or small, we function best when everyone has a seat at the table and when we are working together. This is how I approach my work as well as my volunteer and community work and how I would approach my work on the commission.

I have a history of impartiality in my work and in my volunteer work and look forward to employing these skills on the commission.

statement: I have a very strong interest in how district maps are configured. Embedded in that interest is a concern for how the boundary lines correlate to gerrymandering, voter suppression and bipartisanship. I want fair and appropriately representative maps that have the interest and vote of every resident of the state top of mind.
professional_background: My organizational work in the political sphere was largely based in Illinois in the 1980's and 90's. I lead a team of three to organize of 1000 seat dinner/fundraiser for the Democratic National Comm and multiple other fundraisers for candidates. In Colorado, I have focused more on advocating and working for nonprofits in the areas of climate and  the arts.
org_list: I was a neighborhood canvasser for the Boulder Democratic Party in 2008 and a caucus organizer.
analytic_skills: I am not shy about my ability to ground my thinking in logic, reality and fact. I am widely known to be a truly rational person. As a mediator, we are trained to use analysis to reason our way to a viable result. This happens after every side has spoken and every concern is registered. Not every situation or decision will be made based solely on what is logical but every decision should be based on solid judgement that is grounded in solid analysis. My varied work and life experience have honed my problem solving skills to a place where I can be proud of the successes I've achieved in untenable circumstances. I am not narrow minded, I do not want only Democrats to rule the land. I want balanced and appropriate representation and fair district boundaries is how we get there.
consensus_statement: My training as a lawyer, mediator and arbitrator have utterly configured how I view an issue. Every side and every voice has a right to be heard and considered. I believe in thoughtful, respectful and empathetic listening. To be empathetic you have to be fair and to be impartial you have to want to hear every story. I am a level-headed person not prone to any rage or easy discountenance. I believe that I have learned through training and practice to identify quickly areas of agreement, areas of disagreement and options for paths forward. This is not a one side take all situation. Rather, this is Colorado's opportunity to show the country that we have the ability to reach consensus on highly contentious issue. Our democracy is predicated on bipartisanship along with an actively involved citizenry. I would like to do more to help maintain and strengthen our democracy.
past_political_activity: In the 1980's and 1990's I worked in democratic politics in Chicago. I was a media buyer and writer at Axelrod and Associates. I was a contract fundraiser for the Democratic Party. I was a policy analyst on Adlai Stevenson's governor's race in 1986. I have not donated money to a political race since 2015.

statement: The fine people of the state of Colorado have spoken! By voting in favor of this redistricting process, Colorado committed to fairness. That commitment is reflected in the formulation of these independent committees. Politics are messy business these days. It is well understood that how districts are designated has a big outcome on election results. I want this contribute to the betterment of our state, and of voting in general. Through this representative process, Colorado may well become a national model on how to put an end to gerrymandering. THe country needs to know us to provide this model. I am a "regular" person. I have gotten to know a lot about the state through my volunteerism, my work with school districts throughout Colorado, and as someone who loves exploring great landscapes and hiking trails. I am a dedicated and committed person. Fairness in elections is paramount, and this process will have my full attention.

I keep a clear eye on the stated goal and help to keep people focused on relevant issues.
consensus_statement:
The name of my consulting company is Concurrence Consulting. Concurrence is about achieving agreement among stakeholders. I am particularly skilled at hearing all sides of an issue, and being able to appreciate the different points of view. I have deep experience working with groups to further understanding and to be able to move forward on issues or projects. I am a skilled and trained facilitator. I am comfortable working with a variety of personalities with a variety of interests. I can also spot what is getting in the way of a group reaching its goal, and can work effectively to remove those obstacles.
I have traveled the state, and spent time in rural, suburban and urban communities and I greatly appreciate the distinct priorities and considerations of a given community. I can also see the threads that tie us all together, and can find common ground.
past_political_activity: I have voted in all major elections since I could vote, with the exception of 2000 (I was out of the country and, to my embarrassment, I did not request an absentee ballot). I am a member of the League of Women Votes, and I volunteer to register voters. I like the League as it works to disseminate information so that an informed public can actively participate in government.

statement: Our grand and novel experiment in a constitutional federal republican form of government has stood the test of time for 233 years.  However, we seem to be at a cross-road.  Will we continue to stand for fair and free elections where all races and creeds are fully represented or will we succumb to the temptation of political short-term gain where the end justifies the means.  Extreme gerrymandering is harmful no matter which political party it appears to benefit.  I believe my strong and unique analytical and personal skills will serve the commission well in establishing fair and unbiased district boundaries.
professional_background: For the past 20 years, I have talked with hundreds of Christians, atheists, and agnostics about the symmetry and congruence of scientific and theologic principles and beliefs in such venues as the People’s Fair and the Boulder Creek Festival in my capacity as a Reasons to Believe Denver Chapter officer.  Always listening and trying to understand their unique and diverse thoughts and opinions while also advancing my own. consensus_statement: I have spent my career solving and optimizing scientific problems.  This often means analytically resolving multiple constraints where some of these constraints actually oppose each other.  Because of my unique skills and personality, I have often found myself acting as a conduit between management and engineers.  I am able to speak both languages as it were and am thus able to reform what one side is saying in new terms the other can understand.  Compromise has become a dirty word in modern politics.  The mantra seems to consist of “opposition at all costs.”  If we are to survive as a nation, this must stop.  Both sides of the aisle must learn to reach across to the other side to find common ground; creating new and innovative solutions for the common good of our citizens.  In a truly fair solution, no one gets everything they want, but hopefully each gets the thing(s) most important to them.   I was born and raised on a farm just outside of Kearney Nebraska.  After college, I moved from Kearney; a town of 30,000 people to Los Angeles; a town of 30,000,000 highly diverse people.  My wife and I moved to Denver in 1996.  I understand both rural and urban concerns.

statement: I want to serve on the commission because I care deeply about ensuring a fair political system within Colorado. I am fiercely independent and feel strongly that the two-party system works best when there is a fair balance to it. I am also a dedicated public servant, both in my career and in my volunteer work, and I think that I can bring relevant experience and thoughtful commentary to the process.
professional_background: As a Larimer County Planning Commissioner, I routinely hear and vote on contentious cases with substantial public opposition. As a board member and volunteer with the Overland Mountain Bike Association, I advocate to northern Colorado land agencies for the expansion of single track, soft surface trails. I have also advocated and litigated on behalf of my law clients.

analytic_skills: The application of scientific and statistical facts to predetermined legal criteria is the nature of an attorney's work. Just as important, however, is my ability to look beyond the problem directly in front of me, see the larger context, and recognize the impact of the various solutions to the problem on the larger context. This is ultimately important when working towards a large, complicated goal.
consensus_statement: As a legal advisor, my role shifts between advocate and advisor. As a member of the Larimer County Planning Commission, I work closely with others across a broad political spectrum, some of which have political candidates with strong opinions. My whole ethos is to bring people towards consensus in a way that is not easily obtained. I am comfortable with the law and with parliamentary procedure, which is a great tool for productive discourse by competing views. Frankly, I am someone who cannot be pushed around, but can be persuaded, and whose goal is to balance fairness.

occupation: Assistant Professor, University of Colorado Boulder
education:
PhD, Education, Teachers College Columbia University, 2010
BIS, Philosophy, Political Science and Education Policy, University of Minnesota, 2001
statement: I think there are far too few competitive districts--at both the state and federal level. Such safe districts erode democratic accountability, and often end up in legislators who are not asked to represent diverse, and divergent, viewpoints. I wonder if this situation also undermines the possibilities for political compromise and action. At the same time, I understand that districts also need to represent certain minoritized communities who may be under-represented in general or at-large elections. So, in a sense, I see the complexity of the issues, and hope to help consider these various viewpoints.
professional_background: Before becoming a professor, I worked with several school and community organizations, including in new immigrant communities, working to create reciprocal and respectful partnerships between universities and communities. I do work collaboratively with a range of parents, district officials and other constituents on our district's DAC (district accountability committee). I've chaired the Data and Assessment committee, and played a lead role on the Charter School Application review committee, which often involved negotiating difficult--and vocal--constituencies on the committee, and those advocating various positions. Our committee had to craft careful, fair evaluation reports that could be understood and accepted by advocates both for--and against--expanding charter schools, and also ones that would hold up to subsequent review and appeal.
org_list: I am mostly active in my local school district (serving on the BVSD DAC), and local school (University Hill Elementary). I also served on a state-wide commission to evaluate accountability measures for Alternative Education Campuses (AECs). Through my work and research at CU, I've organized a number of outreach events to help communities better understand--and deliberate about--standards, accountability and assessment. I'm committed to working across political lines to build opportunities for dialogue. I've worked both on the Front Range and also in NE Colorado to hold community forums and smaller school-based dialogues.
analytic_skills: I am trained as a philosopher, and enjoy thinking through the various reasons, criteria or values at play in discussions. For instance, what principles or values might shape or guide redistricting choices? How might these principles be applied, fairly, and with an eye to their consequences, and the perhaps disparate consequences for differently situated groups? I also like careful and analytic writing, from meeting notes to final reports (sometimes an under-rated part of committee work!).
consensus_statement: I am a Democrat, but grew up in a small town with many different political allegiances. I believe that I have a strong ability to hear--and empathize--with other viewpoints. As a faculty member, I have participated on many standing and ad-hoc committees, and often find ways to listen to different viewpoints, forge consensus, and move groups forward productively. statement: Commissions such as this tend to be heavy weighted with a tier of community activists, political operatives and agenda. Having worked in rural medicine for the 9 years prior to retirement and Front Range private practice 20 years prior, the divide between rural and urban interface culture and economies , the tendency for the Front Range to dismiss rural concerns and for rural communities to feel slighted, is amplified by the factors inherent in strictly political and/or population based apportionment. In my mind, this only hardens political divisiveness. A Democrat from Denver or a Republican from Grand Junction have very little motivation to compromise on partisan issues affecting the other disproportionately - gun rights and urban health centers come to mind. We have been fortunate thus far to have fair and reasonable legislators. I don't believe this will continue. This commission and its success is so important, many people need to step up so the panel can select suitable folks, not just expedient people. I have no clue who you seek but would like to give the selection committee choice.

statement: Most of my adult life I have worked with the public, be it in law enforcement or customer service and I have come to appreciate the backgrounds, insight and diverse opinions and perspectives I have been exposed to from people all across the world. People want many different things unique to their own situation, but most of it can be summed up in the general consensus of being treated fairly and equally. Unbiased electoral maps in our state is the first step in creating a true and just process through fair and equal representation at the voting booth and thus through elected officials. I would very much like to be part of the solution for an issue which has been troublesome to many parties for a very long time. No political party should have an unfair advantage over another simply because the way lines are drawn on a map. Fair and equal is the order of the day. It will take a great time commitment, dedication and the ability to communicate with people who represent a variety of views and perspective and to be able to find common ground and reach compromises. I feel strongly I possess these skills and qualities to be successful.
professional_background: As a member of the APWU I worked as a union shop steward for nearly 17-years; Held the position of City Chief Steward; Editor; Vice-President of the area local. I have always been a strong labor advocate and passionately represented union members and their concerns. Often times these issues involved fair and equal treatment of employees, dignity and respect on the workroom floor as well as interpretation of labor contracts and memorandums of understanding. I was also involved with local labor contract negotiations with the United States Postal Service. I held the board position of Program Director with the El Paso County Progressive Veterans and was responsible for contacting, scheduling and coordinating guest speakers to attend and give presentations which aptly represented their organizations and how local veterans may benefit from the services they provided. Volunteered - Performed Phone Banking - Assisted with canvassing - Posted and removed yard signs. My activities have been with many political campaigns at the state and local level.
org_list: American Postal Workers Union - El Paso County Progressive Veterans - Sierra Club - Citizens Project - El Paso County Democrats - Friends of D-11
analytic_skills: Several things come to mind regarding the skills necessary to be successful with this project. Communication both listening and speaking as well as being able to convey thoughts in writing. The ability to work with others and build a team atmosphere with the hopes of achieving fairness and equality with the end product. Thinking outside the box and listening when other do the same thing. Realizing that while not everyone may agree on all things at all times, it is important to form a consensus as a team with the emphasis again being on fairness and equality. The ability to look at the facts as they are and be honest with the team as to how it looks and listen to team members as to what they see. Again, I feel my military background in law enforcement and my many years of working in customer service in the post office has provided me with many opportunities to see problems and situations from various points of view and to apply workable solutions as much as possible. I have an ability to be both tactful and direct when interacting with people from all backgrounds and walks of life. Team work is key. As a Drill Instructor in the Army several times I was tasked with molding a well functioning platoon which included young recruits from all around the country. Some of these young people came from the streets of the inner city to farm kids from small towns and remote rural settings and they had to be taught to work as a team to achieve common goals. statement: My country and this state have provided us with much.  I'd like to give back and help determine Colorado's state and federal electoral district boundaries as fairly as possible, independent from the party politics that have often influenced such boundaries in the past.  I have a deep and sincere interest in seeing our electoral district boundaries are not slanted to benefit one or the other of the two major political parties and believe my mathematics and legal education, experience in working and representing diverse groups of people worldwide and my professional and business background will help me provide value to the commission and help achieve an apolitical consensus.
professional_background: I've been a member of the Colorado Bar since 2009 and a full-time resident since 2012.  I was elected a member of the board of our HOA in 2013 and served for three years.
org_list: American Bar Association, State Bar of Texas, Colorado Bar Association, Kansas Bar Association, Tennessee Bar Association, Energy Bar Association, Association of Corporate Counsel, Preserve at Pine Meadows HOA Board
analytic_skills:
My first undergraduate degree is in Mathematics.  My studies included both traditional Mathematics, statistics, and computer science.  The unifying themes in mathematical logic include the study of the expressive power of formal systems and the deductive power of formal proof systems.  Understanding the philosophy of logic was key to achieving my Mathematics degree.  Mathematics and mathematical logic is an excellent preparation for law school and practicing law.  My legal career necessitated proficiency in analysis, logic and reason.  If a lawyer lacks any one of those skills, the lawyer loses his/her ability to reason and persuade, and will not succeed.
As but one example, I worked in the United Kingdom for several years during which the UK government decided to develop a regulatory framework for trading certain commodities for companies based there.  The issue became how to develop regulations that were at once transparent, provided accountability to government and yet fostered development of a robust and reputable industry would benefit the UK and EU.  My role was part of a 35-person business and government task force that over several months developed what became the regulations for regulating commodity trading in London and Brussels. If our task force had failed to equally address all aspects of our charge, we would've failed our assignment.  That process involved constant focus on solutions that would withstand inquiry, examination and criticism from every angle, recommendations that would be understandable, reasonable and logical.
consensus_statement:
I represented international, privately-held companies for over 35 years, in the US and outside the US.  This offered countless opportunities to work for solutions with diverse constituents around the world.  An advocate by training, I was taught (and lived by) the tenet that in order to represent one's client ably, one must be able to articulate the opposing side's position as well as one's own.  My professional success was attributed directly to my ability to help my clients see all sides, i.e., what my mentor described as the ability to let my clients have things my way.  I believe I have the ability to articulate without being pedantic, and most importantly, I have the ability to listen, learn and adjust my views, necessary skills to achieve consensus.
As an example, much of my business life involved clients who traded commodities and were among the very best in the world.  The trading business is supremely humbling.  Those who are convinced of their own correctness, who are unwilling to fairly judge the situation, risks and rewards, are doomed to quick failure.  I succeeded in that business for over twenty years until I was hired by Buckman Laboratories International to be their chief lawyer in 2002.  My success was directly attributable to my ability to be objectively assess facts and reject every possible decision bias.
From 2002 until I retiring in 2012, I was the Chief Legal and Compliance Officer for an international specialty chemicals company.  We did business in over ninety countries and our associates spoke over a dozen languages.  My job necessitated regular travel to Asia, Africa, South America and Europe, but it was common to hear several different languages spoken daily at our headquarters.  Because our organization pursued excellence in science, we developed and benefitted from a very diverse group of employees from around the world.  Daily I encountered diverse people and unique problems that required listening, interpretation, understanding and achieving consensus, and I excelled in our company's decision-making process.  My job as board secretary and general counsel required continually achieving consensus and agreement among a diverse and very talented board of directors for a company that was owned more than 50% by women, and I was pretty good at it.
In sum, I've been traveling and working around the world from a very early age.  I believe my mathematics and legal education, work and personal background provided many rich tests in evaluating issues objectively and working towards consensus.  I'm confident I can apply my skills to assist our redistricting commissions.

consensus_statement: Throughout my professional career, I have had to influence people who did not report to me, in order to meet my goals and get things done.  Beginning in venture capital, I was not in a leadership role but had to promote investments, nor was I on the board when I needed our CEOs to undertake initiatives.  Later, in a corporate development role at Madison Square Garden, or in operations with K1 Capital, I had no formal control over the people I needed to accomplish my professional goals.  I have always done this by understanding the perspectives and goals of each person around the table, and articulating why said initiative can help to further their goals, and focusing on other people's strengths in accomplishing these team goals.  I find that finding the common thread - the common purpose - brings people naturally onto the same page.  Keeping everyone's goals in mind allows us to find a single direction and work together.

statement: I believe that redistricting is a much understood & appreciated process. Too often it is not organized to serve an economic & social community, usually geographic in nature.  This is a fresh opportunity to organize a new process: that process will be (good or bad -- hopefully overwhelming fair) the basis for the next group -- 10 years from now. analytic_skills: My past career & education was overwhelmingly in science and technology. Starting in electronics, communications/rf, systems engineer & repair,  leading to networking, and computer repair. In all cases solutions to problems had to fit the conditions -- you can't fake data to solve a problem.  Research often solved problems (similar problems, or seemingly similar problems often lead to accurate answers).  Sometimes you found out that you didn't have enough information; I couldn't be afraid to ask for additional resources when potential solutions didn't work, or results didn't meet expectations.  In other words, sometimes you have to start over, as the apparent scope of the problem didn't fit the results.  It happened occasionally -- let your customer know that a problem remained unresolved and add additional resources to the data gathering (where often information about prior work changed the resulting efforts).   As well as add additional 3rd party technical expertise (more finite analysis of the symptoms).    With my business it isn't much different.  If a customer wants some work done I am not particularly familiar with, I research the request:  process, materials, tooling, time required, ability to master the techniques in a timely matter; will it be financially worth it to do the work (do I expect to do it again, not make as much margin; will the first customer be willing to pay enough to do the work, etc).  If it's a small enough part of a job, do I take a loss for the work in the rest of the project?  Do I know someone better suited for the work?  Do I want to do the work?
consensus_statement: Most of my life I have been in repair in one field or another, the past few years in a new career field running my own business. In all cases this has meant learning, researching, brainstorming, and creating processes.  Almost always on a team (at least for significant issues).  Considering a large list of inputs, then whittling them down by the conditions to the best or most likely results.  Everyone wants to contribute -- it's voluntary to even be on the committee. And everyone has something of value to contribute. Some will contribute ideas, some will contribute by asking hard questions or requiring accurate data.  Others simply by putting together data.  Even those that aren't in agreement force the rest to confirm their reasons for a decision.  Being fair is usually as simple as being polite -- let the other person have a say, wait for your turn, etc.  Being impartial shouldn't be an issue for anyone on the committee -- leave it at the door; this is a job as much as it is a civic responsibility.
past_political_activity: Nothing in particular. Attended Legislature Committee hearings 6 years ago. Registered Libertarian.

professional_background: As Denver's first Chief Sustainability Officer (2012-19) I dealt with many advocacy groups and neighborhood associations, but as a city official I could not engage in organizing, representing or advocating for them. analytic_skills: Whether as a practicing attorney (22 years), a non-profit executive (9 year), or as a public official (7 years), I have had to bring substantial skills to bear in multiple disciplines. Much of this work has involved logic and reason. I learned as a trial attorney and as a mediator, however, that you cannot limit yourself to logic and reason; feelings and emotions must be considered and accommodated as well. The key to a successful outcome, particularly one based more on consensus than on majority rule, it to balance both types of reasoning.
consensus_statement: Regarding fairness and impartiality, I have extensive experience serving as a court-appointed mediator and arbitrator. Professionally as both a non-profit executive and as a former public official I have put the techniques used as a mediator to use in many different settings. As just one example, in Ohio I chaired a two-year community based risk assessment and strategic planning project by appointment of the Mayor of Columbus, involving 200 volunteers. We agreed at the outset that all decisions would be made by consensus. Despite the wide variety of stakeholders represented in that group, we were able to reach consensus on the identification and ranking of risks, and over 150 recommendations on how that city should address them. I have had little involvement with the Colorado General Assembly, which in this setting I believe would actually contribute to my ability to be fair and impartial.
past_political_activity: Since Nov. 10, 2015, I have donated to (a) the presidential campaigns of Michael Bennett and Joe Biden, (b) the senatorial campaign of Alice Madden, (c) the congressional campaigns of James Iacino and Diane Mitsch Bush, and (d) the mayoral campaign of Michael B. Hancock. I did grassroots volunteer work for Mayor Hancock and VP Biden. I have have not donated to or otherwise participated in any state legislative campaigns, which is why I am applying for the state legislative redistricting commission rather than the congressional commission.

It begins by outlining the process that will lead to a legal and fair decision. Then backing down to the individual and group interests and listening to their concerns and the challenges they see. statement: After two centuries of "gerrymandering" in Colorado and the United States, the advent of independent redistricting commissions in some states amounts to a movement of historic importance. Redistricting actions taken by the new commissions in the wake of the 2020 census will set an example for the rest of the states to follow, creating a nationwide movement. I would like to be a part of that movement. More specifically, creation of electoral districts, competitive between the two major political parties—to the greatest extent possible—is the best assurance of a healthy exchange of ideas and, thus, a healthy democracy.
professional_background: I consider myself more of a journalist than a political "activist" As a writer and travel consultant with particular interests I have generally avoided partisan politics and organizing for several decades. After a brief leadership position in my state house district in 2009, I resigned after reminding myself of all the reasons I tend to avoid party politics.
org_list: Historic Denver, University Neighbors; Colorado Independent Publishers Association, First Unitarian Society of Denver
analytic_skills: As a trained historian, librarian, writer, and business man, I have a long and proven record of applying analytical skills. After retiring from business, I have written four editions of a travel guide for budget golf travel to Scotland and a guidebook for travelers on Route 36. These publications and my background are at www.fergusongolf.com and www.us36guidebook.com.
consensus_statement: My overriding interest is in helping create a more vibrant democracy in Colorado. The bedrock of that effort has to be creating competitive districts to the greatest extent possible. I'm not naive. I know that's a challenge in many part of the state. Using my own house district as an example, House District 2, a heavily Democratic district, is a travesty of gerrymandering combining South Central Denver with North Denver (the hospital district). Prior to the 2010 census, when my South Washington Park area was combined with portions of Englewood as House District 3, the district was far more cohesive socio-economically and somewhat more competitive. My guess is that virtually all the  commissioners will agree that one-party districts tend toward the election of ideologues. Changing the current situation will be difficult. I am not an ideologue; I can be fair.

Senior Executive Services Executive Core Qualifications Certification, U.S. Office of Personnel Management. Project Management Professional, Project Management Institute. Safety Trained Supervisory, Board of Certified Safety Professionals. Graduate, Federal Executive Institute, Charlottesville, VA.
statement: I believe that voting is a sacred trust and protecting that trust is essential if our democracy is to survive and thrive. Chief Justice Earl Warren said “The basic principle of representative government remains, and must remain, unchanged – the weight of a citizen’s vote cannot be made to depend on where he lives.” While gerrymandering has been with us since the nation’s earliest days, this practice has intensified over the last 20 years greatly reducing the number of truly competitive legislative seats.  Moreover, gerrymandering has been used to limit the electoral impact of ethnic communities. Gerrymandering continues to erode the public’s trust in the value of their vote and, as a result, has discouraged some from participating in the electoral process to the long-term detriment of our democracy. My desire to serve on the commission is to ensure that legislative districts are fairly drawn to ensure the equality of all votes and to promote the competition of ideas necessary to sustain the health of our democracy.
professional_background: None.
org_list: None.
analytic_skills: My training as a scientist and engineer ingrained in me the importance of objective, evidence-based data to analyze problems and create solutions. My training as a business executive taught me that the best decisions were not solely driven by hard, objective evidence, but required an understanding of the people or emotional elements. Taken together, my training has enabled me to not only use logic and reason to solve a problem, but to consider the human side of a problem to create a logically sound and emotionally satisfying solution.
consensus_statement: Bringing people together to achieve a common end has been foundational to my career success. People will always have differing views on or approaches to solving a problem or achieving an end. Consensus is satisfying but elusive. Agreement through informed compromise, however, is readily achievable. A key principle to achieving consensus or agreement is trust between team participants as well as with stakeholders. Developing trust requires a commitment to each other, respectfully listening to competing views, honestly considering these views, recognizing and setting aside our own biases, and persuasion. Whether a team leader or participant, I work to promote trust through dialogue, transparency, and patience to create an environment all will see as fair and impartial. Once trust is established compromise to achieve agreement is possible.
past_political_activity: No political activity beyond voting and donating to candidates. Donations to candidates for various federal offices over multiple elections. U.S. President: Clinton, Biden. U.S. Senator (Colorado): Hickenlooper. U.S. Representatives: Bullock, Gideon, McGrath, Harrison, Perlmutter, Kelly, and Greenfield.

occupation: I am the Managing Editor for Denver Real Producers magazine.
education:
BA, School of Journalism, University of Wisconsin-Madison
MS, Environmental Public Policy and Advocacy, University of Michigan School of Natural Resources & Environment
Courses in Public Administration, Wayne State University
statement: The development of drawing new boundaries for elected official districts is a critical piece of democracy. Ensuring these boundaries are developed fairly with equal representation for each demographic sector of our state's communities is by the far the most important and critical component of ensuring democracy is working effectively for everyone. It would be an absolute honor to contribute to this enormous and essential task. As an active community member in various Denver and Boulder county neighborhoods, schools, and Jewish community organizations across Colorado, I have a unique perspective on working with many different sectors of our Colorado community which I believe would greatly contribute to the commission's work.
professional_background:
I moved to Colorado to run the Office of Sustainability for the Denver Mayor in 2017. In this role, I worked across government departments and in collaboration with Denver neighborhoods to improve natural resource conservation measures. I represented the City and County of Denver to the broader community and among other municipal governments across the country working toward similar goals. 
 
For three years, I organized a coalition of 40 Colorado Jewish organizations, working to represent the broad Jewish community on local, state, and federal policy issues of relevance and impact to this Colorado constituency. 
 
On a neighborhood level, I organized monthly magazines for the residents of Denver's Hilltop and Lowry neighborhoods for four years, working closely with residents and neighborhood groups, to share news of interest to the community. That work led to playing a similar role for the Denver metro Realtor community, and I currently run this industry trade publication. My role is to help build relationships between top producing Realtors and local businesses that service the real estate industry. 
 
For the past two years, I have been an active parent at Eldorado PK-8, serving on the PTO and School Accountability Committee. When COVID jeopardized the 5th-grade commencement festivities, I organized a Netflix Movie Night for the 5th-grade class. I convened a group of parents to help set up the technology, design gift bags, and organized delivery of gift bags to each 5th-grade household. I am currently organizing a pandemic-friendly safe Halloween program for children in the Rock Creek neighborhood. My neighborhood involvement has also included advocacy work to prevent gun violence in our community and keep our children safe.

Cure Multiple Myeloma Corporation

Superior Parents for Gun Violence Prevention
analytic_skills: My professional experience in communications has given me several tools in strategic analysis, problem solving, investigation and consensus-building. As the managing editor of publications, I thoroughly edit all stories submitted, including fact-checking for accurate representation. My role with the Jewish Community Relations Council and several past coalition organizer roles I have played required mediation and consensus-building to develop strategic plans and public messaging on behalf of issues and causes. I enjoy working in teams and often lead collaboration opportunities to optimize efforts at the community level. As an involved parent in my community as well as in my professional roles, I serve as a project manager to prioritize goals and execute various programs.
consensus_statement: I have been involved in community organizing and coalition building for 25 years, both professionally and as a volunteer. I pride myself on approaching coalition work with an open mind and a kind heart. I find it is always more effective to approach a disagreement among team members with respect and the ability to empathize with opposing views than to try to argue and intimidate others to get your way. In fact, I have been known in many situations as the team player who stays calm and is able to create agreement and effectively help reach consensus.
past_political_activity: From 2001-2003, I served as a political campaign consultant in San Francisco for local and state candidates and ballot initiatives. Since 2015, I have contributed to Our Colorado Way of Life and Governor John Hickenlooper's Gubernatorial Campaign.

education: The highest education I have is an undergraduate's degree from Saint Louis University in which I earned it in only three years. My degree is in political science and Spanish.
statement:
One, it is my duty to serve America. Just like President John F. Kennedy said: "Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country." Well, I am doing exactly what he said with serving on this Commission.
Two, I enjoy challenges and solving puzzles. I was an accountant for almost 9 years. Everyday I had problems coming my way, but I soon discovered that many of these problems can be avoided with easy solutions and talking to my coworkers. And I did just that and it worked!
professional_background: My experience comes from running for political office and a member of RTD's disability committee. While on the disability committee, I have advocated greatly that RTD does more. I have seen for three years now that RTD is very slow in making decisions. When I share my ideas and solutions, the disability committee members agree with me. Outside of that, nothing else.
