I graduated from Denver Regional Council of Governments (DRCOG)'s Citizens Academy.
analytic_skills: For this answer, it comes from almost nine years as an accountant. As a former accountant, I had to apply logic and reason to problems every single day. If I didn't nothing would get done and the balance sheets and the GLs would be messed up allowing the potential for misuse of funds and runaway expenses. Thus, I can do the same with this Commission. There is only a set number of people that Colorado will have. This means we can easily piece the puzzle together and come to an amicable solution for everyone.
consensus_statement: I can be fair and impartial easily. For example, while running for the nonpartisan race of RTD, I went to Democrat and Republican meetings. I went door-to-door during my campaign asking for people's votes. I did not care if they were Green, Socialist, Republican, Unaffiliated, etc. I care greatly about RTD and wanted everyone to know how I can make it better for everyone. I can promote consensus amongst the commissioners as I have patience and the ability to listen to people. I prefer to listen, first, before making any kind of judgement. That way, I can think carefully and provide great ideas and solutions that will work for my colleagues, such as the commissioners.

2016 - GOP Candidate for Colorado's 6th Congressional District. I lost at the GOP 6th Congressional Convention in April 2016.
2020 - RTD Board of Directors District A. RTD is nonpartisan and, as such, I attended local Democrat and Republican meetings to let voters know they could vote for me. I lost the election.
I have donated to the Trump Campaign since 2017. Maybe once to the Colorado State GOP party. I have paid entrance fees to GOP meetings for breakfast clubs and lunch clubs. For local and state campaigns, I don't think I have ever donated to an individual candidate campaign.
Also, forgot to add a precinct person for my precinct for the 2020 election cycle.

consensus_statement: I believe by coming in non-biased without any pre-disposed assumptions about how this process should play out allows me to be fair and impartial.  This is not a matter of "winners" vs. "losers" but about finding the best way to represent all residents and voters in our state.  As far as promoting consensus and creating agreement--giving all members the ability to be and feel heard, establishing and agreeing upon a criteria list for this process and outcome, and understanding that seeking alternatives and compromise will be part of this process.
past_political_activity: I have not had any political activity outside of voting in local and federal elections.  I have not contributed to any campaigns nor political organizations prior to nor since 2015.

occupation: President & CEO, Colorado Nonprofit Association since March 2009
education:
JD, Northwestern University
BA, University of Chicago
statement:
Our democracy depends on citizen participation and the belief that individuals can influence government by voting for representatives.  Legislative districts should fairly represent communities of interest and be balanced sufficiently to allow the votes of all community members to be influential in the election outcome.  Based on my experience representing a legislative district where the voting performance favored the other party, I believe that competitive districts make for responsive representation and accountability to the most people.  I also recognize that given the concentration of partisan affiliations in certain areas, drawing competitive districts is difficult, and in those cases, retaining communities of interest should be paramount. 
I also want to serve because I would like to use my decades of experience and knowledge to continue giving back to Colorado through the important process of legislative redistricting. It would be an honor to serve on the Commission.
professional_background:
I devoted my life for the last 35 years to making Colorado a better place to live through advocacy and  considering interest groups.  I have come to know all regions of the state extensively and to appreciate the different regional economies and cultures. 
As the lone Democrat in the House from El Paso County, I advocated for change in air quality, mined land reclamation, school finance and tax policy (before TABOR) in ways that differentiated me.   At the same time, I listened to and represented other views (e.g. home schooling, support for death penalty).  I worked with state and local agencies to solve every-day constituent problems with government. I was re-elected twice and did not run in 1992.  
Gov. Romer and Ken Salazar (both as AG and Senator) actively traveled to and involved all regions of the state. Both believed that governing was the art of the possible, while making decisions based on principle and rarely for politics.  One good example was fashioning the refund mechanism for the first TABOR surplus in 1997. As the Revenue Director, I played a key role in presenting options.  The Governor favored a per capita refund and the Republicans (who controlled both houses) favored an income tax reduction (which benefitted upper incomes.) During a special session, all eventually agreed on the sales tax refund based on tiered income levels, which required a compromise by all and a lot of negotiation, in which I played a role for the Governor.
Sen. Salazar had a specific set of goals to achieve for each region of the state which involved federal policy (e.g. water, agriculture, job creation, public land use.)  In my role as State Director, I worked with the Senator and our state staff to listen to local citizens and elected officials, turn these needs into a plan and track progress. 
Colorado Nonprofit Association is a statewide organization with 1,500 nonprofit members.  We advocate for public policies and public awareness that support a strong nonprofit community, such as charitable giving. My knowledge of and relationships across the state have helped for the Association to advocate for the essential community work of nonprofits.  The Association has spearheaded several legislative policy initiatives to grow charitable giving, most recently Donate to a Colorado Nonprofit that enables a taxpayer to donate their state income tax refund to an eligible nonprofit of their choice.  In 2018, we also merged with a similar organization in Colorado Springs which required balancing the interests of two organizations and their members and merging two organizational cultures to better serve the Pikes Peak Region and nonprofits statewide.
In sum, I believe that representing, advocating for and considering the interests of groups in Colorado is what I have done and do every day.
org_list:
Mile High United Way, Board of Trustees, 2010-present
Metro Denver Leadership Foundation, Board, 2014-2020
National Council of Nonprofits, Board member and Chair for 2 years (2013-2019)
Colorado Commission on Higher Education, 2015-2019 (Vice-Chair during final year)
Colorado CPA Society, Board, 2016-present
Colorado Education Initiative, Board, 2019-present
analytic_skills: I practiced law for 14 years (six in private practice and eight at the Attorney General’s Office.) Applying rules to a set of facts, through analytical skills, logic and reason is what lawyers do.  As director of the Revenue Department, we faced several dynamic problems requiring solution, including a new vehicle emission testing system, modernizing legacy computer systems, revising tribal Indian gaming compacts to name a few.  As CEO of the Colorado Nonprofit Association, I negotiated agreements to form a collaborative shared space, sell a wholly-owned insurance agency and merge with another nonprofit, each of which involved problem solving within a framework of logic and law.
consensus_statement: Consensus begins with agreement on a shared set of values and guiding principles. In this case, the laws setting forth redistricting criteria provide most of the guiding principles.  These principles establish the framework for fairness and impartiality.  As a group, we should always refer back to the law when considering options.  The commissioners should also establish a set of ground rules that allow for all views to be heard and respected.  When disagreements arise, we should work for compromise as a group and be willing to compromise individually in accordance with the law and guiding principles.  My experience as a legislator, attorney, board chair and CEO negotiating agreements has all involved establishing guiding principles and then listening, negotiating, and suggesting language acceptable to all.
past_political_activity:
I served in the Colorado House of Representatives from 1987-1992, representing a district in El Paso County as a Democrat.  My public service also includes Executive Director of the Colorado Department of Revenue for Governor Roy Romer (1992-1999), Deputy Attorney General for State Services for Ken Salazar and John Suthers (1999-2006) and State Director for U.S. Ken Salazar from December 2006 to January 2009.  Of these roles, State Representative and working for Sen. Salazar were inherently political. In the other positions, I worked for a Democratic official (except two years with John Suthers) who won re-election during my service.  During all of this period, I was actively involved in the state and local Democratic party.  While partisan, the politics of that era were practical and required compromise and working across the aisle.  After becoming CEO of the Colorado Nonprofit Association in March 2009, I was not involved in the party except to make a nominating speech at the Jefferson County Democratic Assembly for Dave Ruchman, a long-time friend, when he ran for state Senate (2010.)  My campaign contributions until the 2018 election cycle were mostly to friends with whom I shared public service.  In 2018 and 2020 election, I made contributions to candidates to support change in our country.

occupation: Retired high school math teacher
education: BA Biology Education, Masters Science Teaching in Mathematics, Masters in Business Administration
statement: I think that representation is important which includes a retired female educator.  I have the skills described below and have spent a good amount of my time in committees working with and leading others.  It is important to me that the commission is independent and not influenced from the outside. Gerrymandering should not be allowed.
professional_background: Organizing:  Jefferson County Public Schools 18 years high school math department chair, 3 years School District Math Project Coordinator, state and regional mathematics convention chair. Advocating: 3 years Indivisible environmental concerns.
org_list: Indivisible Southglenn, CO State HD 38 Democrats
analytic_skills: That is my most important skill.  Solving problems (not just in the math classroom) using the math skills in other areas have allows me to be rational.
consensus_statement: I have been a leader of organizations my entire life from high school to even now.  I understand and advocate members responsibility and cooperation having been in the math classroom for 30 years and as the chair of many committees.  Fairness and impartiality are what teachers do with students everyday.
past_political_activity: 2016 - Hillary Clinton Presidential, Andrew Romanoff CO US District 6; 2018 - Jason Crow CO US District 6, Chris Kolker CO State HD 38; 2019 -  Candace Moon Centennial Council District 1; 2020 - Joe Biden Presidential, Andrew Romanoff CO US Senate, Jason Crow CO US District 6, Chris Kolker CO State SD 27, David Ortiz CO State HD 38, Carrie Warren-Gully Arapahoe County Commision District 1

occupation: I teach K-12 mathematics as Lead Instructor at the Mathnasium of Longmont.
education: I hold a Associates in Science from Front Range Community College. I am currently a student at CU expecting to graduate with a Bachelor's of Arts in Mathematics in spring of 2021. As part of my studies I'm taking a class from Professor Jeanne Clelland which covers the mathematical aspects of redistricting, with a focus on using ensemble analysis and historical data to test the fairness of electoral maps.
statement: It sounds like an unusual sort of adventure. I was thrilled when I first saw amendments Y and Z on a ballot, and I would be equally thrilled to help fulfill their vision of a truly independent and objectively fair voting map. I'm also one of the few people in Colorado old enough to serve on the commission, but young enough to have studied the mathematics of redistricting in school. I believe it is essential that someone with that technical experience be on the commission, in order to provide the commission with the tools to create an objectively fair map.
professional_background: I have not been particular active in the public sphere previously, so while I'm eager to consider the interests of all groups impartially, I imagine this is a skill I will learn through my experience on the commission rather than something I bring to the table.
org_list: I am a young and generally private person so I've had limited involvement with volunteer organizations, neighborhood associations, professional organizations, or appointed boards.
analytic_skills: In general my mathematics education and personal temperament make me well suited to solving complex analytical problems. In the case of electoral maps specifically I have a detailed understanding of the metrics which can be used to judge electoral maps, their limitations, and even some recent case law. I also have experience with the Gerrychain software developed by the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering group of Tufts University and MIT. I can use it both to measure the qualities of a given map (compactness, competitiveness, proportionality) and to perform an ensemble analysis. This technique involves teaching a computer to draw several billion legal maps that then serve as a representative sample that you can compare any given map against. My core concern is that the map drawn by the commission fairly represents the population of Colorado and has neutral to no impact on the outcome of future elections.
consensus_statement: As a teacher it's my job to communicate complicated ideas in an accessible way. I listen to my students and seek to understand and root out the causes of misunderstandings. I'm also a generally friendly person who can discuss political issues in an apolitical way. I see the flaws in both major parties, but I also understand the noble sentiments and sensible reasoning which leads them to their respective views of government. As such I can act as a political translator who can decode the reasoning of a Republican to a Democrat, and the reasoning of a Democrat to a Republican, and hopefully lead both back to the common ground this commission will be built on.
past_political_activity: I have never donated to or volunteered with a political campaign. As a long term resident of Weld County I've grown up in a predominantly Republican environment, and as a student at Front Range and CU-Boulder, I've been educated in a predominantly Democratic environment. After voting along party lines in my first election (though I remained unaffiliated) and seeing the outcome I made a personal commitment to vote for a mix of Democratic, Republican, and Third Party Candidates in each election, a commitment which I have carried out in both the 2018 and 2020 elections.

occupation: Current occupation is Technical Support Engineer, Comcast
education: Currently have a bachelors of science in Information Technology.   Have a Green Belt certification for Six Sigma.
statement: I want to server on the commission to help determine district borders that are representative of the people that live within the district.  I don't want to see districts drawn that favor a political party.
professional_background: In considering the interests of groups, organization, or associations in Colorado I look for what is the motivation history and direction these group, organizations or associations they are moving.  I look into see if the group, organizations or associations is working for the members or a political organization trying to push a political agenda or party.
org_list: I have not belonged to any political, civic, or community organizations.
analytic_skills: I have to use logic to resolve issues in my current position. Using an order process and breaking down issues to smaller working issues.  Then systematically work through the issues and test the solutions.   Also using statistical analysis to make sure the results are repeatable and you can determine what they should be.  Then finding where the process could be improved.
consensus_statement:
I believe I can promote consensus and help create agreement among the commissioners by using data and not opinions or "gut feeling".     
I use data to make my decisions.  I keep political views and personal feeling out of making decisions.
past_political_activity: I have not donated money to any campaigns or other political organizations since November 10, 2015.

occupation: Software implementation consultant, Incline Alchemy
education: Bachelor of Arts, Political Science major, History and Film minors, University of Rochester May 2004 Master of Arts, History, University of Rochester, May 2013
statement: I think that having non-gerrymandered districts is a crucial part of a working and fair representational democracy. Especially with our "first past the post" system, dominated by two political parties, allowing voters the ability to pick their representatives (and not the other way around) is critical. I strongly believe that a large contributing factor to our current political extremes is due to parties controlling redistricting, almost guaranteeing their victory, which leads to politicians having to go further and further to extremes. If districts were created with voters in mind, it would likely help to act as a moderating effect on candidates. I have read with interest the research that has been done on trying to make districts fair and representative, instead of being created to enable single party dominance.
professional_background: Since moving to Colorado in 2013, I have tried to learn as much about the state and the different populations that live here. I have worked with the Denver Silent Film Festival board to address fundraising, as well as working to help with selections of films that will be of interest to the Colorado community.
org_list: I am a volunteer with the Denver Silent Film Festival, a festival that screens silent films with live accompaniment over three days. I update the organizations website and Facebook page, as well as assisting during the running of the actual festival.
analytic_skills: I like to gather as much information as I can about a topic/problem, and carefully weigh pros and cons. In my job, I often come across systems/processes that have been in place for decades; I like to understand the underlying reason for them, in order to ascertain whether they are still needed, need to be modified, or need to be left alone to complete the business process.
consensus_statement: Although I stand up for what I believe in, I recognize the importance of treating people with respect and consideration. In my jobs I have had to work with people strongly adverse to change, and in some cases openly hostile. I have learned techniques to help calm people down, and re-engage so that progress can be made. It's not about "who wins," it's about ensuring that the best possible outcome for people and their organizations are met. I try strenuously to avoid people feeling left out of decisions and the build process.
past_political_activity: I have voted in primaries and in general elections. I have donated money to the campaigns of Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.

occupation: Retired
education:
University of Iowa, Bachelor of General Studies 1973
Georgetown Law School, J.D. 1976
statement: I believe that political polarization is destroying rational political discourse and compromise and, unless we find a way to reduce it, will eventually destroy our democracy.  I am hopeful that careful, balanced redistricting will reduce polarization and promote civil, respectful conversations and compromise.
professional_background:
I’ve spent more than 40 years organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering the interests of groups, organizations, and associations in Colorado as a public finance lawyer and as a board member of a variety of Colorado governmental and nonprofit organizations.

As a public finance lawyer, I’ve represented and advocated for the interests of state and local governments in hundreds of complex financing transactions involving many billions of dollars.  As the “bond counsel” (the lead lawyer) and principal draftsman of the documents governing these transactions, my role has been to ensure that the interests, rights and obligations of my state and local government clients, as well as the other governments, financial institutions, groups, organizations, associations and private parties involved in the transactions, are thoroughly considered and balanced so that I can draft the legal documents that clearly describe the rights and obligations of all parties.  I’ve organized new Colorado governmental organizations by drafting and working in the legislature to enact legislation creating new governmental organizations, negotiating and drafting intergovernmental agreements and organizational documents governing the new governmental organizations and representing those organizations in negotiating and completing financings; examples include public highway authorities, regional transportation authorities, CDOT’s bridge enterprise and high-performance transportation enterprise and the Building Excellent Schools Today program. 

As a board member and officer of a variety of Colorado governmental and nonprofit organizations (see list of organizations in the answer to the preceding question), I’ve had intensive hands-on experience in organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering the interests of my organizations, the constituents of my organizations and the other Colorado groups, organizations, and associations with which they interact.
org_list:

-	Governor’s Emergency Council for Economic Stabilization and Growth (in response to COVID19 pandemic), member of Financial Services and Infrastructure Sub-Committees
-	State Pension Review Subcommittee – member (appointed by the Speaker of the House)
-	Colorado Bar Association – member

Organizations to which I do not currently belong but belonged earlier within the relevant time period:

- 	Colorado Association of School Boards (CASB) – board member

-	Denver Afterschool Alliance – board member
-	Be Healthy Denver – board member
-	Mile High Early Learning Centers – board member
-	Allied Jewish Senior Living Center – board member
analytic_skills:
I’ve spent the last 40+ years using my analytical skills, logic and reason to solve problems and bring people together: to complete complex, multi-party public finance transactions as a public finance lawyer; and to implement community-based policies and programs as a board member and officer of a variety of governmental and nonprofit organizations.

As the “bond counsel” (the lead lawyer) for hundreds of complex public finance transactions involving billions and billions of dollars, it has been my job: to identify the legal, financial and operational issues involved in the transactions; to facilitate negotiations among the parties until everyone agrees on all the rights and obligations of each party; to draft the legal documents governing the transactions; to revise and rerevise the legal documents until everyone’s issues have been resolved and written down; and, finally, to deliver legal opinions that the financing transaction described in the legal documents complies with a complex array of federal, state and local laws.
	
As a board member and officer of governmental and nonprofit organizations, I’ve spent thousands of hours using my analytical skills, logic, and reason to identify and resolve issues for my constituents, the community we serve and the public.
consensus_statement:
I’ve spent the last 40+ years successfully promoting consensus and helping to create agreement among a wide variety of people with competing interests and agendas.  As a public finance lawyer, I’ve successfully promoted consensus and helped create agreement among people with competing interests and agendas in order to complete financings.  As a board member and officer of governmental and nonprofit organizations, I’ve successfully promoted consensus and helped create agreement among people with competing interests and agendas in developing and implementing community-based policies and programs for the benefit of  governmental and nonprofit organizations, their constituents and the public.

I have experience being fair and impartial in hearing and ruling on student discipline cases as a member of the Denver School Board, evaluating employees as a partner in a law firm, as a member of the Denver School Board and as a board member of nonprofit organizations and evaluating and selecting the best proposal for services and goods submitted pursuant to request for proposal processes as the Treasurer and a member of evaluation panels for Denver Public Schools and as a member of evaluation panels established by my governmental clients and the nonprofit boards on which I have served.

occupation: Retired
education:
Bachelor of Arts (B.A.), Political Science, Michigan State University
 Masters of Public Policy, University of Michigan
statement:
I have a life long interest in government, public policy and politics.  As you can see from my resume I studied Political Science as an under graduated and received my masters degree in Public Policy.  In my first career I pursued these interests by working for a member of the US House of Representatives (William Ford, MI) and then by working on political campaigns for US House, State Senate and Governor.   
I was fortunate to work for a US House member during redistricting after the 1990 Census and witnessed first hand some of the inner workings of this process as well as seeing how critical district boundaries were in shaping the composition of future governments and ultimately influencing future public policy.    As a graduate student in Public Policy I was able to take a seminar on apportionment and redistricting and learn of some of the academic work around these subjects and some early proposals by academics to limit some of the partisan influences from the process (my favorite from the time was proposal that representatives from each political party would take turns drawing a single district boundary line on a redistricting map – the theory being that by forcing them to alternate turns each side would reduce the ability of either side to maximize the boundaries to their advantage).
I, like many of our fellow citizens (as demonstrated by the passage of the redistricting commission ballot initiative) have become concerned over the increasing bitterness in partisan politics over the last decade.  While I have strong opinions and beliefs over what is “good” policy and advocate for those positions (and the candidates who support them), I also recognize that others hold just as strongly held beliefs that differ sharply from my own.  As we have grown more polarized I have worried that our governing institutions have struggled to perform in ways that serve our common good.  I have come to agree with the position that a significant contributing factor to this polarization has been the process used to draw district boundaries for state and federal elections.  With the massive increase in availability of detailed data about the electorate (by every conceivable dimensions – age, gender, party affiliation, race, ethnicity, income, education, ……) combined the geospacial computing technology available to use this data, we really had reached the point where the party in power during redistricting can maximize their partisan advantages in unprecedented ways. While Colorado’s previous process what not nearly as bad as other states, it still led to may inequities in district boundaries that contributed to this problem.  
The creation of politically motivated boundaries lines resulted in far too many uncompetitive districts where one political party was almost assured of election. The only competitive elections in these districts where in primary elections, which often resulted in the election of candidates that take the most extreme partisan positions.
It is my strong hope that through the new redistricting commission Colorado will draw election boundaries that will result in as many competitive seats as possible, thus improving the opportunity for candidates who will have motivation to seek out solutions that represent that views of  citizens from across the political spectrum.
professional_background: See answer below regarding promoting consensus
org_list: N/A  In my career as a healthcare consultant I traveled around the country on a regular basis which did not allow time for this type of volunteer activity
analytic_skills: In my career as a health care consultant I specialized in the use of data and analytics to drive strategy development and implementation.  I was privileged to work for some of the pioneering healthcare information companies (HCIA, Sachs Group, MedStat – which were eventually purchased by IBM Watson Healthcare) and develop a strong set of technical and analytical skills to use information to drive decision making.  At IBM I led a group of PhD data scientist, health care analysts and consultants to develop data driven solutions to some of the most challenging problems in the business of healthcare.  In this role we used the same type of data (demographical, education, income, location….) and geospacial technology that are used for redistricting.   I was responsible for leading and challenging this team to turn “data” and “analytics” into actionable information and insights to drive decision making processes.  Through this work I believe I have a strong foundation in the technology, analytics and logic required to develop districts that meet the criteria for determining congressional districts.
consensus_statement: Prior to my retirement this past year I worked as a Strategy and Business Development consultant in the Health Care sector.  I this role I would often be hired by large health care systems to work across their organizations - with Board Members, Executives, Physicians, Front Line staff, Community members…. To develop a strategic vision and implementation plan for how an organization was to achieve their strategic goals.   In this role I would have to facilitate a process to bring diverse constituencies to a consensus on a common set of goals.  At the same time I was also responsible for providing my own inputs into this process – advising senior leaders on strategic options based on my industry observations and expertise.  I believe my years of professional experience in strategy and facilitation combined with my passionate believe in the objectives of the redistricting commission will allow me to contribute to a commission that would be able to arrive at a consensus for the good of the citizens of Colorado and not for any individual position or faction.

statement: I have been teaching and discussing voting with people and students for over 35 years. It is a critical element of our democracy and I find it sadly frustrating that so many people choose not to participate, and yet, still want their voices heard. After decades of discussions and study, I know that people fail to participate because they feel that their representatives don't listen or have their own agendas. I believe much of this attitude is the result of gerrymandering and it has caused great dissatisfaction among the voting population. All people want is for their vote to weigh equally with any other vote. Gerrymandering has inhibited fair elections in the US almost since our inception and it is simply time to put an end to the practice. It will encourage more people to participate and will result in more fairness in election results. Additionally, people are sick of the same representatives and senators representing them term after term. The system, as it stands now, is designed to encourage incumbents win re-election, which limits new ideas and voices in our system.
professional_background: Advocacy has been an integral part of teaching the Social Sciences and Special Education for me. I have advocated for young people who have no political voice (students). I have done advocacy work at the individual, building, and district levels. My experience includes advocating for my individual students in a variety of settings involving their school life. I have also worked as a private advocate for a student in another district whose special educational needs were not being met. Additionally, I have presented at the building and district level on topics related to special education advocacy.
org_list: I was a member of the HOA in my neighborhood. I held the Code Enforcement position which required me to ensure that any changes to a home or a property fell within the HOA covenant guidelines.
consensus_statement: Promoting consensus is a time consuming, but necessary process. I believe a critical element is LISTENING to others to see where you can find agreement and then build from there. Compromise is often necessary and frequently leads to better outcomes than those which might have been created independently. The purpose is to create an environment in which each person feels valued as a contributing member. This requires open and honest communication and keeping an open mind to others' ideas.
past_political_activity: My political activity has been limited due to my teaching position in D20. I deliberately remained "publicly" uninvolved in order to maintain neutrality in my classroom. Since retirement, I have contributed approximately $100 to the Joe Biden Campaign, 2020. Since 1980, I have participated in every election at the federal, state, and local levels. I have voted at each level for republicans and democrats - depending on the position, the needs of the nation/state/city, my personal preferences, but character is my primary guide.

Therefore, I have become adept at working with students and families to come to a suitable resolution or simply to thoroughly explain the options and rules. I have an obligation to apply the University and College policies equitably to all students, assisting me in developing my judgement on what is fair. Because of these experiences in my daily work, as a commissioner, I would work toward consensus with the group, while remaining impartial.

statement: The foundation of our democracy is free and fair elections. America was founded as a republic with a representative form of government and all citizens are entitled to be fairly and impartially represented to the greatest extent possible. Gerrymandering distorts the process of how and by whom the people in our state are represented in Congress and the State legislature. I believe this commission provides an opportunity to bring fairness to the process of drawing politically neutral legislative districts in Colorado and, as an unaffiliated voter, I believe I can and will be impartial in carrying out the responsibilities of the commission to achieve that goal.
professional_background: As Associate VP for Business Services at UCAR I was responsible for organizing the business activities of the organization in support of the atmospheric science community and advocating for and negotiating funding and business relationships with a variety of Federal, State and foreign government agencies, as well as private sponsors and contractors. As VP for the UCAR Foundation I was responsible for advocating for and negotiating the transfer of intellectual property from the scientific community to the private sector. As VP for the Summerlin HOA I was involved in representing the homeowners' rights and interests with regards to public rights of way, public roadways, as well as private property disputes.
org_list: Vice President of the Summerlin Homeowners Association in Longmont; Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors, University Corporation for Atmospheric Research Foundation; Volunteer Transporter for Safe Harbor Lab Rescue.
analytic_skills: I have the ability to look at the big picture as well as get into the details in order to analyze and solve problems. At UCAR, I was responsible for contracts, legal, intellectual property, finance, budgeting and facilities management. Each of these areas requires good analytical skills and the ability to apply logic and reason to solve problems. This requires collecting relevant data and information, analyzing that data and information for relevant facts, determining logical and reasonable options and then making the decision about the best option to solve the problem.
consensus_statement: As a negotiator at UCAR, I learned that to be successful I needed to listen to and understand each party's needs and perspective and to try, as much as possible, to reach an equitable and fair consensus among the parties. To accomplish that usually requires weighing all of the pros and cons of each position and being able to communicate how each party can achieve their main objectives while making concessions so that everyone feels that they have come to a win-win for the group as a whole. I believe I have the ability to be fair and impartial because I do not belong to any political party.

statement: While employed in leadership positions it did not seem feasible for me to take on responsibilities such as this one. My whole adult life I have wanted to be more involved in public service at a governmental level. I was asked to run for office on a couple of occasions and decided against it. Since retirement, I have evolved to a place where I am ready to dedicate myself to something special and different. I am a bit of a “policy wonk” and when I voted on the ballot initiatives that created these commissions, I was already thinking about how I could get involved once the process began. I heard about All on the Line and attended one of their trainings in Fort Collins. I was impressed by Olivia Mendoza and became really excited about applying for the commissions. I believe I have the temperament, experience, and skills to play a valuable role as a commission member. I am also dedicated to seeing our State be successful as we take on this cutting edge and forward thinking process that can become a model to the rest of the country for creating fair and just representation within government.
professional_background: During my 25 years with Project Self-Sufficiency (1989-2014) my focus was on assisting low-income single parents as they moved from poverty to financial independence. I continue to have relationships with many of the parents who either graduated from the program or participated in services during my years there. I often serve as a mentor and write letters of recommendation. As Executive Director I represented our organization at the Women's Foundation of Colorado in Denver, attending advocacy meetings and helping with research projects. I also coordinated services with other community based organizations here in Larimer County. During the years of Welfare Reform I was very active at the State and Local levels in advocating for families living in poverty. While Executive Director, I also served as Program Manager as we did not add that position until later. I expended a good deal of creative energy and networked extensively to establish programs for single parents like the Cars for Families program and special child care and scholarship funds. I sought out partners like the fleet services staff at Larimer County, the City of Fort Collins, and Aims Community College to arrange for volunteer car repair. I worked closely with local housing authorities to secure rent subsidies for families in the PS-S program. I developed quite a local and even statewide reputation and received a number of awards mentioned in my resume.
org_list: I have consistently been a volunteer for Project Self-Sufficiency of Loveland-Fort Collins since retiring from that organization in November 2014. I was Executive Director for 25 years. Since leaving employment there, I have continued on the Scholarship Committee and meet periodically with my successor as well as helping out with newsletter articles and special events. After leaving Project Self-Sufficiency, I worked for the Colorado State University School of Social Work for three years placing undergraduate and graduate level students into internships with organizations around the State. Since retiring from CSU, I have continued to serve as a volunteer Field Instructor for various Larimer County organizations accepting students. As recently as May 2020, I was the Field Instructor for two social work students at Alternatives to Violence in Loveland. I have been serving on the Board of Directors for the Sam S. Bloom Foundation (based out of Centennial, Colorado) for over six years and chair two committees. We distribute grants to nonprofit organizations around the State of Colorado. In recent months, I served on a Larimer County advisory committee distributing federal COVID funds to local organizations. We made recommendations after reviewing funding requests.  I have also volunteered with the City of Loveland, helping with resource distribution for people experiencing homelessness. The attached resume provides some additional information on my experience and service over the years.
analytic_skills: I tend to be a cautious thinker, looking closely at the details in any situation, considering worst and best case scenarios, anticipating unintended consequences, and looking at the long term effects of decisions made now. I continue to marvel at the forethought New Yorkers exhibited when they created Central Park so many years ago. I like to do research and look at best practices to discover ideas and examples of what can work and under what circumstances. My mother was an amazing problem solver and could rig up the most fascinating solutions to a practical problem. I have tried to learn from her example. I look at common sense solutions as well as the spirit of the law.
consensus_statement: My social work education and many years of experience have helped me build a skill set that would assist with this process. As a nonprofit leader, it has often been my goal and my role to build consensus by finding common interests and concerns among participating individuals and organizations. Digging deep to identify my own personal experiences that relate to the topic at hand, as well as helping others do the same, creates an opportunity to build consensus. Story telling and other real life examples of how people are affected is often an effective tool. It is important to see beyond the obvious and look for unintended consequences. I would listen to all points of view and differing opinions, especially coming from local communities and special populations that would be impacted. It is critical to consider diversity within populations, issues that bind communities together, and special circumstances experienced by varying communities. I am rather obsessive about fairness and go to great lengths to make sure a process is fair. I try to give people the benefit of the doubt while gathering more information. We each need to look at our own potential biases and rise above those. In my leadership role at Project Self-Sufficiency, I was known for my inclusive and demographic style of decision making. I worked closely with staff and board members, while also seeking input from program participants. While serving as an Election Judge for Larimer County in 2018, I worked side by side with Republicans and Unaffiliated coworkers to successfully review the status of individual voters at a polling place.
past_political_activity: I am currently assisting with phone calling for the Harris-Biden Campaign and assisted Gordon McLaughlin for DA Eighth Judicial District with yard sign delivery. During the primary I helped gather signatures for Kim Akeley Charron for Larimer County Commissioner and for Lorena Garcia for US Senate. In prior years I have assisted with distribution of literature and phone calling for various campaigns. I attend all caucuses and in recent months I have participated in online townhalls and Democratic Party meetings over zoom and other web platforms. I am currently donating funds about once a month to 25 to 30 different local, statewide, and national campaigns usually at the $25 level and occasionally up to $75.

I learned early on that I had to rely on facts and to seek out the reason(s) for an opponent's positions. They're not always "rational" but must be recognized. There usually is a common ground. And...numbers don't lie.
Finding that and identifying options amenable to both 'sides' is critical.

You always have to "put yourself in the others' shoes" and identify common ground.

analytic_skills: I prefer logic and reason to emotional responses. I want the facts, and the evidence to back it up. I am a business owner, and our company has grown considerably these last few years. My husband and I work together... and we don't always agree, but we are both individuals who respect the others opinion, and who also expect each other to present their facts or reasoning for a decision. We will come to a consensus or do more research until we can. It's how we operate our businesses, and our personal lives. To the extent that my 13 year old knows that a well research logical argument will most likely get her the result she wants- vs. an emotional plea.
consensus_statement: I was a teacher for may years, working with many diverse age groups and abilities... teachers and students. You have to be able to take all the input in, and then produce an actionable plan. Compromise, and everyone understanding and working toward the end goal, is the only way to execute the plan. I don't get frustrated easily, and I consider myself to be reasonable person.

statement: My goal in serving on this commission stems from a desire to re-engage in meaningful public work to focus on rebalancing the influence of individual citizens with the long-accrued power of the two dominant political parties. In my view, both Democratic and Republican parties have become too self-serving in a way that seeks to concentrate and solidify political power instead of representing their citizens' membership with an intent to govern responsibly. One of the approaches that the parties have taken is to seek to gerrymander various systems to favor their party interests at the expense of individual citizens. Colorado voters recognize this tendency and are seeking to re-balance the fairness of elections via this redistricting effort.
professional_background: As a professional project and program manager responsible for the Rocky Mountain Region of the USFS' environmental cleanup program, my work in creating and managing partnerships and managing relationships with local, state and federal agencies to clean up abandoned mines and preplan and coordinate for hazardous materials release emergencies is ongoing. In the interagency Regional Response Team, I represent the USFS and US Department of Agriculture. Under my guidance, the USFS continues to partner with various State (CDPHE, CDRMS, CGS & others), federal (US EPA, US DOE, US DoJ, DOI (including BLM and NPS) to address remediation of abandoned hardrock mines throughout Colorado. At home, both as a BM HOA board member and citizen of the Bear Mountain neighborhood, I shared my 20+ years of experience as a volunteer firefighter, red-carded wildland firefighter and emergency response manager at both federal and local levels to advocate for FIREWISE implementation in our neighborhood. This included collaboration with neighbors, local fire department, and Jefferson County staff to include a strong focus on mitigating ingress/egress routes for one-way-in neighborhoods, as well as establishing emergency access easements across private property for both ingress/egress and "safe zones" to be used during fires. In the past, I've also served as chief steward of a (non-partisan) federal employee union (AFGE - American Federation of Government Employees), representing federal employees at the Rocky Flats site to the Department of Energy - in both union and employee negotiations.
org_list: NARFE; AAA; AARP; Bear Mountain HOA (past board member); CWPIP community representative; Rocky Mountain Region Employees Association (USFS)
analytic_skills: In my day job cleaning up abandoned mine sites and improving surface water quality, I've designed and implemented environmental sampling plans. Use of this data, coupled with stakeholder involvement (those effected by project performance and outcomes) drives the site characterization and, therefore, the cleanup decisions. This work includes presentation and analysis of data, as well as use of GIS to communicate the data and what it tells us about the site and anticipated changes to future water quality.
consensus_statement: As a long-term, Independent voter, I've always sought to find candidates that represent the best interests of the people of Colorado. Generally, this has meant voting based on a variety of beliefs, positions and issues rather than voting based on party ideology. I believe that all citizens and, in part, political parties, seek to maintain Colorado as a national leader in effective governance. Building from this common belief, the commission can work to balance citizen and party priorities by ensuring fair elections based on a fair demarcation that does not favor any political party.
past_political_activity: While I vote every year since eligible at age 18, the last time I ran for any "office" was in college (1986-1987; elected student body president (non-partisan, student election) at University of Michigan, Ann Arbor campus). I have attended several marches and rallies (mostly in Colorado) since that time. Without exception, these demonstrations have been non-partisan/issue-based.

statement: Colorado is the best state in the union, we are a beacon of hope for the rest of the nation. We strive to organize our institutions to be fair and just. There is an area however, that could use some improvement. Denver is the Capital and has the population concentration of the entire state. The remaining parts of the state are rural and rural resorts. It is understandable that Denver would have an outsized role in our state, however in the interest of fairness, the rest of the state also needs representation. The Western Slope often does not have a big opportunity for input in policy making decisions. Additionally, the Western Slope is becoming more diverse every year and that diversity also needs to be considered. Through my involvement in various philanthropic activities and civic and political organizations, I have learned a great deal about the communities of the Western Slope and I would like to bring some of my experience and knowledge of the area into the discussions of the Redistricting Commission.
professional_background: Promoting social justice and advocating for others has been a large part of my life. Through my service with Alpine Legal Services, we were able to provide pro bono legal services for for the extensive portion of our community who cannot afford legal services. Members of the community have often contacted me to assist them with other non-legal family issues. I have been able to assist them by connecting them with the constituent services of our elected officials, particularly with Senator Bennet's office dealing with immigration questions. When COVID began, we were very alarmed at the high percentage of Latinos who were contracting COVID in our community. I was able to have 18,000 masks donated and was able to connect the mask distribution with the Food Bank line in Rifle and Glenwood. When our son was enrolled in the Aspen Public Schools from kindergarten through high school I served on many Advisory Committees assisting the schools on many school projects. When it was reported that the Department of Homeland Security was detaining children at the border in cages, I volunteered to help with asylum cases in Texas at the El Paso and McAllen sites. I worked there under the auspices of The Center for Human Rights and Constitutional Law and under the American Bar Association's Pro Bar Legal Project. I am scheduled to continue to work on more asylum cases within the next few weeks.
org_list: Community service has been an important part of my life ever since I graduated from Law school. For many years, I was Chair of Alpine Legal Services which serves our Roaring Fork Valley from Rifle to Aspen. I am a former Board member of the Aspen Youth Center and of the Aspen Valley Medical Foundation. I served on several Advisory Committees at the Aspen School District and chaired the successful bond election for the construction of the new Aspen Middle School. I presently serve on the Advisory Board of Aspen Words (Formerly known as the Aspen Writers Foundation) and I am excited to be one of the founding board members of the new Latino Advocacy group, Voces Unidas de las Montañas, where I serve as the Board Chair. I serve as Chair of Boldly Forward,  a non-profit C4 which is an issues advocacy organization.  I have also served on Governor Hickenlooper's Judicial Performance Commission and Governor Polis' Judicial Nominations Commission. I also served as Co-Chair of Governor Polis' Inaugural Committee.
analytic_skills: Developing your analytical skills and applying logic and reason to a problem was critical to being a successful law student. These skills were used throughout your assignments and exams. It has been my experience that once you are trained as a lawyer, your approach to your life changes. My law school training has taught me to approach most projects and problems in a certain step by step methodical way in order to complete the task or to achieve a solution. It is just second nature.
consensus_statement: I am the eldest of five children, building consensus and creating agreement was a mater of survival. Later, when I was in college, creating consensus was the best way to get your group project finished and submitted on time. Later, as I served on numerous boards, I learned that consensus building definitely made you a more effective board member. I consider myself a compassionate person. One of the basic characteristics of a compassionate person is to be fair and balanced. Being fair is also associated with being just, which is a trait found in thoughtful lawyers. Being fair and just to others is a goal I strive to meet every day.
past_political_activity: I have been very involved in politics at many levels, my entire life. My husband and I have also hosted several hundred political events in our home, some were fundraisers, many were "friendraisers". We have hosted events for Aspen City Council & Mayoral Candidates and Pitkin County Commissioners as well as state candidates at all levels including the Governors races. We have also hosted events for federal races for congressional, senatorial and Presidential candidates. I have contributed to many candidates and PACs  in Colorado at every level, city, state and federal. I have also contributed to candidates and PACs from other states.  I am attaching two documents which list the campaign contributions which I have made since 2015. I do not keep a list myself but I believe the bulk of my contributions, if not all my contributions are captured on those two lists.

Quieter voices sometimes need elevation, while louder voices sometimes need moderation to bring balance to a discussion. That also involved balancing the interests of responsible parties, citizens, communities within the context of science and principles of public health protection. I served on three federal advisory committees charged with recommending revisions to federal environmental regulations (drinking water).  I was often the neutral voice that could bring disparate parties to a common and agreeable resolution of the problem.  Finally, I assisted the federal Agency For Toxic Substances and Disease Registry in 2 locations (Memphis, Tennessee and Cape Cod, Mass.) by mediating discussions toward resolution of disputes between the community and federal agencies relative to environmental contamination. statement: I want to work with other team members to create a system of district that promote healthy political involvement and results. I believe that our Colorado representatives should represent constituents of similar local concerns and not be far removed from many constituents located in the far reaches of a gerrymandered district.  For instance, the SD2 map extends from far east side of Colorado Springs Airport then wraps around south of Colorado Springs and all the way to Idaho Springs, and SD25 extends from Thornton way out to Washington county.  I think we can do better. I think we can make fairer districts.  Colorado is a purple state that has had a tilt to either blue or red depending on the election in the last 25 years.  In most years, we should expect Colorado's 65 state house districts to have a 55%/45% split of major parties serving in the state House. In years, with significant sea changes or "waves" of one party preference, the split should be no more than 65%/35% split. I think our founding fathers intended some degree of stability in government that is insulated from huge emotional swings as well as an inherent competitive nature.  With that said, I will certainly listen to opinions and ideas of others on the commission.  I have observed and participated in Colorado politics for over 25 years.  I believe I can use this experience and my organizational experience to beneficially serve the state of Colorado.
professional_background: As a market director at my company, I manage diverse groups of people. As a senior project manager, I have consistently run teams of 50 or more people to successfully execute large projects. Strong team organization skills are required for these positions. I also have a long history of coaching youth sports, serving on school boards, volunteering to work on and lead school events.
org_list: I attend Arapahoe County Republican dinners, volunteer in church functions, and belong to professional industry organizations such as American Society of Mechanical Engineers and Project Management Institute.  I routinely attend Advanced Bioeconomy Leadership Conference. I have donated time and money to numerous charitable organizations.
analytic_skills: I am an engineer by degree, a project manager by training and experience. I direct a market at my company and am skilled at managing diverse teams of individuals.  I have experience at promoting collaboration with folks of different backgrounds.  I have provided reference letters to substantiate this experience and my ability to converse with those of differing political beliefs.  Logic and reason is a must have skill for what I do, but I also possess softer skills required to work with many diverse folks.
consensus_statement: I will try to find common ground for everyone's concerns. I believe all the commissioners will want the following goal: for our Colorado representatives to represent constituents of similar local concerns and not be far removed from constituents located in the far reaches of a gerrymandered district.  As demonstrated in my attached reference letters, I will listen to others' concerns while promoting my ideas of stability and representative districts explained earlier.  I will not attack others of different political beliefs and will convey my ideas in a non-confrontational, objective manner..  I will keep the focus on providing fair districts that should result in a 4-3 split during most years and occasionally in a 5-2 split during sea change years. I will follow the rules provided set forth on this website.   I have observed and participated in Colorado politics for over 25 years.  I believe I can use this experience and my organizational experience to beneficially serve the state of Colorado.

Both groups are comprised of community members who come together to determine how best to support the efforts of local human services agencies and not-for-profits, using either state funding or private impact philanthropy. consensus_statement: I am a health care attorney. As a health care attorney we are often thrust into situations where people are at their most vulnerable. No one wants to be at the hospital. Patients and their families are often scared, nervous, angry and often grateful...all at the same time. People in their most emotional of times often struggle with decision making. As an attorney, I'm often called on to be an intermediary between health care providers and patients/families. Now with COVID restrictions, we are even more sensitive to the challenges of having a health care event. Every day I have to navigate differing opinions, differing "rights", considering nuance of privacy law, and protecting the institution. Each day ultimately, my job is to insure that patients and families are able to continue their journey with as much dignity as possible.

In a professional setting I assess proposals based on evidence, I consider the scaffolding on which a proposal is built with an eye toward its accuracy and efficacy, and I tend to be a "Devil's advocate", viewing a proposal from many different angles or perspectives.  Given these habits, I like to think I arrive at fair and impartial impressions.  This also means that I respect and appreciate opposing views when they are arrived at through a similar strategy.

occupation: CEO of Minds Matter Colorado
education:
University of Pennsylvania - BS Systems Engineering '03
Thunderbird School of Global Management - MBA Global Management '10
The Broad Center - Masters in Educational Leadership, '13
statement:
As are many others, I'm concerned and often overwhelmed by all issues being politicized and partisan, and for elected officials who continually seem unwilling to compromise in a professional and communal manner. All too often members of both parties seem more concerned with solidifying their own interests and political purposes than looking out for constituents and the greater good -- this is something George Washington specifically warned us about and we're seeing come into fruition. 

Especially in a state like Colorado, where so many voters are unaffiliated, the power of parties to draw districts should be minimized or eliminated. I'm grateful that Colorado has independent commissions to do so, and I know the importance of well-drawn non-partisan districts. I'm honored to be considered for the opportunity to ensure the next 10 years are designed to serve the citizens of Colorado, not political parties.
professional_background:
My entire job is advocating for under-represented voices in our community -- I'm the CEO of Minds Matter Colorado, which connects driven and determined high school students from low-income families with the people, preparation, and possibilities they need to succeed in college, create their futures, and change the world. My goal is to help eradicate systemic inequity in higher education for our students, and to expand our programming to provide access to Minds Matter to every student, corner-to-corner across Colorado.

In addition I've been asked to speak at multiple conferences and summits on issues related to creativity, innovation, collaboration, diversity, equity, inclusion, and anti-racism, including the Harvard Innovation Summit, B:Civic Summit, Colorado Mentoring Summit, and the National Association of Independent Schools People of Color Conference.
org_list:
I've been on the boards of the Luminary Learning Network (a collection of innovative schools within the Denver Public School district), the Civic Canopy (an organization geared towards building cultures of collaboration across the state), and the Denver Metro Chamber Leadership Foundation (an organization that serves to educate and inspire civic leaders in the Denver Metro community), as well as the Minds Matter Colorado and Minds Matter National organizations. I have also been nominated to serve on the Trust of the Rocky Mountain Vipassana Association, a volunteer-led non-profit to teach meditation techniques.

I've also volunteered with myriad organizations in various capacities, ranging from providing presentations to teachers and social entrepreneurs, to leading workshops and panels on diversity/equity/inclusion and education.
analytic_skills:
I'm an engineer by training -- my undergraduate degree is in Systems Engineering from the University of Pennsylvania and I love crunching numbers and analyzing data, drawing important conclusions to inform our work. I've studied extensive statistical analysis, econometrics, and data crunching in my undergraduate work, and feel quite comfortable drawing conclusions and crafting a narrative from data.

In addition, as the CEO of a small but rapidly growing entrepreneurial non-profit, I am perennially thinking strategically and big picture -- What is the current state? Where do we want to go? How can we get from here to there? What needs to happen in what order? I do this all rationally and logically, and lay out steps in a clear process, but with an emotional connection to the end goal, and bringing along teams of volunteers to achieve that goal.
consensus_statement:
People who know me will vouch for my willingness to engage with everyone, put judgment to the side, and have meaningful conversations with people who disagree with me. My search is for the truth, not for the upper hand. I seek common ground and shared values and vision, and I consider my ability to bring people together for a higher purpose to be one of my strong suits. 

In addition, in my past as a consultant, I have trained organizations and groups on effective collaboration, creativity, and consensus-building, so I have a great deal of background, knowledge, skills, and practical experience in building consensus and finding collaborative solutions for difficult problems.

I feel strongly that I'd be able to build consensus in contentious environments if I think the cause is powerful and important enough. This redistricting commission feels like exactly such a cause -- I think ensuring the voices of Coloradans of all beliefs, backgrounds, and communities are valued and equitably reflected in our representation is one of the highest callings in the great democratic republic that is the United States of America.
past_political_activity: I've donated to campaigns for people that I know (Aaron Goldhamer, Lisa Cutter, Mike Johnston, Chantell Taylor) for various local and federal offices, and I've donated to Elizabeth Warren's Presidential Campaign. However I've supported and voted for many Republican and Independent candidates over the years as well. I consider myself firmly centrist, independent, and nonpartisan. My goals are to support what is in the best interests of our country and state, not what's in the best interest of any individual or political entity.

occupation: I am a Certified Court Interpreter. I provide Spanish-English interpretation in Colorado Courts on civil, criminal, probate, and juvenile matters. The State of Colorado and the City and County of Denver are my largest clients, alongside private clients. Previously, I was an Assistant Professor at the Colorado School of Mines.
education: I have a Ph.D. in political science from Northwestern University and a B.A.-M.A. from Johns Hopkins University in international relations. My Ph.D. includes a minor in Quantitative Methods. My qualifications include expertise in statistical software packages, such as STATA, and the mapping software Arc GIS. I speak French and Portuguese, in addition to being bilingual in English and Spanish.
statement: I want to serve on the commission because I know that the geography of political districts has a large effect on representation. The legislative change that put decennial redistricting in the hands of independent commissions in Colorado is a move in the right direction, as partisan gerrymandering has made congressional races less competitive. In addition to creating safe seats, gerrymandering reduces the incentives of elected representatives to be responsive to the median voter, as gerrymandering allows districts to be "packed" with like-minded voters, and is an obstacle to pluralism through the practice of "cracking", or diluting the vote likely to elect the opposing party. These factors combined contribute to higher barriers to entry to political office and lower bi-partisanship.
professional_background: Through my volunteer work with the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network (RMIAN) I seek to ensure that all people have knowledge of their legal rights and receive due process. My work with RMIAN, however, goes beyond my interpretation assignments and extends to helping immigrants become successful members of our community.
org_list: I am a pro-bono interpreter with the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network since 2017. From 2017-2019 I worked alongside Humanitas360 conducting research on prison work cooperatives in Latin America.
analytic_skills: Perhaps the most intense period of training in analytical and logical skills happened for me during graduate school. There I learned to ask questions that lend themselves to empirical testing and to chose and apply the methodology most appropriate to evaluating potential answers. We delved into topics such as whether we can establish a robust relationship between cause and effect and eliminate alternative explanations for a finding, and whether the same findings can be replicated in other settings. I later taught research methodology for the social sciences at the Colorado School of Mines. With my students I explored issues of omitted variables, selection bias, and missing data. My training as a researcher and my experience teaching others how to ask questions and test answers are well suited to the tasks of the redistricting commission: absorbing large amounts of information, analyzing data, and weighing competing interests. I am experienced in the use of statistical software and familiar with geospatial programs as well (e.g. ArcGIS).
consensus_statement: My ability to be fair and promote consensus comes from my years teaching college students and working in the courts. One of the goals of teaching about politics and government is to give students the knowledge and skills to form opinions and defend them. It is the instructor’s responsibility to facilitate class discussion and model appropriate behavior. One technique I have used to facilitate the free exchange of ideas is to collectively agree on a short set of beliefs for opposing points of view on a policy issue, and then assign students to defend a belief, regardless of his/her own stand on the issue. This exercise illustrates that competing points of view can be grounded in acceptable ideas and be the result of sound reasoning. From there, the exercise moved on to the construction of a counter-argument, where students would choose what position to take on an issue. A similar process can be used in other contexts to facilitate consensus. Working in courtrooms I have learned that impartiality is as much a state of mind, as the result of adhering to procedure. Jurors, for example, can be instructed to follow a set of rules in the evaluation of evidence. This, in turn, can lead to a shared understanding of the evidence and to a consensus-based decision that is informed but not pre-determined by prior held beliefs. The process of first reaching an agreement on the steps to be followed in the evaluation of information can be used in other contexts as a way of facilitating joint decision-making. Perhaps the hardest goal to achieve in the process of redistricting is fairness. The American system of representation rests on the idea of equality of representation of all people, yet we know that the same vote will either fall in the winning majority or in the losing minority, depending on the location of the district line. If selected to serve on the commission, I will bring all my energy, knowledge, and experience to achieve this ultimate goal.
past_political_activity: I volunteered for the campaign to elect Phil Weiser as Colorado's Attorney General and for Mike Johnston's primary campaign for the Colorado governorship. My husband and I made a campaign donation to John Plumb's campaign for New York State's 23rd Congressional District in 2016.

occupation: Chief Housing Officer and Executive Director, Department of Housing Stability, City & County of Denver
education: I have a B.A. in Communication from Wartburg College.
statement:
I believe strongly in the democratic process, in public service, and that representation matters. The redistricting commission’s work is critical to our democratic republic, and how it is conducted must be done with transparency, accountability and respect for all Coloradans. I believe in our state, value our communities in every corner, and believe I can bring value and experience to the redistricting commission. 

I am fairly moderate in my political views and am used to working through the passions brought by more strongly conservative or liberal views. I am experienced in interpreting complex data and skilled in asking questions that clarify particulars and gaps. I keep focused on our purpose, our commitment to our community, and how we can contribute to a process that allows all to be heard, where those with the least resources and access are sought out, that is respectful, and comes to a conclusion that works for all of Colorado.

Finally, I am a mom of three young children living in a multi-generational household in the suburbs. I was born and raised in a rural farming community that strongly formed my values, I have lived in and currently work in our state’s largest urban center. I have travelled to nearly every county and town in Colorado. The outcomes from the redistricting commission are crucial in how we value all Coloradans. I am an experienced representative of my congressional district on a commission and a committed community member. I want to model for my children that a good process requires people of all backgrounds to come forward to serve and work together for our future.  It would be an honor and a pleasure to serve Colorado in this way.
professional_background:
I have lived in Colorado for 20 years. I started by living in an intentional community where all residents of the program served as full-time volunteers in Denver. My experience supporting participants in programs for food assistance and basic services informed my interest in public policy and informed decisions that serve, respect, and represent all residents of our community.

In my work and leadership through Housing Justice and the Colorado Coalition for the Homeless, I traveled to most cities, towns and counties in our state. I organized in faith communities to inform and equip people of faith as advocates for affordable housing and for our neighbors who need housing stability. I worked with school districts, county and city leaders across the state to inform and educate on fair housing laws, organized in rural and frontier communities to support women’s health, and communicated with as many communities and residents as possible to understand, inform and shape public policies that moved us toward better health and increased housing stability in our state.

Specifically, I have served as Chair of the Colorado Housing Investment Fund Coalition where I supported the growth of the organization from a couple dozen to more than 200 organizational supporters and hundreds of individual supporters. My role was to help facilitate constructive conversations that shaped our proposal to fund affordable housing throughout Colorado in a way that served all contexts and communities in Colorado. There were a variety of opinions, needs, economic factors, and people to serve. Many of my skills in bringing people together around common purpose, finding compromises, and articulating policies that are flexible to support needs in the variety of communities throughout Colorado were honed in this experience. I participated in community forums in gyms, county courthouses, community rec centers, schools, faith communities, nonprofits, and businesses in congressional districts across the state. This is how I discovered many of my favorite cafes, mountain passes, and county roads in Colorado. This is also how I got to know more intimately the flavors of government and economic conditions that vary from our plains, to our rural resort towns, to our ranching and mining and extraction areas, to our suburbs and urban centers.

I was in the 2009-2010 class of Leadership Jefferson County. We looked in depth at policy areas and government functions in the county. After graduating, I continued as a volunteer with the State Day Committee, where we plan and support the current class on the day they dive into State Government. These experiences have led to lasting relationships across the county and with the West Metro Chamber. 

My most similar commission experience was in serving on the State Housing Board representing Colorado’s 7th Congressional District. I served as a member, then Vice Chair, and finally Chair in my eight years and two terms on the board. We carefully considered many complex investments, regulations and rules, and complicated matters. We worked together as a diverse body with balanced political affiliation and made considered decisions and recommendations. On almost all matters we worked to consensus and hammered out to agreement. I can only remember less than a handful of votes that were split decisions. I presided over meetings and public hearings. Our environment was always respectful and collegial even when matters were complicated and passionate views were expressed.

My most recent experience was on the Advisory Committee revising the Code of Conduct for the Regional Transportation District. This committee met for several months this spring and summer and was conducted virtually. There were complexities, legalities, and a variety of opinions. I asked questions that grew insight for the body and utilized my representation as a mom living in the suburbs and traveling the system for commutes and recreation to give insights. We waded through considerations for customers and employees, as well as organizations, persons experiencing homelessness, and the community at large, and considered equity as we worked through the material. We came to compromises and worked out a unanimous recommendation that was ultimately approved by the board.

analytic_skills: I have always been an excellent student. I do my homework and come prepared for discussion.
