professional_background:
Beginning in 2009 I chaired the South Metro Denver Health Care Policy Task force.  Our task force wrote a proposal for consideration by Colorado's 208 commission on healthcare reform.  This proposal was later written as legislation that was presented in the Colorado legislator in 2009 and 2010.  We worked with business and community organizations and health care trade associations to articulate the significant issues in our healthcare system.  This advocacy for rational reform in healthcare, which would actually reduce the overall cost of the system, and the cost in the system to governments, business and individuals, has been revived this year.  In 2010 I cofounded and chaired the Coalition for Effective Healthcare a 501C4. 
 In 2012, at the request of the South Metro Chamber Board of Directors I wrote a white paper on the significant challenges for business of Colorado's very complex sales tax system.  That white paper was presented to the then Colorado State Senate President.  That led to my personal advocacy with mayors, Colorado Department of Revenue and some legislators.  Ultimately, after soliciting the involvement of American Furniture Warehouse and Colorado Automobile Dealers Association, we interested businesses and trade organizations in joining the effort to fix Colorado's Sales Tax System.  We formed the Coalition to Simplify Colorado Sales Tax, a 501c4.  The Coalition, working with legislators, has participated in the writing of and advocacy of 5 bills that have all passed the legislature and are step by step moving Colorado toward a far more user friendly sales tax system, that is revenue neutral, at worst, and very well may generate more sales tax revenue for the state and home rule cities.
org_list: State of Colorado Task Force to Simplify Colorado Sales Tax 2017 to present; Vice President Board, Coalition to Simplify Colorado Sales Tax; Board Member Cornerstone Productions, 2014 to present; South Metro Denver Chamber of Commerce, National Federation of Independent Business
analytic_skills:
With my healthcare reform advocacy, we engaged political leaders, business organizations, and even healthcare trade associations.  This is a really difficult issue to rally interested parties toward a common solution.  The actual fix to the healthcare system problems, is not that challenging.  Aligning the various players is very challenging.  The businesses of healthcare themselves are the most difficult to move as the American Healthcare industry is the largest industry on the planet with significant players who have a major financial stake in the structure of our system.  We were able to achieve alignment with many at the table including advocates for a single payer healthcare system, with whom we found significant common ground.  As part of my work in this area, I was a significant contributor to the legislation that enabled the Colorado healthcare insurance exchange.

I am a business owner and prior to owning my business was the Colorado senior executive of a company with 650 Colorado employees.  I have consistently in my life faced challenges that required analysis, consideration of multiple courses of action, developing strategic direction and decision making and implementing strategic plans.    We have successfully navigated very difficult situations.  2008-2010 was very difficult for most businesses.  We were no exception.  We developed strategies to navigate our business through a significant recession.    the shutdown of much of our economy as a result of Covid 19 has brought a whole new set of challenges that required fast assessment of the looming problem, multiple options to address the business challenges, selecting a go forward set of plans and implementing it.  Our business has been dramatically impacted by Covid.  Today, we have as many employees as when the pandemic first resulted in stay at home orders.  Our outlook for the future is strong as we have made and implement many decisions that have preserved our company and positioned us for future success.
consensus_statement:
In my sales tax simplifications advocacy I have met with and been in meetings with all stakeholders in the sales tax system - the Colorado Department of Revenue, Colorado Municipal League, individual Home Rule cities, counties, Colorado legislature, business trade organizations and individual businesses.  We were able to listen, respond to disparate interests, find common ground and common objectives and move the ball progressively toward a much better sales tax system for the state of Colorado.

With my healthcare reform advocacy, we engaged political leaders, business organizations, and even healthcare trade associations. Upon discovering this commission, I felt immediately drawn. Having built hundreds of homes and seeing hundreds of people move into Colorado, I cannot help but believe that a redistricting is needed to be fair.  Historical gerrymandering, I believe, has also thrown off districts.  Hence, I am applying for this position as I have a keen interest and a lot of time!  I would be honored to serve on this committee.  
In an effort to be honest with you I need to express that I am a a common person who never really got involved with the parties or politics; other than voting.  I do not know what you are truly looking for.  I am ethical, interested, organized, results driven collaborative, objective and I listen really well to all people and treat everyone with fairness and concern.  
My job in construction was that of a daily problem solver, basically all day long, and I would like to carry that skill forward to something like this.

Then, craft solutions toward desired outcomes and results prioritizing results.  In summary it is important the end point is reasonably thought out with data to back it up.

statement: Gerrymandering is a profoundly anti-democratic problem, effectively disenfranchising millions of voters & causing our legislative bodies to become increasingly radicalized, as representatives from "safe" seats for either party are essentially elected at the primary level instead of the general. I think I could provide the commission with a knowledgeable voice, based on my education & professional experience with GIS. However, I am not deeply involved in politics (aside from being an engaged citizen). I believe I could be a relatively unbiased voice on the commission (no one is completely unbiased), and I know that I know more about the technology used in redistricting than most citizens.
professional_background: I do not organize, represent, or advocate for any groups, organizations, or associations.

analytic_skills: I wrote my Master's project on gerrymandering, focusing on Pennsylvania (which was the subject of Vieth v. Jubelirer, 541 U.S. 267 in 2004). I studied the strengths & weaknesses of various algorithms for generating "neutral" district sets. I have experience explaining complicated scientific problems to lay audiences. Professionally, I am called on to provide logical, reasonable analyses to complex problems as a matter of course.
consensus_statement: I am not involved in many organizations, but in my professional work, I spend a lot of time developing consensus between groups with different points of view, sometimes in rather contentious settings. For example, I was the response manager for the Gold King Mine spill site for two years. I had to work with community members, EPA, BLM, the Uncompaghre Ute tribe, neighbors, & landowners to complete our scope of work, while managing my own team of workers and subcontractors. That experience taught me how to listen to opposing points of view and genuinely consider how to incorporate those viewpoints and concerns. I am also truly disinterested in dictating the outcome of any election, other than making it fair. I would be thrilled for every Congressional district in Colorado to be competitive, if its electorate was truly split. I want distinct parts of the state to be represented, not packed or cracked. I think that fair redistricting may help revive belief in our system of government.

statement: My pursuit of this position is largely due to my professional and educational backgrounds; where I’ve worked and lobbied to assure communities are instituted and planned to meet their safety and well-being needs.  Truthfully, I've spent a good portion of my life obtaining an education, and I'd like to put it to use; as the student loans continually remind me of it.
professional_background: There are too many to mention, some are listed in my letter of intent, however, there is little mention of my pursuits on the Auraria campus.  This is a community of staff, students, professors and administrators.  Because I was a single mother, I had to find an innovative way to attend college; as a State employee, I was able to downgrade and transfer to the college.  While working full time for the college, I attended classes part-time on my lunch hour and after work.  This supplied me with two perspectives on higher education - as a staff person and as a student. Within a couple years, state employment found me managing academic departments, and holding a classified staff senator position, representing Colorado state employees on campus.  The next year, I joined the Chicano Faculty & Staff organization, becoming the Secretary, and by the end of 1996 I began a chapter of the National Association for Chicana and Chicano Studies, promoting the injection of ethnic studies into the CDE's K-12 curriculum.  During these years, I collaborated and joined other student organizations, La Xicana and MechA, in an effort to recruit and retain minority students on campus.  Our prize project was the La Alma de la Raza Curriculum Project, financed by President Clinton's Goals 2000 Grant program.  And during all this advocating, I obtained and developed new skills - the drafting of curriculum, the handling/bookkeeping of large and small state academic budgets, academic student recruitment, the handling of faculty searches, the hiring of part-time faculty, and interestingly, the handling of graduation agreements.  In 1998/9 a new venture was undertaken, teaching other MSCD employees and student staff on the operations of the BANNER database.  Technology came to campus and database experts were in need.

analytic_skills: My Masters of Science in Public Policy should be enough relevancy to assure I'm able to not only use but understand the systematic analysis of issues related to public policy and the decision processes associated with them. This would include the studies and training in the role of economic and political factors in public decision-making and policy formulation; microeconomic analysis [econometrics]  of policy options and issues; their resource allocation and decision models; cost/benefit analysis; and statistical and research methods.
consensus_statement: As a state environmental and educational employee, I've always had to promote a consensus of the administration's pursuit to create a good, safe and clean learning environment.  Working in the public sector can provide either great satisfaction or disarray; as a representative of our government, I feel, it is my duty to assure a consensus is not just heard, but heeded, by our administrators.  If disarray is visualized or experienced, advocates should be supplied to counter or meet the disorganization/disagreement.   Consensus is achieved by finding the middle ground, ideas that meet both or all parties needs; then working toward a mutual agreement on those outliers, merging them or redefining them, possibly allowing a better consensus.  Being impartial can be difficult when it comes to meeting the demands and needs of children and the elderly, they are so vulnerable and require our steadfast and consistent support but their needs should not revoke or overshadow the needs and rights of our younger more vibrant portion of the community - our workforce.  Without our workers/drones, we'd not have a hive/community or a queen bee (leader) to serve.  Fairness is a subjective concept which was consistently taught to me, as I grew up in Denver, during the Civil Rights Movement era; attending parochial school where the Sisters bellowed the importance of integrity and measuring the variables in the discussion; to think of the consequences, before making a decision. And those lessons have been learned and put into action, many times over the years.

statement: I have been involved in public safety for over 35 years. I am committed to my community for which I have lived at the same address for thirty-five years. My commitment to this Commission would be to make sure the intentions of amendment Y and Z are respected and successfully carried out while making sure it is a fair process that represents Colorado.

My varied experience in human resources, law enforcement and now the corporate setting exposed me to the world of consensus building. Being open minded to resolve issues while respecting both the skills, interests and points of view from the people sitting across the table from me. One of my “work rules” is, if we aren’t having fun, what are we doing here, which would follow me into this working group as well.

statement:
When rank partisanship finds its way into processes that are fundamental to our democracy (as it has in other states), it undermines confidence in our institutions and in our system. The unfairness of it can cause apathy and antipathy that lead to civic disengagement and civil unrest. For all their promise, Amendments Y and Z are not the end-all of redistricting reform, but they give Coloradans a shot at a fairer, more transparent process that can help reinforce the legitimacy of our system.

With so many factors at play, “fairness” (in terms of the final map) will be difficult to define and more difficult to achieve. But in Amendments Y and Z, the citizens of Colorado have provided a set of criteria that the commission must work to faithfully balance as they evaluate and provide feedback on proposed maps. They must also work actively to identify, understand, and accommodate communities of interest. I hope to go in clear-eyed on the challenges that come with this task and ensure that we make use of the analytical methods available as we work through this difficult, but necessary, process.
professional_background:
In Colorado, I've organized, represented, and advocated for the Secular Hub--a nonprofit community center for atheists, agnostics, humanists and their families. Bringing experience from volunteer leadership positions in Texas and Arizona, I co-founded the Secular Hub's Community Service Committee, organizing a team of community members to create volunteer and fundraising opportunities and to provide support for members of our community. As the Board Chair and as a POC for outreach events, I represented the organization at public events hosted at our facility and at local festivals like the People's Fair and PrideFest. As a participant in a lobby day at the U.S. Capitol, I shared my community's concerns about pending legislation with the staff for Senator Gardner and Representative DeGette.

I’ve also encouraged increased civic participation in our community by hosting debate viewing parties, a ballot measure Q&A (with an advocate and an opponent), and a Civics lesson with former State Senator Lois Court. More recently, I invited Dr. Beth Malmskog, an assistant professor of mathematics from Colorado College, to speak on how to use mathematics to assess the fairness of proposed district maps.
org_list: Secular Hub (a community for atheists, agnostics, humanists, and other nonbelievers):  Member, 2013-present; Founder, Community Service Committee, 2014; Board Member, 2016-2018; Board Chair, 2016-2017
analytic_skills:
Early in the COVID pandemic, I actively tracked, plotted, and shared information about the spread of the disease. I derived the formula for the exponential doubling rate to track how effectively we were bending the curve and sent (unsolicited) feedback to CDPHE on discrepancies I found in their data. More recently, to answer growing skepticism and my own uncertainty about whether COVID deaths could have been overstated (conflated with other comorbidities), I sought out data on monthly deaths in the US from all causes over the last 20 years and compared them to provisional data from this year. Plotting it, I was able to convince myself and some of my skeptical friends that this year is, indeed, quite an outlier. 

An analytical approach is in my nature and it is what my internal compass compels.

When possible, I try to go straight to the source(s), using intermediaries, analysts, and pundits in a supporting role. While they all have important information to provide, they also necessarily apply their own filters in selecting, organizing, and interpreting the information they communicate. When possible, I try to identify and ask challenging questions that get at the heart of the matter; ensure that due diligence was performed; and reveal weaknesses in assumptions, methodologies, and in interpretations and results.

Both my formal education and work life (in aerospace and software engineering) have had an analytical skew. My education led me to informal studies of deductive and inductive reasoning (i.e. the reasoning of mathematical proofs and of the sciences, respectively). An interest in political discourse led to informal readings on logical fallacies, cognitive biases, and heuristics, as well as the role of nonrational processes in political persuasion. I am no mathematician, but I do have some experience with (and an interest in) statistics, which I think will come in handy for this work. A recent personality/work styles profile (that I cannot endorse, but will mention) identified “analytical” as my dominant thinking style. And I relish opportunities to use my brain in analytical ways (even in non-standard ways, like in a recent review of professional journal articles on evidence-based volunteer coordination practices).
consensus_statement:
In various leadership and non-leadership positions, I have experienced some of the challenges of working with people with deeply held and diverse viewpoints. Staying clear on our purpose and the constraints in which we are operating will be important to keep the team aligned. As I engage, I work to avoid letting my ego get in the way of progress and I try to focus on getting to the best solution (wherever and whoever it is coming from). Being forthright, modeling humility and open-mindedness (by demonstrating a willingness to be swayed by new information), and keeping a goal-orientation can go a long way in eliciting the same behavior from others.

Filter bubbles--political or otherwise--rarely lead their inhabitants to broad-based understanding, much less fairness. Unaffiliated committee members will play an important role in helping hold the committee accountable, provided those (unaffiliated) members can show that they are well-informed and focused on faithfully performing their duty.

As a demonstration of impartiality (or at least an interest in it), I am an intermittent attendee at local house district meetings for both the Republican and Democratic parties. I do that because we all have blindspots, and hearing facts, values, and framings from multiple perspectives can help reveal some of my own blindspots. It has also shown that while the issues that divide us are often amplified in the media and in our minds, when it comes to many of the issues that face us, we have a lot in common.
past_political_activity:
I vote and have made donations to causes friends are passionate about. I also attend both my Republican and Democratic house district meetings. 

Donations:  2018, $50-100, Swing Left; 7/3/2019, $100, Dr. Radhika Nath For Denver Kids

statement: I want to serve on the commission because after Amendment’s Y and Z passed in 2018 I realized I could get involved in the redistricting process even as an Independent voter. I want to be active in crafting solutions that benefit Colorado voters statewide. I consider myself a life-long learner, a good listener, a team worker and a fair person.
professional_background: My experience has been limited to my career as a public school educator. Within that role and responsibility I have organized groups of students, teachers, parents and community members for literacy programs, National Honor Society membership and initiatives, College Board activities and classes, and participation in National History Day competitions and judging.
org_list: Independent Voter, I was a member of the Denver Classroom Teachers Association prior to my retirement in 2016. A member of the Colorado Geographic Alliance and the American Library Association.
analytic_skills: In achieving my Masters in Library and Information Science from the University of Denver in 2007 I had many opportunities to apply sophisticated analysis to situations and scenarios presented as part of my course work and in my subsequent employment as a librarian. From developing authentic collections and embracing the needs of diverse patrons to budget considerations within unique tax districts, the focus on analyzing data enabled me to chart a clear path for providing relevant and productive library service for all. My ability to apply logic and reason to a problem is perhaps best illustrated by my work as a reader for the College Board’s Advanced Placement United States History exam. As a reader, our job is to read and score (according to a pre-set rubric) student’s essays answering one topic question during a seven day session that begins each day at 8am and ends at 5pm. The same question over and over, but answered by high school students from all over the country (as well as those attending international schools). We each read hundreds of essays daily by students whose skill sets vary wildly. Our goal as readers is to award the students for what they know – not punish them for what they omit or get wrong. Many times logic dictates that the student answered the prompt correctly, looking at their writing holistically, and even though there might be minor errors in their writing. Reason takes that logic by the hand and reminds us as readers that the student wrote the essay in 45 minutes, under extreme pressure and without prior knowledge of the prompt. So when we spend the two to three minutes reading and scoring each essay we embrace that reason and logic and our goal to benefit the student’s effort is realized.
consensus_statement: I will promote consensus by being patient in listening to all points of view expressed and by maintaining flexibility in my own opinions. I believe my career as a public school teacher has helped shape my skills in this regard. High School students share their thoughts and opinions about absolutely everything. An integral part of being a good teacher is listening to what they have to say without verbal or visual signs of judgement, and then working towards an answer, resolution or consideration. This skill was, and is, often tested when what is said clashes with my own ideas or realities. That is where the work gets more difficult and can be more rewarding. Often in committee meetings, parent conferences, as well as mentoring new teachers, the same patience and honest listening is needed. Especially in these challenging times, I have no doubt that building agreement with any diverse group of people will be difficult. I believe with my personal history and experience I am up to the task.
past_political_activity: My past political activity has mostly involved teaching my high school Social Studies students about local, state, national government, civic participation and the U.S. Constitution. When applicable, I have encourage my senior students to register to vote. In line with district policy, I have always presented a non-partisan view in my teaching as well as in my professional profile. As a registered Independent voter I have been fortunate and honest in regarding the issues behind ballot measures and candidates, as opposed to being influenced along party lines. I vote given every opportunity not only because it is a privilege to do so, but also because I am answerable to my students as a person of responsibility and leadership. I have not consciously donated money to any political campaign or organization. I was a member of the teacher’s union DCTA and I withheld monies from them that were being directed politically.

I prefer to take a calm look at all the parameters and try to find several possible answers to the issue.  It's also important to get feedback and input from other sources. consensus_statement: During my 33 years of teaching I had many opportunities to be involved in committees and meetings where we had to come to consensus. I have used this training in my work representing taxpayers before the IRS, in my accounting and tax work, on committees for not-for profit organizations, and everyday life.
consensus_statement:
Consensus is really about listening and not just hearing the words being spoken.  I like to repeat questions to make sure I and everyone else knows what is being asked.  I like to clear up any misconception around a question prior to debating the question.  This method actually creates mutual respect.  With mutual respect the committee can then work on consensus.  I had a job where I traveled the country giving tax seminars.  I could attend the needs of a diverse group of people (all of whom wished to be heard) in a fair and impartial way.  Call it crowd control if you will. ; but understand, the only way to fairness and impartiality is through the door of respect of each one involved. 
I believe both my training and experience have given me the ability to be fair and impartial to all concerned.

statement: I’m a fifth generation Coloradoan and I want to assure that Colorado remains strong and representative of all Coloradoans.  I was shocked and saddened how map manipulation in other states caused a distortion in their representation at the federal and state level.  I think this leads to voter disillusionment and a feeling that their votes do not matter.  One of the educational events held at my home was about Amendment Y and Z.  I have become more aware of the importance through All On The Line, which educates people about the importance of fair maps.  Voters need to pick their representatives at the federal and state level, not the other way around.
professional_background: I completed the Organizing for Action Fellows program.  As part of the program, I organized an educational event on Climate Change at a library.  I also hosted educational events at my home, like books club discussions and speakers on ballot issues as well as post card writing parties.  I also had phone banking events at my home to bring attention to events in Denver.  I also helped organize texting events.
org_list: I volunteered with Organizing for Action in December 2016.  That organization merged into All On The Line of which I am currently a member.  I have also attended events with Indivisible Front Range and Indivisible Denver. I attend my House District 6 meetings and activities when I am able.  I used to be a part of a breakfast group “Pancakes with Progressives” that hosted progressive candidates for an informal discussion around a breakfast table.
analytic_skills: My career as a human resource professional required multi-tasking, problem solving and excellent organization and communication skills.  As a HR Generalist, my job responsibilities centered on benefits and recruitment.  I was the team lead for implementing a new payroll/human resource software system. I am proficient in Microsoft office.  Retired from Human Resources, I am now in Philanthropy.  The non-profit I work stopped using their Customer Relationship Software.  I developed a spreadsheet for use in our department that can track needed data and can pull information using pivot tables.
consensus_statement:
One of my earliest memories was going to pick up my grandmother on election day, she was an election judge.  Voting has always been important in my family, but I would not have considered myself “political”. My dad was involved in town council in Pine Haven Wyoming and my aunt was mayor of Pine Knoll Shores in North Carolina.  They both leaned Republican and many in my family still are Republicans. I aligned with the Democratic Party in 2008 because I wanted to help with the convention.  As I have become more involved, I more closely align with the Democratic platform, such as health care and environmental protections than with the traditional Republican platform of less government involvement and conservative social values. With my background, I have cultivated skills that have built fairness and impartially in my core values.
I struggle with the current administration and it is my hope that after November there will be an increased desire for people to work together for the common good.  We can begin this ideal by working together locally. A couple of years ago, I attended an event at the Denver Film Society in which one of the panelists was Eleanor Clift, a Washington journalist.  She proposed that the intense political division was created in part because people did not know each other at the personal level. She mentioned that Tip O’Neill and Reagan could be friends because they created opportunities to be together after work.  With today’s politicians leaving Washington as soon as work is over and not cultivating after work relationships, the camaraderie is lost.  I will suggest that the commission meet on a non-formal basis to cultivate relationships with each other.  If the group as whole chooses not to do this, I will reach out on a one-on-one basis to build camaraderie.
past_political_activity: I have donated money to Steven Woodrow Colorado HD6, Diane Mitsch Bush CD3 and an organization called “Stop Republicans” through Act Blue.  I have also donated money to Amy McGrath for Kentucky Senate and Diana DeGette Colorado House Rep District 1.

statement: I am the daughter of an immigrant. I am Latina, I am married to a black man, and I am the mother of two children, one with special needs. For the past ten years I have advocated for under represented members of my community. I wish to continue to be a voice for people who are not often enough heard. I want to ensure a fair redistricting process to ensure an equitable future for my children.
professional_background: Although not prestigious, much of my organizational experience was obtained while I was president of the PTA. This position required me to reach out to every parent in the school in an attempt to get them involved. I was also responsible for organizing school events where I had to manage a team of volunteers. The largest PTA event I managed hosted 1,000 people. This experience was a launch pad for me to start my own non-profit called Zero Waste Services. For four years Zero Waste Services strived to increase waste diversion and recycling in Jefferson County. Our largest endeavor was to improve the recycling and composting efforts for Festival Italiano, an event that hosts 100,000 patrons each year. This required recruitment, training and management of a large team of volunteers. Currently, I work with Adelante Jeffco. This organization's mission is to provide health and educational resources to the Spanish speaking community. Through our efforts, we have been successful in providing resources to the Latino community during the Covid crisis including a food distribution center and a special bilingual Covid testing site. Politically, I have hosted and organized several fundraising campaign events for candidates ranging from City Council, all the way to U.S. Senate candidate Lorena Garcia. As a PCP, I have organized my neighbors for lit dropping campaigns as well as GOTV efforts. I have frequented many City Council meetings to offer my public comment on issues ranging from Autism, sustainability, education, and racial equity and representation.
org_list: Since 2015 I have volunteered and served for following organizations and boards: Belmar Sustainable Neighborhood (Chair of Waste and Recycling), 3RC Foundation (board secretary), South Lakewood Elementary PTA (president), Zero Waste Services (co-founder), Kendrick Lakes Elementary School PTA, Alameda Connects, Lakewood Forward (board member), Adelante Jeffco, and the Colorado Statewide Parent Organization (board member). I was recently voted onto the board of the Jeffco Public Schools Foundation. My three-year term will begin in January 2021. I am also a member of the Jefferson County Democratic Latino Initiative and a precinct chair person in HD 28.
analytic_skills: Facts are facts and numbers don't lie. My previous board experience has forced me to analyze budgets and determine organizational priorities based on numbers. My pre-2015 work experience contains project management skills which required me to assess time and budget constraints to ensure I was able to meet company deadlines. I feel comfortable I can use these skills to serve the commission well.

I get people to side with me or at least understand where I am coming from by painting a clear picture of my viewpoint. People have always gravitated to the passion I inflect when I speak. I have an ability to explain complex topics by breaking them down into digestible pieces. My moral compass is guided by the common good. This is very evident to anyone I work with, therefore there is never a question about my true intent.

occupation: Associate Director for RiversEdge West
education:
Bachelor of Arts in Environmental Studies and Recreation from Western State Colorado University 
National Association of State Park Directors State Park Leadership School Certificate from North Carolina State University
statement:
I want to serve on the commission because I have a diverse background in being an impartial and fair voice for a multitude of user groups and constituents and I believe that I could fulfill the role of a commissioner well for all of Colorado. I was a Park Ranger for Colorado Parks and Wildlife for ten years requiring me to be a certified Colorado Peace Officer and uphold the law in a nonbiased manner. I took my oath very seriously and treated all people with respect and dignity, striving to find common sense solutions to the various challenges I faced. This held true with the park management side of the job as well where I worked to address the needs of all park user groups.  I worked all over the State of Colorado, affording me the opportunity to truly get to know and appreciated the diverse makeup of our state. 

I also served as a Regional Representative for US Senator Michael Bennet, covering six counties across the western slope. I was a representative for all constituents, regardless of political background and I worked to ensure all voices were heard. I was a constituent advocate first and foremost and I came to understand the various challenges and opportunities that each individual, community and county faced. Finally, I now work for a nonprofit focused on river restoration in the west for the benefit of the multitude of communities who rely on them. I help to facilitate complex conversations with many user groups, figuring out ways to collaborate and work together to promote restoration work. 

Through all of my professional experience, I have also always found ways to become involved with the various local communities I have lived in. Civic engagement is incredibly important to me and I would truly be honored to be able to serve on a larger scale to be able to put my experience at a local and regional level to work for the benefit of the entire State of Colorado. 

Colorado is embarking on a historic process to ensure fair and equal representation in our state, paving a path for the next ten years. This is an incredibly important task so gerrymandering does not occur and all of our Congressional and Legislative districts are mapped in an impartial and fair manner. As an active citizen in the State’s democratic process, I am thrilled that Colorado is moving this forward.
professional_background:
I have been serving on the City of Fruita’s Parks and Recreation Advisory Board for several years where I have worked to represent the interests of all of the City’s constituents. Over the past year, the City has been engaged in a strategic planning process for a new master plan to direct the Parks and Recreation Department for the next ten years. The City’s demographics and socio/economic layout looks much different from 10 years ago, requiring thoughtful and critical thinking into how the City can best serve all interests. I was engaged in the hiring process for the consultant developing the plan, as well as in the potential outcomes and objectives for the plan that is currently still being developed. I have raised concerns regarding gaps in not getting citizen feedback from underserved and minority groups in the community as well as highlighting areas for improvement for people with disabilities and youth engagement. 

I have also been a youth mountain bike coach and mentor for several years, particularly for young girls. Through various after school programs, I have taught skills in confidence, team work, environmental stewardship and leadership through the sport of mountain biking, bridging lessons learned on the trail to future young adults versed in being respectful and confident.
org_list:
•	Current appointed board member for the City of Fruita Parks and Recreation Advisory Board
•	Current volunteer for Colorado State University Community Alliance Program
•	Current youth mountain bike coach/mentor for Boneshaker Adventures 
•	Connected local youth with Grand Junction City Councilmember’s student engagement program
•	Previous elected board member of the Colorado State Parks Protective Association
•	Previous member and current volunteer for the Fruita Rotary Club
analytic_skills:
I have a variety of analytical skills that I use in my current job as an Associate Director for a nonprofit. I oversee all of the programs within the organization, each of which have different staff and partners who are involved, and unique grant funding and fundraising associated with them. On a small scale, I am the project manager for all of the secured grants at any given time, requiring me to track budgets, reporting, meeting deliverables and ensuring contracting is in place and payments occur in a timely fashion. I then look beyond secured funding, working with a fundraising coordinator to strategically plan for current funding gaps and look to how to fund future needs with the direction of the programs. From an organizational perspective, I ensure that each program is running successfully and in line with the current strategic plan. Often times, I analyze budgets both short term and long term to assess sustainability and whether or not it makes sense to continue with certain program aspects or divert to other opportunities both in terms of potentially diversifying funding, and providing additional professional development opportunities for staff.

The creative analytical skills that I am able to utilize at the nonprofit has been extremely rewarding for me. I really enjoy thinking outside of the box and I am a big picture thinker. If something doesn’t make sense as to why or how we are doing something, I am not afraid to ask the difficult questions as to why and look for other solutions.  My team was having a difficult time keeping track of so many disparate grant budgets so I researched possible solutions. I organized and talked with various consultants and integrated a budget tracking system into a grant management program we were already utilizing. 

Finally, I have strong communication skills. I help guide and lead various collaborative, watershed groups throughout the southwest, from small place-based groups to large multi- state, regional collaboratives. These groups are built on consensus building and are at various stages in their lifespan- some have been around for over a decade and some are just getting started. I help staff and partners think through intended outcomes and objectives, create strong meeting agendas, and navigate discussions, helping to keep them on task.
consensus_statement:
I will promote consensus among the commissioners by first and foremost being an active listener and respecting all opinions and perspectives, while keeping the main objective in mind. Diverse ideas and experiences are truly a strength when trying to find an outcome that will serve a multitude of people in a large geographic area. As a Regional Representative for Senator Bennet, I led a serious of health care roundtables throughout the western slope. The opinions and emotions at these meetings were highly contentious and I would lay out the ground rules of being respectful and allowing anyone who wanted to speak to have the floor.  Being empathetic to individual experiences was truly key, but the follow up and asking clarifying questions so the entire group could understand where the person was coming from was even more important. Getting to the ‘why’ and talking through this allowed for civil discourse. 

As an Associate Director for a nonprofit, I oversee a group of professional staff from various backgrounds, working in various geographic areas across Colorado and Arizona. I lead large, grant development projects, where often times, staff have very different opinions on what the project components should like, who to engage and collaborate with, whether or not the project promotes the long-term strategic plan and how much risk should be taken.  I ensure that all staff are first and foremost engaged and participate in every planning discussion. I also make sure everyone has a chance to articulate their thoughts, being respectful to differing personalities and learning styles and trying to make the atmosphere comfortable. This allows me to sift through a possible project outline by treating everyone fairly, and through open dialogue, also making sure we are staying true to the intended outcome. 

Through my background in law enforcement and park management, as a representative for a US Senator and as a leader for a nonprofit organization working with a diverse group of staff, stakeholders, as well as my involvement with the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board, I have been afforded the opportunity to learn and excel in various environments as a sensible, fair and unbiased leader.
past_political_activity:
I have been an active and informed voter since I was eligible to vote.  I participated in a neighborhood canvasing project for a local school district bond and bill levy ballot measure in 2017. 

I donated to Senator Michael Bennet's Presidential Campaign in 2019.

occupation: I am a part-time self-employed consultant to non-profit organizations working in the progressive advocacy community. I help non-profits with membership, events, fundraising, and strategic planning. I am also the mom of two school-age children.
education: I have a Bachelor of Arts degree from Tulane University in Political Economy and Women’s Studies. I grew up in Aurora, CO and am a graduate of Overland High School.
statement:
We have seen what happens in other states when districts are drawn in a way to include certain voters and exclude others – and it’s a major step to erosion of democracy. We are lucky that it doesn’t have to be like that in Colorado, where we can create maps that are reflective of our communities. Fairly drawn maps are a pillar to making sure Colorado is prosperous and equitable for all who live here, not just those who live in the right district. 

I view drawing fair maps as the first part of a cycle. If districts are created fairly, then leaders who truly represent their communities will be elected. Citizens will feel their needs are being met and their lives will improve, and they will be more inclined to participate in democracy by voting and holding their elected leaders accountable. Fair maps help to eliminate the power of special interests or corporate interests.
professional_background: I consider myself an active participant in Colorado's progressive community. I have supported non-profits that register young people to vote, and that advocate for reproductive rights, among other issues. I often talk to members of my community (like fellow moms) about what's happening in Colorado and how they too can get involved in advocacy. In 2018 I hosted postcard writing parties for candidates and ballot initiatives (Great Schools, Thriving Communities). During the Denver teachers strike, I organized a fund to raise money for grocery gift cards for teachers at two neighborhood schools.
org_list: Cobalt Advocates (formerly NARAL Pro-Choice Colorado); I have served on the board since 2015.
analytic_skills: I would bring strong analytical skills to the commission, and the ability to keep an eye on the big picture as well as the small details. My strength would be identifying opportunities and challenges, communicating well with other commissioners, and being able to juggle multiple data points to come up with possible solutions.
consensus_statement: If I am chosen to work on the commission, I would work earnestly in a process of consensus decision-making, where all members are able to feel they have achieved a fair outcome. This requires active listening, understanding different viewpoints and lived experiences, and sometimes making compromises. It is in the interest of the people of Colorado for the commission to work hard to find a consensus solution and for this to be a legitimate process. I believe one of my strengths is understanding where someone else is coming from and helping to communicate that to other members of the commission. I would also seek to make sure that no one individual is dominating the process and that all voices are heard.
past_political_activity: I have been a volunteer for campaigns, including No on Proposition 115 (2020), Jason Crow and Phil Weiser (2018), and others. I have also donated to campaigns in Colorado (especially to women running for the state legislature) and at the federal level. In my role on the Board of Directors of Cobalt Advocates, I serve on the Small Donor Committee and have participated in candidate endorsements (interviews, etc).

education: Bachelor's degree in Mining Engineering and a minor in Business from Virginia Tech.  Graduated Dec 2009.
statement:
I am a moderate who agrees with certain views from each party.  However, both parties have strayed so far to the extremes that I don't feel like I have a real choice anymore, and I know there are many other people who feel the same way.  I've found in my relatively short lifetime that when two sides are very far apart, 80% of the time the best course of action is somewhere in between.  Right now, the loudest sides of both parties drown out any calls from moderates to have civil dialogue and actually create compromises.  There are many reasons why this has happened (media and social media bubbles on both sides, the current primary system weeding out moderates, etc...), but one of the primary factors is partisan gerrymandering leading to non-competitive districts.

This independent redistricting commission gives me hope that it's possible to make non-partisan districts that are truly competitive and where each citizen's vote has the same impact no matter where they reside.  I'm a firm believer in the statement "citizens should choose their representatives, not the other way around," and this commission, if run correctly, is a good step in the right direction for this state.  It's one of the few ways I've seen available for moderate citizens like me to be involved in a meaningful way, and I would be honored to be a part of this effort.  There are certainly other steps that would need to be taken to help raise the bar of dialogue, but this is a step in the right direction.
professional_background: n/a
org_list: n/a
analytic_skills: I'm an engineer by training and am very comfortable with numbers and fact-based problem solving.  I often make spreadsheets for my own use, like with analyzing real estate deals, budgeting/saving, projecting sales for a new product, and many other situations.  I use these spreadsheets and the resulting information to guide personal and business decisions, not the other way around.
consensus_statement: I would act as a check to any extremes from both parties.  My main focus would be to create districts that are fair for all citizens, regardless of party.  I've spent years managing ~30 employees at a drilling company, and I've also started my own business.  Both experiences have trained me to be patient, listen more, and then find the best and fairest solution moving forward.  There are many times when friends or family of a particular party complain about the other side, and while I may agree with their points, I'll often act as the Devil's advocate for the opposite party.  I feel very strongly that the vast majority of people are reasonable when they're not yelling or getting yelled at, and it's this kind of civil dialogue that I will help promote if I'm on the commission.

statement: I lived and voted in Texas for much of my 21 year Air Force career and witnessed first hand the ridiculous results of partisan gerrymandering in that state. Election districts should be composed of regions designed with primary consideration to geography and cultural similarities of the area not political affiliation.

statement: As mentioned above I have lived and loved life my entire 41 years in beautiful Colorado.  I have called Western Colorado home for almost all of those 41 years.  With that said I feel like Western Colorado is often left out or poorly represented when it comes some of the major decisions Colorado is faced with.  It is easy to let the larger cities and communities take the reins leaving the smaller towns and rural areas in the shadows.  Colorado has changed so much over the years with significant growth and changes in the more metropolitan areas, but we are still one state, the state of Colorado and I feel the Western Slope needs a seat at the table much more often than it is provided.
professional_background: I was born and raised in Grand Junction Colorado but i have lived my entire life all across the state.  However, I decided to settle down and raise a family back in Grand Junction.  As a result, all my civic work has been at a local level in Grand Junction.  I care deeply about Colorado and especially the growth and development of my hometown.  As a result, I was an active member of the GJ Community Center Campaign advocating for a more complete life for all Grand Junction residents. I was also a member and vocal proponent for the GJ Event Center campaign, which promoted diversifying Grand Junctions historic and limited economic development possibilities.
org_list: Appointed to the Downtown Development Authority 2009 - 2017 / Downtown Grand Junction Improvement District 2009-2017 / Grand Junction Historic Preservation Committee 2014 - 2017
analytic_skills: I graduated from Metropolitan State University of Denver with a bachelor’s degree in behavioral science, so when it comes to understanding others, working together and communication, I feel I excel. Being able to understand or acknowledge the importance of understanding where others are coming from, I think is key.  Logic reasoning is only possible when there is mutual respect, creativity and a clear dedication to the facts.
consensus_statement: I will start by saying I am a democrat living in arguably one of the most republican areas within Colorado.  I am also a small business owner and proud to be an active member of my community.  What this means is drawing lines in the sand or taking hard stances without listening to the other side, for me isn’t an option, to say I am outnumbered would be an understatement.  Being able to work together, see both sides of a problem or at least attempt to see both sides of a problem is a reality both here in rural Western Colorado but honestly should be the case no matter who you are or where you live.  I think it is so important during a time when I think most feel more divided than ever to find leaders who are willing to reach across the aisle, work towards solutions versus drawing hard lines but most of all, demonstrate common courtesy and respect for all.  This is something I am passionate about and something I know I could easily bring to the table if appointed.  I am also 1 of 8 children! So, believe me when I say, working together and working towards solutions is the only way to not only survive but prosper and grow. Nothing like being a part of a very large family to teach you, sometimes you stand your ground, sometimes you give, sometimes you compromise but no matter what you find a way to “make it work”!
past_political_activity: Local politics -Grand Junction Community Center campaign 2019 / Grand Junction Event Center campaign 2017/ Women’s Leadership Committee for John Hickenlooper for US Senate 2020

statement: For our democracy to remain strong, we have to ensure that everyone's vote—regardless of political party—counts the same.  Among other things, achieving this means getting rid of gerrymandering.  The new Commissions for Congress and the Colorado Legislature can achieve this, but only if the members of the commission are willing to draw district boundaries that are free from political considerations.  I want to help accomplish that.

consensus_statement: For the Commission to achieve consensus, the commissioners need to set aside political allegiances and vote for district boundaries that make elections fair for everyone, not just for Republicans or Democrats.  As a commissioner I would do my best to achieve that.

One vote should equal one vote not be smothered out because of any gerry mandering or wild lines drawn on a geographical map to benefit one party over another.

statement:
Having worked with diverse families as an educator, I have some insight into the social challenges faced by people who have languages, experiences, and cultures different from my own. 
Having my own children (who both have moderate special needs) and having to advocate on their behalf has increased my confidence in understanding dense legal jargon related to special education law (even moreso than when I was a teacher) and has given me insight into the struggles others face in simply trying to gain equal footing.

It's no surprise that our country is divided on many issues currently, so having the opportunity to do something cooperative and beneficial is something I don't want to miss. While I am fairly 'regular' as a white, female, middle-class mom, my experiences will lend themselves to advocating for those that don't share the same history as me. I do have some  have experience being a minority, as I am an atheist, and am comfortable dealing with the misconceptions that many people have about it. I believe that a secular perspective can be beneficial in these kind of matters.
professional_background:
During my Bachelor's degree studies I was a member of the Colorado Student Association. I represented Western State University on this board from 2000-2002, and then represented CU-Denver from 2002-2003. Additionally, I was a student trustee to the (now disbanded) State Colleges Board of Trustees in 2001-2002 for Western State University. After transferring colleges, I was a student representative for the Auraria campus Board of Trustees, representing CU-Denver from 2002-2003.

I advocated for the passage of ballot measures 4A & 4B in my neighborhood during the most recent election. I am a firm believer that schools need adequate funding to prepare students for the increasingly competitive world in which we live, and that teachers are generally underpaid and under-appreciated in our society. 
I am comfortable advocating for children with special needs and developmental delays, and often connect people I meet in passing to the appropriate services available to them in their community (i.e. community center boards, Child Find, Special Olympics Young Athletes, and social support groups).
I have also worked with volunteer groups in my community, such as Highlands Ranch Helps, and have organized donation drives to benefit Meghan's Wish Foundation (supporting kids in foster care), Together We Rise, and Aurora Warms the Night.
org_list:
Democratic National Committee member, 2016-2018
Infinity Middle School PTCO, 2019-20
Resident volunteer for Beacon Point HOA election canvas board, 2020
analytic_skills: I am a firm believer is the Socratic method of discourse, wherein you ask questions and work towards ideas and beliefs being honestly examined and evaluated. My go-to statements for children and adults alike when discussing anything are "Why?" and "Tell me more". Being a religious non-believer lends itself to valuing science & logic, learning how to dissect and reconstruct ideas, and advocating for a more fair society.
consensus_statement:
I am an individual who believes in equal representation and equal treatment. I am passionate about bringing people together in positive ways. My neighbors joke that I am the community welcome-wagon, and I strive to make people feel welcome and connected. 
I am more than comfortable questioning why things are the way they are, evaluating the evidence, and coming to a consensus that is fair. I understand that there are often differences between the letter and the spirit of the law, and am comfortable discussing the reasoning behind both sides. I always want to know where someone else is coming from, especially when we disagree. If I can understand their point of view, it widens my perspective on the world, and I hope that by understanding my point of view others walk away with broader horizons too. 
I am a staunch believer in fair, secular government and belive that no one group deserves special treatment because of their religious, cultural, or political affiliations.
past_political_activity:
Volunteered to canvas for Obama in 2012. 
Was a paid member of the DNC 2016-2018.

statement: I strongly believe the new way to redistrict on a non-political basis is extremely healthy for Colorado voting and belief in the democratic process. Peoples faith in the validity of the democratic process is enhanced if federal and state legislative boundaries are fairly drawn rather than to favor any political party. In particular, the growth of independent voters strongly suggests disapproval of party affiliation. The Commission will have an interesting difficult task in balancing the desire to maintain districts with common geographical communities of interest against the desire to see more politically competitive districts.

I was Co-Chair of the Raise the Bar Yes on Amendment 71 committee in 2016 when that Amendment was adopted. I am on the Executive Committee of Building a Better Colorado, a non-partisan business group promoting state-wide community by community analysis of major civic issues like voting, campaign finance, state budget issues like TABOR and Gallagher.

analytic_skills:
Having been a building failure investigator for 16 years most of my problem solving has a the following basic framework.
1. Investigate.  Through physical investigation, research, interviews, and testing, all information is collected around the problem at hand.
2. Evaluation.  Utilizing the data collected one or more causes of the issue and a process for resolution are developed.  solutions should be determined to not only fix the symptoms but prevent the issue from persisting.
3. Implementation.  Once a path to repair is chosen a scope of work and maintenance plan is developed and carried out. 
4.  Commissioning.  Perioding check up are scheduled to check on the effectivity of the work completed.

statement: I have been a stay at home parent for the past six years. I have enjoyed nearly every minute of my time with my children, and I am not ready to return to the work force. But I do feel like my children have reached an age where some of my time and energy can be devoted to other things that I think are important. I don't think I have any particular skills or experience that make me a perfect candidate for this commission. I'm sure there are other people who are far more qualified than I am. But I am interested in contributing to my community and my state. I'm young and energetic. I think that sometimes what is missing in politics is the voice of an average citizen, with average knowledge and average concerns. I think I could be that person on the commission. I live in Douglas County, where my neighbors mainly vote straight republican on their ballots. I have voted for both parties on the same ballot, and some days that makes me feel like "the most liberal person in Highlands Ranch." I feel like the people in the middle sometimes have their voices drowned out by the louder voices on the edges. I would like to be a voice for the moderates of both parties on this commission.
professional_background: None
org_list: None
analytic_skills: I have an accounting background and have worked with medium and small size businesses. I often think of most political issues from an economic perspective. Often questions are presented as "what is the cost of acting now?" But I think some people forget to ask "what is the cost of waiting?" Addressing the cause and effect of all possible choices, made or not made, is a skill that I would bring to the commission.
consensus_statement: I believe in all relationships, both personal and professional, it is vital to recognize when to stand your ground and when to pick your battles. The most important aspect of compromise is clear and effective communication to get to the heart of the issue for each individual on the commission. I will contribute to creating agreement among commissioners by continuing to discuss what's important to all parties until we are able to find a middle ground on issues.
past_political_activity: No political activity or campaign donations

I have also spent a fair amount of time in several different periods looking at the re-establishment of county boundaries, specifically the boundary between Pitkin and Eagle Counties which unfortunately does not follow logical geographic and physical boundaries, but is instead a straight line, resulting in fairly large disasociation of a portion of the voting populace from the seat of county government.

statement: I have been a Colorado resident since 1973, and I have traveled throughout the state exploring trails, peaks, campgrounds, hot springs, skiing, biking, driving tours, lakes and rivers.  I have also been driven to explore areas in reading books about Colorado history and how important it is to know how history can shape our present and future. Through all these different lenses I have seen many changes both good and bad.  My jobs, personal projects and volunteer efforts have been focused mostly on customer service and have  involved strong listening and analytical skills to produce a workable solution.  I care very much about contributing to a process that will result in a balanced, healthy, and sustainable Colorado for all its inhabitants and environment.
professional_background: Prior to 2015, I served on  four different non-partisan boards (Eagle Valley Humane Society, Eagle County Crime Stoppers, Vail Recreation District, and Western Pack Burro Association). I was a member and officer for three out of four.  I organized meetings, annual events, fundraisers and volunteers. I also advocated for victims of crime and represented constituents.  As an officer and a board member I was also responsible for an outcome that would take many ideas and opinions into consideration for the benefit of the community.

Virtual Legislative Volunteer for Representative Millie Hamner, May-January, interim sessions 2013-2018
Virtual Social Media Volunteer-2015-2019 Western Pack Burro Association
analytic_skills: I have a degree in Geography, which has taught me how to analyze the human/environment interaction through past, present and future.  The knowledge I gained from that has influenced my jobs, volunteer work and hobbies since then. My paralegal education helped me to understand legal issues and their applications. Serving on four different Boards of Directors has given me well-rounded experience with a broad range populations and situations.  Being able to consider different points of view and apply to a common goal has been essential for success. All of this has given me skills and experience to adapt and succeed in finding solutions to situations that presented challenges.  The new gymnastics center in Vail is the best example of how I was able to participate as a citizen and then a board member to bring about change and introduce a progressive eight years to Vail’s recreation community.
consensus_statement: My work on four non-partisan boards that represent law enforcement, animal welfare, recreation, sports and balancing the needs of the members and their constituents. Through considering a wide range of opinions and balancing the needs and goals of different communities, we were able to achieve one shared goal: partnerships.  Victim Services based out of a law enforcement agency in Eagle County was new and I had to fund my job through a grant at first.  It eventually became a funded position through the Eagle County Sheriff’s Office (ECSO).  I formed partnerships with existing victim advocate groups and worked with other law enforcement agencies to incorporate how each agency could help. The new gymnastics center involved finding land and funding to relocate since the existing space was being used by Eagle River Water & Sanitation District (ERWSD) for a planned expansion.  Discussions involved the Town of Vail, ERWSD, Vail Recreation District (VRD) and Eagle County School District.  New partnerships and funding mechanisms were formed and the facility was built next to Red Sandstone Elementary School in Vail.  This project resulted in the VRD board moving on from this project and learning how to form other new partnerships with Vail Ski & Snowboard Academy and other recreation districts in the valley to share our field spaces for tournaments and training. Since the Vail Valley has limited space for field sports this was essential to keep and grow recreational programs for the entire valley. The new animal shelter was a new partnership with Eagle County Animal Control that was necessary since neither the Eagle County Humane Society or Animal Control could afford to build a shelter without help. These two projects were very successful, and they benefit these communities today.  I have learned through my jobs and volunteer work that different opinions can produce sustainable and productive results.

education:
Yale University, BA in Political Science; 
Cornell University Law School, JD
statement: Since college, where I majored in Political Science, I have been interested in the process and effects of redistricting.  Current political polarization requires a thoughtful approach to redistricting to ensure that all Coloradans' voices are heard.
professional_background: I have served on the boards of trustees of two schools, a community center, and two cultural organizations.  During my board service I have learned to listen to concerns and build consensus among board members with divergent viewpoints.  I would draw upon my training as a lawyer and community volunteer to apply those skills to disagreements among the commissioners.
org_list: Since 2015 I have served as President and Board Member of Friends of Chamber Music, and in a volunteer position as Juvenile Justice Investigator for the ACLU of Colorado.  During the 2020 General Election I served as the Election Judge Supervisor at the Blair Caldwell Library Voter Service and Polling Center.
analytic_skills: Lawyers are trained to examine information and identify the relevant facts and issues.  I know how to analyze facts to identify what is relevant, how to synthesize arguments, and how to explain my conclusions clearly.
consensus_statement:
I will promote consensus by looking for areas of agreement among the commissioners and seeking ways to expand those areas.  Where agreement is elusive, demonstrating that one has heard and understood different points of view is an effective method of reaching consensus.  As a lawyer, I understand that the best results come in cases where both my client and the opposing party feel their arguments have been heard and understood.  As a U.S. Peace Corps Volunteer in the 1990's, my job was to encourage environmental reforms in a coal mining region of the Czech Republic.  Finding common ground between environmental NGO's and mining interests required tact, diplomacy, and a sense of shared purpose.

I respect others' life experience and point of view, and have actively engaged in interactions with those whose political opinions differ from my own.  I am confident that, from both a professional and personal point of view, I am able to be fair and impartial.  Perhaps most importantly, I am able to express myself diplomatically.
past_political_activity: I participated in a voter registration drive in Denver in 2008, canvassed for Hillary Clinton in 2016, and have (with my husband) occasionally given small donations to Democratic candidates and the Democratic Party.  Since 2015, I have donated $100 or less to the campaigns of Chris Hansen, John Hickenlooper, and Joe Biden.

occupation: I am a landscape architect, but I am not currently employed beyond looking after a toddler.
education: My highest level of education is a Master of Landscape Architecture from the University of Melbourne in Australia. My undergraduate degree is a Bachelor of Arts with majors in Russian Language and Arabic Literature and Language from the University of Sydney also in Australia. I also studied at the University of British Columbia for one year at the bachelor level. I studied abroad during my bachelor’s at Moscow State University in Russia and Notre Dame University in Beirut, Lebanon. I have also taken several classes at the Denver Botanical Gardens for botanical illustration. I hope to one day complete the full botanical illustration degree.
statement: I have wanted to contribute to the democratic process with my renewed admiration for democracy since returning to the US. I am specifically interested in serving on the commission, because the issue of redistricting has become so controversial nationally. I feel this community-generated commission is a genuine opportunity to change that narrative and move away from a non-productive, hyper partisan country. I also see great potential for this commission to become best practice nation-wide. I believe that this century will present unimaginable challenges and the current atmosphere in the country is toxic and will debilitate us a nation to respond to these challenges, unless we decrease the partisanship. We need to rebuild trust in community, institutions, and professionalism. I also don’t believe the level of partisanship within this country is inevitable, as I do not think that I have experienced such deep partisanship in other countries that I have lived. Finally, I believe I have useful qualifications for this position. Since returning to the US, I have wanted to contribute to the democratic process with my renewed admiration for democracy. I feel this would be an ideal avenue for this Since returning to Colorado, I have been actively trying to increase my personal engage with democracy, which I do not take for granted, having lived in Russia and Ethiopia. Therefore, I try to make phone calls and write letters whenever I hear of potential legislation or issues that I believe need to be changed. Within the past half year, I have become increasingly focused on work with Canada Geese Protection Colorado. It has been fascinating to witness how with continual perseverance, change is starting to happen. The group is now allowed to attend biweekly meetings, which ensures increased transparency. Denver Parks and Recreation has agreed for us to help set up a task force, which I will probably be a member of, regarding this issue. They have also said that there will probably be no further culling next year. I have learned that change needs persistence and governmental systems need to be understood to be effective. contribution.
professional_background: Since returning to Colorado, I have been actively trying to increase my personal engage with democracy, which I do not take for granted, having lived in Russia and Ethiopia. Therefore, I try to make phone calls and write letters whenever I hear of potential legislation or issues that I believe need to be changed. Within the past half year, I have become increasingly focused on work with Canada Geese Protection Colorado. It has been fascinating to witness how with continual perseverance, change is starting to happen. The group is now allowed to attend biweekly meetings, which ensures increased transparency. Denver Parks and Recreation has agreed for us to help set up a task force, which I will probably be a member of, regarding this issue. They have also said that there will probably be no further culling next year. I have learned that change needs persistence and governmental systems need to be understood to be effective.
org_list: I am an active member of Canada Geese Protection Colorado. I am also a founding member of an internet group called Ethiopian Architecture and Urbanism. I was in the Chair of Landscape Architecture at the Ethiopian Institute of Architecture, Building Construction, and City Development. There, I wrote the curriculum, launched, and lectured in the first degree for landscape architecture within Ethiopia.
analytic_skills: I believe that by having a master’s I have demonstrated a commitment and ability to apply logic and reason to a problem. While I worked at the Ethiopian Institute of Architecture, Building Construction and City Development, I received the highest student feedback of any academic staff of which there were over 200, which testified to my commitment to my position, which was fundamentally about teaching students how to apply logic and reason to their own work. In Melbourne, I worked as a consultant for the City of Melbourne doing community engagement. Through this work, I learned that people are generally rather reasonable with their beliefs and issues. However, it takes listening with an open heart to understand their issues. This experience gave me direct experience with community engagement and consensus building. My background in landscape architecture will be directly relevant to this position. I use GIS and CAD and have made many maps within my professional life at different scales. I have analyzed and generated large watershed-scale areas as well as microclimates on a smaller scale. I have generated maps based on several specific parameters and then generated other maps with different, but similar, parameters and compared them. This experience has given me intimate exposure on how maps can be manipulated and the importance human generated lines can hold. Inherent to a landscape architecture education and the profession is the overlap it has with city planning. Therefore, I think this will also contribute to my ability to understand population dynamics. I have published several academic works, such as a conference paper and two book chapters. Such publications were all written in connection with various universities spanning three continents. In addition, in my personal life I enjoy continued learning.
consensus_statement: I have spent nearly the entirety of my adult life living, studying, and working amongst different cultures and people often with opposing beliefs and values. I feel that the most important aspects to understanding and appreciating a culture or person different from you is deep listening and being open to what is being said. Therefore, I would use this same approach when beginning to promote consensus amongst the commissioners. However, as the process proceeds, the position I form will be based upon facts. Therefore, I would not approach this task with the aim of trying to convince others about my beliefs or political views, but rather about the facts and what they indicate. Therefore, responding to the facts would be the basis of my position and would be the means I use to attempt to convince others of my position. In addition, I do not think it will be possible to achieve a ‘perfect’ outcome with complete consensus with everyone. Therefore, compromise will be essential to how I approach challenges and situations and ultimately a fair result. My own family composition attests to an ability to compromise and thrive with difference. My husband is Ethiopian and we have different religious, cultural, ethnic and historic experiences, yet we have been happily married for over five years with a beautiful son. Beyond the belief that fair redistricting will also help to rebuild trust within communities and lessen the toxic partisanship of our nation, I feel that my background in academia and research will help me be fair and impartial.
past_political_activity: I am politically active, but not in an official capacity. I have voted in every election since being of age. I donated to several democratic campaigns in the past year, including: Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and most recently to the Democrats in Georgia to help flip the Senate. Before this year, I do not believe that I have donated to other political campaigns. I often write letters and call political leaders when there is legislation to be decided and I want my voice heard regarding that legislation. I have been doing this for years, including while I lived abroad. Lately, I have been regularly active in campaigning to end the culling of geese and for more transparency in the city of Denver. Through this process, I have become more aware of how the City Council, Denver Parks and Recreation, and the Mayor’s office operate. Together with other advocates, we are working to set up a community science group to watch the lakes and learn more about the geese. While living in Moscow, Russia, I volunteered with an organization that helps forced migrants and refugees, where I taught English on a weekly basis. I later started volunteer translating for the European Court for Human Rights. For this position I would translate legal documents from Russian into English that would be presented to the Court. The vast majority of these cases were against the Russian Federation.

consensus_statement: Finding common ground is essential to developing districts that share economies, interests, and demographics. Using and agreeing upon factual data is the first step to finding consensus. Most importantly, listen other opinions to identify agreed-upon and shared views, then build from those positions of agreements.
