occupation: Professor of Biology, Colorado State University Pueblo
education: PhD in Biology (March 1991) from University of Georgia (USA); Master's degree in Agronomy (August 1987) from University of Georgia (USA); BS in Agricultural Engineering (1979) from Institut Polytechnique Rural de Katibougou (Mali); Certificate in Economic Development (March 1996) from University of California Riverside (USA); Certificate in Mediation (March 2012) from Colorado State University (USA).
statement: As proud Coloradan, I feel a strong sense of responsibility to uphold democracy in this state. Unfair district maps are a threat to democracy, because they could cause people to lose confidence in their votes, and/or not vote at all. The upcoming redistricting process based on the 2020 Census should ensure that a politician knows and engages his/her constituents and cannot just rely on his/her base to secure (re-)election. Constituents with common interest should be able to have common representation. I teach at Colorado State University Pueblo, live in Colorado Springs, and have friends all over the state. I would like to see Colorado be a national leader in development of fair and equitable apportioning congressional districts, leading to elections that reflect the will of the people, and thus strengthening trust in our democratic system.
professional_background:
I have been Professor of Biology at Colorado State University Pueblo (CSU Pueblo) for over 25 years and was recently chair of Biology department for three years. Before moving to Colorado I was Director of a research center in Mali. My managerial background also includes being Director of the Master in Biology program at CSU Pueblo for seven years. The outside collaboration with research scientists at other institutions in US helped me approach teaching and critical thinking from a broader perspective. I chaired and/or served on several committees at CSU Pueblo, including faculty senate committees and the University Board on Diversity and Equality. I conducted several community outreach research projects, working with stakeholders and thus gaining experience about how to effectively seek and capitalize on community input. Serving professional organizations at the local, regional, national and international levels also improved my personal skills in working with people from different backgrounds and reaching agreement. 

Among others, I received the CSU Pueblo’s Award for Outstanding Scholarship, the CSU Pueblo’s Award for Outstanding Service, the CSU Pueblo’s College of STEM Outstanding faculty member Award, and was inducted into Who’s Who Among America’s Teachers for Excellence in Teaching. I have published extensively and have been technical reviewer for several agencies and international journals. I conducted consultancies to several international agencies. A recent community outreach research project in my lab, which involved participation of stakeholders, was instrumental in putting Pueblo, Colorado on the EPA Superfund National Priority List due to high concentrations of hazardous heavy metals in topsoil in areas of the city, leading to current cleanup in these parts of Pueblo to protect public health. I am a Certified Mediator and I served as University Grievance Officer at CSU Pueblo for five years; this experience will benefit the commission when it comes to consensus decision making.
org_list: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). I am member of Pueblo NAACP. The mission of NAACP is “… to secure the political, educational, social, and economic equality of rights in order to eliminate race-based discrimination and ensure the health and well-being of all persons.” Pueblo African American Concern Organization (PAACO): I was President of PAACO for three years. Our mission was to raise scholarships for needy Pueblo, Colorado college students, regardless of ethnic backgrounds or other considerations.
analytic_skills: Having been a college professor for over 25 years at Colorado State University Pueblo, with extensive research experience (I published over 50 scientific articles), I use the scientific method and statistical analysis, and I teach students how to use critical thinking when it comes to solving problems. While department chair and chair of various committees at Colorado State University Pueblo, I have skillfully worked with students, staff and faculty to solve complicated problems. As redistricting commissioners, it is essential that we address the following when we establish working ground rules: What is our primary function as apportioning congressional commission, a process that will impact Colorado for the next 10 years? What are the legal requirements? What are the strengths and weaknesses of current congressional maps? How do we plan to address the issues identified in order to achieve adequate representation of all the different stakeholders in our society, in a mutually respectful environment? How do we listen to one another first with an open mind before formulating our stands? How do we reasonably agree to disagree? What do we agree or disagree with, and why or why not? How do we overcome our biases (because these exist) and navigate this contentions territory? How do we productively capitalize on the expertise of staff and on data made available to the commission? How do we carefully read and analyze pertinent information, including 2020 Census data and computer modeling to reach conclusions based on data and evidence? How do we assign specific tasks to individual commissioners? How do we reach a practical compromise? Most importantly, how does the commission effectively solicit and receive public input in order for voters to actively participate in the process and help develop fair maps that are not skewed to favor a particular party or interest group, and that are best for Colorado as a whole?
consensus_statement: Voters will not trust the redistricting commission’s work unless there is fairness and impartiality, regardless of the personal differences and various perspectives of the commissioners. As a Certified Mediator who was University Grievance Officer for five years, I understand the importance of practical compromise in consensus decision making. As Research Center Director, Chair of the Biology Department at Colorado State University Pueblo (largest department on campus), and chair of various University committees, including the University Board on Diversity and Equality, I have always listened to others first and tried to understand them, before making my point. The commissioner needs to effectively examine the situation from all angles and from all people’s perspectives, even when issues become contentious, in order to reach agreement. The redistricting process must yield a group decision; consequently, the input of every commissioner must be seriously valued.
past_political_activity: No partisanship contributions to political campaigns or organization since November 10, 2015.

occupation: Instructor of Political Science, University of Colorado Boulder
education: AB Social Welfare University of California Berkeley; MA Political Science University of Arizona; PhD Political Science Harvard University
statement: There are two basic reasons guiding my interest:  First, I strongly support the interest of fair representation.  Among other things, this means that district lines are not written in such a way to ensure a particular outcome, but rather that citizens in each district are given real choice with candidates that attend to the needs and interests of the population.  Second, I am a strong believer in shared community responsibility.  While it is easy to criticize the decisions of others, we often forget how difficult it is to shoulder the decisions.  I offer my time and effort to share that responsibility.
professional_background: I have concentrated my efforts on addressing environmental issues and community support.  These are issues I take a hands-on approach to through my volunteer activities and then focus on through my classes (regularly teaching an upper division course at CU Boulder focused on environmental policy, for example)
org_list: Boulder Rotary Club; American Red Cross (Boulder-Broomfield Chapter, Disaster Action Team); Institute for Environmental Solutions (steering committee for CO community projects, 2014-present); Global Greengrants (pro bono researcher, 2017-2019); Eco-Cycle (pro bono research associate, 2016-2017); Wild Foundation (pro bono project coordinator, 2015); Colorado Alliance for Environmental Educators; North American Association for Environmental Educators; Community Food Share (weekly volunteer in food distribution, 2015-2018)
analytic_skills: I am well-steeped in a variety of analytical methods, from quantitative to qualitative analysis, and seek the best available data to build understanding.  Not all social phenomena are measurable or accepted as valid, and thus I am also very much attuned to how ideas are communicated, sometimes very intentionally designed to divide.  I have also paid attention to the details of redistricting (legal rules, political manuevering, technology aids in achieving politically-favored results, etc.).  While I cannot claim expertise in mapping, I am an analytical thinker and balanced thinker who can spot bias.
consensus_statement:
Being even-handed and building consensus are critical practices in my teaching and community service.  I seek to identify needs and shared interests in building towards agreement -- moving away from hard positions to language that fosters a commitment to supporting our common ground.  I have long used the negotiation principles and practices developed in the book "Getting to Yes."  
In terms of my ability to be fair or impartial, these are practices critical in any effective community activity or in the teaching environment, and most particularly in the contemporary political science class. I communicate to students at the outset that we should expect disagreement and this is partly due to our different sets of life experiences.  Furthermore, none of us has a lock on "the truth," and instead it is the collective set of perspectives that will help us to identify our common reality and get us closer to "the truth."  This is akin to the traditional Indian parable, "the blind men and the elephant."  With this at the foundation, I am committed to not only giving fair and equal voice to competing perspectives, but also asking individuals to "step into the shoes of the other" as we consider why we might disagree.  I favor coming to the middle rather than than win-lose outcomes.
past_political_activity: As an academic focused on American politics, I am an avid observer of politics, including of redistricting politics.  I regularly teach undergraduates on issues of American politics, including on the US Congress, and oversee students engaged in political and campaign-related internships (for all political parties and a wide range of candidates at local, state and national levels). I am a regular voter, participated in some nonpartisan get-out-the-vote efforts in 2016, and have been a nominal financial contributor (a small donation to Joe Neguse's District 2 campaign (2019); small donations to state Senate candidate Sally Boccella (2020).

occupation: Retired.  (see attached resume for previous careers)
education: Masters in Computer Information Systems, Masters in Landscape Architecture and Urban Design, BA in Geology, Health Coach Certification
statement: I believe that Coloradans should be represented fairly as possible and I will be a strong advocate for that as demonstrated by my volunteer effort with the Tablerock HOA. An independent team to perform redistricting is a great step in the right direction for true representation of the people of Colorado. I would be honored to work with a team of people to achieve that goal in a bipartisan manner!
professional_background:
Our HOA covenants was set up unfairly such that more than 1/2 of the community was paying more for HOA fees than others and the disparity was growing every time HOA fees were raised because of a covenant rule that stated a portion of the neighborhood was required to pay 1.5 times more than the other portion. The fees are used for maintenance of amenities in the community to which all households have equal access.  I lead the committee to research (with the help of a couple of board members) how we could change the covenants and educate the community on how the fees were used for amenities shared across the community. We learned that we would have to have an election to add an amendment to remove the 1.5 times rule. 

I sent out polls for the community to vote on preferred methods of equalizing the fees. Although this seemed like an insurmountable task, the poll indicated that 18 or 19 of the homeowners who were paying less would vote for the change to the covenants and increase their fees.  This was an indication that the task was not insurmountable and we proceeded with community meetings and presentations which I put together. Two board members and I presented the information.  An election was held and the committee and I canvassed the neighborhood to make sure everyone was aware of the amendment and voted.  All of the 153 households that were currently paying more needed to vote to pass the amendment since the margin was going to be so slim. This was a harder task than it would seem, since some of these homes were rented and/or the owners were hard to reach, or they were in the process of moving.  In addition, 20 households that were paying less were needed to vote for the amendment and increase their fees. 22 (2 more than the 20 needed) neighbors voted for the amendment and raising their fees, while 100% of the homes who had been paying more voted in approval of equalizing fees.  We are now in the 3rd year of our HOA fees being equalized across the entire Tablerock neighborhood and the contentious issue has been solved.
org_list: Volunteered for Tablerock HOA as a committee member and Lead to equalize HOA fees in our neighborhood. Poll watcher in primary 2020.  Participated in RLA for Jeffco elections after the primary 2020. I have volunteered to be an Election Judge in the general election.
analytic_skills:
My original and main career was in Computer Science as a software developer in Java and C/C++.  I worked as a team lead and applications architect for developing banking, financial, reporting, and project management software.  (see attached resume for details). Software teams are often comprised of intelligent, strong-willed individuals.  I ran design and code reviews and was able to facilitate buy-in to best approaches based on requirements and goals. 

I have an MS in Landscape Architecture and Urban design which required a great deal of analytical work in mapping and design where I used Adobe software such as Illustrator, InDesign, Photoshop, and CAD to represent design proposals to a jury of faculty. 

With my HOA committee team and a couple of board members were were able to resolve a contentious issue that had existed since our community's inception (around 12 years).  Nobody thought we’d be successful but we were! This involved some neighbors voting to pay more in fees until theirs were equal to what other neighbors had been paying (as detailed above in the volunteer experience section above).
consensus_statement:
It comes down to keeping the goals and requirements impartially in mind, communicating them, listening, and compromising where possible.

As a poll watcher, I impartially looked for inconsistencies and areas of weakness in the election system.  I worked well in a bipartisan team during the Risk Limiting Audit (RLA) of the primary election.  I was a team lead and applications architect for developing software.  In my software career, I worked successfully with intelligent co-workers to resolve and compromise on design issues.  
I and the rest of the HOA team was able to convince people that were paying less in HOA fees to see that it wasn't right that some people were paying more for the same amenities. I was also able to communicate effectively with people that were upset over changing HOA fee covenant rules by listening, discussion, and outreach via presenting researched information, and holding Q&A sessions.  One of the more valuable skills of being a health coach is listening and supporting a client in their goals.  It often comes back to establishing clear goals and providing support to reach them.
past_political_activity: I was a poll watcher for the 2020 Jeffco primary elections and donated to Dan Rosier, Joni for Jeffco, Trump, Cory Gardner and other conservative candidates.

statement: As an unaffiliated voter in Colorado, I have found limited opportunities to be involved in politics beyond simply voting. I believe that the legislative redistricting commission has an amazing opportunity to ensure that Colorado's legislative districts serve as an honest reflection of those who live in them, without the partisan gerrymandering we've seen over so many years. I would be extremely honored to be entrusted with a role on the legislative re-districting Commission and believe its work will have a lasting impact on the State - for the better.
professional_background: I think the only the only applicable experience I have to this question is my experience with CASTA - the Colorado Association of Transit Agencies. As president of the Board of Directors of CASTA, I helped represent and advocate for literally every transit agency in the State. As a Board member, I have worked hard to ensure that the voice of every member agency of CASTA was represented in Board discussions and outside lobbying efforts. Its not always easy to maintain a balanced viewpoint that represented interests from all across the State but I think we do a pretty good job at CASTA. I think the fact that I have been elected to the CASTA Board for two terms now illustrates that my peers and colleagues from around the state (those who elect members of the Board) trust my intent, judgement, and ability to lead.

analytic_skills: As an urban planner with a background in systems engineering, I am a data driven decision maker. That's not to say that I'm blind to community values and motivations, or that I'm not politically savvy - because I am. As the Executive Director of one of Colorado's six regional transportation authorities, all of my decisions and recommendations are transparent, based in logic, and made with the best interests of the communities I serve in mind. I think this mindset and skillset will serve me well if I am fortunate enough to be appointed to this Commission.
consensus_statement: As an unafilliated voter, I see the pluses (and negatives) of both sides of our traditional political "aisle". As an executive leader with a proven track record working in the public sector with and on behalf of varied communities, I am always striving for consensus and agreement in difficult conversations. This can only be done by being fair and impartial - even in difficult or stressful conversations. I have found (for better or worse - and not always to my pleasure) that I am a natural leader when it comes to pulling groups together to develop mutually beneficial solutions. This has been confirmed by some work over the years with professional coaches and assessments such as Hogan Lead and Hogan Challenge - I'd be happy to share the results of those assessments if anyone wanted to see them. How do I do it? I'm just myself - no bull. I'm also a pretty nice guy who people respect and want to work with - even if they need to give a little. I am always looking for the win-win and my track records supports this.
past_political_activity: I have never ran for any public office, volunteered for any campaign, participated in any party caucus, or donated to any political campaign.

occupation: Self-Employed
education: BS in Engineering with Political Science double major.  MA Political Science.  Airline Transport Pilot.
statement:
Having worked to pass these amendments, I know they can only succeed if non-partisans continue that work.  This is one of life’s ‘If not now, when?  If not me, who?’ moments.  I mean that, really.

I earned two political science degrees and taught American Government to future military officers.  That officer corps has a well-earned reputation for being the most trusted, least partisan group in our nation.  That’s how I taught as well; non-partisan.  The students still didn't know my political views at the end of the semester.  That open minded approach attracted me to Y & Z.  It’s also why I’ve been a member of both major political parties at various times in the distant past but have been unaffiliated for many years.

This commission’s goal of ending gerrymandering in Colorado is critical to our democracy and will be a model for our republic.  That’s well worth doing; it’s well worth a citizen’s time and effort.
professional_background:
Volunteer in the effort to pass Y & Z.

My other perhaps relevant efforts are all local, such as organizing volunteers to teach character and ethics at a university, organizing neighbors to mitigate against wildfire risks, and organizing neighbors to join the county approval process for a local commercial development.
analytic_skills:
I am far more analytical than emotional.  It’s kept me alive in aviation, an unforgiving profession.  I also taught data analysis and forecasting to professional analysts in my small business.  And I have three US patents with a few more unsuccessful applications.  Patents require initiative and insight as well as analysis.

Building on that experience, my business partner and I created a method to measure group cultures empirically and despite the resistance, fear, delusion, etc. that often invalidates surveys.  That’s a current and concrete example of applying data analysis to human issues.

All of that means I see patterns in data and impartially follow them to their logical conclusion.
consensus_statement:
I have an acute sense of fairness.  I support the underdog and resist bullies.  At the most basic level, that’s why Americans with much talent and many options choose to serve our nation in various military and civilian capacities rather than follow easier, more lucrative paths.

I’ve also been a partner in a small data analysis firm, following facts where they led.  That background is certainly relevant to demographics, census data, affiliations such as minority groups, etc.

I believe such experience and qualities will be common among the commissioners and so will contribute to consensus, or at least agreement, that meets the commission’s charter and Coloradans’ intent.
past_political_activity: I volunteered on two presidential campaigns and two congressional campaigns, all in Colorado and for both Democrat and Republican candidates.  The last of those was in 2010.  I have not donated money to any campaign or political organization since November 2015.

other_names: Sarah Elizabeth Erickson, Sarah Piersky, Sarah Elizabeth Piersky
occupation: Occupational Health Registered Nurse-Children's Hospital Colorado
education: I have my bachelors degree in nursing and am currently a licensed registered nurse working at Children's Hospital Colorado. I have previously worked in the ICU at the Denver VA Medical Center, as a hospice case manager, and in a sexual health clinic. I am currently enrolled in my masters degree in nursing with a focus in healthcare policy through Chamberlain University.
statement: Over the past two years, I have been re-evaluating my professional career and thinking about how I want to best utilize my skills as a nurse. I have become very interested in the political process and the intersection of how healthcare and policy can ensure more people have access to high quality healthcare. I am currently working on my masters in nursing with a focus on healthcare policy and want to work at a state or federal level to advise, research and craft policy that makes our healthcare system more efficient, effective, accessible, affordable and equitable. Serving on the commission would be a perfect introduction into learning how individuals and communities engage with government and the civic process, and would allow me to use my voice to advocate for those who are unable to advocate for themselves.
professional_background: As a nurse whose career has spanned age, race, economic, religious and sexual identity demographics, I have become passionate about using my voice to advocate for those whose voices are often overlooked. Since 2015, I have volunteered with Hope House Colorado, a nonprofit organization that provides educational and financial assistance to teenage mothers that come from generational poverty. In the past five years, I have created several educational opportunities to allow the teens to learn more about their bodies and safe sexual practices, while also occasionally being a professional mentor to young women who have expressed interest in pursuing careers in the healthcare field. I am additionally involved with Cobalt, which raises awareness and supports policies at a state and federal level that protect women's access to reproductive healthcare.
org_list: I volunteer with Hope House Colorado as the volunteer nurse educator. I have also previously been involved with National Nurses United, a nursing union that I was a member of when I worked at the Denver VA Medical Center.
analytic_skills: Many times throughout my career, I have had to draw on logic and reason to solve a problem. Frequently in my time as an ICU nurse, I would need to utilize critical thinking and applied logic to determine why my patient was declining quickly, which involved referencing their medical chart, looking over previous lab values and anticipating what the provider might order to help resolve the patient's problems. In my current role managing calls from employees regarding COVID, I must use algorithms and policies to determine who needs to be tested for COVID and who is safe to return to work without potentially infecting other employees. I utilize logic and reason every day in my job as a nurse and as a masters student, and will bring that same level of commitment to the commission as well.
consensus_statement: As a nurse, it is my responsibility to take medically complex information given by providers to give patients and their families the necessary information to make the best decisions for their care. Additionally, I take the expressed wishes of patient and their families about their goals of care and advocate for their needs to their medical team. A significant component of my job is creating consensus among many groups of people with often very differing views. As nursing is the intersection of science and caring, I am able to use both appeals to emotion and appeals to reason to bring people together towards a common goal. Nursing requires fairness and impartiality, as my job is to care for my patients and advocate for their expressed goals rather than applying my thoughts, feelings or opinions to their care. I will use all of the skills and knowledge I have generated as a nurse to promote consensus, agreement, fairness and impartiality on the commission.
past_political_activity: I have only recently become involved with politics and civic engagement. I have not volunteered for any political campaigns or organizations yet, but have donated money. These are some of the political organizations/campaigns I have donated money to: Human Rights Campaign, Planned Parenthood of the Rocky Mountains, Blue Revolution 2020, Cobalt, John Hickenlooper for Senate, Joe Biden for President, ActBlue.

statement: I believe that there is work to be done to serve our families and our communities.  I believe that the success of our democracy depends on our ability as citizens to continue to build a society in which the rights many of us take for granted are secured for all of our people, and all of our children - regardless of race, ability, gender/sexual orientation, economic background, education, or cultural and linguistic background.  I also believe that it is essential for us to find common ground amidst the current divisive political climate, if we are to serve the future of our democracy.

consensus_statement: I believe that it is essential to begin our work together from a position of shared humanity.  There are similarities we all share - families, life cycles, neighborhoods, emotions like hope and fear, the communities we've built, the lands we roam.  My husband and my best friend do not share my political affiliation, and yet I know we share values.  I work hard to understand their positions, to find common ground, and to accept our different view points with grace, compassion, and respect - and I politely insist that they treat me with the same consideration.

occupation: I am a public health research scientist employed by Denver Health and Hospital Authority. I study drug abuse on the national stage.
education: I hold a doctorate from the University of Denver in biophysics.  I've been formally trained in statistics and the hard sciences. My career since school has been as a researcher in public health studying drug abuse across the nation. Relevant to this application, I'm an expert in statistics, demography, and spatial mapping. More broadly, I'm also an expert in epidemiology, research study design, and technical writing.
statement: I believe districting must be scientifically based so that votes from citizens best represent the will of the people. Modern statistical and GIS should be employed so that demography and geography are leveraged for the representation of the people. Independence of the commission is of utmost value, so that partisan influence is minimized. Colorado's split demographic among Republicans, Democrats, and Unaffiliated is an ideal design for the commission.  I wish to represent the unaffiliated voter, since my political outlook is one that a centrist attitude, not skewed toward one party or another. I believe my background has the right technical skills, but since I am not politically active, I would fit the criteria for an unaffiliated member of the commission.
professional_background: I have not represented or organized for any political organization.  I have experience participating in scientific societies as advocate for students and presenting my scientific work.
org_list: I'm currently a member of the American Statistical Association. Prior to this, I was a member of the American Chemical Society for 8 years.  I am not a part of any political organization.
analytic_skills: As a PhD scientist, on a daily basis, I employ complex statistical analytics to solve scientific problems (as demonstrated in my published scientific work). Before a solution is discovered, we must correctly frame a problem and the goals of any analysis. Without the correct scientific question, any analysis is useless.  Once a problem is correctly framed, then a solution can be sought. I build defensible bodies of evidence to support public health initiatives in my professional work. In this commission, I would employ the same skills to the redistricting task. The redistricting problem must be correctly framed, the tools to solve the problem characterized, and the solution well defended logically.
consensus_statement:
In my professional work, I regularly communicate complex scientific ideas to non-scientists in government and industry. We learn skills that help those not familiar with science to understand the science. I think this experience will be helpful in this commission. As commissioners, we must find consensus on the best districts to represent the citizens of Colorado. I would need to bridge understanding between commissioners and between the commission and the public.

I work for a nonprofit safety net hospital. We provide statistical analyses to the pharmaceutical industry and to federal government regulators, where our independence is crucial to our success. Our role is intentionally and specifically impartial so that we might provide the best analysis for government to develop policy, not favoring either side in an evaluation of drug safety. We must be impartial so that medicines are proven to be safe and effective for the benefit of the populace. I believe my impartiality as a public health scientist to pharma and regulators would be best utilized by this commission.
past_political_activity: I am generally only active as a voter. I have voted regularly in elections since moving to Colorado in 2003. I do not consider myself affiliated with either party. I usually split my ballot between Democrats and Republicans, as I assess each candidates based on past experience and stances on issues. I felt the 2020 election ballot, in it's entirety, is the most important election of my life.  Only in 2020, my wife and I have donated a small amount of money to Kamala Harris's primary campaign. That was the first time I donated to a candidate.

statement: I believe strongly in inclusion, fairness, equality, honesty, and transparency in government.  I am deeply upset by the entrenched divisions currently fomented in this country.  Working together to dismantle voter suppression is the best  way to begin to heal our country and reestablish trust in our government.
professional_background: My spouse and I spoke at several rallies for civil union and marriage in Colorado including as the one gay couple chosen to speak on the day the Supreme Court approved national marriage.  We were interviewed frequently on television and were selected by reporter Brandon Ritterman of local NBC-TV as exemplary Colorado activists.  Senator Pat Steadman asked us to testify before the CO Senate committee on filing state taxes jointly. I also testified on the use of service dogs trained by owner.  I have been a regular member of brain injury support groups at Rocky Mountain Human Services, Brain Injury Hope Foundation, and neurological support group at Swedish Hospital.

analytic_skills: I love intellectual challenge.  I approach challenge first with thorough study and confidence that a right solution can be revealed by process.  Then I listen to all points of view before I work toward deriving a consensus.  As mayor of a village in New York, I had experience in brain storming, problem analysis, negotiation, finding solutions, and supporting those solutions with calm and patient explanation.
consensus_statement: I was the first woman and first gay elected as mayor in a historically industrial village in New York.  I was the only mayor in the county who negotiated a police contract without arbitration.  When people in the village organized an angry protest, I was able to go out into the street and listen to their concerns to defuse the misunderstanding.  I resolved all pending law suits against the village, some of several years' duration.  In one instance I had to bring together branches of state government that had never before met to solve a problem together.  Working with the New York State DOT, I brought about a compromise on road design that had been argued for years.  Negotiating with neighborhoods, local town boards, and prospective developers, I was able to preserve critical open space. Also negotiating with the US Senate committee on environment, Nabisco as the owner of polluted property, and professional remediation companies, I was able, without further threat to the environment, to address the clean up of three Superfund sites which had been in litigation for nearly twenty years.  I bring opposing voices to the table.  I listen.  I believe in working together to find a solution as a team.  I am patient with the process of consensus.  Working to achieve marriage equality for gay couples took years of courageous conversation, listening, patience, humor, and understanding the fears and concerns of others.

statement: I lived in North Carolina for many years and saw how African Americans were systematically denied equal representation. Gerrymandering strategies such as "cracking" (diluting voting power across many districts) and "packing" (concentrating voting power in one district to limit voting power elsewhere) were common and remain so to this day. I always said that if I had the time later in life I would address this issue. It is where the rubber meets the road in the voting process. Colorado is fairer than most states but it could be better.

statement:
I want to serve on this commission for three reasons.

First, I strongly support the mission of this commission. I know from personal experience that competitive districts benefit our communities. I seek to help the commission fulfill its mission.

Second, I am uniquely qualified to serve on this commission. All of my experiences seem to be pointing to this particular opportunity. In other contexts, I have put into practice the skills and abilities called for—organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering interests. I have a proven track record of fairly and impartially creating agreement and promoting consensus. My experiences campaigning and as a candidate have provided me with analytical skills that are particularly relevant for this effort.

Third, I desire to leave a legacy. If this commission does its job well, its impact will be no less than 10 years, the period until the next census. I believe, though, that the commission’s legacy could be much longer. The precedents set and procedures put into place are likely (with tweaks) to be used by future commissions. The echoes may be generational. In addition, Colorado is a leader in the nation in the use of citizen-based independent redistricting commissions. We may be able to show the rest of the country how to be successful in putting an end to partisan gerrymandering. I want to be a part of this legacy. 

I am applying for both the Legislative and Congressional Redistricting Commissions. My preference is to serve on the Legislative Redistricting Commission. However, I would consider it a privilege and honor to serve on either commission.
professional_background:
Two experiences illustrate particularly well my abilities in organizing, representing, advocating for, and considering interests. The first is when I lead the Poudre Schools District Accountability Committee review of the first charter school application in Fort Collins. The second is successfully leading my homeowners’ association in changing the neighborhood covenants.

As an unpaid volunteer, I was an active participant in the Poudre Schools District Accountability Committee when the first charter school application was submitted. At the time, charter schools were a political hot potato. Following state law, it fell to the District Accountability Committee to review the application and consider the interests of the applicant, the school district, and the community as a whole. I volunteered to head the review subcommittee and organized four other subcommittee members. Under my leadership, the subcommittee created a fair and impartial process by first identifying 28 application requirements specified by state law and the school district. The subcommittee then painstakingly reviewed the application against these standards and evaluated whether required information was provided, whether it was sufficiently detailed, and whether the applicant's proposal for each requirement was acceptable. Finally, I represented the subcommittee by presenting to the entire District Accountability Committee and to the school board our findings regarding the merits and deficiencies of the application.

The subcommittee did a masterful job and, as a result, everybody was angered. The pro-charter people were upset because we did not unquestionably accept the application. The anti-charter people were upset that we did not flatly deny the application. These reactions are evidence of our impartiality. 

And the subcommittee? We had more than consensus. We were unanimous in our findings. By focusing on the standards set by law and first developing a fair and impartial process for review of the application against the standards, the subcommittee was able to stay above the political fray.

In the end, the applicant was able to address deficiencies in the application and the charter school was approved. Since then other charter schools have come and gone in Fort Collins but this school remains strong and successful. I truly believe our subcommittee deserves some credit for that. I am proud of my efforts in organizing the subcommittee, representing the subcommittee before the school board, advocating for the subcommittee’s recommendations, and considering the interests of the various stakeholder groups.

I envision a similar process for the redistricting commission. This effort has the potential to be politically destabilizing for some entrenched interests. After all, if the commission does its job well, some currently uncompetitive districts will made competitive... and some people are not going to like that. I believe if redistricting commission focuses on the standards set by law and develops and follows a fair and impartial process around those standards, it will be successful in achieving its mission.

More recently, as an active participant in my homeowners’ association, I served on the Board of Directors when it sought to make a covenant change. Want to take on a challenge? Volunteer for your HOA!

As President for much of this process, I organized most aspects of this effort. I sought to ensure that Board members were thoroughly informed of all available options. With impartially, I insisted that the Board patiently allow anyone to speak and that everyone be heard. In this way the Board was able to consider the interests of all our neighbors. I also stepped aside when others wanted to take a more active leadership role (and then stepped back into leadership when they decided leading really was not that much fun). In this way I was able promote consensus by building trust and creating buy-in.

In the end, the Board reached unanimous agreement on a proposal to present to our homeowners. We were able to achieve consensus among our homeowners with 150 of 175 voting households in favor of the proposal. These numbers are truly amazing--a very high level of neighborhood engagement with 86% of households in agreement!

Per state law, our final step was to obtain court approval of the changes. I represented my HOA in court and advocated on behalf of my neighbors.

Our efforts were successful. Following approval by the court, the covenant changes went into effect. They had an immediate impact on our HOA, greatly strengthening its financial situation. This summer costly repairs were made to the asphalt path through our neighborhood common area. The funds for these repairs were made available because of the changes to our covenants. I am deeply satisfied to see the legacy of my efforts and the positive impact of effectively organizing this project, representing and considering the interests of my neighbors and our neighborhood, and advocating for them.

These experiences give me confidence that I will serve well if selected to serve on this commission.

I am experienced digging into voter and demographic data to determine precinct and district composition and to assess likely electorate behavior. 

I am a people-oriented analyst. This means that I have the soft skills to work effectively with others while possessing strong logic and reasoning skills.

I have great confidence in my ability to serve well on a redistricting commission. It is my sincere hope that I will have the opportunity to do so.

Respectfully submitted,
Eric Kronwall
consensus_statement:
In my discussion of my experience in organizing, representing, advocating for, or considering the interests of groups, organizations, or associations in Colorado, I recount two challenging situations where I promoted consensus, created agreement, and was fair and impartial. Please carefully review that portion of my application.

I am a process person. How we get to an outcome is often just as important as the outcome itself. I have found it is much easier to get to agreement and consensus when processes and procedures are hashed out beforehand. If selected to serve, I will urge my fellow commissioners to first develop processes and procedures for how business and hearings are conducted and how proposed district maps are evaluated relative to legal requirements and competitiveness. 

Building trusting on a one-on-one basis with the other commissioners facilitates agreement and consensus. I have done this in the past by:
> Making and keeping promises,
> Transparency,
> Bending over backwards to elicit and listen to the input of others, and
> Assumption of positive intent.

In addition to creating agreement and promoting consensus, good processes help to assure fairness and impartiality.
past_political_activity:
For at least the past 15 years I have actively participated as a volunteer for numerous political campaigns, supporting candidates for Fort Collins and Loveland City Council, State House of Representatives, State Senate, and Larimer County offices. In 2011 on my own initiative, I developed a campaign training course for candidates and campaign managers. My current campaign participation is most often as an unpaid strategy and messaging consultant.

My most significant political activity was running for Fort Collins City Council in 2015. This non-partisan race was very competitive. In a district with about 14,000 registered voters, I lost by 140 votes. While I did not care for this outcome, I know in my heart of hearts that the citizens of Fort Collins benefited from a competitive race.

I have first-hand experience and a perspective shared by few others--that of a candidate--about what makes a race competitive and the benefits enjoyed by our communities from competitive races. This fuels my motivation to serve and partly explains my strong support for the mission of the redistricting commission. My experience and perspective uniquely qualify me to serve, having provided me with relevant analytical skills.

Since November 10, 2015, I have donated money to: Vote for Eric Kronwall Committee, REALTOR Political Action Committee, Vote Nate Budd Committee, Larimer County Republican Party, Irene Josey for Treasurer Committee, Sean (Dougherty) for Larimer County Committee, National Republican Senatorial Committee, Elect Noah (Hutchison) Committee, Elect Emily (Gorgol) Committee, Wade Troxell Mayoral Committee, Aislinn (Kottwitz) for Larimer Committee, Cory Gardner for Senate Committee. In addition, a portion of my annual Colorado Association of REALTORS and National Association of REALTORS dues are used for political purposes.

professional_background: While on HOA board, I opposed a fee increase for internet upgrade but when it passed by neighbors, I led the effort to implement the new fee and served as Treasurer and point person.  As Regional Director at Americans for Prosperity, worked with the ACLU to pass a campus free speech bill and criminal justice reform legislation in several western states.  During the 2000 Congressional redistricting fight, when plans - some put forward by Republicans - split El Paso county, I filed a motion to intervene as I believed that it was inappropriate to split a county for political purposes especially given that there are five military installations in El Paso county.

analytic_skills: Applying analytical skills is one of my strengths.  Whether it is my self-taught skills of auto repair, ammunition reloading, home repairs, furniture making or work related budget issues, I enjoy analyzing problems and then working my way slowly through the obstacles or challenges that come up so that I can get to a final solution that is viable. I've used these skills in getting bipartisan legislation passed in Congress and in state legislatures in the past.  To me, analysis and problem solving is essential in finding a workable solution and one which can build consensus.  The goal is to get a balanced outcome which all parties can live with and nobody feels like they were run over in the process.
consensus_statement: I have always been someone who tries to evaluate plans, ideas or proposals based on how they match up to my guiding principles.  Here, my guiding principle would be to evaluate plans based on how they best represent communities and I would stick to that focus.  In addition, I have consistently shown throughout my career that I work with those on the other side of the aisle to form a consensus.  As an example, while working as a Republican staff member in Congress, I worked with the Clinton administration to write the Military Family Housing Privatization Act which became law.  I also worked with Nancy Pelosi to stop Most Favored Nation trade status for China and also with former Congresswoman Pat Schroeder and her Chief of Staff Kip Cheroutis on numerous military installation issues including the closure of Fitzsimmons Army Hospital and the attempted closure of Fort Carson.  These examples demonstrate my ability to work with those that I may disagree with politically for the greater good.

I was president of Aegis Strategic, LLC from 2013-2017 which was a political consulting firm and had several clients across the country but in general, I did not work directly with the candidates but oversaw business operations.

statement: I am a deeply optimistic believer in our governmental system. When I voted last year to create the commission, I knew I wanted to be on it to do a great job at what other states have mangled. I love Colorado and I have a lot of pride in how well we do a lot of things in this state, especially voting related. I want this to be one of the ways that Colorado is successful in taking good care of our citizens and in showing the country that it is possible to be fair minded, just, and forward-thinking. We are all those things and I want to see it come to fruition.
professional_background: I am a trained facilitator who has worked for 30 years to facilitate group process to best represent the needs of both the group and the people they represent. I have worked on diversity issues and inclusion and equity work across the state to center the voices that need to be heard. I currently work with three organizations that do work to represent and advocate for Coloradans - CIRC, Project Protect Food Systems, and The Community Remembrance Project.
org_list: In reverse order - Project Protect Food Systems, a state-wide organization for food security doing communications, The Race Justice Task Force of the Episcopal Church in Colorado as a leadership development volunteer, The Community Remembrance Project a volunteer working with youth, I have been on the Board of the Fyera Foundation for two years. I have been a facilitator for the Longmont Community Justice Partnership. I am involved in various community leadership programs as a facilitator and trainer including Leadership Cleveland, and the Episcopal Service Corps. I am also involved in the Colorado Immigrants Rights Coalition as a trained observer and do facilitation pro-bono for groups who are doing visioning and diversity and inclusion work.
analytic_skills: I have finished a PhD that includes qualitative data analysis. I am trained as an academic in how to teach and use critical thinking in humanities and social science disciplines. I also wrote a book on the use of communications skills to support data and quantitative information in decision making which is in the publication process, and a book for more general audiences on trauma aware communications skills that includes sections on using data. I am uniquely qualified to work on a hot topic with a divided group to create collegiality and success.
consensus_statement: I am trained by Columbia University School of Public Health, by Kaiser Permenente, The Restorative Justice Project, and several no-institutional training programs to facilitate group process. I am a deep believer in communication and consensus and know from 30 years of work in the field as well as being an educator how to make that happen, even in rooms where conflict is a big issue. I know how to participate in tough discussions and how to teach people to listen and process data even when triggered. It is what I wrote my dissertation on, and how I do my work every day. I would bring to this commission the skills of facilitation and group process and can be both a good participant and a resource.
past_political_activity: I have been involved in politics as a volunteer since I was a child. I was pulled in a wagon to campaign against Nixon and have worked on various campaigns as a volunteer ever since.  I have given to Biden, Obama, Polis, and various state initiatives as well as MoveOn.Org and Swing Left.

occupation: Military Instructor, AEgis Technologies Group
education: BA in History, Colorado State University, and numerous military technical certifications
statement: I'm a historian and a social studies teacher by training; these concepts have always mattered deeply to me. I believe that gerrymandering is one of the most insidious threats to the future of our Republic. I can't say I'm a fan of either major political party, but I don't think either has a chance to legitimately function without fair districts.
professional_background: My community interest has always been professional, after college I was a substitute teacher for Poudre and Thompson School Districts. I taught middle school for Garfield RE-16 at Grand Valley Middle School in Parachute, CO for a year and then at an online charter high school in the Metro Area (Mountain View Virtual, which no longer exists) before I started working on federal defense contracts.
org_list: I'm a member of the Association of Old Crows (professional military organization)
analytic_skills: I've had the benefit of a liberal arts education prior to my technical military training as a signals intelligence analyst and satellite communications technician. I've had a chance to work with a huge swath of different types of people, from children struggling with learning disabilities to seasoned veterans with advanced technical degrees working on the bleeding edge of their fields.
consensus_statement: I've straddled both political camps my entire life, especially as a public school teacher joining the military. I'm a professional communicator and public speaker, and after working with middle school students, I have many tools in my belt for getting things done and building compromises.
past_political_activity: I donated small amounts (<$50) to the Obama campaigns in '08 and '12, I voted third party in 2016.

other_names: Jeanette Hensley, Jeanette Campbell-Hensley, Jeanette Rogers
occupation: Retired from State of Colorado where I held several management positions in my 30 plus years of service, working with low-income adults and children, people with disabilities, seniors, while balancing the needs of the Medicaid or Human Services Agencies.  I currently volunteer with Colorado Senior Lobby, an all volunteer, non-partisan non-profit, who provides educational programs regarding how to be your own best advocate at the legislature, we educate the legislature on the needs of older adults throughout the state, and provide updates on the benefits that older adults contribute to their communities and the state.
education:
CSU - BS Communication Disorders,  minor Psychology 1980 
Barnes Business College - Computers - 1988 Certificate
statement: Serving on this commission will provide a voice for the older adults in Colorado and those who may not have a voice of their own.  I want to see my community and Colorado come together in a fair and equitable way.  It's important to have fair and equal representation in each of the Legislative Districts.  Having lived in House Districts 34, 54,  and 29, and Senate Districts 24, 7, and 19, I have a good understanding of the similarities and differences in each district.   But more importantly, I am familiar with each of the counties in Colorado and their unique needs and how important the local control is to their citizens.  I want to assure that all are represented in the redistricting.
professional_background: My past position as the Director of Aging and Adult Services for the Colorado Department of Human Services, I advocated for Older Adults, Adults with Disabilities, and low-income adults.  I worked closely with the County Departments of Human Services, Area Agencies on Aging, Aging Disability Resource Centers, Independent Living Centers, community providers, State Legislators, other State Departments, advocate groups, the Colorado Commission on Aging, Colorado Cross Disability Coalition and stakeholders.  I am the Legislative Committee co-chair and on the Board of Colorado Senior Lobby for the past 6 years, but a member for 20 years.  I provide training to older adults on how to advocate for themselves and others at the legislature and in their communities.  I have worked for 30 plus years serving individuals with disabilities, low-income families, older adults, and school age children.  I toured Colorado doing listening sessions and getting feedback from older adults, service providers, family members and  social service agencies prior to the White House Conference on Aging, then I was selected by the chair of the White House Conference to represent Colorado at this event which is held every 10 years.  After the Conference, I was instrumental in keeping the momentum going, by providing feedback to those who I met with before the conference and formed the "SilverPrint Colorado" entity.  This group had members throughout Colorado working on areas of health care, community engagement, protection and support for at-risk adults, ageism in the workforce and workforce issues for older adults, and transportation.  Throughout my life I have worked to make life easier for those who need and want the help.  In the PTA, I started a parents group for single parents to help them/us with the stresses of life, the issues our children had and to know that "you are not alone" in the journey.
org_list: Adams County Democratic Party, Precinct Chair; Colorado Democratic Party,  Colorado Senior Lobby- Board Secretary, Legislative Committee Co-Chair, Capital Gang Leader; Visiting Nurse Association- Foot Clinic; Direct Care Workforce Working Group - HCPF;  Polis/Primavera Campaign, Rolling Hills HOA - Swimming Pool Design Committee & Social Committee
analytic_skills: As the Director of Aging for the Colorado Dept of Human Services, it was my responsibility to provide budget forecasting for the programs to the Ex. Director, the Joint Budget Committee, and the Office of State Planning and Budgeting, and to the State Auditors.  I have analytical skills, reasoning skills, good communication skills, consensus building skills, and am a creative thinker.  I am able to be detailed oriented as well as being able to see the big picture.  I have used mentoring, guidance, support, brainstorming as well as logic to be able to discuss different ideas and practices.  Between working with the state programs and working closely with school administrators, teachers and parents, I know how to bring people together to arrive at a decision that all can accept.  This doesn't mean that one side gets everything they want, it means we all work to get to a position that we can all accept as being fair and equitable and it can be implemented in an appropriate manner.
consensus_statement: My 30 plus years of working for the State of Colorado in various  capacities and in different levels, I have worked well with others.  I started out working for the Developmental Disabilities programs, then moved to the Medicaid unit, and worked my way up to become the Director of Aging and Adult Services.  Throughout this time, I have worked with many community providers and clients to help them receive the most appropriate services for them and to help them understand the different programs available to them.  I worked with the County Departments of Human/Social  on providing education, receiving feedback and coming to consensus with program directors of the Medicaid and Human Services programs I worked, developed and administered.  It is important to remember that one size does not fit all of the state.  Colorado is very diverse and has different needs in each county.  I was able to work collaboratively with the Counties, service providers and clients to implement long-term care services in each county.  In the late 80's and early 90's when the Single Entry Points were being developed I was working with the different County Commissioners and County Directors to help divide the state into 23 different long-term service providers and case managers.  This was a difficult task as each County wanted to be the center, and some counties didn't want to partner and work with their neighboring counties.  In addition, when Medicaid started to serve clients through the HMOs I worked with various HMOs, state legislators, physician groups, and hospitals to make sure all services were provided to clients in all areas of the state.  Then when I served on the Colorado Commission on Aging representing CD3, which is a very large and diverse district, I needed to be sure that all the cities, counties, rural and urban areas were represented and needed to work with the other Commissioners who represented their CD.  The Commission had a Democrat and a Republican from each district and worked on consensus.
past_political_activity: HD 34 Kyle Mullica, SD  24 Faith Winter, Andrew Romonoff Primary Congressional Senate, Adams County Democratic Party, Colorado Democratic Party, Congressional Senate Democratic Party
