statement: With the climate of the political, economic, and civil atmosphere at this time, I feel the need to step up and become active and have my voice heard.
professional_background: I have not represented any of these associations.
analytic_skills: I come from a military family with a lot of A type personalities as well as two children, now adults with Adhd and ADD and have always been the peacekeeper.  I have learned to defuse situations and play the go between to make things work.  In my professional life I had to learn how to read people to get an idea of what they wanted with projects, even when they were not sure themselves.
consensus_statement: I like to look at things from both perspectives and listen to both reasons before I make a decision.  From my experiences in life there are always three sides to everything and you have to have all the information to make an informed decision.
past_political_activity: None

occupation: retired
education: BS Geologic Engineering, MA Secondary Mathematics, PhD Foundations of Education. Colorado Teaching Certificate: Secondary Mathematics. Undergraduate and graduate coursework in Philosophy, Graduate work in Applied Mathematics.
statement:
My reasons for applying to serve on the Redistricting Commission revolved around my desire to make political life in our society more just for all Coloradans. Though I am today well-educated and economically comfortable, I grew up in agrarian circumstances where I expected to be neither. As is the case for many from less fortunate childhoods, especially those plagued with violence at home, finding a better life and making life better for others cannot be disentangled. I grew up in rural circumstances in Oklahoma and Texas never expecting to attend higher education, then accepted an opportunity to study engineering Colorado. Education served as my steppingstone to a better life. I was very fortunate to arrive at Colorado School of Mines understanding the virtues of hard work and persistence. I am, thus, especially well-trained in mathematics and the sciences, and was the 21st woman graduate of Mines, with a degree in Geologic Engineering, providing unique experiences about being a member of an under-represented group. Though women were seldom hired for engineering jobs at the time, the Arab oil embargo made any engineer who could work in the petroleum industry desirous, even women. I worked in petroleum engineering (monitoring oil reservoirs and production) for 15 years: in a field office in very rural NM, in a research center in Littleton, CO, and at a regional bank in an energy lending group. In each, I was the sole woman engineer and know the isolation of being under-represented. Along the way, I completed graduate coursework in Applied Mathematics. 

I left engineering and retrained in education to address my life-long goal of making life better for others. I studied philosophy for a year to think about my goals. Since education had provided my opportunities, I decided to give back in this area. But since my worldview was narrow and specific to my circumstances, I needed to better understand the views of others unlike myself, as well as come to deeper understandings about life in a democracy and how education served democracy’s aims. I became a certified teacher of secondary mathematics in CO and earned a master’s in Math Education, then entered a doctoral program in foundations of education (the area where I could learn about education in a democracy). My goal was to become a professor and to teach on a campus educating under-served graduate students. I earned my PhD in Boulder and after a short time on the itinerant-faculty circuit landed my dream job in Detroit at Wayne State University, a Research-1 University serving Black, recent immigrant, and lower-income students. Thus, I spent the last 15 years of my work life serving these students, in particular guiding 26 of them through the doctorate and into leadership positions in their communities. Preparing new leaders is central to the aims of social justice in a democracy, which in the US has focused on equity in education, economic well-being through employment, and enfranchisement. Redistricting is part and parcel of how political structures enact long-standing ideals of our democracy, and I possess skills relevant to the Commission.

My two areas of academic expertise, research methods and social justice in education, contribute to my qualifications for the commission. My mathematical skills, background in geologic engineering, and abilities to manage both quantitative and qualitative information relate directly to the need of the Commission to understand complex data sets and their impacts on diverse people arrayed across Colorado. My expertise in social justice, my academic preparation coupled with my experiences living and working in both urban, suburban, and rural locales with socioeconomic-, racial-, ethnic-, and language-diverse people, provide me with unusual vantage points on the histories of injustice and misrepresentation in the US. These experiences also help me understand the need for justice through fair elections, and help me see not just my own needs, interests, and desires, but also seek to understand and to advocate for the needs, interests, and desires of those least likely to be included in making decisions that impact their lives. Granted I can never directly experience the discrimination felt by many in our society, but I have tried to become more knowledgeable about their circumstances. 

Fair election maps provide an avenue for ensuring that each person is included in political decision-making that influences their lives, the lives of those they care about and of those whose experiences they share. Election maps, when fair, encode our society’s promise that democracy be founded on mutual respect for one another, and on a commitment to participation that springs from thoughtful consideration of important issues impacting everyday lives. My engineering studies and career were underpinned by maps in every setting; in fact, geologic maps represent complex data displayed geographically. 

Thus, serving on the redistricting commission represents an additional way I might contribute to improving the lives of others. I seldom seek out “committee” work in my retirement, but agree to such service when my expertise is well matched to committee/commission goals. As my CV demonstrates, I have a long track record of committee work in my profession(s). In engineering work, teams of differently qualified experts and inter-corporate committees served as the primary way to share technical information and reach consensus on decisions where there were competing interests. At universities, faculty committees guide the institution. In fact, at WSU, shared decision-making was an integral part of the faculty union contract with the Administration, and faculty members took these responsibilities seriously. In addition, I served for over 12 years on the University’s Institutional Review Board. This Board protected diverse research participants’ rights (as I explain further in a subsequent section of this application).

In my community, I am active in a community chorale, a large church, and regularly contribute to food banks and serving homeless meals. I also participate in homeless services in urban settings. These activities provide insights into the wider communities where I have lived.

Thus, I am highly qualified for the task at hand, with my background in mathematics, geology (which in large part is a deeper dive into maps representing complex data displayed geographically), and in social justice scholarship, as well as by my persistent engagement in my profession with others who come from diverse circumstances. Throughout my career, I have worked primarily in settings where group (teamwork) decision-making was the norm. For myself, I have lived experiences with being poor, being hungry, and being the only person like myself in teamwork, offices, and large corporate settings.
professional_background:
I volunteer in online communities to help (women primarily) connect with like-minded individuals working for social justice: to engage in advocating for the rights of homeless, hungry, LGBTQI+, low-income communities’ access to clean air and water, and racial and ethnic communities under-served in especially educational settings. 

In my religious denomination, I advocate for the full inclusion of LGBTQI+ persons, and over the last 5 years have sewn over 500 rainbow stoles for church members to wear as a symbol of full inclusion.
org_list:
I am active in my county party as a volunteer and in Arvadans for Progressive Action (a nonpartisan) community group devoted to social justice. In addition, I am a member of the Arvada Chorale, have sung with both the Spirituals Project (a group dedicated to preserving and teaching about Negro Spirituals) and the Denver Gay Men’s Chorus, and am a member of the Chancel Choir at my church. I attend Lukas Elementary School PTA meetings (where a grand-daughter attends) and volunteer at a community Arts Camp as a costume designer and seamstress. I was appointed to serve on the Jeffco Schools: School Safety Task Force. 

Most of my other community volunteer work is done outside of “organizations.” I am a sustaining contributor to The NOAH Project (homeless services in Detroit MI), to The Table (Arvada community food bank), and participate in meal service at The Rising and The Delores Project  (homeless food services). In addition, I sew about 250 fleece hats for the homeless annually, produce fleece blankets for homeless and lower-income families and, during the early days of the pandemic, I was able to sew (and donate) about 900 quilter’s-cotton masks for food banks, women’s shelters, and homeless food services, and for essential workers.
analytic_skills:
In both my engineering, academic career, and home life; logic, analytic skills and problem-solving have been central to my practices. Clearly, engineering and academic work overwhelmingly depend on mathematical science underpinned by logical decisions. I have for the last 50 years worked with maps and with large data sets of both quantitative and qualitative information, upon which decisions rested. As an engineer, I worked in 3 diverse settings, all of which depended on understanding how numbers represent the world around us, and how decisions I was in volved in making impact the lives of others. In the last of these I was the Senior Reservoir Engineer in a large state bank’s energy lending group, and the only engineer employed in the holding company. Here, I worked with technical and financial data to ascertain to what extent given oil production revenue streams might support loans. In fact, I held this position on Black Sunday, May 2, 1982, the day Exxon walked away from their holdings in the Piceance Basin, devastating Colorado’s Western Slope. My role at the bank required my participation in top-level meetings to ensure the bank not only met all guidelines for lending and asset management, but also supported long-time customers whose economic circumstances had changed overnight. I have also served on university-wide and college budget committees responsible for monitoring and advising administrations about budgetary matters during the recession of 2007, which was especially deep in Michigan. As happened in Colorado, significant changes in University and College operations followed, with reductions in faculty lines, shifts in enrollment, and changes in degrees and certificates offered.

In both careers, creative analysis proved central to workplace activities. All engineering decisions depend on strategic planning, optimizing production, collaboration between engineering and field staff, and creative brainstorming to find workable solutions to difficult problems. This is no less true of a faculty member’s responsibilities on a campus where the faculty are central to decisions about a College and University’s future given exigent circumstances. In both engineering and academia, industry downturns and state reductions in campus revenues created circumstances requiring mid-course corrections and restructuring, which were accomplished in academia through my budget committee service. 

Critical thinking skills are required for success in both engineering and academia. For instance, energy loans require persistent auditing to ensure they remain on track, and I was solely responsible for this aspect of a relatively large loan portfolio. I was also responsive to shifting circumstances, such as fluctuating oil prices, and monitored every loan based on its own production stream, but incorporating new information affecting all loans. To make a case attesting to each loan’s status required persistent development of case study information and data interpretation.
consensus_statement:
Collaborative decision-making, and consensus building, has been central to my committee work, and used both empathy and mutual respect for others. As to empathy, in engineering I was considered a “bleeding heart,” someone who incorporated empathy into routine engineering and corporate decisions. But an example from everyday life exemplifies how empathy is a core part of my character. One dark night as I drove home to Lakewood from late classes in Boulder, I encountered a car north of Golden with its flashers on. Of course, being from the country, I stopped to render aid. A first-language Spanish-speaking family was trying to reach the Jeffco jail where a family member was being released. I gave one of the adults a ride into Golden to connect with this family member. At the jail, the family member was repeatedly rebuffed by the clerical person on duty, who said,  “What? I can’t understand you. Can’t you speak English?” The family member was speaking English and I understood her. With the family member’s permission, I stepped in, introduced myself, and repeated what they had been saying. Only then did the clerical staff act as if they understood and the jailed person was released. I was very embarrassed for Jeffco, and ashamed of my community for being so callous. It was empathy that required me to stop and empathy that led to my providing a ride into Golden. But my shame and embarrassment came from my seeming to be (albeit unwittingly) a participant in this sort of callous treatment of members of marginalized communities in our society. This experience deepened my empathy for those who suffer persistent slights and insults in our society.

As to mutual respect of others, I held a wide range of leadership positions where I treated others with respect despite differing opinions. Engineering ethics requires that engineers recognize the limits of their own expertise and respect the expertise of others, and the same holds among the professoriate. Engineers work hard to get things right, which requires gathering information of both a technical and social nature. That is, like the commission's work, engineering problem-solving routinely situates technical issues within a real-world of people with diverse interests. Engineering work routinely influences the lives of others and engineers cannot pretend otherwise, requiring that these contextualizing situations be understood from the perspective of everyday folks impacted by decisions. In addition, as a professor, I served for over 12 years on one Committee of the University’s Institutional Review Board. Committees included faculty and community members, who guaranteed that every research proposal respected the rights to informed consent of every research participant. Faculty members of the committee spanned the University Schools and Colleges, and each faculty member served because they represented one sort of academic expertise. Research participants came from Detroit MI, a very diverse urban center in the US, as well as from third-world countries around the globe. Members of this committee were trained in, and guided by, community (cultural) expectations for lower-income residents, for Black Americans, for Middle Eastern Americans from diverse national heritages, for diverse indigenous communities, for diverse sub-communities within the LGBTQI+ community, and for recent and long-term immigrants from Central and South American, Middle Eastern, Eastern European (Balkan), and south and eastern Asian countries. I thus have deep training about diverse persons, their cultural practices, and the protection of their rights. Impartiality in both engineering and academic collaborative decision-making came from requiring that stakeholders be included, that their concerns be addressed, and their advice be followed, and fairness emerged through operational structures that encouraged, instead of blunted, participation. 

Taken together my childhood roots in settings quite unlike my adult situation, my educational preparation, and my work and life experiences as an adult provide me with especially well-informed vantage points on life in the US.
past_political_activity: My political activity has been in service to campaigns and issues that revolved around improving social justice. I have volunteered for local, regional, and state-wide campaigns where candidates’ goals and integrity matched my expectations. During the last 5 years, I donated to these and other campaigns, particularly campaigns of women and members of marginalized racial, ethnic, and gender-identity communities. Recipient Name: Alexis King For District Attorney, Amy Padden For Attorney General, Amy Padden For District Attorney, Brianna For Colorado, Brianna For Colorado, Brianna Titone's 439 Fund, Brittany Pettersen For Colorado, Broomfield County Democrats, Cannon For Jefferson County Coroner, Cary Kennedy For Governor, Coloradans For Karla Esser, Colorado Rising For Health And Safety, Committee To Elect Julia Varnell-Sarjeant, Cutter For Colorado, Dave Young For Colorado, Elect Lisa Neal-Graves, Fair Tax Colorado, George Stern For Colorado, Iman For Colorado, Jake Lilly For District Attorney 2020, Jefferson County Democratic Party, Jena Griswold For Colorado, Jessie Danielson For Colorado, Jessie PAC, Kerr For Jeffco, Kerry Tipper For House District 28, Lesley For CU Regent, Lindsey For Colorado, Matthew Maillaro For Da, Our Colorado Way Of Life, Phil Weiser For Colorado, Progressive Values SDC, Rachel For Colorado, TracyforJeffco

occupation: I own my own consulting firm, KMC Insights Consulting, LLC.
education: MA Economics, Northwestern University. AB Economics and Applied Mathematics, University of California at Berkeley
statement: I am 10-year resident of Colorado, and my experience living and voting in our great state has only been during this recent decade of change.  The Colorado of 2020 is not the same as the Colorado of 2010 (or 1910); and El Paso County is not the same either.  As a redistricting commission, we are going to need to be equipped to use today’s data to inform choices around district boundaries which fairly represent the all the people of Colorado.  As one example, Colorado’s population of school-aged children has grown by 230,000 between 2010 and 2019.  This is likely to be the fastest growing segment of Colorado residents as the 2020 Census reporting becomes available.  As mother of school-aged children, I want to be sure the commission members analyze fairly the data put before them before drawing districts which have implications for both our current and next generations of voters and elected representatives.
professional_background: I have worked for 20+ years as a strategy consultant, advising private-sector businesses on how products and services can better meet their customers’ needs.  Across hundreds of professional engagements with business leaders, I have been asked to understand consumer populations, interpret multiple sources of qualitative and quantitative data, and clearly communicate recommendations.  As my resume highlights, I am trained statistician and social scientist.  I have also had roles in managing a statistical software start-up and as a college-level economics lecturer.
org_list: Multiple years as a PTO Board Member, School Accountability Committee, and Parent Sounding Board Representative for an Academy District 20 Elementary School; El Paso County Democratic Party member.
analytic_skills: I organize, aggregate, and summarize multiple sources of information so that decisions makers can take action.  I have 30 years of experience with quantitative data analysis and statistical software packages, including performing analysis on US Census data files. I have taught quantitative analysis methods to 100s of business professionals.
consensus_statement: I form my perspective based upon data.  I also believe that listening to others and discussing differences are critical skills to building consensus.  Part of my professional work is facilitating focus groups and small group discussions where I am asked to inquire actively, listen whole-heartly, understand empathetically, and manage time well.  Working in the consumer behavior field requires me to establish rapport quickly across people of different ages, genders, ethnicities, and life experiences around the world.  I believe these skills will serve me well in interacting with a diverse set of fellow commission members on a common set of objectives for the people of Colorado.
past_political_activity: This is my first year of any notable political activity, and I have never run for or held any elected office.  In 2020, I served as a precinct organizer for the El Paso County Democratic party.  For the November 2020 General Election, I volunteered as a poll watcher for the Colorado Democrats, and I was hired as temporary Election Judge by El Paso County.  During the summer and fall of 2020, I have volunteered my time campaigning for several women candidates in federal and state-level offices.  Year to date for 2020, I have contributed about $375 in total across the following groups/candidates:  El Paso County Democratic Party, Meg Fossinger, Jillian Freeland, and Diane Mitsch Bush.  I do not believe that I’ve made any financial contributions from 2015-2019.

occupation: I am currently the Executive Director for a community-based victim service nonprofit in Colorado Springs, Colorado. I have been in the business of victim advocacy for 17 years and have been working in cultural community-based nonprofits since 1990; whether I lived in urban Denver, or rural Nebraska, or in the growing and progressing Colorado Springs. You will see in my resume that I have served community in local, statewide, and national positions as a technical assistance provider for victim service nonprofits in a variety of settings.
education:
I have earned a GED from the Emily Griffith School of opportunity in 1989 when I left South High School in Denver’s Washington Park neighborhood which is the same school from which my parents graduated and where they met. I attended the Community College of Denver until I became pregnant and left school to raise my children and take care of my family. As an adult, I attended the Women’s College at the University of Denver but have not completed the degree requirements
Over the past 20 years I have built a solid career as a victim advocate, a technical assistance provider, a researcher, and a trainer. I am considered a subject matter expert on the topic of anti-domestic violence and anti-sexual assault.  I have recently become an unlicensed psychotherapist in the state of Colorado and am attending a yearlong certification course for MindBody Therapy. While I continue to hold out for finishing my university degree one day, over the course of my life I have educated myself, being well-read and well mentored. I have attended at least 30 hours of continuing education training in each of the last 20 years.
statement:
I want to serve on the commission for multiple reasons.
First, I was asked to apply by someone I respect and admire as a leader in the city. I want to honor that request, and their recognition of me in the community, as a trusted person. 
Also, I love Colorado. This is my home, where I was born, and raised and have worked and built my life. I have benefited from this state and have on purpose made this my home. 
In different professional roles I have had the opportunity to see the majority of the state with my own heart and eyes. As a child, being a native of Colorado, I traveled and stayed with family in different parts in most of Southern Colorado and along what is now known as the Front Range. I feel connected to rural and frontier Colorado as well as urban centers because of my time in and connections with colleagues, friends, and family who span all of Colorado. 
I come from a multi-racial, economically and politically diverse family. This helps me to aim for options that serve the well-being of all of us. I also know what it is like to move through social tiers and change one’s life trajectory through hard work and participation in the system. I am a testament to that. 
Finally, having built my career and gained professional respect through what some would call, my own gumption, it is also through the network of generous mentors and knowledgeable guides. Many people of many walks have invested in my success. It is my purpose and choice to continue to invest in our collective good and my beloved Colorful Colorado. This commission has a worthy purpose, and I believe I will be able to contribute meaningfully to the commission’s work.
professional_background: I have many years of experience in organizing, advocating for, and considering the interests of people impacted by violence crime, people impacted by social disparities, as well as with cultural communities seeking healing and well-being.  As an anti-domestic violence advocate, a trainer, a coalition staff member, a person engaged in community research, and through other related roles, I have worked to hear directly from people who are impacted, and to work with individuals and communities to find practical ways forward.  I look forward to bringing this perspective and skill set to the commission’s work on redistricting.
org_list:
I am presently on the Domestic Violence Offender Management Board (DVOMB) under the Department of Criminal Justice (DCJ) in the state of Colorado. 
I am a member of the Colorado Association of Psychotherapists.

consensus_statement: Differing perspectives are important and valuable in building good solutions, so disagreement is not a problem, but rather an indication that indeed people are putting forward their contribution.  Moving forward once many views have been expressed is then the work of respectful dialogue, listening and considering as well as speaking. When others at the table feel heard and respected, we can talk about solutions or compromises without any personal disrespect. Keeping our eyes on the values and the goals that the commission is tasked with can help in seeing that we are all working on behalf of something none of us can achieve individually.  Fairness and impartiality in terms of respectful inclusion, while being values-led, is a cornerstone of much of the work that I do in my professional life.

statement: A free and open electoral process is the very foundation of an effective democracy.  Without it, the will of the people becomes distorted and subject to manipulation by a few.  While I don’t always agree with election results, I can accept them if I believe that they reflect the will of the people.  However, if I believe the elections were unfairly manipulated, the legitimacy of the results comes into question.  I believe that this commission is charged with creating electoral boundaries that will permit elections that reflect the will of the people.
professional_background:
In Colorado, I have been on several boards of directors, and planning committees where I have developed a reputation for asking insightful questions, and challenging untested assumptions.  After the Stem High School shooting, our church decided we should investigate how to reduce isolation and help build a more resilient society beyond the church.  A “Wellness Committee” was formed and the focus was narrowed the to young adults between ages 14 and18.  I was elected to chair the subgroup focusing on developing resilience in the 16-18 year olds.  To determine what mental health issues our target population were facing, I suggested that we add members to our advisory group who were in the 16-18 year old target age range.  We then consulted with private therapists, community mental health programs, Arapahoe/Douglas County Mental health consortium, researched the literature, and searched to find what services were already being offered to address those issues.  The Wellness Committee then made recommendations to the church.  While the Corona Virus has delayed an implementation of these recommendations, preliminary efforts are being made to establish an independent nonprofit organization to implement these suggestions to provide preventive services so that the mental health issues do not develop in the first place.

The most relevant example however, was when I was on the Interim Planning Group for the Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services and I chaired a potentially contentious public hearing.  I was told that a group that was upset with HRS might attempt to disrupt the meeting.  I began the meeting by explaining the purpose of the meeting, and laying the ground rules that we would only be discussing issues related to the stated purpose of the meeting.  If people had other issues they would like to discuss, HRS staff would be available at the back of the room to discuss their issues in private.  When the first member of their group began to speak about their grievances, I politely asked if their comments were related to the topic of the meeting.  They agreed that they were not, and I suggested that they discuss their concerns with the HRS staff member at the back of the room.  This process continued through a third person from their group, after which their group no longer attempted to disrupt the meeting.  As I was leaving the meeting, by chance, I met the leader of the group in the elevator, and he apologized for his group’s behavior.  I was able to develop a solution where his group felt heard, but which did not disrupt the intended purpose of the meeting.  So often people who disrupt public meetings are doing so because they do not feel heard, and know of no other way to express their grievances.

As President of the Florida Society of Psychotherapists, I felt that our organization lacked focus.  We represented a wide variety of mental health professionals in private practice, including psychologists, mental health counselors, social workers, and marriage and family therapists, each with competing interests.  I called a board retreat to discuss what interests we had in common, and what services we could offer our members that they did not get from other organizations.  The previous President thought this would be a waste of time, but I convinced her to attend.  We looked at what we were currently offering, what other organizations were offering, and what needs weren’t being met, and decided to focus on private practice needs.  As a result, our membership rapidly increased.

As an individual investor, I have been highly successful in applying logic and reason to find promising stocks, analyzing their prospects for long term growth, and assessing obstacles and trends to obtain success.  While I pay attention to several newsletters to narrow the field of stocks to investigate, those newsletters may have biases or may discount important information which I find from other sources.  That is not to say that the stock market is always logical in the short run, or that my analysis is always correct.  But my performance beats the forecasts of many professional financial analyst’s.
consensus_statement:
In my book, Don’t Carve the Turkey with a Chainsaw: Resolving Family Conflict, I discuss how “conflict is not based on reality, but on people’s interpretations of that reality.”  To understand the other person’s interpretation of reality you must listen.  However, most people only listen to the other person’s reality 1% of the time, and when they do listen, it is to attend to information that confirms their own position and discounts contrasting information.  When you are more concerned with what YOU are saying than hearing what the other person has to say, you listen only long enough to defend your own position, or find flaws in your partner’s logic.  They do likewise, and the more they defend their position, the more they believe their own propaganda.

So, what is the best way to promote consensus?
1. First present our facts and our interpretation of the facts, giving reasons. 
2. Understand the other person’s thinking using sincere questioning and listening. Good listening involves detective work that helps uncover not only the content being expressed, but also the feelings, values, motivation, and interpretations behind the content. 
3. Focus on interests, not positions. Positions are the solutions you generate to solve a problem.  Interests are the underlying reasons influencing the decision.  It is frequently much easier to develop consensus about interests than positions. Frequently, a solution can be developed that addresses common interests, and develops a position neither party had previously considered. 
4. Brainstorm win/win solutions that focus on the future, then select the best options.  When we focus on what we want to happen in the future, rather than focusing on past misdeeds, we can avoid blaming, and the defensiveness that comes with it. 
5. Implement the solution.  
6. Evaluate the outcome using independent measures.

All this requires that the people we are dealing with feel safe, knowing that they will not be attacked, or humiliated.  Judgmental comments, insults, blaming, interrupting, interrogating questioning, all-or-nothing statements, and dishonesty all annihilate safety. “Respect is like air.  If you take it away, it’s all people can think about.  The instant people perceive disrespect in a conversation, the interaction is no longer about the original purpose—it is now about defending dignity.”

I believe my ability to be fair and impartial has been demonstrated in leadership roles where I have received considerable respect as documented by the provided letters of recommendation, and experiences. 

•	Quotes are from my book, Don’t Carve the Turkey with a Chainsaw: Resolving Family Conflict.  Free copies are available on request.

analytic_skills:
a. From 1985 to 1987 and from 1988 to 1997–I worked as a personal computer troubleshooter.  I  resolved a constant stream of software, hardware and network problems–for a good number of computer users.  
With each trouble call–I had to start by finding out what was really needed or what was really going wrong.  Then, I had to apply a good deal of reasoning/logic and computer knowledge–to find a solution. And last, I needed to explain the problem (as well as possible) to the user and tell them “what to do next time”.      

b. I’ve been a volunteer Colorado Master Gardener in Otero county–from 2007 to the present.  Most of my gardening trouble calls need my on-site investigation–gardening knowledge--research–and then reasoning--to determine (1) what the gardener’s/plant’s problem is and (2) how to resolve or deal with the problem.  

c. I am a volunteer raptor monitor at John Martin Reservoir State Park (2006 to the present). (Raptors are predator birds–such as hawks, eagles, harriers, etc.).  At the state park, I first locate  raptors. Then I use my observation skills--knowledge about raptor plumage, behaviors, and migration habits–and my logic/reasoning--to determine the actual species, I’ve found.  (I report the numbers & species to Colorado Parks & Wildlife.  They use this data to keep track of the welfare--of the state park’s wildlife.) 
						
d. One of my hobbies is genealogy: Genealogy takes a surprising amount of logic/reasoning. For example, how do I tell, if I’ve found the same ancestor--in two (or more) different records?  I need to judge dates–locations–the spelling of names & places–handwriting–handwriting, in a non-English language--other records, in a document–family stories, etc. Sometimes the records do not match up. Then I must use my reasoning–knowledge of history–and knowledge of genealogy–to make a best guess.
consensus_statement:
a. As to promoting consensus: When faced with disagreeing persons–I try to find & propose different points of view–or present other possible solutions.  
For example, I was placed on a Jefferson county jury in July 1998 (a child neglect case)–and somehow elected chairman of the jury.  At first, two or three, of the jurors--went on and on–“psychoanalyzing” and blaming the mother, for everything.  I realized--that line of debate would get us nowhere–because, you can’t get inside anybody else’s head.  So I suggested that we concentrate only on the actual physical evidence–i.e. what had been presented in court, and what had happened to the children.  That seemed to concentrate everyone’s thinking.  The jury was able to reached an agreement--and return to court--in a surprising amount of time. 

b. As to being fair or impartial: As an employee, I was recruited (occasionally), to go thru job applications or to join applicant interviews.  The applications & interviews contained all sorts of inputs–a variety negative remarks--bad grammar & spelling–”don’t care” attitudes–and political statements.  I found that I needed to “wall off” the negative & extraneous inputs. Responsibilities, experience, genuine qualifications, & awards are (hopefully) left. Then, I could make reasonable choices.

consensus_statement:
The most important job of public universities is to serve as an arena for civic engagement. For 46 years, my introductory graduate course in public service and public affairs began by teaching and modeling the “rules of civic engagement.” In a culture heavily influenced by rant-radio talk show hosts and ideologically charged political sound bites, people typically get little training on how to discuss policy issues on which they disagree deeply. This makes democracy less functional.

Groups are more effective when they follow the rules of civic engagement, which are:
•	No matter how much you disagree with someone, be more concerned with learning what they believe and why than with explaining or defending your own viewpoint.
•	No matter how illogical or uninformed they seem to be, do not shout them down, call them names, or tune them out by stereotyping them in your own mind.
•	If you have trouble with these two rules, repeat this mantra silently as you listen: “Is it possible that under any circumstances, some part of what they say might conceivably be true?” Repeat until they finish and ask you what you think.
•	If this mantra gives you trouble, do it while breathing through your nose, not your mouth.

After a few weeks of modeling, students unconsciously begin to use these rules themselves. The class transforms itself from a theater for eloquent bullies into an arena for civic engagement by a group of reflective, intelligent adults. Shouting, name-calling, and derogatory asides die out. Speakers get better at stating their views succinctly and supporting them effectively with expert opinions, personal experiences, data, and logic. Classmates turn toward the speaker, listen more closely, and interrupt less. They address questions and comments to each other by name. Little by little, as the dominant ones listen more and talk less, the quieter ones creep into the newly cleared conversational space. Soon, no one misses class except for work or family emergencies. This is how we learn together.

The principles of civic engagement transform lives and strengthen democracy. If selected for the Commission, these are the principles I pledge to follow.

occupation: Decision scientist working at Colorado State University
education: PhD in Decision Science and Information Systems, University of Arizona BS in Mechanical Engineering, MIT
statement: I think, like many Coloradans, I have become concerned about the polarization of political discourse in our country. I became interested in the redistricting process after stumbling across a monograph by Professor Robert Loevy who participated in the 2010 effort in Colorado. That spurred me to read "RatF**ked" by David Daley. Clearly, redistricting is a complex process involving multiple competing priorities. That type of problem is one with which I have a great deal of expertise. I have specialized expertise in data analysis and the design decision support systems. My research is focused on problems involving temporal and geo-spatial uncertainty. I believe I have a lot to offer the Colorado redistricting effort: I have the time, the interest, and the expertise. I think I also have the right demeanor -- I am an idealist but not a zealot. When facing conflict, I seek out a solution having the most good for the most stakeholders. In summary, I want to serve because I think I can add value to the process, and because I believe that a successful redistricting process in Colorado might serve as a positive model for our country.
professional_background: As a faculty member at CSU, I deliberately avoided participation in special interest groups. I believe that by maintaining neutrality on political and social issues, I fostered an atmosphere with my students that promoted free exchange and critical thinking. So rather than directing my energies to causes that I admire, I have directed my service directly to my students. For example, using my uncompensated personal time to coach students for international competitions.
org_list: I have served as an officer in each of the HOAs of which I have been a member for the last 20 years, most recently as the President of the Miner's Lake HOA.
analytic_skills: I am a decision scientist by training. I have spent more than 30 years conducting research into decision scenarios that are characterized by high stakes, time pressure, and uncertainty. My earlier work involved the study of decision making in teams and small groups, and so I am an expert in processes used to form consensus in heterogeneous groups, including Social Judgment Theory mentioned above. More recently, I have been investigating biases in judgment and perception related to geo-spatial reasoning -- for example, estimating the location of landfall for a hurricane, or the best location to search for an aircraft lost at sea. The process of redistricting involves many of these same geo-spatial biases. My research has been funded by several federal agencies, most notably the Office of Naval Research. I am especially skilled at transforming the findings of my research into practical guidance for sailors and Marines. I look forward to bringing these same capabilities to bear on the Colorado redistricting effort on behalf of all the citizens of our state.
consensus_statement: I think the key to resolving conflict will be to discover the shared values among the stakeholders. This requires the ability to listen and have empathy. Those are skills I possess. Not all values are shared, and in that case, it is important to understand the relative importance of the goals for each stakeholder. The process of promoting consensus involves finding ways to promote the shared values while also trading-off on the relatively less-important unshared values. I have a lot of experience with this sort of small-group decision process via many years of faculty meetings and neighborhood meetings. Obviously, the stakes in those examples are much lower, but the process is the same: how do you reach agreement without creating animosity among people you work with or live near?  In particular, there is a specific analytical technique called "Social Judgment Theory" that has been used successfully in Colorado to resolve community disputes on important issues, and with which I have practical experience.  In the case of redistricting, I think I am aided because I don't identify with any political party, so I don't view the process through the lens of winning and losing. Rather I think I can be fair and impartial while working towards the shared goal of finding the best district boundaries that achieve the priorities of the Reapportionment Amendment and the Hobbs decision.
past_political_activity: I have donated to Amy McGrath in her campaign against Mitch McConnell for the US Senate in Kentucky. I donated to Pete Buttigieg during the 2020 presidential primaries. I'm not sure if this counts as "political," but my wife and I donated to the ACLU to help them support the children who were separated from their parents while seeking asylum.

statement: I was excited to vote in favor of Ammendments Y & Z in 2018 because I believed it would put Colorado in a position of leadership when it comes to fair redistricting and elections. I believe strongly in fair elections, and while I have my own personal opinions on issues, I also deeply believe that everyone should have fair representation in elections, regardless of their opinion or position. I have been disappointed to see examples where redistricting became a tool used for voter suppression or gerrymandering and am very excited that Colorado developed a process to avoid these outcomes when redistricting. I believe I can support the process as a member of the commission with my background in leadership, communication, team-building, education, and data analysis and I would be thrilled to be of service to all Coloradans in helping to maintain fair elections.
professional_background: My first experience was in 2001-2001 when I served as an Americorps community organizer for a year, working with residents of mobile home parks, lawyers, and advocates to represent the interest of mobile home residents and to lobby cities, counties and the state to promote affordable housing solutions. Recently as a member of the board of directors for the Colorado Mountain Club, I have represented the organization in a development and fundraising capacity to community partners. I have also represented my industry (outdoor/climbing industry) by participating on the board of advisors for the Warren Tech High School Outdoor Leadership Program as well as at the Climbing Wall Association annual conference, where I have participated as a panelist. In my current employment, I have also advocated internally to promote access to climbing for community groups and partners, which has led to long-term engagement with several community groups.
org_list:

Board of Industry Advisors, Warren Tech High School, Outdoor Leadership Program, 2017-present
Climbing Wall Association, 2016-present
analytic_skills: Some of my past jobs and training have involved significant data-analysis and program evaluation, but regardless of my role I am a data seeker in my decision making process. And while I try to empathize with an emotional perspective, I do not let emotional arguments determine my decision making. As an example, in the customer service context that I operate in currently, an individual might bring up a complaint or may be vocal about an opinion. As convincing as they may be about their concern or opinion, I will dive much deeper into the root of the issue to determine if their concern is widely held or represents a larger problem, before making a decision based on one or a handful of comments. It can be tempting to make decisions based only on an individual's compelling argument or emotional plea, but I am committed to delving deeper and gathering more information to understand a problem better (and determine if it is in fact a problem) before attempting to solve it. In the real world, great data doesn't always exist, so to avoid analysis paralysis and be in a position to move forward, I supplement data-analysis with experience, seeking input, and discussing options, and considering potential outcomes before making a decision. I also keep in mind the larger goal - solving a problem should be in service of achieving our vision and mission. For example, my company's current vision is to transform the world through the experience of climbing (we run climbing gyms). When I receive input from customers, I will consider the problem of a member feeling excluded from the community much more seriously than the problem of our gym not having a sauna for member use. One problem (inclusion) is directly related to achieving our vision, the other (sauna) simply represents someone's personal preference for their gym experience, but solving that problem will not contribute materially to our overall vision. Part of the reason I would like to be involved in this commission is because I enjoy the process of problem solving and am excited to participate in the challenging process of redistricting for Colorado.
consensus_statement:
I am a big-picture thinker and in my job am frequently required to move a group toward consensus. Of course I have personal opinions on issues, but I do let let an attachment to a particular position cloud my ability to consider many perspectives and keep the larger objective in mind. I have found that my own opinions often evolve as I engage in discussion or a consensus-building process, so I have learned over the years that my initial position on may not be my final position - all of which is to say I am committed to achieving the larger goal/vision of my work than remaining attached to a particular strategy/tactic or position. I am able to listen actively and engage with people who hold perspectives different from my own to reach conclusions or take action. In a group setting such as this commission, I could play a role of facilitator, active listener, observer, and monitor (in the sense of monitoring if our work is on track or identifying if we are getting away from the bigger goal/objective). A major professional challenge I have moved through recently is a merger of two companies, and my role at a leader in the organization was to repeatedly express the vision of the company, the objectives/goals we are moving toward, gather input from stakeholders, and to have conversations that build buy-in to our new company's direction. In this process, I have been able to support two large teams in moving in a new direction, finding common ground with this direction, and generally feeling bought-in to our collective work and the outcomes. I like to approach problem solving as a collaborative learning process, where through the process we elevate the group's collective knowledge and wisdom to come up with solutions and make decisions that best serve our common goal. In this process, I may not always get "my way," but I also know that a group can come up with more brilliant, practical, or elegant solutions that I could on my own, so I promote collaboration, learning, and always refocusing on our common goals. 

I believe I also am well equipped to be fair and impartial on this commission. I do not put my personal opinions/values above the larger goal, in this case supporting fair redistricting and fair elections. As a manager and supervisor, I have tried to apply principles of fairness to my teams, to reduce the possibility of favoritism or expression of bias. Being fair and impartial isn't always easy, th

statement: I look at the current districts and often wonder - "How in the heck did anyone come up with that map?" Living in the same spot in the suburbs of Denver during a 17 year span resulted in me being placed in three different U.S. House Districts. Some of my neighbors two miles away would be in a different district which made no sense to me. I like to think of Colorado as a giant puzzle made up of 64 counties - or Mountainous or Plains - or Urban Rural, Suburban - or ... and it becomes obvious that coming up with districts that make sense, are fair, and take into account such a variety of factors - is an extreme challenge and it would be fun to solve that puzzle.
professional_background: I'm not a political organizer by nature but serving as the Treasurer for both a Square Dance Club and an HOA in my past really allows you realize how an organization that seems straight-forward in its goals is comprised of so many people with different goals! Dealing with money issues as a treasurer forces you to balance the emotional feeling money (and politics) can impair or passionate people which can affect their reasoning skills. This commission would be an extension of that by treating "groups of people (such as Democrats or Republicans)" in a similar way as you would have to juggle individual people and viewpoints.
org_list: I've been an active member of multiple Square dance clubs in the Denver Metro area and served as Treasurer and board member for one of the clubs. I'm a member of multiple volunteer groups like the Colorado Trail Foundation, Colorado 14'ers Institute and Continental Divide Trail Coalition. A year ago I moved to Salida to live part-time while I finished my last year of work in Littleton. With the COVID-19 pandemic, it has been a challenge to get to know my new community fully with so many groups shut down but I have already participated in the local food banks and homestead "Farm to Table" organizations. In 2021 I will be "retired" in Salida full-time and look forward to much more involvement when the pandemic restrictions are lifted.
analytic_skills: For my 38 year career, I've been a software Engineer doing coding, testing and design of complicated software that runs and monitors spacecraft designed here in Colorado. For the most recent 10 years of my career I primarily have designed automated software tests that test application and system software that others have written to verify that on a spacecraft it will perform flawlessly. Even a very minor mistake can result in the lost of the functionality of a spacecraft that costs 100's of millions of dollars to build, launch and operate. Using logic and analytical skills are my two strongest traits. For engineers, it can be very difficult to use that approach with others and have the ability to understand the intuitive and emotional nature of people which you have to consider to really understand the problem and come up with the best solutions that may at first not seem like the most logical.
consensus_statement: I have traveled though nearly every county and major town in Colorado so I think I can relate to the viewpoints of people who live in the wide variety of places in this state. I've served as jury foreman on multiple jury trials where fairness and impartiality are of the utmost importance. "Get the data, brainstorm, listen to others, and come up with the best solution" has been a normal way of life in my entire career. Having twelve people of different political viewpoints will force us to have to come up with sound solutions that are not secretly based on "This will help my political party".
past_political_activity: None. I consider that an advantage of starting with a clean slate and not having preconceived ideas of how the state should be apportioned.

With the Grand Valley Ducks Unlimited chapter I contributed by soliciting donations from various organizations and businesses and also took recommendations from various stakeholders in the community to the board for consideration.

occupation:
Design Engineer
KL&A Engineers & Builders in Golden, CO
education: Master's degree in structural engineering from the University of Colorado in Boulder (2020), Bachelor's degree in civil engineering from Colorado State University in Fort Collins (2018)
statement:
I would like to serve on the commission because I want to ensure that the representative district boarders are drawn fairly without the effects of gerrymandering. As an unaffiliated voter, generally displeased with the two party system, I am interested in making sure the Colorado State representatives in congress are elected fairly and competitively. 

Colorado unfortunately has a history of gerrymandering in order to give one political party more power over another. Districting commissions often also re-draw districting lines in order to protect their own seat (or the incumbent member of their party) in office. These tactics need to stop in order for the voice of the people of Colorado to truly be heard. If the districts are organized such that the representative earns the votes of their constituents. This is very important to me as a Colorado voter because not only to I want my voice to be heard and  I want to ensure the same for my fellow Coloradans.

The great President John F. Kennedy said, “Let us not seek the Republican answer of the Democratic answer, but the right answer. Let us not seek to fix the blame for the past. Let us accept our own responsibility for the future.” My primary goal as a member of this commission will be to seek that right answer. I love this state, and I believe that the governmental tactics and changes taking place here in Colorado have been and continue to be a model for the nation. That is why I am interested in serving on the commission, not only to serve my state but to serve my country.
professional_background: As a general contractor, it was important to maintain a positive relationship with all of the trade partners working on site to keep them coordinated and functional. As a project engineer with Martines Palmeiro Construction (MPC) I had to advocate for both the organizations who worked under mine and our clients in the day-to-day tasks in the field. Often times a trade partner would interfere with another trade partner’s work for their own convenience. I had to ensure that the best interests of all the trades were executed in order maintain a functional site. Furthermore, it was also my responsibility to ensure that the best interests of the owner were being executed despite the fact that the owner was not present on site. Nearly all of the trade partners I worked with are based in Colorado, as many of them are small businesses in the Denver area.
org_list:
I spent the majority of the past five years since November 10, 2015 as a student at both Colorado State University (CSU) in Fort Collins and University of Colorado (CU) in Boulder. Because of this most of my public involvement was within my university community. At CSU I served as student ambassador for the College of Engineering, which I belonged to. As an ambassador I worked primarily with high school students considering majoring in engineering, at CSU or otherwise. I gave advice to these students as they made their college decisions and offered my perspective to them as both an engineering student and as a CSU Ram. 

At the end of my undergraduate education at CSU, I joined a professional origination known as the Order of the Engineer. This is an organization that upholds the ethical standards of engineers in our society. As many people entrust their lives with the structures and technology designed by engineers, this organization continuously reminds them of the responsibly they hold.

In graduate school at CU, I earned a scholarship from the Structural Engineers Association of Colorado (SEAC) and have attended a number of meetings and site visits with the organization since. Although I am not an official SEAC member, I am currently considering joining this organization as well.
analytic_skills:
Being a structural engineer, logic and reason come very naturally to me. I am a fast learner and an analytical thinker. I am exceptionally good at Excel and I enjoy solving mathematically interesting problems. I am also a young and enthusiastic individual who likes a good challenge. 

When I was a graduate student at CU, I had to apply these skills to my research project in order to report accurate and unbiased results. For this project, I was tasked investigating the effects of a polymer additive on the freeze-thaw properties of concrete. To do this, I had to college and analyze a significant amount of data over the course of several months. I also had to write and defend my thesis in front of several faculty members and concrete experts to prove my results were valid. I would take a similar approach to the task of re-districting Colorado. My “data collection” phase would involve hearing the voices of my fellow Coloradans scattered throughout the state. My “analysis” phase would be the actual re-drawing of the district lines with the assistance of the other commissioners. And finally my “defense” phase would be to convince and mediate among the other members of the committee.
consensus_statement:
As a member of the commission, I will advocate for the use of the shortest-split line method to divide the voters throughout the state into fairly divided, equally populated areas. The use of this algorithm is at least a good place to start, because it uses a mathematical method that is free of bias. I would also use that as an argument among the other commissioners, because you can’t argue with math. As an engineer, I am good at both being analytical and convincing of an impartial answer.

Next, I think it’s worth considering the cultural density of the various areas of the state. For example, because Baca County and Prowers County are culturally similar to each other, it may make sense to group them together in the same district. However, it is important to make sure there is a healthy amount of competition for the candidates running to represent these districts. For example if it is known that the majority of voters in Weld County are Republicans and the majority of voters in Larimer County are Democrats, it may make sense to group Weld and Larimer County together in the same district to encourage both the Republican and Democratic candidates for that district to campaign harder to earn their votes
past_political_activity:
In the past five years, I have been interested but not heavily involved in political activities outside of voting. I have not given money to any organizations other than the perchance a Marco Rubio bumper sticker in 2016. At the end of 2019 I also signed a petition in Colorado that put Proposition 115 on the 2020 ballot and made a $5 donation supporting the initiative.

Although I grew up in a mostly conservative household, I am an independent thinker who may align with the Libertarian party rather than the Democratic or Republican party. I even voted Libertarian in 2016 because I felt that both of the two major candidates were not representative of how most people in America think. But because I do not want to subject myself a political party, I am an unaffiliated citizen and have chosen to apply for this commission as such.

That is the only way for the election process to properly reflect the will of the citizens of Colorado and for elections to be truly considered by all to be legitimate.

statement: I pledge to the citizens of Colorado to deliver on the requirements of the state constitution to the best of my abilities. My goal will be to ensure that the inaugural commission will become the gold standard for independent redistricting commissions in the nation. I acknowledge that this will not be an easy task because our highly mobile society has allowed us to sort ourselves into clusters of like-minded neighbors of similar demographics and income levels. Despite our competing interests, the citizens of Colorado are calling for the highest standards and have rejected having their elections be decided by partisan computer algorithms that dilute their voice in good government. I see my role as a commissioner to objectively and impartially implement the new constitutional requirements for equitable and competitive election districts.
professional_background: As a council-appointed member of the Colorado Springs 2020 Districting Process Advisory Committee, I represented the fastest growing district of over 81,000 people-- a population slightly larger than Loveland. My role included soliciting input on the proposed boundaries, conducting the public outreach meeting, and synthesizing the comments for the committee report. I also worked with my fellow committee members and studied maps of demographic information to ensure that neighborhoods with a higher number of ethnic minorities were fairly represented in our recommendations for redistricting.
org_list: Member of the City of Colorado Springs 2020 Districting Process Advisory Committee. Member of the Pikes Peak Rural Transportation Authority (PPRTA) Citizens Advisory Committee. Member of a citizen-led neighborhood group exploring how to fix the inequities in the property tax structure of the Briargate Special Improvement Maintenance District. Registered adult volunteer with the Boy Scouts of America (Pikes Peak Council). Outreach Committee Chairman with Bike Colorado Springs, a fiscally-sponsored group of the non-profit Trails and Open Space Coalition.
analytic_skills: I am a software engineer who likes facts and data. Using math and logic to create solutions is my profession. I strive to be a System 2 Thinker. In 2014 I served as an expert witness on a complex patent case in federal district court involving database security which required deep analysis of the subject matter and an understanding of the law. Since July 2020 I have applied my analytical skills to assist the Colorado Springs City Clerk with redistricting the City Council District boundaries based on election precincts and demographic data for a city of approximately 481,000 residents. I created web-based maps using shapefiles and GIS software to help my colleagues on the advisory committee better understand the relationship between the proposed district boundaries and the local communities of interest.
consensus_statement: It is remarkable to witness the wisdom emerge from a diverse group of reasonable and intelligent individuals working toward a common goal. Being part of a group starts with humility and an understanding that no one individual has all the answers. Forming consensus requires preparation, amending one’s opinion when presented with new information, putting into practice the principles of active listening, and ensuring that all voices are heard. Consensus is not unanimous consent but rather an outcome built on mutual respect, judicious deliberation, and authentic inclusion of minority viewpoints.
past_political_activity: I have been a regular voter in Colorado since 1994. In the past I was affiliated with the Republican Party so I could vote in the local primaries. In 2008, I affiliated with the Democratic Party to support the candidacy of Barack Obama and became a neighborhood precinct chairman to further his candidacy. In 2014, I changed my voter registration and became an unaffiliated voter. In the interest of full disclosure, I have made no donations to candidates, political parties, or political action committees in the 2020 election cycle.

statement:
My experience of serving in the legislature has given me a good understanding of the differing needs of the different geographical parts of the state (Eastern Plains v Western Slope), rural and urban differences, as well as the need for ethnic and racial diversity and inclusion of a variety of special needs of people and communities.  It is important to take all of that into consideration, as well as fair representation of different political parties.  It is important to value all of those differences and also honor that we are ONE state.

I have participated in discussions with "Build a Better Colorado" working to reach the best consensus on statewide issues.  In an attempt to better understand my own community, I have participated in Leadership Lakewood, Lakewood Citizen Police Academy and Lakewood Citizen Planning Academy
professional_background:
The advocacy I have done for my church body is advocacy for social justice, like anti-poverty, healthcare, affordable housing, racial justice, equality and environmental issues, NOT lobbying for the special interests of the church. The same is true for AAUW, a voluntary organization, with a mission of advancing equity for women and girls through advocacy, education, and research.  In both situations, I work with others within the organization, as well as other organizations to determine to determine the specific legislative priority agenda and ballot issue positions.  In AAUW, I take the lead. Organizations we work with include League of Women Voters, FAMLII Coalition, Colorado Coalition for Reproductive Health, Rights and Justice.

Neither organization endorses partisan candidates or political parties.

Dating back to the 1980's, I have held a variety of leadership positions in my church body on the churchwide (national) and synodical (a 5 state geographic grouping) levels and in my congregations - Lutheran Church of the Resurrection in Lakewood, that closed 5 years ago, and now at Augustana.

consensus_statement: Fair maps are critical so that the various diverse communities can be heard and represented in our government at all levels.  During my tenure as a state legislator, I had the reputation of reaching across the aisle and working collaboratively with my colleagues in both parties.  As an example, on what I consider to be one of the most important Senate bills I passed, creating the Colorado Health Benefit Exchange, my House sponsor was a member of the other party.  We worked collaboratively along with the governor's office to create the first bipartisan Exchange in the country.  In the end, neither of us got the exact the bill we hoped for, but we created something that is still working today.

statement: As a native Coloradan, it is important to me to contribute toward shaping Colorado’s future. When voters in Colorado overwhelmingly approved Amendments Y & Z, I knew I wanted to get involved in ensuring that democracy is protected in Colorado. I have a background as a communicator and journalist and have been a vocal advocate and writer for media literacy in education and voting rights. My interest in politics and history spans 40 years, and I am highly motivated to help ensure that Colorado’s Congressional and Legislative districts remain independent, which was underscored by voters in 2018.
